status_message:
Our economy has been in the news recently. Business is slow, redundancies are rising, but unemployment is still low. 

I did a dialogue with leaders from the unions and labour movement yesterday. I told them this is unlike the Global Financial Crisis in 2008. Today growth is positive, EDB is attracting substantial investments, and we are creating many new jobs. The current slowdown is not an infection that can be cured with one course of antibiotics. What we need instead is a sustained longer-term strategy to build ourselves up, and go for growth.

We are working with businesses to transform industries, upgrade SMEs, and help companies expand overseas. For workers, we are investing in skills training programmes and job matching schemes.

Many countries face similar economic problems. If any country can succeed, Singapore can. We have the tripartite partnership, and will work as one nation together! – LHL

This year’s parade will take place this Saturday, 5 November, at Suntec City. I hope you will join in with your family and friends, and be part of building an inclusive society in Singapore. – LHL

Like other traditional holidays that we celebrate – Chinese New Year, Hari Raya Puasa and Christmas – Deepavali is a joyous festival enjoyed with family, friends, and food!

Our Team Singapore athletes have done us proud this year, and now we have one more reason to celebrate - the Singapore National Culinary Team were crowned the overall champion at the Culinary Olympics 2016!

Like the Olympics Games, the Culinary Olympics are held every four years, but always in the same place – Erfurt, Germany. This time 30 countries took part. Singapore is the first Asian country to win double gold in the Cold Display and Hot Cooking categories.

Congratulations to team manager Chef Louis Tay and the team for your hard work, and to the Singapore Chefs Association and sponsors for your support! 

Click on the link below to see some of the beautiful dishes the team created. I’m sure they taste even better than they look. – LHL

Promoting Ong Ye Kung and Ng Chee Meng 黄志明 to full ministers as of 1 November.

Both will continue to share the Education portfolio. Chee Meng will be Minister for Education (Schools) and concurrently 2nd Minister in the Ministry of Transport, and Ye Kung Minister for Education (Higher Education and Skills) and concurrently 2nd Minister in MINDEF.

Building a leadership team is one of my top priorities. These changes are part of the renewal process, to reinforce my Cabinet and get a younger team in place, ready to take over. I hope that Singaporeans will give them your full support, and work with us to take Singapore forward.

The full statement is on the PMO website here: bit.ly/2fdx8Fe

– LHL
 
(Photo from Ng Chee Meng’s Facebook page)

Met Mdm Jenny Yim, a bus attendant, and Mdm Norazizah, a trainer, (on my right and left respectively) at the Club-100 @ North West  annual dinner last night. Both are pioneer donors of the club since it started 8 years ago. 

Based in North West CDC (Community Development Council), club members donate at least $100 a month to the North West Food Aid Fund. The fund provides food rations, vouchers and tingkat meals to the needy. Club-100 @ North West started with just 10 members – it now has 620! Together, they have raised $5.3 million over the last 8 years and helped 12,000 needy families. 

Our CDCs do a lot of good work to help the less fortunate, and organise activities to connect communities. They depend on the invaluable support of volunteers and donors. Thank you for your contributions, and for helping to build a strong community that cares and looks out for one another. – LHL

(MCI Photo by Betty Chua)

Sat down with Ian Bremmer, editor-at-large and foreign affairs columnist at TIME magazine, last week before my trip to Bangkok. We talked about many things: the ongoing US elections, the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), US-China relations, the US presence in Asia, and coping with an undefined future.

You can click on the link below to read the interview. – LHL

Young Singaporeans ask: “Will there be a future for us?” My answer is “Yes!” – as long as you are willing to work for it, not just for yourselves, but for one another. 

Many young people came to the inaugural Dialogue with SITizens at the Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) last night. My theme was “Preparing for the Future Economy”, but students also asked me about the social stigma faced by those with mental illnesses, the rise of extreme politics elsewhere, and NS for women.

Good to see them engaged, informed, and interested in a wide range of issues. Ultimately, how well Singapore does, and what kind of society we become 30 years from now, depends on the next generation.

You can listen to my speech and dialogue session here: http://bit.ly/2eLqDpq 

– LHL

One of the fun things about chatting with young children is that you never quite know what they are going to say. Came across this amusing clip of a young boy having a chat with a familiar couple. :)

There is still time to donate to the President’s Star Charity, if you haven’t already done so. Hope that you will support this worthy cause to help the less fortunate. – LHL

#Guesswhat the red script says? :)

If you think this beautiful calligraphy is Arabic, then you are half right! It is written in Arwi, a written form of Tamil that uses an expanded Arabic script. The Singapore Kadayanallur Muslim League (SKML) presented it to me last night at its 75th anniversary dinner.

The SKML's roots go back much further than 75 years, in fact, to the 19th century. They comprise Tamil Muslims originally from Kadayanallur, a city in Tamil Nadu close to the southernmost tip of India. Weavers by trade, many left in search of a better life after British textile mills began exporting cheap textiles to India, putting them out of business. 

Some sailed to Malacca and Penang (and set up Kadayanallur associations there as well). Many arrived in Singapore with little more than the clothes on their back. They became labourers at the port, and sold wet ground spices for curries. 

Today, many have become successful professionals. They have made Singapore their home for three generations or more, just as so many others have done. 

The Tamil Muslim community in Singapore is small – about 20,000 – but have woven their own distinctive strand into our multicultural tapestry. The SKML works with organisations like the Singapore Indian Development Association and MENDAKI Singapore to help more Singaporeans. My congratulations to the SKML on your 75th anniversary. Keep up the great work! – LHL

(MCI Photo by LH Goh)

Congratulations to the students from PCF Sparkletots Preschool @ Teck Ghee on their graduation!

Joined proud parents and teachers at the K2 graduation ceremony yesterday. The students put up a little concert, singing and dancing to songs from their favourite movies. 

Primary school will start a new chapter in your lives. May you enjoy your learning journey in school and make lots of friends. Never forget to thank those who support and inspire you as you grow. – LHL

Had an enjoyable musical evening at the Singapore Chinese Orchestra’s (SCO) fundraising gala dinner last night. 

The SCO has a unique challenge – to both preserve traditional arts, and forge its own distinctive identity. It weaves in elements of Southeast Asian culture with traditional Chinese instruments and music. It has in large measure succeeded, reaching music lovers across diverse backgrounds and cultures. 

As patron, I’m pleased to see the SCO celebrate its 20th birthday. Also happy that the SCO has raised $1.5 million this year! A big thank you to the donors, for contributing generously. Your support keeps the arts flourishing in Singapore. – LHL

Have arrived home from Bangkok. I paid my respects to the late King Bhumibol Adulyadej at the Grand Palace this morning. Also conveyed Singapore’s deepest condolences to the Thai people on their great loss.

His Majesty had a long and benevolent reign. He was a great leader who shaped Thailand’s development and improved his people’s lives. He will also be remembered for fostering the enduring friendship between Thailand and Singapore. May he rest in peace. – LHL

One of Bangkok’s many wats (temples) in the golden hour, snapped as my plane made its final approach to Suvarnabhumi Airport yesterday. Am here to pay my respects to the late King Bhumibol Adulyadej. – LHL

(Photo by me)

Our public officers work hard to serve the nation. I was proud to present National Day and Civil Service Long Service awards to 44 of them this morning to recognise their contributions. 

The recipients were from agencies and statutory boards under the Prime Minister’s Office – Civil Service College Singapore, Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau, Singapore, Elections Department, Monetary Authority of Singapore, National Population and Talent Division, National Security Coordination Secretariat, and PSD Singapore – and also from the President’s Office.

Thank you for your dedication and hard work! – LHL

Last Saturday, I attended the Paya Lebar Methodist Girls’ School reunion dinner as a guest. Last night I attended my own Trinity College, Cambridge get together!

The occasion was a visit by the Master of the college, Sir Greg Winter, to Singapore. Enjoyed catching up with fellow alumni – Singaporeans, Malaysians, British, Greek, Finnish, Nepalese, and probably other nationalities too, who live and work here. 

We chatted about the world, as well as how things were (and are) in Cambridge. 年少时候，谁没有梦 – grateful to the college for giving us the nurturing and stimulus to pursue our dreams and passions. :) – LHL

(MCI Photo by Kenji Soon)

Went for a #jalanjalan at Gardens by the Bay before my trips to India and Australia. 

I have been to the Gardens many times, for events (bit.ly/2edSVIt) and for leisure (bit.ly/2ebHWzX), but each time I discover something new and interesting.  

Good to see so many people relaxing and enjoying one of our beautiful green spaces in Singapore. – LHL
#Guesswhere I spotted this odd critter? :) – LHL

I’ve done more travelling than usual this year – 6 countries in the past 3 months, with a couple more trips to come! (http://str.sg/4fiA) Happy to reaffirm our strong partnerships with our overseas friends.

Wherever my travels take me, it is always comforting to see the distinctive uniforms and hear the familiar accents of the Singapore Airlines crew, and receive their warm and unfailing care.

Thank you for your great service, and for keeping SIA a great way to fly! – LHL

(With the crew on my flight back from India 2 weeks ago./ Photo by me)

Ang Mo Kio Community Centre is 40 years old! 

Celebrated the CC’s anniversary with Mr Yeo Toon Chia (Ang Mo Kio’s first MP), residents and activists last night. They all have fond memories of the CC and have each contributed to make it the vibrant place that it is today.

Contrary to legend, Ang Mo Kio did not get its name from the tomato fruit. The town got its name from a “kio” (hokkien for bridge). This kio was built by an “ang mo” (hokkien for Caucasian) – John Turnbull – at what is now the junction of Upper Thomson Road and Ang Mo Kio Avenue 1. You can read more about the town and its history here: www.bit.ly/2dr3MjY. – LHL

Happy to join students, alumni, and staff of Paya Lebar Methodist Girls’ School in celebrating their 100th Founder’s Day last night. 

PLMGS is one of a handful of schools that have reached their 100th birthday. It has many outstanding alumni, who have served our country and community in different roles.

The school was recently in the news after winning 15 awards at the World Robot Games International Competition, despite only setting up its robotics interest group this year. They were also the only girls in the competition! (http://str.sg/4xeW)  

PLMGS also has a strong tradition in the arts. Their handbell group performed for us at this year’s National Day Observance Ceremony at the Istana.

Congratulations PLMGS on your centennial! May you continue to be “an outstanding school of choice producing women of fine character with a passion for life and learning” for many years to come. – LHL

Had a productive second day during my recent visit to Canberra. Started the morning by witnessing several MOUs which will raise our ties with Australia to the next level.

Our Comprehensive Strategic Partnership (CSP) covers many areas. We are upgrading our free trade agreement, to make it easier for professionals to work in each other’s countries. Science and innovation will get a boost, as will arts and culture. We’re also jointly developing state-of-the-art facilities in Queensland, for the SAF to train together with the Australian Defence Force (which means the ‘Wallaby’ will get bigger soon :) ).

Our relationship goes back a long time, and we have come a long way together as friends. Perhaps with the CSP, we can start calling each other ‘mates’! – LHL

Just got back from Australia, and learnt the sad news of Thai King Bhumibol Adulyadej’s passing. 

King Bhumibol was the world's longest-serving monarch, much beloved and revered by his people. He dedicated himself wholly to his country and to improving his people’s lives. His wise leadership and enormous prestige held the country together.

I last met King Bhumibol in 2009, during the ASEAN Summit in Hua Hin, Thailand. He was a most gracious host and took a close interest in ASEAN programmes to promote economic growth and development.

On behalf of Singapore, I offer my deepest condolences to the Royal Family and people of Thailand on their sad loss. May King Bhumibol rest in peace. – LHL

(An audience with King Bhumibol after I became PM in 2004./ ZB Photo © Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Reproduced with permission.)

An excellent first day in Canberra. Here are some video highlights of my visit! – LHL

(PMO Video by Alex Qiu)

Singapore and Australia are very different countries. Australia has abundant natural resources and is more than 10,000 times the size of Singapore (in fact, we are smaller than many sheep farms there!). They are traditionally Anglo-Saxon in identity, while we are an Asian society. 

Despite this, we have forged a deep and longstanding friendship. Not just because of shared strategic interests, but also because our peoples share similar outlooks. We are both open, practical, inclusive, direct, and pride ourselves on our multicultural societies. 

That is why I am happy we have concluded the Comprehensive Strategic Partnership, which will make us even closer partners. I spoke on this (and more) in my address to the Australian Parliament this morning, which you can watch here: http://bit.ly/2ef3bnU 

– LHL

Just arrived in Canberra for an official visit to Australia. These children from Avondale Grammar School heard I was visiting, and sent me this cute video on what I should do in Australia! 

I’d love to grab PM Malcolm Turnbull to go to the beach and have an ice cream together, and visit Uluru, Sydney, Melbourne and Rottnest Island. Sadly, we’ll be busy working. 

I will be meeting PM Turnbull with his Ministers, and am also very honoured to be invited to address a joint session of the Australian Parliament. 

Singapore and Australia have a Strategic Partnership, and we are signing several agreements to take our friendship forward. 

Australia is one of our oldest friends, and we share warm ties. Looking forward to the visit! :) – LHL

(Video courtesy of Avondale Grammar School)

Proud to see Singapore student Kenneth Sng making the opening remarks at the 2nd US Presidential #Debate. Kenneth is the Student Union president of Washington University in St Louis, the venue of today’s town hall debate. He spoke on behalf of the students to welcome the candidates and the audience to the university. 

He is also a Jurong Junior College alumnus and Singapore Public Service Commission scholar. Glad that he mentioned “Singapore, my home”, in his remarks.

Well done Kenneth. Keep the Singapore flag flying high! – LHL

#debate2016

Enjoyed last night’s Mystique X Charity Gala Dinner for the Down Syndrome Association - Singapore (DSA), celebrating its 20th anniversary. 

In Singapore, we matter to one another. Every person counts. The DSA has done a lot of good work. It helps people with Down Syndrome enhance and advance their lives. It runs programmes for infants, children, and adults. Last night its members performed for us, dancing, drumming, and playing the piano. DSA also auctioned off their paintings and photographs to raise funds. 

The DSA shows what we can accomplish when we help look after one another. My thanks to the organisers and sponsors of last night’s event for their generosity and hard work, and to DSA members and their supporters for their enthusiastic participation. – LHL

Spoke with The Hindu, an Indian daily newspaper, while I was in Delhi. The journalist asked sharp questions on regional Free Trade Agreements, the India-Singapore tax treaty, and India’s role in ASEAN. 

You can read the full interview here: http://bit.ly/2cZ6xFI.

– LHL

Happy Children’s Day to all our kids!

Just arrived home from India this evening. India celebrates Children's Day on 14 November, the birthday of their first Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru. 

Mr Nehru was very fond of children, and promoted their education and welfare. In Singapore too, we do all we can to equip our kids for the future. 

Some things are universal though, no matter where you go. Children love balloons, especially giant ones! – LHL
 
(In New Delhi./ MCI Photo by Betty Chua)

Highlights of my visit to Udaipur.

It has been a fruitful trip. Glad to see progress since Singapore and India signed the Strategic Partnership last November. Homebound now! :) – LHL

(PMO Video by Chiez How)

Udaipur, Rajasthan, is known as the City of Lakes and Venice of the East. With its picturesque landscape, historic architecture and a young workforce – it has all the right conditions to be tourist haven. 

Glad Singapore can support the city’s growing tourism industry by sharing our expertise and experience. The Institute of Technical Education, Singapore is helping to set up the Centre of Excellence for Tourism Training. The MOU with the state government will also promote collaboration between Singapore and Rajasthan in tourism and urban solutions. Hope our partnership will be useful to many parties from both sides. – LHL

Delighted to reaffirm the strong Singapore-India bilateral ties in my meeting with President Pranab Mukherjee yesterday.

We met at the majestic Rashtrapati Bhavan, the official home of the President of India. It was originally built by the British, as the residence for the Viceroy of India. Few official premises can match its grandeur and scale. – LHL

谋事在人，成事在天。Sometimes Mother Nature has her own plans. We were just ten minutes away from Udaipur when bad weather and poor visibility forced our plane to turn back to New Delhi. Waiting at Delhi airport now, hoping the weather clears and we can find our way to Udaipur (again). Stay posted for updates. :) – LHL
 
(Video of the bad weather we encountered during our aborted landing in Udaipur. / PMO Video by Chiez How)

Highlights of my first day in New Delhi. Will be  off to Udaipur, Rajasthan this afternoon to launch the Centre of Excellence for Tourism Training we are helping to set up there. Will also be checking out other Singapore-related developments in the area. – LHL

(PMO Video by Chiez How)

Delighted to meet PM Narendra Modi again yesterday. We picked up from his visit to Singapore last November (http://bit.ly/2dNgzzw), and reviewed progress since we signed the Strategic Partnership. 

We talked about financial cooperation, air links, and Mr Modi’s “Skill India” and “100 Smart Cities” initiatives. Singapore cannot do a hundred Smart Cities, but we hope to help develop one - Amaravati, Andhra Pradesh’s new capital city. :)

At a reception for overseas Singaporeans in the evening, I met individuals and business leaders who are contributing to India’s development in different ways, and helping to raise our profile in India.

With these exchanges, I am confident that our ties will continue to flourish. – LHL

Namaste from New Delhi, India!

Singapore and India have a long history of relations. We share a colonial heritage, cultural ties, and strategic interests. I will be spending the next few days finding out about developments in India and strengthening our partnership. Stay tuned for more updates. – LHL

This evening, Muslims in Singapore welcomed the Islamic New Year of 1438 Hijrah. 

The first month of the Islamic year, Muharram, is one of the four holy months in the Islamic calendar. For Muslims it is a time for prayer and reflection, and to renew their commitment to do their best.

Wishing all our Muslim friends a blessed New Year! – LHL

Umat Islam menyambut ketibaan tahun baru 1438 Hijrah, malam tadi. 

Bulan Muharram adalah bulan pertama dan salah satu daripada empat bulan suci dalam kalendar Islam. Bagi umat Islam, ini merupakan detik untuk menilai semula tahun yang baru berlalu dan menguatkan azam untuk pertingkatkan diri menuju ke arah perubahan yang lebih baik.
 
Selamat menyambut tahun baru Hijrah kepada semua umat Islam. – LHL

Am back home!

Spoke at the Special Session of the Nikkei International Conference on the Future of Asia yesterday. I talked about China’s growth and emergence, and Japan’s need to strengthen its outward engagement. 

The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) will help Japan to make domestic changes, and become more competitive. Japan’s Diet will be debating the TPP soon, and I hope that they will ratify it.
 
Japan has played an important and positive role in Asia for decades, promoting peace, stability and development. May it continue doing so for many years.

A busy first two days in Tokyo. Was hosted to lunch by Their Majesties Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko; had meetings with PM Shinzo Abe, and Japanese political and business leaders; and attended a belated National Day reception with 400+ overseas Singaporeans.

Here are some of the highlights. You can also view more photos here: http://bit.ly/2dfWZc8. – LHL
(PMO Video by Alex Qiu)

Happy to meet PM Shinzo Abe again. This year is the 50th anniversary of Singapore-Japan diplomatic relations. Our partnership is strong and broad. Besides robust economic and trade links, people-to-people ties are close too. Over 35,000 Japanese work in Singapore, and Singaporeans love Japanese food. :) 

PM Abe and I discussed what more we could do together. Following our meeting, he presented to me the Grand Cordon of the Order of the Paulownia Flowers, awarded to the late Mr Lee Kuan Yew. It was a high honour, given in recognition of all the contributions by Mr Lee to Singapore-Japan relations over decades. 

My thanks to PM Abe for his warm hospitality. I am grateful that PM and Mrs Abe attended Mr Nathan’s lying in state last month, and PM Abe came for Mr Lee’s funeral last year. I am confident that Singapore-Japan ties will flourish for many more years to come.

You can view my speeches here: http://bit.ly/2drv9wD

– LHL

Saddened by the passing of former Israeli President Shimon Peres שמעון פרס.

Mr Peres was a visionary who served his country tirelessly all his life. I was privileged to meet him several times, and to benefit from his wisdom and friendship. 

I last called on him in April, at the Peres Centre of Peace in Tel Aviv. He received me graciously. Then 92, he was focussed on the young and the future. He told me why he was convinced that science and education were the way to foster greater understanding between peoples. 

Mr Peres was the last of the founding generation of Israeli leaders. As defence minister in 1976, he advocated the brilliant Entebbe hostage rescue operation. He was the only Israeli statesman to have served both as President and Prime Minister. Mr Peres passionately believed in peace between Israel and the Palestinians, and received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1994 for his efforts to promote peace in the Middle East. 

Mr Peres has left a lasting legacy. He has inspired younger generations to continue striving for peace and reconciliation, not just in Israel and the Middle East, but across the world. – LHL
 
(Calling on Mr Peres at the Peres Centre of Peace in April./ MCI Photo by Chwee)

Happy to meet 400+ overseas Singaporeans at a belated National Day reception in Tokyo last night. Everyone was in high spirits, coming together for the shared love of Singaporean food and company. 

Earlier in the day, Their Majesties Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko hosted me and Ho Ching to lunch. They were most gracious and hospitable, and remembered fondly their state visit to Singapore in 2006. – LHL

Met Kiran from Anderson Secondary School and many other students at the Singapore Indian Development Association Excellence Awards (SEA) ceremony yesterday afternoon.

Kiran did very well for his PSLE and is currently a student councillor and in the school choir. I asked if he could sing, and he replied “they seem to think so!”. I always admire people who can sing, because I totally can’t! :)

Kiran was one of 466 students who received SEA awards for excelling in academics, sports or the arts. Every year, SINDA’s programmes help more than 20,000 students to fulfil their potential. 

Congrats to all SEA recipients, and a big thank you to all the partners of SINDA who make these awards possible! – LHL

(MCI Photo by Chwee)

If you encounter an emergency or terrorist attack, what can you do?

Terrorism is a reality of modern life. The terrible attacks that are in the news practically every week threaten religious harmony, undermine trust, and polarise societies. 

#SGSecure is our nationwide response to the terrorist threat. The Government measures against terrorism are necessary but not enough. The SGSecure movement will teach you the skills you need, and enable each of us to protect ourselves, our families, and Singapore. 

The question is not whether Singapore will be attacked, but when. I urge all Singaporeans to take part in the SGSecure programmes, so that when a crisis happens, we can stay alert, stay united, and stay strong. 

You can watch my speech here: http://y2u.be/O7RgArtMme4

– LHL
 
#stayalert #stayunited #staystrong

The Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI) is 110! I had celebrated their centennial with them in 2006. Happy to see it still doing well and doing good in the decade since then.

The SCCCI makes valuable contributions to our economic restructuring. It offers members an extensive business network; supports them in doing business overseas, especially in China; and helps SMEs to develop capabilities and upgrade. 

Beyond business, SCCCI members have contributed much to the community. Over the years they have raised funds to help the needy, started schools, and played a vital role in our nation-building. Today, the SCCCI still strongly supports Chinese culture, language and education.
 
Hope SCCCI will continue to thrive. Congratulations on reaching this milestone! 

You can watch my speech (in Mandarin) here: http://bit.ly/2d5Qv0J

– LHL

很高兴昨晚能出席新加坡中华总商会成立110年的志庆晚宴！ 我在晚宴致词时（http://bit.ly/2d5Qv0J ）谈到总商会百多年来的辉煌成就，应该归功于领导团队和建国一代华商的无私奉献，及会员的鼎力支持。

还记得10年前，我出席总商会百年大庆时，送了总商会一个牌匾。上面刻了“再创辉煌”四个字， 以鼓励总商会再接再厉，继续为我国华商和社会作出贡献。

一转眼，十年过去了。这十年来，我们一起走过了风风雨雨，一同经历了金融风暴。 我国的经济和社会结构也起了一些根本变化。不管世界如何演变，总商会仍焕发活力、坚持不懈地为会员和国家谋福利，这是值得我们表扬的。

Selamat Hari Raya Haji to all our Muslim friends!

This year, 680 of our pilgrims have made the journey to fulfill their hajj. The hajj is the fifth pillar of Islam. Every year, millions of Muslims perform this pilgrimage to the holy lands in Saudi Arabia. Wishing our pilgrims a safe and meaningful journey. 

Muslims also perform the korban (sacrifice) rites today and distribute the meat to the less fortunate and share among families and friends. Unfortunately, some sheep did not survive the flight to Singapore. We are investigating how this happened. 

Nevertheless, the korban rites are carrying on as scheduled. Those who have pledged to do korban are able to do so. My deep appreciation to all who have worked hard to enable korban rites to take place here. – LHL

Glad to be back home after a long week away in China and Laos! 

The #ASEAN and other summits in Vientiane concluded yesterday. The issues we discussed (terrorism, South China Sea, the Korean Peninsula) are complex, and different countries have quite different perspectives. But by exchanging views, we can at least prevent things from getting worse. And if we are lucky, we can make things a little bit better. 

Our region has prospered because there has been peace, countries have cooperated with one another, and we have deepened our interdependence through trade and investments. We must continue to engage with our neighbours, strengthen relations, and tackle our challenges together.

My thanks to our Laotian hosts for their hospitality, especially PM Thongloun Sisoulith who chaired the many meetings. – LHL

Another full day, this time at the 29th #ASEAN Summit.

During the retreat session, I spoke on three challenges. First, terrorism. Not a new topic but the situation is getting more serious - more self-radicalisation, Southeast Asian terrorist groups linking up with ISIS in the Middle East as well as groups elsewhere, and more frequent attacks. 

Second, growth and trade. The ASEAN Economic Community is a good start. We need to conclude the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership. This will expand opportunities for all our businesses. 

Third, maintaining ASEAN unity and credibility. The South China Sea issue is a test of this. Understandably, ASEAN countries have different positions, but we must stand together in the common interest to maintain the peace and stability of the region.

Following our retreat, we met the leaders of China, Japan, Korea and Australia. These meetings enable leaders to exchange views, forge closer cooperation, and bring our region closer. It is an ongoing and necessary process. – LHL

A busy day at the 28th #ASEAN Summit in Vientiane yesterday. This is our first Summit since we established the ASEAN community last year. We also welcomed Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte, Vietnam Prime Minister Nguyễn Xuân Phúc, Myanmar State Councillor Aung San Suu Kyi, and also the host, PM Thongloun Sisoulith, to their first meeting with the ASEAN family.

In the plenary session, I suggested three areas for ASEAN to work on. First, to strengthen ASEAN unity and Centrality, because if ASEAN countries are divided, we will lose our relevance and value to our partners. Second, to review and streamline ASEAN’s processes. Third, to address transboundary challenges, such as haze and Zika. We must prepare for an extended campaign against Zika in the region. Singapore will work with our ASEAN partners and the international community to combat this disease.

Also met Australian PM Malcolm Turnbull and Chinese Premier Li Keqiang on the sidelines of the Summit. Glad that Laos is holding the two ASEAN Summits back-to-back this year. More on the 29th ASEAN Summit tomorrow! :) – LHL

Wrapped up #G20 meetings in Hangzhou yesterday evening. Am now in Vientiane, Laos, for #ASEAN Summits and related summits.

The G20 forum brings together major countries to discuss the world economy. China invited Singapore as a guest to the meeting, to represent the Global Governance Group (3G). 

In my speech, I suggested three approaches to promote international trade: (1) help businesses and workers compete at home and tap global markets, (2) promote trade regionally through free trade agreements like the TPP, and (3) cooperate internationally to free up trade, e.g. by ratifying the WTO Trade Facilitation Agreement and concluding the Environmental Goods Agreement. This will boost growth and create prosperity for our peoples.

My thanks to President Xi Jinping, organisers and volunteers for making the G20 Summit a success. Looking forward to more discussions with ASEAN counterparts and other leaders over the next few days. – LHL

Mediacorp broadcast my interview - “On Race and Politics” - last night. I explained why I am making changes to the Elected Presidency (EP) now.

Many of you must be closely following the news on the local #Zika cases. We have been tracking Zika for a while now, and knew it was only a matter of time before it reached Singapore. 

Scientists are still learning about this new disease. But we know that for most people it is mild, and in fact often causes no symptoms at all. Pregnant women are at risk, as they are with other viral infections like dengue and chicken pox. Do take precautions and get tested if you show symptoms.

The cases so far have been in Aljunied and Bedok, but we must assume that Zika is elsewhere in Singapore too. Our best defence is to eradicate mosquitos and destroy breeding habitats, all over Singapore. Do the 5-step Mozzie Wipeout. Let's all do our part to fight Zika, and dengue as well.

For more info on Zika, go to www.gov.sg/zika. – LHL

Met United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon today. He completes his second term as UNSG soon, and we are honoured that he is making a farewell visit to Singapore.

The UN is important to us. It is part of the international order that enables countries to live in peace, resolve conflicts, and tackle global issues like sustainable development and climate change. Without the UN, it would be much tougher for small countries to protect ourselves in the international arena.

Singapore is active in the UN. We helped to form the Forum of Small States (FOSS), a group of 100+ countries who work together to make our voices heard. This is how a small country can make a contribution and advance our interests in the world. - LHL

With deep sorrow, today we bade farewell to one of Singapore’s most illustrious sons.

Mr S R Nathan was a man of great personal integrity, commitment and generosity. He lived life fully, and never gave up despite the challenges he faced. He could always be counted on to do his best for Singapore, even at personal risk and sacrifice. 
 
Mr Nathan played a significant role in our nation-building. He was a President for all Singaporeans, who cared deeply about racial and religious harmony. Even after he retired, he continued to share a lifetime of experience and wisdom with younger Singaporeans. 

Mr Nathan had hoped that Singaporeans, especially the young, would draw one key lesson from his life story: “to not give up.” Mr Nathan lived by this precept, and we will remember him for it. Thank you Mr Nathan, for giving the best years of your life and more to Singapore. Rest in peace. – LHL

(PM Lee's eulogy for the late former President S R Nathan./ MCI Video by Gov.sg Production Team)

Accompanied Japanese PM Shinzo Abe and Mrs Abe to pay respects to the late Mr S R Nathan at Parliament House today. PM Abe was stopping over in Singapore en route to Kenya.

In his condolence letter, PM Abe expressed his respect and gratitude for Mr Nathan’s act of courage during the Laju hijacking.

In the 1974, four terrorists hijacked a ferry, the Laju, and took the crew hostage. After eight days of negotiations, they finally agreed to release the hostages in exchange for safe passage out of Singapore. Mr Nathan led a delegation of 12 Singapore officials as guarantors to accompany the hijackers to Kuwait. 

Fortunately the incident ended well with no casualties. But it was a serious and harrowing encounter, and Mr Nathan clearly showed his mettle in the face of uncertainty and danger. 

As President, Mr Nathan made a State Visit to Japan in 2009. There he met the victims of the Hiroshima atomic bomb, the first foreign Head of State to do so. PM Abe mentioned this to Mrs Nathan just now. It meant a lot to Japan.

Grateful to PM Abe and Mrs Abe for attending Mr Nathan’s lying in state. May we build on Mr Nathan’s legacy to bring our bilateral relations to greater heights. – LHL

STATEMENT FROM THE PRIME MINISTER’S OFFICE

The Government has accepted the wishes of the late Mr S R Nathan and his family in making the following funeral arrangements. The Government will provide all the necessary assistance.   
 
As a mark of respect to Mr Nathan, the State flag on all Government buildings will be flown at half-mast from Tuesday, 23 August to Friday, 26 August 2016.
 
The body of the late Mr Nathan will lie in state at Parliament House from 10.00am on Thursday, 25 August to 12.00pm on Friday, 26 August.  The public may pay their last respects at Parliament House from 10.00am to 8.00pm on Thursday, 25 August. On Friday, 26 August, members of the diplomatic corps and other officials may pay their last respects from 9.00am till 12.00pm.

A State Funeral Service will take place from 3.00 pm on Friday, 26 August at the University Cultural Centre (NUS). It will be attended by Mr Nathan’s family, friends and former colleagues, the President, Cabinet Ministers, MPs, civil servants as well as Singaporeans from all walks of life. 

The State Funeral Service will be followed by a private cremation at Mandai Crematorium. 

Condolence boards will be available at Istana for those who wish to pen tributes to the late Mr Nathan from tomorrow morning at 6am. Condolence books will also be opened at all Overseas Missions for overseas Singaporeans and friends.

The public can express their condolences and share their memories of Mr Nathan at the official website - www.remembering.sg/srnathan and the Remembering S R Nathan Facebook page at www.facebook.com/RememberingSRNathan

The public can call the hotline at 6336-1166 (operating hours: 8am - 10pm) with queries, visit www.remembering.sg/srnathan or the Remembering S R Nathan Facebook page for more details.  
 
PRIME MINISTER’S OFFICE
SINGAPORE
22 AUGUST 2016

Deeply saddened by the passing of Mr SR Nathan today. He passed away peacefully at the Singapore General Hospital, surrounded by family and loved ones, three weeks after suffering a stroke. 

Mr Nathan’s life is an inspiration to us all. His was a story of how a young boy strove to triumph over his circumstances and make a contribution to society. He held many public service posts, and occupied the highest office in the land.

Mr Nathan was our longest serving President. He was a warm and approachable President who endeared himself to Singaporeans. He impressed visitors with his knowledge of world affairs, and served with dignity and distinction.  

I have known Mr Nathan for 40 years, since I was a young officer in SAF. I remember him as a man guided by a deep sense of duty to the nation. He stepped up each time duty called. He was a true son of Singapore.

My condolences to Mrs Nathan and the family. Our thoughts and prayers are with you in this time of grief. – LHL

The second issue to review is the qualifying criteria to become a candidate for President. The main purpose of the elected President scheme is to give the President the mandate to decide on two major matters: reserves and appointments. 

The President who safeguards reserves and men must have the right experience to decide whether the Government’s budgets and spending proposals are sound and justified. He must also be able to judge character, motivation, integrity, ability of names put up, and to know what advice to seek and accept.

That is why candidates must meet the qualifying criteria before they stand for election as President. Candidates must have held key appointments in the public service like Speaker, Chief Justice, Ministers, Permanent Secretaries, or had experience in the private sector running large and complex companies like Singtel, DBS and Keppel Corp. The Constitution defines these as companies with $100mil paid up capital.

But this $100mil paid up capital criteria is out of date. When we set it 25 years ago, our economy was much smaller, and our reserves too. Now our economy has grown, government spending and reserves have increased.

The benchmark companies which we had in mind when setting the qualifying criteria have also grown much larger. Running a $100mil company is no longer commensurate with the responsibilities of the President, so we have to update the definition.

#ndrsg

First, strengthening the role of the Council of Presidential Advisors (CPA).

When we designed the system, we had in mind not just an elected President, the person elected by voters, but a President advised by a Council of Presidential Advisors. So that when the President makes decisions, he will have the benefit of the collective experience and judgement of the CPA.

We envisaged that over time, as the CPA became more established, we would build it up further. The CPA arrangements have worked well. The changes proposed to the CPA are incremental and straightforward.

#ndrsg

REVIEW OF THE ELECTED PRESIDENCY

PM Lee: We have a good political, parliamentary system inherited from the British. We have adapted it over time to fit our needs, and one major change we made was to make the President an elected office. The President is the Head of State and the symbol of the nation. Therefore instead of being chosen by Parliament, he has to be elected by the people of Singapore.

We have operated this two-key system for 25 years, and made many adjustments to it. But some aspects have not been revised and we need to bring them up to date.

In January I appointed a Constitutional Commission, chaired by the Chief Justice, to review 3 things:
  - To consider how the President can give more weight to the advice of the Council of Presidential Advisors (CPA)
  - To update the criteria for someone to be a candidate to be President
  - To ensure that minorities regularly have a chance to become President

The Commission submitted its report to me last week and made recommendations for improvement in all 3 areas. We are still studying the report and will release it soon.

Tonight, I won’t talk about specific recommendations by the Commission. I want to explain why we are reviewing the Elected Presidency and to tell you why in these 3 areas we should make changes.

#ndrsg

Q3: HOW DO WE ENSURE GOOD POLITICS FOR SINGAPORE?

PM Lee: I have described some of our strategies to ensure that we progress together and to keep our place in the world. But for all these plans to work, Singapore must have good politics. If our political system malfunctions; if we fail to produce good leaders; if we cannot work together, and are divided among ourselves; then all our best laid plans will come to naught.

The Brexit referendum was a vivid reminder of the importance of good politics. The vote for the UK to leave the EU is already affecting the UK economy. But the bigger impact of the referendum was to deepen fault lines in British society. Why did it happen? Voters lost faith in their leaders and the whole political class. Large segments of the population felt that they were not benefitting from the country’s progress.

The same thing can happen here. Can Singapore be different? Yes, provided we have politics that unite the people and uphold our multi-racial society. Our leaders must be attuned to people’s aspirations and respond to their concerns, and our political system must be sound.

#ndrsg

One of our big pluses is that our religious and community leaders have taken courageous stands. They condemn the terrorist attacks forthrightly, refute extremist views, and make clear that terrorists do not represent Islam, or Singapore Muslims.

Our Muslim leaders have expressed concerns to us about foreign preachers visiting Singapore who don’t understand our context and want to preach their exclusivist practices and doctrines here. I am glad our leaders are vigilant, making sure that the Islam practised in Singapore suits our multi-racial context.

I also welcome the call by Malay/Muslim community leaders to make the Asatizah Recognition Scheme (ARS) compulsory, to ensure that our religious teachers and scholars are reliable guides for the community. I commend them for taking the initiative to deal with a sensitive problem. These measures will ensure that all asatizah in Singapore understand how Islam is practised there, and can guide their students to live in harmony with fellow Singaporeans of all races and religions.

#ndrsg

TERRORISM
 
One urgent issue where we have to cooperate with our neighbours is terrorism.

Almost every day we read of new attacks somewhere: US, Europe, to Middle East, and closer to home, in Indonesia and Malaysia. Terrorist groups are active all around us in Southeast Asia. In Singapore, the threat is not just from outside but also domestic. We have arrested a dozen Singaporeans who have been radicalised.

Look at other countries. People react in two possible ways after an attack. One, they show a collective will to stand together. The other reaction is distrust and suspicion. The question is: which will happen in Singapore?

Our diplomats and security forces, the Home Team and SAF are doing excellent work. But they alone cannot guarantee our security and safety, or hold us together. All of us must do our part, from understanding our national interest, and supporting Singapore in our relations with other countries, to preparing ourselves to deal with terrorism, and standing together after a terrorist attack.

I will be launching the #SGSecure movement in September. It is a call-to-action to all to be sensitised, trained and mobilised to protect Singapore from a terrorist attack.

Ultimately, what matters most is our resolve to hold together and fight to defend our place in the world.

#ndrsg

(SPH Photo)

MALAYSIA & INDONESIA

PM Lee: Malaysia and Indonesia are our two most important partners. We work hard to build our ties, but these are sensitive, complex relationships. There will be differences from time to time, because of their deep-seated attitudes towards us, but today, on the whole, relations with both countries are good.

Last month, I was in Putrajaya to witness the MOU on the High Speed Rail between Singapore and Malaysia. PM Najib hosted us to lunch. The durian was good, but the High Speed Rail will be better!

I meet President Jokowi regularly, including once over nasi lemak, and have been discussing how to enhance our economic cooperation, and encourage more Singapore companies to invest more in Indonesia. We also want to work with Indonesia to tackle trans-boundary haze and deal with companies that are causing it.

#ndrsg

(Right-Photo by Ho Ching; left-MCI Photo by LH Goh)

Sometimes the interests of our friends will conflict, and we will be pressured to choose sides. One current issue which may upset the peace, stability, and friendship of the region is the South China Sea. It is a complicated dispute.

China claims the “nine-dash line”. Four ASEAN countries – Philippines, Brunei, Malaysia, Vietnam – have overlapping claims with China and with one another. The US has no claims but they do have interests at stake.

3 years ago, the Philippines launched a case against China under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). The Tribunal heard the case, and in its Award in July said that China’s claim to historic rights within the “nine-dash line” is incompatible with UNCLOS. China has categorically rejected the Award as “null and void”.

What is Singapore’s interest and stand? We don’t have any claims of our own and we don’t take sides on the specific claims of any of the claimants. But in other ways, we have a lot at stake. Three things matter to us:
  - International law
  - Freedom of Navigation
  - A united ASEAN

Therefore, on this South China Sea issue, we have our own principled and consistent stand. Other countries will persuade us to side with them but we have to choose our own place to stand, and not succumb to pressure.

Singapore has a reputation to protect. We cooperate with other countries, but we make our own calculations. That is what makes us credible and valuable to others, to our ASEAN partners, and powers like the US, China and Europe. It has taken us a long time to build up this reputation, and we must be very careful to maintain it.

#ndrsg

At the same time, Singapore is good friends with China and hopes that China will develop and grow well too. Because an unstable and backward China will cause Asia great trouble, as happened in 1950s and 60s. Over the last 40 years, China has been stable and prosperous, and this has greatly benefitted Asia and the world, including Singapore.

We are working with China on their “One Belt, One Road” strategy; exploring opportunities in infrastructure, connectivity, financial services, urban planning and clean technology; and participating in the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank.
 
President Xi Jinping said recently the US and China should “cultivate common circles of friends”. This is precisely what Singapore is trying to do – to be among America’s circle of friends, and China’s too.

#ndrsg
 
(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

Q2: HOW DO WE SECURE OUR PLACE IN THE WORLD?
 
PM Lee: To start off with, we have to defend ourselves and that’s why we have the SAF. But we also need a network of friends. In our neighbourhood, with the big powers all over the world, and in faraway places.

That is why I have been busy with foreign trips this year. Beyond our neighbours, Malaysia and Indonesia, our most important friends include major powers like the US and China.

I just came back from an Official Visit to the US, at the invitation of President Obama. This was a significant gesture. My visit reflects Singapore’s warm and deep friendship with America, and was also a signal that the US values its friends and partners, and appreciates Singapore’s support for the role that America has played in the Asia-Pacific for more than 70 years.

COMMITTEE ON THE FUTURE ECONOMY

We also need an overall strategy – to spot changes and respond to successive disruptions, to make our companies resilient and able to keep finding new ways to do business, and to prepare our workers to do different and new jobs during their working lives

That is what the Committee on the Future Economy (CFE), chaired by Ministers Heng Swee Keat and Iswaran, are doing.

It is not quite done, but I will give your a preview of 3 of the themes:

1. To help companies build new capabilities. The digital economy is one promising area.

2.To promote entrepreneurship as they play an important role in our society. Not just in creating jobs and prosperity, but with their resourcefulness and optimism, they give our society the confidence that “anything is possible”.

3. To develop a skilled workforce. That is why SkillsFuture is crucial. We are preparing our students well for the new economy, equipping them with relevant, in-demand skills. We are also offering courses to upgrade those already working and help them achieve deeper mastery.

Besides upgrading workers in their present careers, we are helping workers who get retrenched, or who change careers, to transition and find new jobs.

These are the ways our economy, and our workers, can thrive amidst disruption. This is how we can progress together, and thrive in a competitive and dangerous world.

#ndrsg

(MCI Photo)

Q1: HOW DO WE PROGRESS? 

PM Lee: We aspire to be among the leading cities like New York, Shanghai, London, Tokyo, Sydney. Yet at the same time, we want Singapore to be our home, where we belong and where our families feel safe and secure, where we build a compassionate and inclusive society, leaving no one behind.

But among all the economic issues we are dealing with, the defining challenge which we face in this era is “disruption”. Because of technology and globalisation, and disruption will happen over and over again, relentlessly.

We can respond to disruptive change in two ways: close ourselves off, and try to stop people from using the new technology; or, embrace change, and let the disruption happen, and adjust to it. 

Every industry is getting disrupted differently. EDB, SPRING Singapore, Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore - IDA and IE Singapore (International Enterprise Singapore) will work with industries and with the trade associations and chambers. They will develop specific programmes to help companies use new technologies and invest in skills.

PM Lee: A lot has happened since my last NDR. We had a good GE, and we now have our next generation of leaders firmly in place. We have been working hard to lay the foundation for the next 50 years, with SkillsFuture, our education policies, the SGFuture conversations and projects, and the Committee for Future Economy.

My subjects will not all be easy or fun, and some sensitive topics may even make us feel a bit uncomfortable. 2. How do we secure our place in the world?
3. How do we ensure good politics for Singapore?

#ndrsg

Recently, somebody asked me at a dialogue “If God appeared before you and asked you for three things that you would want for Singapore, what would these be?”

I was taken aback. I thought for a while and replied: If we wish for material things, we will regret it, because after we have got it, we will not be satisfied and we will want more. But what I would like is that we be blessed with a divine discontent - always dissatisfied with where we are; always driven to do better. And yet, that we have the wisdom to count our blessings, so that we know how precious Singapore is, and we know how to enjoy and protect it.

If just these two wishes are fulfilled, that will be enough. Then we can keep on building something special in Singapore for many more years, and “Achieve Happiness, Prosperity, and Progress, for our nation”.

Thank you and Good Night

加强多元种族的和谐社会

总理说，新加坡能有今天的种族和谐，建国一代，尤其是华社，功不可没。他们和政府携手合作，奠定了一个多元、和谐社会的基础。经过多年的相处，大家在直觉上都明白各种族和宗教，都必须互相迁就，互相包容，才能维持现有的和睦。

不过我们的社会还没有完全达到对所有种族，无论肤色或语言，都一视同仁的理想。在条件相等的情况下，一位少数种族的候选人在华人占多数的选区竞选时，就会处于劣势。而新加坡，每个选区都是以华人居多。这也是我们实行集选区制度的原因。集选区制度确保了少数种族能在国会拥有他们的代议士。

总理说，要让一名非华族候选人当议员，已经很不容易。何况要一名非华族候选人当民选总统，就更困难。 所以，今年初，总理提议修改宪法，调整民选总统制度，其中就包括确保我国每隔一段时间，能有一位非华族的总统。

在现有的制度下，新加坡将来很可能长期没有非华族国人当选总统。这会削弱非华族同胞对国家的认同感， 影响我国社会凝聚力。这关系到新加坡的社会和谐，以及国家的发展与安全。所以，总理希望华族同胞会支持这个宪法的改革。这样，将来优秀的非华族人选，就能够成为国家元首，代表所有新加坡人。

总理说，调整我国的政治体系可让各个种族都有参与感， 都以身为新加坡国民感到自豪。这才能确保新加坡在面对各种挑战时，甚至是在危机发生时，大家可以更团结，从容应对。所以我们要坚守多元种族原则，让它延续下去。为下一代打造一个更美好，更灿烂的未来。

总理华语群众大会演讲2016

总理说，随着国家经济越来越发达，增长的速度必定会放缓。所以标新局 (SPRING Singapore) 和新加坡国际企业发展局 (IE Singapore) 针对中小型企业的需求，推出新的措施，帮助它们发展新的专长，利用科技扩大生意，开拓海外市场。中华总商会和其他商会也很积极地帮助会员寻找新的商机，推出各种计划帮助它们。

经过一番努力，我们已经看到了一些亮点，例如在一般制造业、家具设计、食品业等方面，有些传统公司转型 ，成功地向海外发展。总理也强调，危机也能带来转机。希望中小型企业能善加利用政府所推出的配套，进行转型，提升本地业绩或到海外发展。

除了帮助企业，总理也谈到政府推行的多项计划，跟企业合作，帮助工友调整，适应新环境。不少雇主也积极地帮助员工提升技能，借此提高生产力。另一方面，政府也帮助工友的家庭解决各种生活上的问题，让所有的家庭老有所养，壮有所用，幼有所长。

总理说，过去十年，政府推出了多项措施和配套，加强社会安全网。 政府尤其关心退休人事。因此，推出了终身健保和建国一代配套，帮助大家应付医药费。政府也改善了公积金终身入息计划(CPF Life)，提高了公积金存款利率，也推出了乐龄补贴计划。

但是，总理说，乐龄健保计划(ElderShield)还有待改善。因为现在，不是每个人都加入这项计划。总理说，卫生部将成立一个委员会来检讨这项计划。希望涵盖更多的人、提供更好的保障，同时确保保费是大家所负担得起的。

乐龄健保计划扩大之后，我们的社会安全网就可说是相当完善了。

Rapat Hari Kebangsaan 2016 – Ucapan Bahasa Melayu 

Dalam ucapan Bahasa Melayu, PM menekankan peri pentingnya masyarakat berbilang kaum Singapura untuk terus bersatu-padu.

Beliau turut menggesa agar masyarakat Melayu/Islam menguasai teknologi dan tidak lepaskan peluang untuk terlibat sepenuhnya dalam Ekonomi Baru. Beliau berharap masyarakat Melayu/Islam akan merebut pelbagai peluang untuk meningkatkan kemahiran dan taraf kehidupan melalui SkillsFuture.

PM juga menyentuh tentang ancaman keganasan yang semakin meruncing dan berbahaya di Singapura. Singapura terkenal sebagai negara yang berbilang agama dan rakyatnya bertolak ansur serta menghormati agama lain. Namun ada kalanya, pendakwah asing tidak faham konteks berbilang bangsa Singapura dan cuba memecahbelahkan keharmonian kaumnya. PM mengalu-alukan inisiatif masyarakat Melayu/Islam untuk memperkukuhkan Skim Pengiktirafan Asatizah (ARS) dan menjadikannya wajib bagi semua asatizah di Singapura. PM menyambut baik usaha dan azam masyarakat Melayu/Islam. Ini juga memberi jaminan dan meningkatkan keyakinan bahawa semua asatizah dapat membimbing pelajar mereka untuk mengamalkan Islam sesuai dengan konteks berbilang kaum Singapura.

Sebelum mengakhiri ucapannya, PM juga menarik perhatian kepada sistem Presiden Dipilih yang sedang diperhalusi untuk memberi peluang kepada kaum minoriti menjadi Presiden dari masa ke masa. Dengan keyakinan dan sokongan padu, barulah Presiden dapat melaksanakan peranan untuk menyatupadukan rakyat Singapura. 

Menggulung ucapannya, PM menekankan bahawa masyarakat Melayu/Islam adalah anggota penting yang telah banyak menyumbang kepada kesejahteraan dan kemajuan Singapura. Beliau menyeru masyarakat Melayu supaya meraikan kepelbagaian dan bersatu hati supaya dapat terus menikmati keharmonian, kemajuan dan kemakmuran pada masa akan datang.

I am too old to have played with Super Soakers, but my children loved these powerful water guns when they were small. So this BBC article on the inventor caught my attention and brought back memories. 

It is an inspiring story of Lonnie Johnson, former NASA engineer and inventor. It tells how he invented not only the Super Soaker but also the Nerf toy gun, which were both hugely successful. He used his fortune in royalties to set up a scientific lab that is developing green batteries and a hydrogen powered engine.

Johnson’s story is especially remarkable, as he is an African American who grew up in the American South in the 1960s, when blacks were still discriminated against and downtrodden. But he had a natural sense of curiosity and a “never-say-die” attitude, and he made it. 

He also spoke of why we must expose the young to ideas, and let them experience success. This will foster self belief and grow more successes.

So let us celebrate small successes, have passion and keep doing what interests us. Keep trying, and if at first you fail, try again. You never know where your efforts will take you! - LHL

Was deeply honoured to welcome Joseph Isaac Schooling and his parents, May and Colin Schooling to Parliament House today, where we formally congratulated him on his gold medal and expressed support for Team Singapore in #Rio2016. 

Joseph’s win signifies much more than Singapore’s first Olympic gold medal. He sweated and sacrificed. With determination and fire in the belly, he has shown a new generation of aspiring athletes that dreams are worth striving for.  

Achievements, too, are more than medals. Many of our athletes have come away from the Olympics with new personal bests, and valuable experience going up against the world’s best. Swimmer Quah Zheng Wen set two new personal bests in the pool. Rower Saiyidah Aisyah (Aisyah Rower) reached the quarterfinals, finishing as 3rd best Asian competitor. Sprinter Timothee Yap and shuttler Derek Wong went up against Usain Bolt and Lee Chong Wei respectively - both the best in the world. They have worked hard, and they all deserve recognition for their efforts. 

The Games are still ongoing and our athletes are still competing in their respective events. I hope you’ll join me in cheering on our women’s table tennis team in their semifinal match taking place right now! - LHL

At my joint press conference with President Obama in Washington on Tuesday, we were asked about the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP). I shared my perspective from this side of the Pacific. 

The TPP is a deal. It is the outcome of a tough bargaining process that all 12 member countries have negotiated. Each agreed to improve market access to the rest, and commit to a set of common rules, in exchange for the others doing the same. 

It is not just about exports but also about imports. It will benefit consumers as well as producers. Our people will enjoy a wider range of products, services, and opportunities that will improve their livelihoods.

It also has a strategic dimension. It promotes interdependence instead of rivalry, and ultimately peace instead of war.

President Obama has been critical in pushing for the TPP. The deal will not only benefit American workers and businesses. It will show clearly that America will stay engaged in the Asia Pacific, and deepen ties with its many friends and allies in the region. – LHL

Capped off my US visit on Tuesday with a long fruitful day. Singapore’s first official visit was in 1967, when President Lyndon Johnson invited Mr Lee Kuan Yew to Washington DC. 

50 years ago, we were newly independent, struggling to build a modern economy. America was divided over the Vietnam War. Mr Lee explained to the US why Asia mattered to America, and why their active engagement was crucial to the millions living in non-Communist countries in Southeast Asia. 

Today, thanks to US sacrifices and efforts, we live in a more peaceful, stable and prosperous region. Singapore’s relationship with the United States has flourished. We are partners in many areas - trade, defence, R&D, education, and are continually exploring ways to do more together. 

Most importantly, we enjoy strong people-to-people ties. So it is fitting that we are marking 50 years with a scholarship for student exchanges in each other’s countries. We have come far, and have many more things to do together. 

In Narita now, waiting for my flight home! – LHL

Singaporean Zulfikar Mohamad Shariff has been arrested and detained under the Internal Security Act for terrorism-related activities. Zulfikar used social media to propagate radical ideology, glorify ISIS, and exhort Muslims to take up arms and wage militant jihad.

Zulfikar also helped to radicalise at least two other Singaporeans. He aimed to provoke Singapore Muslims to push for an Islamic state to replace our democratic system. Fortunately, our security agencies caught him before he could do more harm.

Such extremist, violent beliefs have no place in our multi-racial and multi-religious country. The government will be alert to spot such individuals, but we need everyone’s help to uphold and protect our harmonious way of life. 

Together, we can stay united and strong. - LHL

Attended Mr Chor Yeok Eng’s wake today. 

Mr Chor belonged to the Pioneer Generation who built Singapore. He dedicated his life to the country and to improving the lives of Singaporeans. 

As a young man, he joined the PAP to fight for an independent Singapore. As MP for Bukit Timah, he saw the poor neighbourhood turn into a beautiful modern estate, and improved the lives of residents. 

Mr Chor’s integrity and character shone on many occasions. In 1956, when a 2,000 strong mob threatened to burn down the former Yeo Hiap Seng factory in Bukit Timah, he stopped them. He reminded them that they were against the colonialists and not the local manufacturer. 

Mr Lee Kuan Yew considered Mr Chor one of his oldest, most steadfast and courageous party comrades. He said that if he had to choose one other to go to battle with him, he would pick Mr Chor. 

After retiring in 1984, Mr Chor kept a watchful eye over his old constituency. I often met him when I visited Bukit Timah for constituency events, and was glad to see him again last year when we celebrated the 60th Anniversary of Bukit Timah.

I would like to express my deepest condolences to Mr Chor’s family at this time of sorrow. – LHL

Happy Racial Harmony Day!

Harmony between our different races and religions is a fundamental principle of our nation. We celebrate our diversity, and share each other’s customs and cultures.

Unfortunately, in many countries, we are seeing more cases where people reject diversity and inclusion. Just look at the extremist terrorist attacks in recent weeks - Orlando in the US, Dhaka in Bangladesh, Nice in France, Puchong in Malaysia - each incident chilling, driven by hatred, and heartbreaking. 

In Singapore, we must always stay united as one people, and never allow any such event to break or divide us.  – LHL

There is an old proverb: “measure twice, cut once”. Building and Construction Authority (Singapore) (BCA) has put a new spin on that, with “Build Twice: First Virtual, Then Real”. :)

Saw firsthand this morning how BCA is rolling out new technologies to build greener, more environmentally sustainable buildings. 

One of them is the Skylab, a rotating structure built atop the new Academic Tower at the BCA Academy. It is fitted with over 200 sensors. The structure can be rotated, to position the sun and wind at different angles. Caught up with PM Najib Razak over lunch before witnessing the signing of the Memorandum of Understanding on our High Speed Rail (HSR) in Putrajaya this afternoon. 

PM Najib and I agreed to build the HSR between KL and Singapore three years ago (bit.ly/29PWwem). Since then our officials have worked hard and long, through several Ramadans and Rayas, to reach agreement on key issues.

The HSR is a massive, long-term investment. Good execution will be crucial. We need to work closely together on many joint decisions and implementation issues. PM Najib and I will give full attention to this, because we want this major project to be done right.

With the HSR, people will think of Singapore-KL the same way as they think of London-Paris, Seoul-Busan, Taipei-Kaohsiung, Shanghai-Nanjing, or Tokyo-Osaka.

Read this thoughtful piece in yesterday’s The Straits Times. The writer reflects on her childhood days growing up in a kampung. She remembers fighting spiders with her cousins, free roaming chickens in the compound, and gathering twigs for her grandmother’s kitchen fire. But along with these idyllic scenes she also recalls the potholed roads, dirt, discomfort, and lack of basic sanitation that was the reality of kampung life. It reminded me of Jack Neo’s movie, Long Long Time Ago 2, that I watched recently (bit.ly/1OsCMic). 

The rapid pace of change, and the uncertainties of a globalised world, make us nostalgic for an older and seemingly simpler way of life. There is such a thing as a kampung spirit, which we should maintain in our modern lives. But kampung life was hard, and we are much better off today. 

We should remember our past, but we should not idealise it. That is the way to take Singapore forward, and build ourselves a better home for the future. - LHL

The UK vote to leave the European Union (EU) in the #Brexit referendum is a turning point. It reflects the anxiety of the British population over immigration, their resentment at having to negotiate with and accommodate European partners, and their desire to assert British identity and sovereignty. 

Other developed countries also face similar challenges as Britain. We all live in a globalised, interdependent world. The desire to disengage, to be less constrained by one’s partners, to be free to do things entirely as one chooses, is entirely understandable. And yet in reality for many countries disengaging and turning inwards will likely lead to less security, less prosperity, and a dimmer future.

The next few years will be uncertain ones for Britain and Europe. Leaving the EU is as complicated as joining it. What new arrangements will be made? Will Brexit hurt investor confidence more broadly, and the global economy? How will Britain’s leaving affect the rest of the EU? How will this affect us, living in Asia but part of the same globalised world?

It is too early to tell, but we need to watch developments carefully. Nobody can foresee all the consequences of the Brexit. 

The British voters have decided. We wish Britain well. I wish David Cameron well too, who has been a good friend of Singapore and has announced his intention to resign as PM.

Singapore will continue to cultivate our ties with Britain, which is a long standing friend and partner. We hope in time the uncertainty will diminish, and we will make the best of the new reality. - LHL

When was the last time you read a good book? I enjoy reading, but read less than I would like for pleasure. It is partly finding time, and also (if the book is serious) the effort of focussing on something not work related. But recently I have read several good books:

Ari Shavit’s My Promised Land: The Triumph and Tragedy of Israel, tells the story of Israel’s nation building and the conflict with the Palestinians through personal stories.

Operation Thunderbolt, by Saul David, is about the spectacular Israeli commando raid on Entebbe airport in Uganda, to rescue hostages after an aircraft hijacking, which happened exactly 40 years ago.

A Rage for Order, by Robert Worth, is about the Arab Spring, and how things have gone since then. Also told through personal stories, it brings home vividly the passions and struggles that combined to cause the upheavals in the Middle East.

I read these books partly because of my April trip to Jordan, Israel, and the Palestine Territories.

Came across this The New York Times piece explaining why Berlin is a “playground paradise”.

It’s not just that the actual playgrounds are creatively designed, physically challenging and plentiful, but also the attitude of parents. German parents believe in giving their children the space for adventurous play — to explore, climb, build, and in the process, develop a sense of “selbstständigkeit” or self-sufficiency. 

The article describes how in the US (and I suspect in Singapore too), playgrounds are less challenging because parents are more protective of their kids. But it is good for children to learn through exploration and risk taking, and to take a few tumbles in the process. They will grow up more confident and resilient, better able to cope with unfamiliar or difficult situations. 

I asked the Housing & Development Board about this, because HDB builds many playgrounds in our housing estates. HDB tells me that they are trying out more interesting designs, like a forest-themed playground in Bukit Panjang, and a military-inspired design in Choa Chu Kang (where Keat Hong Camp used to be). I hope these will be popular with children and their parents, and will lead us to create many more fun spaces for kids! - LHL

Happy to visit the Singapore-Myanmar Vocational Training Institute (SMVTI) in Yangon yesterday. 

SMVTI came about when Myanmar leaders asked for our help in skills training. In 2014, both sides signed an MOU to set up the Institute. We assisted in building the premises, and also deployed 3 Institute of Technical Education, Singapore staff to develop the curriculum and help run the school. Companies from both countries have generously sponsored equipment and training facilities, and I hope more will do so.

The Institute trains skilled workers in hospitality and tourism, electrical skills and electronics, facilities management and engineering services. Entry to the six-month courses is very competitive, and I found the students bright and keen.
 
After the SMVTI, I took a walk around downtown Yangon, which has many old pagodas and colonial buildings, and went to the rooftop of the Sakura Tower to view Yangon’s cityscape. – LHL

Met 300 Singaporeans living in Myanmar at a reception in Yangon yesterday. There were business owners, MNC employees, students on internships, and families. Some have been here for over 20 years! Many are looking forward to visa-free travel between Singapore and Myanmar. 

Before flying here, I had several meetings in Nay Pyi Taw. Myanmar Union Parliament Speaker Mahn Win Khaing Than and Lower House Speaker U Win Myint both expressed appreciation for Singapore’s support for Myanmar’s human resource development. Also met Senior General Min Aung Hlaing, Commander-in-Chief of Defence Services, and former President U Thein Sein, who now heads the USDP party. – LHL

Spent a fruitful day in Nay Pyi Taw yesterday. Called on President U Htin Kyaw and State Counsellor Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. 

Myanmar is an old friend and partner of Singapore. We mark the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations this year, but historically our ties go further back into colonial times. In fact the same person, Dr William Montgomerie, was appointed by Stamford Raffles to help plan the growing city of Singapore, and later on also planned the city of Rangoon.

Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and I witnessed the exchange of diplomatic notes on visa exemption between our two countries. From December, Singaporeans and Myanmars will no longer need visas to visit each other’s countries, for up to 30 days. 

Hope this encourages more travel and business between our peoples! - LHL

(PMO Video by Alex Qiu)

Just arrived in Myanmar’s capital, Nay Pyi Taw, for an official visit at the invitation of President U Htin Kyaw.

Will be meeting Myanmar leaders over the next few days and visiting the Singapore-Myanmar Vocational Training Institute (SMVTI) in Yangon. Look forward to meeting President U Htin Kyaw and State Counsellor Daw Aung San Suu Kyi today. Also hope to catch up with the Singaporean community in Myanmar and share more photos! :) – LHL
 
(MCI Photo by Chwee)

Had dinner with attendees of the International Monetary Conference (IMC) last night. The IMC is a forum for the chairmen and CEOs of major financial institutions to meet and exchange ideas. 

We discussed what opportunities lay ahead for Singapore. One key advantage we have is our location and accessibility within Asia, one of the most vibrant parts of the world. But with many others in the region coming up quickly, we must stay on our toes to stay ahead. 

Singaporeans have a per capita GDP of about S$80,000 - one of the highest in the world. But this doesn’t mean we’ve reached nirvana. We strive to keep on growing and upgrading, so that we can create better jobs and a better future for ourselves. - LHL
 
(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

Swiss voters strongly rejected a proposal to introduce a Universal Basic Income (UBI) in a referendum yesterday (bit.ly/1O9HeTh). 77% of voters said no to paying an unconditional income to all Swiss nationals and legal residents, whether working or unemployed.

The Swiss vote has revived discussion about UBI. Countries are worried about income inequality and structural unemployment, and are casting around for fresh solutions. UBI seems a simple and ideal idea. But in reality it would have drastic impact on taxes, public expenditure and working attitudes.

FT columnist and economist John Kay’s recent commentary explains why a UBI would not work. - LHL

Some highlights of my visit to Geylang Serai for the Hari Raya light-up and bazaar. - LHL

Tomorrow the fasting month begins. Wishing all Muslims a blessed Ramadan!

Gembira dapat merasmikan penyalaan hiasan lampu Hari Raya Aidilfitri bersama penduduk dan pengunjung Geylang Serai malam tadi. Kali terakhir saya merasmikan acara ini ialah 12 tahun lalu!
