The annual Asia Security Summit, aka The Shangri-La Dialogue, is currently taking place (at the Shangri-La Hotel of course). Defence ministers and senior military officials have flown in from all over the Asia-Pacific region and beyond to meet and discuss defence and security issues. Organised by the International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS), Singapore has hosted it since it began in 2002. 

The Dialogue kicked off with Thai PM Prayut’s keynote address yesterday. Many more discussions are planned during this weekend. 

The Dialogue is also a good occasion to catch up with our international friends and partners. I have met quite a few who are here for the forum. This weekend will be a busy and fruitful one for all of us. - LHL

I meet Thai PM Prayut Chan-o-cha often, but usually at international meetings. He was last here for his introductory visit a year ago (bit.ly/1PrEqRJ). He graciously accepted my invite to speak at this year’s Shangri-La Dialogue, and I was glad to host him for tea before the event yesterday.

Thailand is an important neighbour. Many Singaporeans visit Thailand – Bangkok for shopping, Phuket and Chiangmai for holidays. We enjoy warm people-to-people ties, and close economic and security cooperation. 

Strong partnership between countries is precisely what PM Prayut called for in his keynote address last night. No country can overcome its challenges alone. Only through interdependence and mutual security can we all progress together. - LHL

(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

Had lively and open discussions at the Group of Thirty (G30) dinner last night. 

The G30 is a consultative group on international economic and monetary affairs that comprised of leaders of the global finance industry and academics. DPM Tharman Shanmugaratnam is a member and it was his turn to host the meeting. Tharman invited me, so as usual I had to sing for my supper. :)

After my dialogue we turned to lighter fare. Loh Jun Hong and Jonathan Shin from More than Music entertained us with music and storytelling, including this beautiful rendition of Elgar’s Salut d’amour. They had to sing for their supper too! :)

- LHL

(PMO video by Alex Qiu and Chiez How)

Ho Ching and I went to the Singapore Botanic Gardens last Sunday for our evening #jalanjalan. We caught a bit of the concert by The People's Association Youth Chinese Orchestra, who were performing for the Garden’s Heritage Week celebrations. 

There will be two more concerts this weekend: one by the Singapore Lyric Opera on Saturday, and another featuring Singapore artists on Sunday. An enjoyable way to spend the weekend, weather permitting. :)

There are many other things you can do – take a guided Heritage tour, visit the Garden’s Heritage Museum, and enjoy free entry to the National Orchid Garden. You can find out more about Heritage Week at http://bit.ly/27FS0ad. - LHL

Have accepted President Obama's invitation to visit him in Washington DC in August. Singapore has very good relations with the US. I look forward to the visit. It will mark the progress we have made, especially with this Administration. It will also be a chance to see how we can build on our friendship beyond the November US elections. - LHL

I talked about developing Mandai as a nature and wildlife destination before (on.fb.me/1PLQjhT). Today, Mandai Safari Park Holdings announced more details. The project will include two new wildlife parks (a new Bird Park and a Rainforest Park), a nature-themed education centre, and more public spaces for everyone to enjoy. 
 
The new Bird Park will house one of the world's largest collections of birds. Nine aviaries will feature different habitats including wetlands, bamboo forests, and rainforests. There will be a breeding and research facility for endangered species. 

The Rainforest Park will have walkways for visitors to explore its multiple levels from the forest floor to the treetop canopies.
 
Together with the existing Zoo, Night Safari and River Safari, the new parks, waterways and playgrounds will make Mandai an ideal destination for animal and nature lovers young and old. Happy to see the plans for Mandai taking shape! - LHL
 
(Artist's impression of the new Rainforest Park./ Picture courtesy of Mandai Safari Park Holdings)

Visited Heng Swee Keat in the TTSH Neuro ICU at NNI this evening. Delighted to find him recovering well, and making steady progress. He was fully lucid, communicative, and cheerful.

The doctors are happy too. But they have advised Swee Keat not to receive visitors yet, so that he can get as much rest as possible.

I told him we had made arrangements to look after his residents in Tampines while he recuperates. He gave me two thumbs up. :) 

Swee Keat wants to thank everyone for their support. He especially sends his greetings and best wishes to his Tampines residents and volunteers, who have been asking after him. - LHL

I enjoy doing #guesswhere photos, but Joel Chia takes it to the next level. Also known as Idroneman, he uses drones to take stunning aerial photos of Singapore.

His subjects are varied: schools, the beach and even the PSA container terminal. He shows us Singapore from a different perspective that many of us rarely consider. Happy to see that we have such creative talent. Gives me a few new ideas! :) - LHL

The June school holidays have begun! We have many beautiful parks and beaches, and the holidays will be a great time to head outdoors for some family fun.

This June, why not bring your family to Pulau Ubin? I visited it on Ubin Day in 2014, and took some photos (including this one) while cycling round the island. Since then, Ubin Day has expanded into a 5-week open house, and renamed Pesta Ubin. Families can join free guided walks around the island and even learn fly fishing. 

Happy holidays to our students and teachers! – LHL

(The old Ketam Quarry at Pulau Ubin. / Photo by me)

Singapore and Cuba have long-standing ties, so I was happy to host Cuban Vice-President Marino Alberto Murillo Jorge yesterday. He is here on an S R Nathan Fellowship.

Mr Murillo is in charge of Cuba's economic restructuring, transforming its centrally planned economy into a competitive market economy. He is interested in how Singapore has grown and prospered, and how we manage our government linked companies. But as he told me, each country is different, and Cuba has to find its own way forward. 

We pick up ideas from others wherever we can, and we happily share our own experience with others who find us interesting. We are all learning from one another. :) - LHL
 
(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

The weather has been stormy these few days, with heavy showers and lightning storms. I hope you've been staying dry! Singapore is a lightning capital of the world, but few photos have captured it as strikingly :) as this composite by Darren Soh | Photographer. 

You can see from his photos that Darren has a knack for making the everyday extraordinary.  He shows Singapore’s urban landscape in a fresh light. Have a look when you get the chance. Nicely done, Darren! – LHL

Enjoyed a #jalanjalan along Jurong Lake Park before my trip to Russia. The lake was scenic and tranquil, with many joggers, anglers and nature-lovers. 

Jurong has quite a history. Once a freshwater swamp forest, it was cleared to build an industrial estate in the 1960s and 1970s. 

Today, we are redeveloping Jurong to make it a greener, more inviting place for families to enjoy. I mentioned some plans in my 2014 National Day Rally — the new Jurong Lake District, a new Science Centre, more community spaces, and the High Speed Rail terminal. 

When all these are ready, the Jurong Lake District will become a great place to live, work and play — no passport required. :)  – LHL

Arrived home this morning from a fruitful trip to Moscow and Sochi. It allowed me to reacquaint myself with Russia and give our ties a boost.

The ASEAN-Russia Commemorative Summit in Sochi showed goodwill on both sides, and a shared desire to do more together.

I welcomed President Putin’s proposal for ASEAN, the Eurasian Economic Union (EAEU) and the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) to explore the possibility of a partnership. Singapore is exploring our own bilateral SG-EAEU FTA, and we also encourage Russia to engage other ASEAN states individually.

Step by step, this will foster economic partnership, peace, stability and growth in all our countries and the region. – LHL
 
#ASEANRussia20 #РоссияАСЕАН20

Found out that Presiden Joko Widodo and I were staying on the same floor in our hotel in Sochi, so I asked to drop by for a quick catch up. We had a good 4-eye meeting for 30 minutes before the Summit started. 

We talked about the terrorism threat, and how our agencies are cooperating to fight it together.

President Jokowi described his efforts to improve the business environment in Indonesia, including in the Batam, Bintan and Karimun region. I said that we valued our economic ties with Indonesia, and our investors appreciated the Indonesian government’s support for their projects. 

We looked forward to our next retreat later this year. Indonesia will be hosting, and we are hoping to visit Kendal, near Semarang in Central Java, where Sembcorp has a joint venture to develop a big industrial park. 

- LHL

It's good to be home, and in time for Vesak Day! On this day, Buddhist devotees commemorate the birth, enlightenment and nirvana of Siddharta Gautama Shakyamuni Buddha. 

Wishing all Buddhists a happy and peaceful Vesak Day weekend! – LHL

Arrived in Sochi yesterday for the ASEAN-Russia Commemorative Summit.

Had a good meeting with President Владимир Путин (Vladimir Putin), who is hosting the event. We welcomed the progress made by the High-level Russia-Singapore Intergovernmental Commission (IGC). Am also happy that President Putin expressed his support for an FTA between Singapore and the EAEU.

Look forward to more fruitful discussions with him and the ASEAN leaders at the Summit. – LHL

Had productive discussions with PM Дмитрий Медведев (Dmitry Medvedev) today. We took stock of our good relations and discussed how to do more together.

My father believed that Russia would play a major role in world affairs. He first visited in 1970 and eventually came more than five times. Even after he retired as PM, he kept the links up. He served on the board of the SKOLKOVO - Moscow School of Management. He also was a keen supporter of the Russia-Singapore Business Forum.

So I am very happy to continue building on our good relations. Our trade has almost quadrupled in the last ten years. But in absolute size, it is still not huge. 

That is why Singapore signed an MOU with the Eurasian Economic Commission (EEC) yesterday. I hope this will pave the way for an FTA between Singapore and the region. 

Beyond trade, today we signed two MOUs: one between the Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth - MCCY and the Russian Ministry of Culture, and the other between Nanyang Technological University, Singapore and the Russian Academy of Sciences.

We should work at our cooperation, and have something to show by our 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations in 2018! – LHL

(ST Photo © Singapore Press Holdings. Reproduced with permission.)

Some highlights of my first two days in Moscow. Photos of my visit can be viewed here: http://bit.ly/1U0Lpji - LHL

(PMO Video by Chiez How)

A busy day in Moscow. Very pleased that we have signed an MOU to deepen interaction with the Eurasian Economic Commission, which oversees the economic union of five countries - Armenia, Belarus, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, and Russia. This will help us learn about each other, find new areas for cooperation, and hopefully lead eventually to a Free Trade Agreement with them.

Also met the Mayor of Moscow, Sergey Sobyanin, who has ambitious plans for the city. We discussed business and investment opportunities in Moscow and how Singapore firms can participate more in this.

At lunch and dinner I was hosted by two old Russian friends of Mr Lee Kuan Yew. Learnt much about developments in the region from my fellow Russian guests. – LHL

Spent a good first day in Moscow. Caught up with the small but growing Singaporean community and some exchange students in Moscow. Also met the Singapore Business Federation delegation as well as senior representatives of Singapore companies in Russia.

This is not my first visit to Russia. My last visits were to St. Petersburg for the 2013 G20 Summit (bit.ly/1TmgoaO) and to Vladivostok for the 2012 APEC Summit (bit.ly/1rSx0fY). But my last time in Moscow was on honeymoon in 1978! So it was good to return and see the vast changes since then, and how some things, like the Moscow Kremlin, remain unchanged.

Ahead of my visit, I was interviewed by the Russian News Agency TASS. I spoke about the ASEAN-Russia Summit in Sochi, Singapore-Russia relations, religious and racial harmony in Singapore, among other topics. You can view the full transcript in English here: www.bit.ly/27x8rWp 

– LHL

Just arrived in Moscow (or Москва in Russian) for a working visit. Look forward to meeting PM Medvedev, government officials and Russian business executives before heading to Sochi (a Black Sea resort city) on Thursday for the ASEAN-Russia Summit. More photos to come! :) – LHL

How has Singapore managed to stay clean and incorrupt? PM David Cameron asked me to contribute an essay on Singapore’s experience, for a book launched at the Anti-Corruption Summit last week in London. SMS Indranee Rajah attended the Summit, with support from CPIB, MINLAW and MFA officers.

My essay cited specific stories and events in our long and continuing fight against corruption. For it is easy to list good principles and policies, but much harder to make them a reality. Our success owes much to past and present Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau, Singapore officers, as well as officers from the Attorney-General's Chambers, Home Team and other agencies. 

Read my essay by clicking on the photo and link below. – LHL

Spent the afternoon watching Jack Neo’s Long Long Time Ago 2 (我们的故事2) with grassroots leaders from Ang Mo Kio. The movie takes us back to our early years of nationhood. It showed how tough life was in the kampungs, but also how wrenching it was for people to leave their familiar kampungs to resettle into HDB estates. But because of their hard work, and their willingness to change, we built today’s Singapore.

“Nation building” sounds abstract and straightforward. But actually it was made up of the joys and sorrows, the blood, sweat and tears of so many individual families. Jack Neo told the story well - I am sure I was not the only one to tear up during the show. 

My thanks to the cast and crew. They have captured a treasured part of our people’s history. Do catch it if you have time. :) - LHL

我们都有自己的故事。今天下午与宏茂桥的基层领袖一起看了梁智强导演的<<我们的故事2>>。这部电影把早期新加坡甘榜里艰苦但充满人情味的生活描述的栩栩如生，演员们也很用心的演出，把我们带入了剧情，一起欢笑，也被他们感动而流泪。要了解新加坡建国时代，人民是怎么从甘榜迁居到政府组屋的过程，不妨看一看这部动人又幽默的电影。- 李显龙

Went to The People's Association (PA) Headquarters yesterday for a board meeting, and to meet grassroots leaders.

The PA Headquarters at King George’s Avenue occupies a historic site. Many Singaporeans have fond memories of this place - it was home to Victoria School (1933 - 1984) and Christ Church Secondary School (1985 - 2001), and the venue for many community activities and mass rehearsals. When PA moved here in 2009, the original facade was conserved and restored. 

It is a fitting home for the PA, whose mission is to foster a more caring and cohesive community. My thanks to all PA members and supporters for working tirelessly to make Singapore a better home for all. - LHL

Here's the team that responded to the emergency at the Cabinet room on Thursday. Thanks to all in SCDF and the Home Team for your hard work every day to look after Singaporeans and protect Singapore.- LHL

Saw firsthand how the Singapore Civil Defence Force responded to our emergency at the Cabinet room on Thursday, and was deeply impressed. Wrote to Commissioner Eric Yap to thank the ambulance team and all who helped. They were competent and confident, a credit to the SCDF, the life saving force. – LHL

Visited Heng Swee Keat at the ICU in Tan Tock Seng Hospital this evening. He was sedated. His condition is stable, but he will remain in the ICU for some time. He is in very good hands, like all patients at the National Neuroscience Institute (NNI). 

I also spoke with Swee Keat’s family. It is a tough time for them. They are touched by the sympathy and support from so many Singaporeans, and asked me to thank everyone for their prayers and good wishes. We all hope Swee Keat will have a full and smooth recovery. – LHL

We were having our weekly Cabinet meeting just now when Heng Swee Keat suddenly collapsed. The doctors in Cabinet (we had three present) attended to him immediately. We called an ambulance, which took him to TTSH. A CT scan showed that he had had a stroke. Doctors are attending to him now. Hope Swee Keat will be alright - he is a valuable member of my team. - LHL

Mr Heng Swee Keat had a sudden stroke due to an aneurysm, which is a localised weakening of a blood vessel. He underwent initial neurosurgery to relieve pressure in his brain due to the bleeding. The aneurysm was successfully closed.

Mr Heng will remain under close monitoring in the intensive care unit of Tan Tock Seng Hospital.

Met more than 100 Ambassadors, High Commissioners, Honorary Consuls-General and their spouses at President Dr Tony Tan's Annual Diplomatic Reception yesterday. It was nice to see all their national costumes too!

These ambassadors are our valued friends. They are our links to their home countries and help us build relationships with their countrymen. The annual reception is a good opportunity to thank them for their counsel and good work. - LHL

Attended Dr Lee Seng Gee’s wake today. 

There have been many successful businessmen in Singapore. But very few like Dr Lee, who was even more successful as a philanthropist. He was a rare, selfless and humble individual, who led Lee Foundation to become the largest private charitable foundation in Singapore, and to support many good causes, regardless of race, language and religion. 

The Lee Foundation has transformed countless lives and benefitted many institutions including the National Library, and academic institutions like NAFA, SMU, NUS and NTU. Dr Lee’s life reminds us that success is defined not by your wealth, but by your contributions to the community.

We encourage businesses and individuals to give back to society, and make a difference to others. Dr Lee’s life sets an example to us all.

My thoughts are with his family during this time of grief. – LHL

Families and friends are often the ones offering us quiet support while we pursue careers or personal goals. They are the reason why we strive so hard and our biggest cheerleaders when we succeed. 

Glad Murali Pillai’s family (and volunteers) were present in the Strangers’ Gallery to share and witness his swearing-in as MP yesterday. Once again, congratulations to Murali! Look forward to seeing him realise plans for #BukitBatok and hearing him speak up for his constituents in Parliament. - LHL

We must keep fit to stay healthy. Even better if the whole family works out together. So I was glad to see many AMK-Hougang families at the newly renovated Ci Yuan Sports Park and Family Sports Carnival yesterday. 

Ci Yuan Sports Park has many new facilities, including three-generational fitness equipment where families can exercise together. There are also beach volleyball and pétanque courts, a jogging track as well as a children's playground. 

Hope that residents will take the time to enjoy the facilities and keep up a healthy and active lifestyle. – LHL

Happy Mother’s Day to all mums and mums-to-be!

Joined Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨 and Yio Chu Kang residents old and young at their Mother’s Day Celebration yesterday. Kids from PCF Kindergarten, My First Skool, and Jamiyah Kindergarten performed songs and dances dedicated to their mothers. 世上只有妈妈好. Mothers are our pillars of strength, our inspirational role models, and our biggest supporters. Take time today, and everyday, to show your mum how much you love her. To fathers: don’t worry, our turn will come soon! :) – LHL

Congratulations to Murali Pillai on his win! Thank you, Bukit Batok voters, for your strong support. You have chosen an MP who is committed, trustworthy, and will go the extra mile for you. 

Murali and his team have campaigned hard, but now their real work begins. He has served faithfully in Bukit Batok for many years, and with your support, will serve residents for many more.

Congratulations to our swimmers Yip Pin Xiu and Theresa Goh, for breaking records at the International Paralympic Committee Swimming European Open Championships in Funchal, Portugal!

Spoke at the May Day Rally this morning. 

This year we are celebrating May Day in a cautious mood. With the global economy slowing down, many workers are worried and anxious. This is an issue in Singapore too, with retrenchment a reality for some. We are watching this closely, and have measures to help workers retrain and find new jobs. 

One scheme is the Career Support Programme (CSP), proposed by Minister Lim Swee Say. The CSP provides wage support for a year, to defray hiring costs and encourage employers to try hiring PMETs who have been retrenched mid-career, and hopefully employ them longer-term. 

Another measure is to help our workers upgrade and uplift themselves. Secretary General Chan Chun Sing told me NTUC intends to raise $50 million to partner universities to teach new skills to mid-career workers, including PMETs. I told him if he can raise $50 million, the government will write the cheque for another $150 million, for a total of $200 million in the NTUC-Education and Training Fund. NTUC will start by partnering with NTU, with more universities later down the road.  

In these are times of rapid change, we must take our challenges seriously, but we should have confidence. The Government and Labour Movement are ready, and with the people’s support for our programmes, we can emerge stronger than before. 

Click here to view my May Day Rally Speech: http://bit.ly/1W0F8aW – LHL

In government, good policy and good politics cannot be separated neatly and absolutely. The Singapore system needs both to work. Our political leaders and senior civil servants play different roles, but they must share the same fundamental values and ideals — like meritocracy, multi-racialism and clean government — and the same major premises about Singapore.

Our politics and policies have worked constructively together to bring us to SG50. We have to keep this virtuous circle going so that political leaders and the civil service can work hand in hand to lead Singapore forward.

I spoke on this at yesterday’s Administrative Service dinner and promotion ceremony. I trust the Admin Officers will serve with commitment and integrity, and make a difference to Singapore and our citizens.

Some highlights of what I did in Israel over the past 4 days. - LHL

(PMO Video by Alex Qiu)

Called on former President Shimon Peres, an Israeli statesman. He has served his country all his life. As Foreign Minister, he played a key role negotiating the 1993 Oslo Accords, signed by PM Yitzhak Rabin and PLO leader Yasser Arafat, which led to the creation of the Palestine Authority. For this, all three won the Nobel Peace Prize. Now 92, Mr Peres is still actively working with his organisation, the Peres Center for Peace, promoting peace in the region.

Yitzhak Rabin was assassinated in 1995, and I stopped by Rabin Square in Tel Aviv to pay tribute to him. He, too, was a great leader. The Oslo Accords were a key step towards a two-state solution, and I hope more progress will be made soon.

Met current Israeli president Reuven Rivlin too. He was a warm host, and showed me my father’s two volumes of memoirs in his private library. 

Am on the way to the airport now. It has been a productive trip but am looking forward to going home. – LHL

Short clip on my visit to Ramallah, which included a visit to the Arafat Mausoleum. - LHL

(PMO Video by Alex Qiu)

Palestinians revere Mr Yasser Arafat, their first President, as the founder of the Palestinian movement. So when I visited the Palestinian Territories yesterday I paid my respects and laid a wreath at the Arafat Mausoleum.

I also called on Prime Minister Rami Hamdallah, who hosted me to lunch. We value our friendship with the Palestinians, and want to see them living at peace with Israel. I encouraged them to resume negotiations towards a two-state solution. 

One modest way we can help the Palestinians  is through technical assistance. This is why we are doubling our Enhanced Technical Assistance Package from S$5 million to S$10 million.

Earlier, I visited Temple Mount  in the Old City of Jerusalem. The site holds special significance for many — it is a holy site for Islam, Judaism, and Christianity. I was honoured to have the chance to visit a place which means so much to so many, and to see the Dome of the Rock and Al-Aqsa Mosque up close. – LHL

DPM Teo Chee Hean (who is Acting PM as I am away) has advised the President to issue the Writ of Election for Bukit Batok constituency. Nomination Day will be 27 April (Wednesday) and Polling Day 7 May (Saturday). Details here: http://bit.ly/23ZgJUj

DPM Teo and I spoke earlier. Now that the Budget is out of the way, we are calling this by-election to enable residents of Bukit Batok to have their own MP as we work together to improve Singaporeans’ lives.

Partnership between Government and citizens is key to our success. I hope Bukit Batok residents will elect the candidate who will be concerned for their welfare, represent them ably in Parliament, and make Bukit Batok the best home for them. – LHL

Was deeply moved by my visit to the Yad Vashem Holocaust Museum in Jerusalem yesterday. 

"Never again!" This declaration refers to Hitler’s murder of six million Jews during WW2. But taken more widely, it is a goal mankind has yet to realise in full measure.

Since the Holocaust, other massacres and genocides have happened. Mankind is capable of terrible violence. We must come together to prevent more, regardless of race or religion. 

Earlier, I called on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu - בנימין נתניהו. Our two countries have a longstanding relationship. When Singapore unexpectedly became independent in 1965, the Israeli Defence Forces helped us to build the SAF from scratch. For that, we will always be grateful. 

PM Netanyahu and I discussed many areas of cooperation, from innovation and R&D, to cyber-security and countering terrorism. At the same time, Singapore is concerned about the Middle East Peace Process, like many other countries. 

I encouraged Israel to resume direct negotiations with the Palestinians to reach a just and lasting two-state solution. We are friends with both Israel and Palestine, and hope to see them living in peace together. - LHL

Crossed from Jordan over to Israel yesterday. Before I left, I had breakfast with Prince Ghazi, the cousin of King Abdullah. He is the King’s Chief Advisor for Religious and Cultural Affairs and Personal Envoy, and like the King a firm believer in inter-faith dialogue and harmony. 

Next, I visited Al Maghtas, the site by the Jordan River where Jesus was baptised by John the Baptist. Then we crossed the King Hussein/Allenby bridge into the West Bank. 

Like us, Israel believes strongly in research and technology to improve lives. So it was an honour to receive the Doctorate Philosophiae Honoris Causa from Hebrew University. Also witnessed the signing of 3 MOUs between Hebrew University and Singapore institutions NRF, NUS and NTU. 

Ended the day with a tour of the Old City in Jerusalem. It is a fascinating place. Once seen as the centre of the world, it has holy sites sacred to the three Abrahamic faiths — the Dome of the Rock and Al-Aqsa Mosque for Muslims, the Western Wall and Temple Mount for Jews, and the Church of the Holy Sepulchre for Christians. – LHL

Highlights from my visit to Jordan. Photos here: http://bit.ly/1qAw0vZ

(PMO Video by Alex Qiu)

Met Singaporeans living in Jordan on Saturday evening. Many are students here for religious and language studies. I was happy to learn that they are doing well and enjoying their time here. 

Jordan has been a good friend to us from the beginning. It co-sponsored our membership in the UN in 1965. Our two nations share a mutual interest in fighting terrorism, including ISIS. 
 
Earlier, I visited Petra, “a rose red city half as old as time”. It is a fascinating place to explore, with lots of natural beauty, culture and history. It was built two thousand years ago, yet still holds lessons for us. An ancient people, the Nabataeans, built a thriving trade hub here. 

The Nabateans adapted to the harsh desert environment through astonishing engineering feats, building aqueducts and water systems to channel and store precious rainwater. Two millennia later, we in Singapore still need to conserve water, and use technology to meet our water needs. 

– LHL

Arrived in Amman yesterday evening. On the first leg of my Middle East trip — Jordan, Israel, and the Palestine Authority. 

Looking forward to the visit. We have warm and friendly ties with all three. King Abdullah of Jordan has visited Singapore often — 12 times since he became King!

Off to an early start today, to visit Petra. Will update with more photos! :) - LHL

At the Committee of Supply (COS) debate for PMO yesterday, Josephine Teo spoke about the importance of valuing and celebrating parenthood as a society. One point she made struck me: quite apart from financial incentives and practical considerations, a country’s Total Fertility Rate (TFR) depends also on historical and social factors, which are often not well understood. 

She gave the example of France, which has a TFR of 2.0 — one of the highest among developed countries. France has good social policies to support and encourage parenthood. But when Josephine visited France to study their experience, all the people she met gave one more explanation: "1945". France lost so many of its citizens in the Second World War (600,000 dead) that after the War ended in 1945, there was a strong desire - a national psyche - to repopulate the nation.

The TFR is a statistic, but it is made up of countless individual stories. I was reminded of the late Congressman Tom Lantos whom I met years ago. He was a Hungarian Jew and Holocaust survivor. He lost most of his family in the concentration camps. After the War, he emigrated to the US and became a Congressman. He had two daughters and 18 grandchildren. His daughters decided to give him as many grandchildren as they could, to make up for the family members killed.

Singapore is fortunate not to have experienced such calamities. Our TFR was 1.25 last year. We should do all we can to encourage couples to have more kids. Hence the enhancements to paternity leave, shared parental leave, and adoption leave that Josephine announced. They come into effect next year, so if you are thinking of having a baby (or another baby), now is the time to start trying! :) - LHL

Was happy to meet Norwegian Prime Minister Erna Solberg today. 

Norway and Singapore enjoy good economic relations, especially in the maritime sector. Our ties go back more than a century. Norway established an honorary consulate here in 1906, soon after it became independent. As PM Solberg told me, the right to establish its own consulates overseas was the final issue which led Norway to dissolve its union with Sweden in 1905 and become an independent country. 

During her visit, PM Solberg spoke at the 6th Norway-Asia Business Summit, and gave a public lecture at The International Institute for Strategic Studies Asia (IISS Asia) – Fullerton Lecture Series.

I thanked PM Solberg for Norway’s strong support for Singapore’s participation as an observer in the Arctic Council. 

Look forward to enhancing the close and longstanding friendship between our countries. – LHL

The hot spell has caused water levels in Linggiu Reservoir to fall to a historic low. This reservoir in Johor supplies half our water needs. Last August, I posted about how the reservoir was only half full (bit.ly/1YrvKKF). Now it is just over one third full.

Minister Masagos Zulkifli described how this has affected the reliability of our water supply from Johor in the Committee of Supply (COS) in Parliament today. We have been able to mitigate this using our other National Taps, but we must continue to diversify our water sources. Climate change will bring more extreme weather patterns, e.g. more prolonged and severe droughts. We are building another NEWater factory by 2016 and two more desalination plants by 2019. PUB is also looking at a fifth desalination plant on Jurong Island.

Water has always been and will always be a strategic issue for Singapore, which is why I watch the water levels very closely. We must continue to conserve and make the most of this precious resource. You can do your part by not wasting water, recycling what you can, and always using it wisely. – LHL

I enjoy Xinyao (新谣) songs like 细水长流 and 小人物的心声, but I did not know much about the history of the Xinyao movement. So when I heard about the movie 我们唱着的歌 The Songs We Sang, I decided to go.

Ho Ching and I watched the movie yesterday. It told the story of Xinyao, how it began with student groups in the old Nantah composing 诗乐 (poems to music) in the late 1970s, then became popular with JC students who were bilingual, and now has caught on with a new generation, and even beyond our shores in Taiwan. 

Xinyao's history is tied up with the changes in our society and education system, and the difficult time which that generation of Chinese-speaking Singaporeans had, in schools and at work, adjusting to the new economy using English as the working language. 

I found the movie moving and powerful. And I got a surprise bonus — in one scene I found my old Chinese teacher 黄伟光老师 teaching a class in Catholic High School! 

Afterwards, I chatted with director Eva Tang and part of her team who made the movie, to congratulate them and tell them how much we enjoyed it. 

The movie is still on at Golden Village, Plaza Singapura. Watch it soon if you can! 
 
– LHL

昨天我和何晶看了《我们唱着的歌》，才知道原来“新谣”是“新加坡年轻人自创歌谣”的简称。虽然常听到“细水长流”和“小人物的心声”，但是对新谣的历史和时代背景不是很熟悉。邓宝翠导演把新谣的点点滴滴整理成一部富有感情，很有意义的记录片。

看了之后，深受感动，也感受到到新谣和新加坡创作忠实支持者的热忱和爱心。相信跟新谣一起成长的人看了都会回想当年，回味无穷。宝翠和她的工作团队花了两年的时间制作这部片子。如果你想多认识新谣，请不要错过! - 李显龙

I am deeply saddened by my sister Dr Lee Wei Ling’s claim that I have abused my power to commemorate the one-year anniversary of Mr Lee Kuan Yew’s passing in order to establish a dynasty. The accusations are completely untrue.

The first anniversary of a person’s passing is a significant moment to remember him and reflect on what he meant to us. The more so with Mr Lee Kuan Yew. The Cabinet had discussed how we should mark the occasion. My advice was that we should leave it to ground-up efforts. Groups should keep their observances in proportion, and focussed on the future.

The Cabinet recognised the strong desire of many Singaporeans to show their respect for Mr Lee, and honour what he did for us. We reviewed the events and observances that different groups had planned, and agreed that they were generally appropriate. They expressed the sincerely felt sentiments of Singaporeans, which my Cabinet colleagues and I deeply appreciate.

The idea that I should wish to establish a dynasty makes even less sense. Meritocracy is a fundamental value of our society, and neither I, the PAP, nor the Singapore public would tolerate any such attempt.

- LHL

Attended the final Nuclear Security Summit yesterday. 

The NSS was created to address the threat of nuclear terrorism. Singapore has no nuclear materials or facilities. But we take our responsibilities seriously, and contribute to the international effort. As a global transhipment hub, we do our part to combat illicit trafficking of nuclear materials through Singapore. 

Nuclear terrorism may not be the most imminent threat today, or the most urgent. But it can easily become an awful reality unless countries act effectively against it in good time. I hope the international community will continue to work closely to fight nuclear terrorism. 

Heading to airport soon. Looking forward to going home. :)  – LHL

Terrorism has taken many lives, and we must remain resolute in countering it.

Today, I visited the National September 11 Memorial & Museum, built in remembrance of the nearly 3000 people who lost their lives in the terror attacks on 11 September 2001 (at the World Trade Center; near Shanksville, Pennsylvania; and at the Pentagon) and in the earlier World Trade Center bombing on 26 February 1993.

I had just conveyed our deepest condolences to the people of Pakistan and the victims of the brutal terrorist attack on Easter Sunday. It was especially heartrending that many victims were women and children. It is yet another reminder of the need for continued vigilance against terrorism. – LHL

I always look forward to meeting Singaporeans when I visit a city, as it is a good opportunity to find out how they are doing. So I was happy to meet 300 Singaporeans – students, working professionals and families – at our UN mission in NYC today. Happy to see many of them doing well. It shows how old disused places can be preserved and given a new breath of life, and gives us many ideas for our Rail Corridor.

Starting right means starting young. When I was in Secondary 4, aged 15, I attended the Outward Bound Singapore ( OBS ) course on Pulau Ubin. For 17 days my coursemates and I were stretched to our limits, learnt to work together, and mastered new skills like crossing this rope bridge. It was a significant growing up experience for me. 

Nowadays, OBS courses are shorter. But they continue to help young people to build confidence, resilience, and teamwork, skills and attitudes critical if Singapore is to thrive and prosper.

That is why Heng Swee Keat's #SGBudget2016 speech yesterday included building a new OBS campus on Coney Island, so more youths can benefit from an Outward Bound experience. 

The Budget also had other items to help our young grow up to be the best they can be:

We will make First Step grants ($3,000) into the Child Development Account of each eligible Singaporean child, to help pay for their healthcare and childcare. 

A new initiative, called KidSTART, will give children whose parents need more support a good start in life. 

We will also help families with young children living in rental housing own a home again, under the Fresh Start Housing Scheme. 

More details at bit.ly/1MFT7tY

You can view Swee Keat’s full speech here: http://bit.ly/1VLZfrH 

- LHL

Sorry to learn of the passing of Cikgu Muhammad Ariff Ahmad. He was a giant in the Malay literary world. Cikgu had a deep passion for and proficiency in the Malay language. His views were well sought after, including by the late Mr Zubir Said, in crafting the lyrics of Majulah Singapura.

Cikgu founded Angkatan Sasterawan ’50 (Asas ’50) to nurture interest in Malay literature, in Singapore and the region. He received numerous awards, including the Cultural Medallion for Literature in 1987 and the Long Service Medal in 1989.

We are grateful to Cikgu Ariff for his contributions to Singapore and the Malay/Muslim community. My deepest condolences to his family. - LHL
 
Saya dukacita mendapat tahu tentang pemergian Haji Muhammad Ariff Ahmad. Sebagai tokoh persuratan dan budaya Melayu yang amat disegani, cinta Cikgu Ariff kepada bahasa, seni dan budaya Melayu cukup terserlah dan pengetahuannya, mendalam. Yesterday, I joined Parliamentarians, Cabinet colleagues and my father’s previous constituents to mark the one-year anniversary of his passing.

In the morning we held a ceremony in the Chamber of the old Parliament House, It was attended by past and current MPs, as well as former Parliament staff. It was a simple and moving observance.

In the afternoon, the Cabinet observed a minute of silence before we began our weekly meeting. I spoke briefly about Mr Lee Kuan Yew and what it was like to be in his Cabinet. You can watch my remarks here: youtu.be/q4n3ou0KSZ8

In the evening, I visited Tanjong Pagar, my father’s constituency for 60 years. The residents had held a remembrance ceremony for him. I was happy to meet many of them, and to see the impact he had left on their lives. 

Thank you to everyone for making the day a meaningful one. – LHL

The shocking terrorist attacks in Brussels today remind us yet again of the serious and continuing threat of terrorism. 

I have written to the Belgian Prime Minister, Charles Michel, to express our condolences and sympathies to the families of the victims, and to the Belgian people.

Minister K Shanmugam Sc had just spoken last week about tightening up counter-terrorism measures in Singapore. We face a severe threat in Southeast Asia. It is not a matter of if, but when, that an attack will take place here. Indeed, today’s attacks in Brussels happened even though the Belgians were on full alert. 

I hear that recently on a double decker bus, the driver stopped the bus, pointed at a bag left near the entrance and asked whose it was. The tension was palpable as he went round the second deck to try to identify the owner (whom he found). He then explained that we have to be vigilant about bags lying around, because of possible terrorist attacks, and the passengers murmured their assent. So the message is getting through to Singaporeans. - LHL

Saddened to learn about the deaths of two SMRT trainees today. My deepest condolences to their families. 

We understand that faults and malfunctions do happen in our train system, and generally take them in our stride. But it is different when two young men lose their lives in a workplace accident. 

SMRT is working with the police to investigate the matter, to find out how the accident occurred. Whether it turns out to be an unforeseeable mishap, an individual lapse or a system problem, we must do our best to ensure this does not happen again. - LHL

Deeply saddened by the passing of Mr Lee Khoon Choy, a member of the PAP Old Guard, at the ripe old age of 92.

Khoon Choy, whom we all knew as “KC”,  started off as a journalist with Nanyang Siang Pau in the 1950s. Mr S Rajaratnam recruited him to join the PAP. KC fought in the 1959 elections and won, thus beginning his long career in politics and the Public Service. 
 
Mr Lee Kuan Yew once described KC as a man who “had it” — a man of courage that did not melt under pressure. In the early 1960s when the PAP was battling pro-communist factions in the party, the pro-communists targeted KC. He received a letter with a bullet, a death threat. In 1961, thousands of Chinese school students staged sit-ins. They threw rotten apples at him and shouted, “李炯才, 进棺材 (Lee Khoon Choy, enter the coffin)!” KC did not buckle. He stood with the PAP and was loyal till the end.
 
KC also served as Ambassador and High Commissioner to eight countries. As Ambassador to Indonesia, he played a crucial role in thawing relations between Singapore and Indonesia. Singapore had hanged two Indonesian commandos who bombed MacDonald House in 1965 and killed innocent civilians. KC persuaded Mr Lee Kuan Yew to wear a batik shirt and scatter flowers at the graves of the two men in Jakarta. This conciliatory gesture enabled Mr Lee to establish a relationship with President Suharto. In recognition of his contributions, KC was awarded the Distinguished Service Order in 1990.  

After KC stepped down from public service, he returned to his first love — writing and painting. I was honoured to launch his book “Golden Dragon and Purple Phoenix” in 2013. 

KC believed that “every human being should know his own roots. A tree without roots cannot grow. Human beings are the same.” Indeed, as we remember his life, we remember our roots and what our pioneers like him did, to put Singapore on the path it is today. My deepest condolences to his family and loved ones. – LHL
 
[At the launch of Mr Lee Khoon Choy’s (far right) book “Golden Dragon and Purple Phoenix” in July 2013. / ST Photo © Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Reproduced with permission.]

This afternoon we focused on how to promote an innovative, entrepreneurial ASEAN Economic Community. Singapore welcomes the US initiative to help ASEAN do this, which will complement our individual efforts. 

We have much to learn from American entrepreneurial culture. I personally found my meetings with companies and personalities in Silicon Valley last week useful. Talking to Singaporeans in the Valley, it was clear that they are learning a lot and benefitting from the exposure.

As Singapore's first hospital, Singapore General Hospital has a special place in Singaporeans' hearts. The current campus dates to 1981. With an ageing population and medical science advancing rapidly, it is timely for us to refresh the campus. So I was happy to launch the new Master Plan today, to build a new SGH to serve future generations. 

Amidst the new buildings we will preserve links to the past. The Bowyer block (in pic, with clock tower), built in 1926, will be at the centre of the new campus. It will be an icon to honour those who have given their lives to public healthcare, and to remind us of how SGH has been treating patients for two centuries. 

Revamping the SGH campus will take 20 years of hard work. It is a worthwhile effort to assure Singaporeans of continuing good, affordable healthcare. My thanks to Ministry of Health, SingHealth, SGH and all the partners involved for working tirelessly on the Master Plan. You can watch my speech here: http://bit.ly/1PYfpNW – LHL

Singapore needs good policies and good politics to succeed. Our political system is working now. But we must keep updating it to continue to have a high quality government in the longer term – one that is honest, competent and effective, that is always accountable to the electorate, and that upholds a multi-racial society.

In Parliament today, I announced 3 things we will do to ensure this:

First, we will increase the minimum number of opposition MPs, including Non-Constituency MPs, from 9 to 12 by the next election. We will also give them the same voting rights as MPs. This will in effect aid the opposition, giving their best losers more exposure and possibly building them up for the next round. But I believe this will be good for the government and good for Singapore. No ruling party and government should ever be afraid of open argument. Ultimately, Singapore will benefit from a contest of ideas.

Second, we will further reduce the average size of Group Representation Constituencies, and create more Single Member Constituencies. The GRC scheme ensures that we will always have at least a minimum number of minority race MPs in Parliament. But we have to find the right balance between big and small GRCs, and the right mix of GRCs and SMCs.

Third, we will review the elected President scheme — to keep the eligibility criteria up to date, to strengthen the Council of Presidential Advisors (CPA) which assists and advises the President, and to ensure that minorities have a chance to be elected President.

You can view my full speech here: http://bit.ly/20stbdh

- LHL

The 13th Parliament was sworn in yesterday. In his Address at our 1st session, President Dr Tony Tan cautioned that even though we are in a stronger position today than in 1965, we cannot expect an easy journey ahead. 

In this new term of government, we have five priorities: (1) keep Singapore safe and secure; (2) renew our economy; (3) foster a more caring society; (4) transform our urban landscape; and (5) partner Singaporeans in nation building. 

The government will also study carefully whether and how we should improve our political system, to ensure a clean, effective and accountable government over the long term.

Today is Pongal. I wish all Singaporeans celebrating it “Happy Pongal”!  
 
Pongal is a traditional Tamil harvest festival. It marks the beginning of the auspicious month of Thai and is celebrated over 4 days. Families decorate their houses with kolams (also known as rangolis) and sugar canes, light oil lamps, and in a new pot, cook rice with milk and jaggery. The milk is allowed to boil over to symbolise luck and abundance.
 
If you’re looking for something to do this weekend, why not visit Little India and learn more about this festival? Or take a walk down Serangoon Road and enjoy the street light-up. (bit.ly/1n0HJmg)

Looking forward to joining residents at Cheng San CC on Sunday for their Pongal celebrations! :) – LHL

Listened to Maestro Zubin Mehta conducting the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra at The Esplanade yesterday evening. For two hours we focussed only on the music, putting everything else aside. It was marvellous.

The orchestra played Beethoven’s Leonora Overture No. 3, Ravel’s La Valse, and Tchaikovsky’s Symphony No. 6 “Pathetique”. At the start they played the two national anthems. It was a rousing and beautiful rendering of Majulah Singapura.

This was an 80th anniversary concert - it is both the Orchestra’s 80th season and Mehta’s 80th year. Mehta conducted with energy despite his age, and despite having just had a hip operation. The organisers surprised him with a cake after the concert (and the orchestra played Happy Birthday!). Glad I could wish him happy birthday in person too. - LHL

Our foreign policy is a balance between realism and idealism. I spoke about this as well as our fundamental interests and international relations at the S Rajaratnam Lecture yesterday. The Lecture series is organised by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA) Diplomatic Academy.

Compared to where we started off 50 years ago, Singapore’s position in the world has improved immeasurably. We are respected and successful. We enjoy good standing in the international community and we have friends from around the world.

For this, we have generations of MFA officers and Ministers to thank, starting with our first Foreign Minister, the late Mr S Rajaratnam, after whom the Lecture series is named. In fact, MFA has done such a good job that people hardly know they exist, until they lose a passport somewhere. :)

In the end, both our external influence and our domestic success comes down to us as individuals. In the words of Mr Rajaratnam, “Being Singaporean is a matter not of ancestry, but of choice and conviction.” If we have that conviction, we can achieve success for Singapore as one united people, we can have an effective foreign policy, and we can keep our little red dot shining bright in the world.

Thank you to Ambassador Ong Keng Yong for moderating the Q&A session. You can view my lecture here: y2u.be/a1Rq7Vv1bUk

Shocked to wake up to the news of the multiple terrorist attacks in Paris. At least 40 people have been killed, and about 100 hostages taken. We do not know who perpetrated these ghastly murders yet. 

It is not the first time innocent civilians have been massacred like this in this troubled world. But each time it happens we again feel appalled and outraged beyond words, for an attack like this is in fact an attack on our shared humanity.

Our thoughts and prayers go out to the victims and their families, and to the people and government of Paris and France. 

I am just about to leave for Antalya in Turkey for the G20 meeting, where one agenda item is terrorism. This latest incident renders our discussions more relevant and urgent than ever. 

- LHL

Deeply saddened to learn of the passing of former West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt.   

Mr Schmidt was a visionary leader and a strong supporter of closer relations between our countries. Mr Lee Kuan Yew described him as a 'clear-headed and tough-minded' leader who had a thorough grasp of important issues. They found common ground on many issues, and were close friends for four decades. 

In 2012, Mr Schmidt made the long journey from Hamburg to Singapore to meet my father. The two friends spent three days discussing world politics. It was to be the last time they met. Their conversation was recorded and included in the final chapter of “One Man's View Of The World”, the book my father published the following year.  

Mr Schmidt also had an acute musical ear. I recall one poolside dinner my parents hosted for him. As usual my mother had some classical chamber music playing in the background. That evening she had on J S Bach’s Goldberg Variations. In the midst of the conversation, he turned to my mother, and asked if the pianist was Glenn Gould, which indeed it was. My mother asked how he knew, and he said there was something unique about Glenn Gould’s playing style. 

My deepest condolences to Mr Schmidt’s family and the German people on their loss. - LHL

[Mr Schmidt and Mr Lee having a conversation in Shangri-La Hotel in May 2012. / ST File Photo © Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Permission required for reproduction.]

Racial and religious harmony is one of Singapore’s most remarkable achievements. But what we enjoy today is far from a natural state of affairs. 

Our pioneers worked hard to bring different communities together, through events and celebrations, and through deliberate policies on housing, education and the National Service. 

Religious and community leaders have built personal friendships and trust with one another. They discuss sensitive issues that arise with mutual respect and give and take. 

At the OnePeople.sg Community Leaders’ Conference this morning, I emphasised the importance of this harmony to our multi-religious and open society. We must stay vigilant, strengthen our ties and harmony, and ensure that future generations understand these complexities and work together to resolve issues amicably. 

We can be of different races and religions, but we are first and foremost, Singaporeans.

Was saddened to learn of Denis Healey’s passing at the ripe old age of 98 last night. 

When Singapore became independent, we were defenceless. We needed the British forces stationed here while we built up the SAF. But the British economy was in trouble, and their government wanted to withdraw from “East of Suez”, to ease the defence burden.

Denis Healey was the UK Defence Secretary, and a friend of Mr Lee Kuan Yew. He fought to keep British forces in Singapore as long as possible. 

The British bent over backwards to help us. British regulations required them to destroy surplus equipment, but Healey agreed to let us have their surplus equipment when British forces left Singapore. 

Healey also sold us the Hawker Hunter aircraft, and helped train our air force to operate and fly our first fighters. 

Mr Lee Kuan Yew described Healey as having a powerful intellect, “like a computer which kept on putting out new solutions as more data was fed in”. He later became the Chancellor of the Exchequer, and was described as “the best Prime Minister Britain never had”. 

My deepest condolences to his family on his passing. – LHL 

(Denis Healey sitting down for dinner with my father in 1966, in their first meeting in Singapore to discuss British defence spending. / ST File Photo © Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Permission required for reproduction.)

Announced my new Cabinet Line-up today. The changes will provide Singapore with a competent team to lead us beyond SG50.
 
Our challenges are now more complex. More issues involve multiple ministries. I am appointing three coordinating ministers to oversee three major areas: Teo Chee Hean will continue as DPM and be Coordinating Minister for National Security; Tharman Shanmugaratnam will be DPM and Coordinating Minister for Economic and Social Policies; Khaw Boon Wan will be Coordinating Minister for Infrastructure.
 
Two ministries – the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of Trade and Industry – will have two ministers each to oversee their expanded scope of work.
 
We also urgently need to prepare the next team to take over from me and my senior colleagues. Chee Hean and Tharman will no longer have specific ministerial responsibilities. I will put many younger colleagues into key ministries to broaden their experience. I have also reinforced my team with newly-elected MPs as well as existing backbenchers.
 
These moves will help prepare the next generation of leaders that will work with you. Half of the office holders will now be below 50 years old. I will do a mid-term review and expect to make further changes. We must have a new team ready to take over, soon after the next general election.

Called on the Governor-General of Australia, Sir Peter Cosgrove, earlier today. The Governor-General is the Queen’s representative in the country. This is Sir Peter’s first State Visit to Singapore, but he is an old visitor here. As a young infantry officer, he was posted to the Australian battalion stationed at Terendak Camp in Melaka, and would often come down to Singapore for weekend breaks. 

I told Sir Peter that I went to the US Army Command and General Staff College at Fort Leavenworth. He asked: "Which year?" I replied: "1978-79". He said "You must know Kerry Gallagher". I said: "Yes of course. Kerry was at Fort Leavenworth with me." He had also been Sir Peter's classmate at Duntroon. Small world! :)

This year Singapore and Australia celebrate 50 years of diplomatic relations. It is a long and deep friendship. Many Singaporeans have close ties with Australia, whether for study, business or family. May our relationship endure for many more years to come. – LHL

Did you know the NTUC was formed 54 years ago today?

In 1961, when the People's Action Party (PAP) split between the non-Communists and the pro-Communists, the labour movement split up too. The non-Communists retained control of the PAP. In the unions, the pro-PAP unionists, led by Devan Nair and Mahmud Awang, founded the NTUC.

Over the years, NTUC has played an important role in making tripartism work. This has been a tremendous competitive advantage that has helped us journey from Third World to First. Thanks to all the union leaders, unionists, members and volunteers, past and present, who have contributed to building a better Singapore for all. – LHL

Paid my respects to the late Mr Lee Bock Guan at the Singapore Buddhist Lodge yesterday. Mr Lee was President of the Lodge for many years, and built it up into a major charitable organisation. 
 
Mr Lee believed that education was key to breaking the cycle of poverty. He helped thousands of beneficiaries through the SBL Education Foundation. 
 
The Lodge helped the needy regardless of their religion, and collaborated closely with charities belonging to other faiths, such as Jamiyah and the Hindu Endowments Board. 
 
Mr Lee twice received the Public Service Star for his tireless efforts and good works. Even when he had a stroke and was hospitalised, he worried that his illness would delay help to the needy. 
 
Singapore has lost a good man, and a servant of the people. My deepest condolences to his family for their loss. – LHL

PM Lee: At the National Day Parade, there were two special moments for me.

One was when Kit Chan sang “Home” and we sang together so loudly from all around the Padang that we could hear ourselves.

The second moment was when I met the kids in the bright LED costumes on the Padang after the parade. They were in high spirits and their faces shone with excitement and hope. I thought to myself, these are the faces of the future of Singapore. 

At SG100, these kids will be about 60 years old. I hope they will be back at the Padang celebrating again, remembering SG50, congratulating each other on how far they have come, and looking at more young, radiant faces of children and many grandchildren, and singing Majulah Singapura!

#ndrsg

(Photo by PM Lee)

PM: Nobody can be sure or promise that Singapore will still be doing well come SG100. 

After Mr Lee Kuan Yew died, one of his friends wrote to me. She described a dinner conversation that took place during a gathering of Mr Lee and his old friends in January 2015, shortly before he was hospitalised.

His friends had asked him: “Will there be a Singapore 50 years from now?” He said: “Of course there will be … even better!” 

#ndrsg #rememberingleekuanyew #rememberinglky

(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

PM: My team and I take very seriously our responsibility to make sure Singapore lasts beyond us. My core team are already in our 50s and early 60s. We must have the next team ready in the wings.

Will Singapore stay special for our children?
- A multi-racial society strengthened by diversity, not splintered by divisions 
- A rugged society where everyone strives to do his best, but looks out for his fellow men
- A people who live up to our song “One People, One Nation, One Singapore”

If you are proud of what we have achieved together and support the future that we are building, please support me and my team, so that together, we can keep Singapore special for the next 50 years.

#ndrsg

PM Lee: In the last ten years, we have written another chapter of the Singapore story.

We said we would build more beautiful homes that Singaporeans could afford, and we did (e.g., Punggol 21 and Dawson).

We said we would strengthen our safety nets, and we did.  We introduced WorkFare, Silver Support and ComCare, built new hospitals, and made healthcare more accessible and affordable (CHAS, PG card, and MediShield Life).

We said we would create more pathways for our children to chase rainbows, and we did:
- NorthLight School (Official) and Assumption Pathway for students who failed their PSLE, because we believe in our young and we will never give up on them
- School of the Arts, Singapore, School of Science and Technology, Singapore to cater to varied talents
- First-class campuses for our Institute of Technical Education, Singapore
- New universities (SUTD Singapore University of Technology & Design, Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT), SIM University (UniSIM))

We said we would transform our city, and we did (Changi Airport Jewel, T4 & T5; Gardens by the Bay, beautiful parks connectors and ABC waterways like Bishan-AMK Park).

We said we would transform Marina Bay and we did. In 2005, Marina South was still empty. At my NDR that year, I promised you Marina Bay would be special by our Jubilee. Today in 2015, Marina Bay is entirely transformed.

We did this together. We had a vision, we believed in it, and together, we realised our dreams.

#ndrsg

(Photo by PM Lee)

THE SINGAPORE SPIRIT

PM: After 50 years, this sense of togetherness and purpose is stronger than before. The Singapore spirit shines when we celebrate our successes together, such as when our athletes made us proud at the SEA Games. Or in times of need when we help one another, like people rushing to help a man run over and stuck under a truck, or Singaporeans in Bangkok who contacted our Bangkok embassy offering their help after the #bangkokblast.

Our spirit shone brightest when Mr Lee Kuan Yew passed away. It brought out so much in us, and on the day of his funeral, we were mourning Mr Lee’s passing, but also affirming what he stood for, and celebrating what he had achieved. That day, something changed in us. Our shared moment of sorrow bonded us and we knew that we were Singaporean.

#ndrsg

(MCI Photo)

FAMILIES AND BABIES

PM Lee: Glad to hear from Grace Fu that we have given out almost 20,000 SG50 Jubilee Baby gifts so far, including one to Tin Pei Ling. I hope couples will continue to have many babies beyond SG50.

Having a child is a major responsibility but we will help you, because every Singaporean child is precious to us. We will do so in four ways:

1. We will help couples live closer to their parents by introducing a Proximity Housing Grant. Every Singaporean household will be eligible, whether first-time buyer or not. You will get the Grant when you buy a resale flat with or near your parents, or your married children.

2. We will increase the amount of the Baby Bonus, and give it for every child. This will provide more support for larger families.

3. We will increase the Medisave Grant for Newborns. It will be enough to cover MediShield Life premiums for the child until age 21, and also help with other healthcare expenses.

4. Fathers play a vital role in bringing up children. You have to do your part. Paternity Leave will be increased from one to two weeks. The Government will pay for the extra week of leave. We will implement it on a voluntary basis first, and the Public Service will volunteer straightway. 

The Baby Bonus, Medisave Grant, and Paternity Leave changes will apply with effect from 1 January 2015.

#ndrsg

(MCI Photo)

ELDERLY WILL ALWAYS HAVE A PLACE IN SINGAPORE

PM: We made the Pioneer Generation Package (PGP) to express our gratitude to the pioneers who contributed so much to building today’s Singapore. PG Ambassadors visited every pioneer in their homes to chat with them, understand their needs, and explain the PGP.

Minister Gan Kim Yong leads the Ministerial Committee on Ageing. He will announce an Action Plan to make Singapore a model for successful ageing. 

One sneak peek from his plan: Many people in their 60s want to work longer. The tripartite partners have been discussing this, and they have reached an agreement. We will pass legislation to raise the re-employment age from 65 to 67 by 2017.

#ndrsg

(Photo courtesy of Pioneer Generation Office)

AFFORDABLE AND ACCESSIBLE HOUSING FOR ALL

PM Lee: We are going to do three more things to keep HDB flats affordable and accessible to all Singaporeans:

1. The income ceiling will be raised from $10,000 to $12,000 for HDB flats, and from $12,000 to $14,000 for ECs, so that more households can buy HDB and ECs. 

2. We will raise the household income ceiling for Special CPF Housing Grants (SHG) from $6,500 to $8,500 so that two-thirds of all first-timer households will qualify. We will also double the maximum SHG from $20,000 to $40,000. 

3. We will help those in rental flats to own a flat. With latest changes, first-timers can still afford a 2-room flat even if you earn below $1,000, if you hold a stable job and contribute to CPF regularly. The Fresh Start Housing Scheme will help second-timer rental households own a 2-room flat. The flat will have a shorter lease and stricter conditions on resale. A Fresh Start Grant will be provided to help pay for the flat. We will support the family with counsellors to guide them to solve their problems holistically. The family has to play its part, and show that they are putting their lives in order.

#ndrsg

PM Lee: There is an African saying: “If you want to go fast, go alone.  If you want to go far, go together”.

HDB housing is one important way we make sure we go together. The HDB home ownership programme has been a tremendous success. Today, more than 90% of HDB households own their flats. 

In Singapore, no matter who you are, you live in a good neighbourhood with good homes, parks and waterways, and you feel safe and secure. This must always be the reality for all Singaporeans.

#ndrsg

The Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) provides applied-learning pathways for students who prefer more hands-on learning. 

We will build a new campus for SIT in Punggol. It will be integrated with a creative industry cluster JTC will build just across the road. Students can go from classroom to workplace and apply what they learn. 

It will also be integrated into Punggol Downtown and HDB’s upcoming Northshore District. The community will share its facilities – classrooms, workshops, and multi-purpose hall.

#ndrsg

PM Lee: SkillsFuture provides Singaporeans opportunities to develop to their full potential, whatever their starting point may be. 

The SkillsFuture Earn-and-Learn Programme gives fresh ITE and Polytechnic graduates a head-start in careers. They earn a full-time salary while learning new skills, so that they can upgrade to higher jobs. We have also created the SkillsFuture Credit. Every Singaporean aged 25 and above will get an initial $500 of credit, with top-ups from time to time, to spend on training programmes throughout life.

PM Lee: We have to be alive to our external environment. We have good relations with our neighbours, but it may not always be like this. Even in the next 10 years, we cannot be sure.

On our National Day, just recently on 9 August, one Indonesian newspaper published an overview of the relationship between Indonesia and Singapore. The article quoted what a senior politician said about the haze: “I would only consider apologising (for the haze) if Singapore and Malaysia are thankful for the oxygen they enjoy (from Indonesian forests) for 11 months (each year)”. This may not reflect the Indonesian Government’s view, but we have to take note of it. It is a deep seated mindset – that a little red dot should know its place in the world. That mindset will not disappear for a long time.

We have to stay on top of regional developments, and watch relations between the major powers in the region. We have been able to maintain our security and standing in the world because we have a strong SAF, successful economy, and good diplomats and leaders. We must maintain and strengthen this if we are to hold our own in the outside world.

#ndrsg

TRUST & GOOD GOVERNMENT

PM Lee: We have kept faith between the Government and the people. As the Government, we have kept our promises. We are honest about the choices we have to make, and do not shy away from hard realities or sugar-coat difficult issues. In turn, the people trust the Government to have their interests at heart and they support its decisions. Therefore, even in tough times, we can act decisively together.

One tough issue we have is immigration and foreigners. Singaporeans understandably have strong views on it. The Government has heard them. But there are no easy choices on this matter. Every option has a downside, and whichever option we choose will involve some pain. 

PM Lee: I believe that I am doing what Singapore needs and what best safeguards your interest. It is my responsibility to make this judgement and act on your behalf.

#ndrsg

SELF-RELIANCE & MUTUAL SUPPORT

PM Lee: We knew right from the start that to strike out and blaze a path on our own, everyone had to pull their weight and be counted. That is why Mr Lee Kuan Yew exhorted us over and over again to become a rugged society. Our people must be robust and tough, able to take hard knocks, always striving to be better. No one owes us a living and we have to make our own way forward. 

But a rugged society doesn’t mean every man for himself. We are strong even though we are small, because we are strong together. The ethos of our society is that if you work hard, you should do well. At the same time, if you do well, we expect you to help others.

We must inculcate this same ethos in our young. That is why we encourage our children to play sports, and send them to adventure learning and character education – to bring up a generation who will grow up tough and able to work closely together.

#ndrsg

(Photo courtesy of National Youth Council – Outward Bound Singapore)

MULTI-RACIALISM

PM Lee: We separated from Malaysia because we believed in the ideal of a multi-racial society. We believed that before race, language, and religion, we should first and foremost, be Singaporean.

We encouraged all the communities to come together, but yet gave each community space to maintain their own cultures and ways of life. When difficult issues arose, we dealt with them together. We made extra effort to ensure that every community could hold their own and not be left behind. 

Therefore, for SG50, every community in Singapore is celebrating because all have progressed with the nation. Each group is celebrating with other groups, because we are one united people.

#ndrsg

(Photo courtesy of NDP 2015 Publications Committee)

What an exhilarating journey these past 50 years have been! Three factors got us here, PM Lee said;

1. Multi-racialism 
2. Self-reliance and mutual support
3. Keeping faith between Government and people

总理在演讲中把焦点放在国外的发展，提醒大家新加坡所面对的外在威胁。这也是李光耀先生所关心的课题，因为它关系到新加坡长远的利益。

国外局势随时可能影响区域的稳定，从而破坏新加坡的安定，威胁我国的安全，因此国人必须团结一致，才能捍卫国家利益，维护国家安全，确保社会和谐。

总理说，新加坡在这50年来，建国前辈的努力付出造就了今天的新加坡。在这个共同奋斗的过程中，人民和政府之间建立了互信。领导的班子有责任把国家治理好，和人民分享成功的果实。在接下来的50年，新加坡还会是一个闪亮的小红点，再创无数个高峰，迈向辉煌百年。

#ndrsg

(Photo by MCI)

总理说这50年来新加坡取得的成就，华社功不可没。华商领袖积极开创事业，带动经济发展，也负起各种社会责任。华社另一支柱是文教界的许多人士。他们的努力和苦心，让一代又一代新加坡人打下华语基础，发挥双语的优势。

总理也指出，华文媒体工作者对各种课题详细的报道，让不熟悉英文的民众了解国内和世界的动态，以及政府所推行的政策，例如建国一代配套、终身健保计划。总理鼓励大家再接再厉，让华社蓬勃发展，让华族文化更多姿多彩。

在面对生活费这个课题时，总理说，政府在解决衣食住行和医疗费方面，下了很大的功夫。政府接下来会建更多小贩中心，以合作社及社会企业的形式管理。这个形式除了能提供较便宜的食物以外，一部分利润也能用来主办优惠活动，确保大家可享用价廉物美的熟食。

总理也举出许多现有的政策，以减轻国人在交通费和医药费的负担。所有学生 – 包括理工学院的学生 – 都享有优惠车资卡。政府也在今年提供50元的公共交通礼券给60岁以上的乐龄人士。在医疗方面，建国一代配套和终身健保计划也帮助国人省下不少医药费。

Lui Tuck Yew has told me that he does not wish to stand again in the coming General Election, and I have reluctantly accepted his decision. He had told me this early this year. My senior colleagues and I tried hard to change his mind, and are disappointed that we did not succeed. 

Tuck Yew has done a lot for my team and for Singapore over the last decade, especially these last four years as Minister for Transport. When I asked him to go to MOT in 2011, we both knew that I was giving him a very difficult job, but he did not hesitate. There were urgent things to be done, and public expectations were high. 

He put his heart and soul into the task, and made many improvements to the public transport system. The benefits will be seen in the coming years. The job is not yet complete, but we are heading in the right direction.

Besides Transport, Tuck Yew also served in the Ministries of Information, Communications and the Arts, Foreign Affairs and Defence. As an MP in Moulmein, he has worked to improve the lives of his residents. 

We will miss Tuck Yew. I thank him for all that he has done for Singapore over the last decade, and wish him all the best in future. - LHL

Exactly 50 years ago, a radio announcer read the Proclamation that marked the birth of our nation. This morning, at National Day Observances, we remembered and celebrated that pivotal moment. We heard the Proclamation again, this time read by the late Mr Lee Kuan Yew (in a recording done in 2012). 

We have come far in 50 years. While we enjoy today’s prosperity and progress, never forget how hard we worked to get here. What we have is special and precious, and must never be taken for granted. 

Today we sang Majulah Singapura proudly. To still do so in 50 years’ time, let us work together as one united people, regardless of race, language or religion, for the happiness, prosperity and progress of our nation. – LHL

Amidst SG50 celebrations, I am watching our water stocks closely.

Vivian Balakrishnan visited Linggiu Reservoir in Johor on Monday. The reservoir ensures that there is always enough fresh water in the Johor River to supply PUB’s waterworks downstream at Kota Tinggi.

Because of prolonged dry weather, Linggiu Reservoir is now only half full – lower than it has ever been. (See Vivian’s photos at http://on.fb.me/1KPSSzQ.) If the dry weather continues and Linggiu Reservoir is emptied, PUB will be unable to draw all the water we are entitled to from the Johor River.

I visited Linggiu Reservoir in 2012. (See my post at: http://on.fb.me/1eShI3x.) After my visit, I decided to build more NEWater and desalination plants, to make our water supply more resilient. One more NEWater plant will be completed next year, and a third desalination plant in 2017.

In Singapore, water will always be a precious resource. Never take it for granted, or waste it. Please do your part to conserve water. – LHL

The Electoral Boundaries Review Committee (EBRC) has submitted its report. 

When I appointed the Committee two months ago, I asked it to redraw the constituency boundaries, to have smaller Group Representation Constituencies (GRCs), and at least 12 Single Member Constituencies (SMCs). The Committee was also to take into account population shifts and new towns that have come up.

They have done so. They have added one SMC and one GRC, giving a total of 13 SMCs and 16 GRCs. 

We will have more 4-member GRCs (6 instead of previous 2), and fewer 5-member GRCs (8 instead of 11). 

To make smaller GRCs and more SMCs, some boundaries have had to be changed. This will be the electoral configuration in the next general election. 

Wherever the boundaries may be drawn, MPs should serve the residents they represent to the best of their ability. And voters should support the candidates or teams who will best represent their interests, both in the constituency and as the government of Singapore.

More details on the Committee’s report at: http://bit.ly/1HNcAbA

– LHL

Answered a question today on Singapore’s role in sustainable development. This was in a dialogue at the FutureChina Global Forum organised by 通商中国 Business China.

I joked that Singapore is such a small country that even if we all stopped breathing it would make little difference to climate change. More seriously, we have few options for renewable energy. There is no space for nuclear power, and other sources are either not feasible (wind, hydro) or limited in scale (solar), so we have to rely heavily on fossil fuels.

But we will be a responsible member of the global community, and help to build consensus on an international agreement which is fair and implementable for all countries. 

Also each of us can make changes to our lifestyles, to save energy. Every little bit counts. - LHL

“Chasing Rainbows” is the English edition of a Chinese book 《追虹》 written by Choo Lian Liang. It was translated by her daughter, Sim Ann 沈颖.
 
Lian Liang is a veteran television producer and an accomplished writer. I’ve known her for 30 years, and Sim Ann too (not quite so long :) ). 

I read 《追虹》 cover to cover. It is a fascinating family history of four generations, beginning with Lian Liang’s great-grandfather in 1899. He failed the Imperial examinations, and sailed from Chaozhou to Singapore to find work. The family lived through the Japanese Occupation, the post-war anti-colonial struggle, and China’s Great Leap Forward. These tumultuous events profoundly affected their lives and fortunes. 
 
Many of us have similar histories of forebears who came to Singapore in search of a better life. “Chasing Rainbows” tells a vivid story of how the pioneers chased that rainbow and found the pot of gold. May it inspire our generation to be as intrepid, and to do even better. – LHL
