When I visit places, I look out for unusual signs to photograph and add to my collection. Here is one in Singapore, reported in the column “What’s That Thing” in Slate, which examines “mysterious or overlooked objects in our visual landscapes”. Turns out these “umbrella” road signs are unique to Singapore. ;) - LHL

Congrats to Temasek on your anniversary!

For 40 years, Temasek has overseen government-linked companies like SIA, DBS, Keppel and Sembcorp. It has established an international reputation for prudence and excellence. It has grown its portfolio of Singapore companies and overseas investments into a sizeable nest egg that forms part of our reserves.

A big thank you to all the people who’ve worked in Temasek all these years. Long may you continue to build companies and invest for future generations of Singaporeans. - LHL

(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

Warmest congrats to New Zealand Prime Minister John Key, for leading his National Party to a third successive general election victory.  

Prime Minister Key has close ties with Singapore - he worked here in the mid-1990s. On my last visit to New Zealand in 2012, I brought him some packets of chilli crab sauce - one of his favourite Singaporean dishes. :)

Next year, Singapore and New Zealand commemorate 50 years of diplomatic relations. I look forward to continue enhancing our ties with PM Key and his team, and wish them every success in their new term. - LHL 

[With PM John Key at the ASEAN Global Dialogue in Phnom Penh, Cambodia in Nov 2012. / SPH Photo © Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Reproduced with permission.]

Another spectacular F1 race this year! Congrats to Lewis Hamilton, who won for the second time in Singapore, despite a spirited challenge from Sebastian Vettel.

Watched the race with some Pioneer Generation members, and students with special needs, who have overcome tough challenges of their own. 

Also congrats to Singapore Airlines, which is the title sponsor of the Singapore Grand Prix this year. Exciting from start to finish. - LHL

Prof Chan Heng Chee asked me what issues worried me. I replied two: rising nationalism in our region, and ISIS in the Middle East. This was at the Singapore Summit lunch dialogue today. 

Was also asked about Scotland’s independence referendum, the Trans-Pacific Partnership, ASEAN cooperation, and other issues too.

To catch the rest of the dialogue, please see this playlist (http://bit.ly/1sJlFYm). – LHL

Time for a #guesswhere. :) – LHL

---

Thanks for guessing! This was quite easy, since many of you would have seen these cats in town. :) Yes, these Kucinta cats (aka Singapura cats) on Cavenagh Bridge, at Boat Quay along the Singapore River caught my eye when I was there recently. Go see them for yourself, and the other sculptures along the river too. They make it a really nice place for an evening walk. - LHL

(Photo by me)

Hong Kong looks beautiful from the Peak. Snapped this on my morning walk yesterday. The city is below us; Victoria Harbour, Kowloon and the mountains are beyond. 

And so back home. The SQ flight was full, perhaps with visitors for the F1 weekend. – LHL

Spent yesterday meeting people and seeing a few places in Hong Kong. At the City Gallery, I learnt how HK is planning to expand and upgrade the city over the next 30 years. Was impressed with the masterplan and efforts to increase its connectivity to the Pearl River Delta. e.g. the West Kowloon District is taking shape as a new hub for arts, culture, business and living in the city.
 
Also met Mr Tung Chee Hwa, the former Chief Executive of HK, and had dinner with the current CE CY Leung.

HK and Singapore share many similarities. We are both building for the future, while balancing the need to conserve our green spaces. HK is a thriving business and financial hub in Southern China. Singapore is doing well in Southeast Asia. We compete, but we also benefit from each others’ success.

Just came back from a walk at Victoria Peak, and flying home this afternoon. - LHL
 
昨天与香港特首梁振英和香港前特首、现任中国全国政协副主席董建华个别会面, 谈了很多。
 
香港和新加坡有很多相似之处。我们都为了应付未来的需求在建设不同的设施。不过我们也要保护我们的绿色空间, 在这两者之间取得平衡。 参观城市规划展览馆后，了解了香港在接下来30年据将如何扩大和提升这个城市。整个规划很宏观,让我印象深刻。
 
香港正努力提高其与珠江三角的连贯性。西九龙艺术文化区正在形成，也包括了新的活动和商业中心。  香港是中国南方一个繁荣的商业和金融中心。新加坡是东南亚的商业和金融中心。我们一起竞, 但我们也受益于彼此的成功。   
 
刚从维多利亚山顶散步回来，今天下午就回国。 - 李显龙

Had a full day yesterday in Nanning. 

Besides the opening of the 11th CAEXPO and the Singapore Pavilion there, I attended a roundtable dialogue with Chinese CEOs. 

Also had lunch with the Singapore business delegation. They comprised companies big and small, who have made progress doing business in China.
 
Am now in Hong Kong, which I have not visited since 2001. Look forward to meeting Hong Kong leaders and business people, and bringing myself up to date. - LHL

在南宁的最后一天，参加了多项中国 - 东盟博览会的相关活动，忙了一整天。 

活动包括为中国 - 东盟博览会和新加坡馆主持开幕仪式，接着跟几位中国总裁进行圆桌对话。 

这次新加坡有大概90家公司参与博览会，是历年来最多的一次。参与的公司有些是大规模的，也有比较小型的，它们在中国发展的成绩都不错。 
 
现在人在香港。自2001年, 相隔13年，我都没有再来过，因此这次机会难逢，我希望可以从香港的领导和商业人士，重新认识香港。- 李显龙

Many of you have written me to wish my father a happy birthday. Thank you very much! Am touched by your warm messages (and the pictures some of you posted), and will show them to my father when I get home. He has also put out a statement to thank you all for your birthday greetings and good wishes, and to wish you all the best in return. – LHL

Spoke at the opening ceremony of the 11th China-ASEAN Expo (CAEXPO) today. I was here for the 3rd CAEXPO in 2006. Happy to see that both Nanning and the Expo have grown much in the last eight years.
 
Ties between Singapore and China are prospering. Last year China became Singapore’s largest trading partner, and Singapore was China’s top foreign investor. 
 
China has proposed new ideas to promote economic cooperation with ASEAN, such as upgrading the ASEAN-China FTA, setting up an Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, and promoting the 21st century Maritime Silk Road. We look forward to working with China on these initiatives. - LHL

The saying is “桂林山水甲天下” (Guilin’s beauty is unparalleled under heaven). I'm glad I finally had the chance to see it for myself. :) Cruised down the Li River yesterday from Guilin to Yangshuo. There we walked down the picturesque West Street. 

Also watched a spectacular musical performance - 印象刘三姐 “Impressions of Liu Sanjie” - performed on the river with the iconic scenery as backdrop. The cast, local Zhuang minority villagers, rendered the legend in a medley of songs, dances, lights and ethnic costumes.
 
Many Singaporeans visit Guilin each year. I met Guilin Party Secretary Zhao Leqin yesterday, and we shared the hope to do more together through tourism to Guilin. - LHL
 
终于有机会欣赏桂林动人的美景。“桂林山水甲天下”的确名副其实。
昨天乘船游漓江，从桂林到阳朔。全程一幅又一幅的山水画，一直出现在眼前。
也到了阳朔热闹的西街，走了一圈。

晚上观赏了著名印象刘三姐的精彩表演。以山为背景，在水上的表演结合了缤纷的彩灯，几百位壮族村民，用歌舞把当地的传说呈现给大家。

桂林党书记赵乐秦提到，每年到访桂林的新加坡游客很多。希望在旅游业方面两国有合作的发展空间。- 李显龙

Visited Guilin for the first time yesterday. Took a cruise down the beautiful Li River, checked out Yangshuo's West Street, and watched Zhang Yimou's “Impressions of Liu Sanjie” show. Here are some highlights. - LHL
 
(PMO Video by Alex Qiu)

It was good to be back in Shenzhen. My last visit was 23 years ago. Met Shenzhen Party Secretary Wang Rong, visited Internet giant Tencent and upcoming Shenzhen-Hong Kong Service Industry Cooperation Zone, Qianhai, and saw Shenzhen’s vibrant city from Lotus Hill. - LHL
 
(PMO Video by Alex Qiu)

Shenzhen has grown tremendously since I last visited in 1991. It has become a vibrant city, clean, well laid out, and building for the future. 

I visited Lotus Hill yesterday morning, where a statue of Mr Deng stands, watching over the transformation of Shenzhen, and of China. 

Met a good friend for lunch: Shenzhen’s Party Secretary Wang Rong. He used to be Party Secretary of Suzhou, and is a great supporter of our China-Singapore Suzhou Industrial Park. 

Next, I visited Tencent, one of the largest Internet companies in the world, well-known for WeChat, the text messaging service used by most Chinese, and quite many Singaporeans too. 

Also visited Qianhai, which will be a zone for Shenzhen and Hong Kong to cooperate on service industries. 

Shenzhen and Singapore share interesting similarities. We were both once fishing villages, and both reliant on immigrant populations. Now, Shenzhen is a modern city, upgrading its economy just like us. There is much for us to learn from each other, and many opportunities to collaborate. - LHL

相隔23年，深圳已经转变成一个干净、充满活力、设施齐全、为长远发展做好了周详策划的城市。

昨天上了莲花山，有一座邓小平先生的巨型雕像，它见证了深圳和中国的积极转变。

中午和好朋友深圳党书记王荣先生共餐。他曾经是苏州党委书记，当时开发中新苏州工业园区，給我们很大的支持。

为了多了解在深圳企业的情形，就访问了腾讯，中国一家很成功的互联网公司。腾讯的WeChat应用程序， 非常先进便用，简化了很多生活中需要的服务，很受中国人华欢迎。在新加坡，也有不少用户。

也参观了新开发的前海深港现代服务业合作区。

深圳和新加坡有很多相似之处。我们都曾经是渔村，都依靠移民人口与人才。现在，深圳跟新加坡一样，是一个现代化的城市，在提升其经济。我们还有很多互相学习和合作的机会。 - 李显龙

The Sino-Singapore Guangzhou Knowledge City is taking shape. A business park, MRT lines, and high rise housing are being built. The Knowledge City will be a model for economic restructuring and industrial upgrading in Guangdong province. 
 
After lunch with Guangzhou’s Mayor Chen Jianhua yesterday, we took a stroll at the beautiful Lizhi Wan (荔枝湾; i.e. Lychee Bay), a preservation area with many traditional Cantonese houses.
 
Our ties with Guangdong are prospering. Look forward to seeing the developments in Shenzhen today. - LHL
 
中新知识城到目前的进展良好。知识城在现阶段将建立一个工业园区、地铁线和高楼公寓。知识城竣工时，将成为广东经济转型和工业升级的重点平台。
 
在陈建华市长的陪同下，下午到广东名胜荔枝湾，参观了传统的西关大楼，了解当年的日常生活习惯，很有意思。
 
新加坡和广东的关系良好，合作项目很多。昨天抵达深圳，希望了解它近年来的发展。-李显龙

Arrived in Guangzhou yesterday to begin my visit to China. It’s been 8 years since my last visit to this city.

Guangdong Party Secretary Hu Chunhua hosted us to dinner. We talked about the challenges of transforming and upgrading an economy. China and Singapore are both walking similar paths, except that Singapore started earlier. 

Today, I’ll be visiting the Sino-Singapore Guangzhou Knowledge City (SSGKC), a major project which fits in with Guangdong’s plans to upgrade its industries. Then we go to Shenzhen. - LHL

阔别了八年，再次来到广州，看到广州的新面貌，感觉到这城市的活力。很高兴再见到广东省书记胡春华。我们谈了很多，包括经济转型升级所面对的挑战。中国和新加坡已经踏上了相似的途径，不过新加坡先起步。今天我将会去考察中新广州知识城。这是一项配合广东政府要提升当地企业的重要项目。接着，我们会到深圳去。-李显龙

Visited the lantern carnival at Gardens by the Bay last night, to celebrate the Mid-Autumn Festival with Ho Ching. The displays were pretty, and very popular with the crowds old and young. 
 
The organisers clearly had made a big effort. Here are some of my pics. Do try to visit before it ends this Sunday! - LHL
 
昨晚是中秋，我和何晶在滨海湾花园赏灯笼过节。这些五彩缤纷，光芒四射的大型灯饰，很受欢迎。大家都抢着最好的位置拍照留念，我也拍了不少照片。 :) 机会难得，请大家趁学校假期，去看一看，这星期天就结束了。- 李显龙
PMO Photo by Alex Qiu

Sunset over Jurong Lake. I took this pic from the White Rainbow Bridge that links the Chinese and Japanese Gardens during a walk in June. When this area becomes the Jurong Lake District, it should be a really nice place to live, work and play. (http://youtu.be/STQ0aSdG7OM?t=1m43s) – LHL

(Photo by me)

#Didyouknow: Potong Pasir was originally home to a sand quarry? In fact, Potong Pasir literally means 'cut sand' in Malay. The town has certainly come a long way since then!

I visited Potong Pasir CC yesterday evening to check out the new annex. Residents can now use a post office, POSBank, and Fairprice supermarket when they visit the CC. After that I joined residents for the Lantern Festival celebration. Also had a go at making mooncakes - it's harder than it looks!

MP Sitoh Yih Pin and his team have worked hard for more than a decade to win the support of residents, and to improve their lives. Thank you for the warm welcome and keep up the good work! - LHL

Happy Mid-Autumn Festival to all! It’s a time to get together with family and friends to enjoy the evening, beautiful lanterns and delicious mooncake.

I saw many happy faces at the Teck Ghee Lantern Night at Bishan-Ang Mo Kio Park yesterday. Many children of different races came to enjoy the festivities with colourful lanterns.

Hope you’ll be taking part in similar mid-autumn celebrations in your community! - LHL

祝大家中秋节快乐！昨晚的月亮没有那么亮，不过碧山-宏茂桥公园却被几千个灯笼照亮了。刚好也是学校假期，所以看到了很多居民，全家三代，一起在公园团聚，赏月，吃月饼，提灯笼，气氛很热闹。希望今晚的月亮会很明亮，大家可以跟家人过一个好中秋！- 李显龙

(MCI Photo by LH Goh)

Enjoyed Dao Sha Pia, a short film by Chong Yu Lun. I met him recently, at the Istana National Day Observance Ceremony. He is serving NS in the Presidential Guards Platoon of the Military Police Command.

Dao Sha Pia is a tale about a father and son. Told simply, it warmed my heart, and would resonate with our National Servicemen too. NS can be tough, but it helps us realise what is important in life, especially our families. I hope you will enjoy this short film too. :) – LHL

27 years ago, we opened the North-South Line –  our first MRT line. Today, I was happy to break ground for two new stations – Lentor and Mayflower – on the Thomson-East Coast Line (TEL) – our sixth line.

This will make a big difference to residents. The stations should be done by 2020, though the whole TEL will take a little longer to complete. 

Over the next 3 years, we will expand our MRT network by a quarter. By 2030, our network will double. 8 in 10 households will be within a 10-minute walk from a train station.

My thanks to LTA, and its partners China Railway 5 and Gammon, for building our new stations. Thank you also residents of Lentor and Kebun Bahru for your support and understanding, especially during the construction. 

Look forward to riding the TEL! - LHL

Grateful for another chance to answer your questions on MediaCorp’s live TV chat last night.

Got some excellent questions (especially from primary school students). Some were on current issues like jobs and employment, others on building a better Singapore. There were also fun questions on my favourite superheroes and ambition as a child! (For the record, I’ve since re-learnt the names of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles.)

Sorry I couldn’t answer more questions – but with only an hour, and over 700 questions coming in, this would have been tough!

If you missed last night’s show, do watch it again here: http://bit.ly/1qgjlLR Many thanks to the MediaCorp crew for putting the programme together. - LHL

(A wefie with Dawn and Nicholas before the chat began :))

Caught this pretty sunset on Monday, just before my radio talk show with Capital 95.8FM at MediaCorp. I’m heading there again now for another live chat, this time on TV, and in English. It will be telecast on MediaCorp Channel 5 and Channel NewsAsia Singapore, from 8pm to 9pm. Talk to you soon! – LHL

Was very happy to witness Indonesian president Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono receiving the Order of Temasek from President Tony Tan yesterday evening. 

President SBY has been a good friend of Singapore. Under his leadership, we strengthened our ties with Indonesia, and enjoyed a stable and predictable neighbour, one focussed on development and regional cooperation.

It seems not so long ago that President SBY and I exchanged introductory visits, but ten years have passed since he and I took office at about the same time. They have been good years for our friendship. I am glad to have worked with President SBY, and wish him all the best in his future endeavours. - LHL

Well done Singapore Symphony Orchestra!

SSO’s debut last night at the 120th BBC Proms, at the Royal Albert Hall in London, went very well. The orchestra put on a brilliant performance, wowed the audience and won critical praise.

With technology, ingenuity, determination, we can push our limits further than we think! 

I was delighted to open the Jurong Rock Caverns (JRC) today. It is Southeast Asia’s first underground facility for storing liquid hydrocarbons. By going deep under the seabed, we freed up 60 hectares of surface land, enough for six petrochemical plants.

My deepest condolences to Mrs Lim and family on the passing of Professor Arthur Lim.  

Arthur was a pioneer, visionary and giant in Singapore medicine. He founded our National Eye Centre, conceived the Singapore Eye Research Institute, and put Singapore medicine on the world map. 

Arthur mentored generations of eye surgeons and lit the lives of millions of people around the world. He trained more than 5,000 specialists in the 10 eye centres that he helped establish in China, restoring the vision of about one million cataract patients there.

His legacy will live on as we remember his life and his contributions. – LHL

After welcoming new Singaporeans in Cheng San yesterday afternoon, I presented 150 residents in Teck Ghee their Pioneer Generation Package Welcome Packs.

I was moved to see these elderly men and women, who had done so much for Singapore, now in the autumn of their lives, come together to receive their Packs and to be honoured. They looked happy, and with good reason.

PM: Government will set up an advisory panel to study: 

a) how people can be allowed to take out part of their CPF  savings in a lump sum after the age of 65, subject to limits; 
b) how the Minimum Sum should be adjusted over time, so that members can continue to get an adequate basic retirement payout; 
c) how members can have more flexibility to invest their CPF savings; and
d) how CPF Life payouts can take account of cost of living adjustments.

The final Minimum Sum adjustment, scheduled for next year, will be $161,000 for those turning 55 from 1 July 2015. With a property pledge, you will only need $80,500 in cash.  

#ndrsg

CPF plus HDB have enabled a majority of the population to save enough for retirement, PM noted. However, a minority may not have enough. A new Silver Support scheme will be introduced to help low-income elderly Singaporeans. It will pay a bonus each year, starting from age 65, to help them with their living expenses and cost of living. More details will be announced at Budget next year.

#ndrsg

PM: There are many ways to unlock the value of your house. You can rent out a room, or right-size and take advantage of the Silver Housing Bonus, or take advantage of the Lease Buyback Scheme.  #ndrsg

ASSURANCE IN RETIREMENT: 4 key points from PM’s speech -

1. CPF and home ownership go hand-in-hand in providing for your retirement. 
2. The current Minimum Sum is not too much.
3. If you own a house, you only need to set aside half of the Minimum Sum – or $77,500 – for those who turned 55 this July.

总理华语群众大会演讲2014

总理说没有刻苦耐劳的建国一代，就没有今天的新加坡。 我们应该饮水思源，用一个恰当的方式，向建国一代表达我们的一份谢意。政府推出特别配套，希望能为建国前辈带来生活上的帮助。 
 
政府的另一大目标，是确保大家有足够的退休金，可以安享晚年。这个可以通过公积金制度和住屋政策两大政策来达到目的。总理说政府了解一些国人对公积金制度有一些见解，所以将调整公积金制度，使它更加完善，可以更好的帮助人民。总理说另一个能够保障国人晚年生活的政策就是居者有其屋政策。政府也会继续调整这些措施，尽量帮助国人利用房子来养老。总理将会在英语的演讲中进一步地解释这些政策。
 
总理也强调政府要让国人对未来充满信心和希望。无论国人处在哪一个起跑点，都有机会提升自己。在职场上一边工作，一边学习，也能出人头地。政府的教育目标，是要让人们按照自己的兴趣、专长和天赋，追求一个适合自己的学习道路，使自己的才华得到最充分的发挥。
 
要有好的生活，总理说，我们一定要有蓬勃的经济来进一步拓展国内和国际市场，特别是亚洲新兴的经济体，包括日益强盛的中国。政府会通过论坛促进新中企业交流，加深新加坡企业对中国的了解，促进新中两国创业者之间的合作。
 
总理说，新加坡华族，因为文化背景相近，以及具备双语能力，可以更容易融入中国社会。一直以来，政府也不遗余力支持民间组织，推广华族文化和母语教育。总理说，我们的宗乡会馆就做了很多工作，积极提倡文化和教育事业。政府会全力支持宗乡总会提出设立华族文化中心的构想。总理会在下个月为中心主持动土仪式。
 
华族文化中心所推广的文化，除了传统和现代中华文化，也将涵盖新加坡独特的华族文化。经过多年的酝酿，新加坡华族文化已经逐渐形成一种南洋风格。 
总理说，新加坡已经步入了第一世界，但是我们还没有发展到极限；我们还有无限发展的空间。我们需要的是先辈那种勇于开拓、积极进取的精神，新加坡才能攀上另一个高峰。
让我们朝着这个方向一起前进，共同努力。
 
#NDRsg

Rapat Hari Kebangsaan 2014 – Ucapan Bahasa Melayu 

Dalam ucapan Bahasa Melayunya, PM telah mengulangi penghargaannya kepada golongan Perintis Melayu.

Encik Lee menekankan bahawa warga Perintis Melayu sebenarnya ada pilihan (samada untuk menyertai Malaysia atau kekal di Singapura) apabila Singapura Merdeka. Tetapi mereka memilih untuk jatuh-bangun bersama Singapura sehingga negara ini mekar menjadi sebuah masyarakat berbilang kaum dan agama yang unik – yang bersatu padu dan harmoni. Beliau mengulangi penghargaannya kepada golongan Perintis Melayu kerana yakin dengan masa depan Singapura dan bertungkus-lumus dengan kaum lain, membangunkan Singapura.

Salah seorang tokoh Perintis Melayu cemerlang yang disebut PM ialah Encik Yusof Ishak, Presiden pertama Singapura. PM mengumumkan 3 bentuk penghargaan sebagai menjunjung budi dan pengorbanan Encik Yusof kepada Negara:

Pertama, sebuah masjid baru di Woodlands akan dinamakan “Masjid Yusof Ishak”.

Kedua, Institut Pengajian Asia Tenggara bakal dikenali sebagai “ISEAS – Institut Yusof Ishak”. 

Ketiga, NUS akan memulakan “Kerusi Profesor Yusof Ishak dalam Sains Sosial”. 

Dalam ucapannya, PM turut menarik perhatian tentang kemajuan besar yang dicatat masyarakat Melayu/Islam sepanjang 50 tahun lalu. Ini ketara melalui contoh-contoh individu Melayu/Islam yang berjaya saban tahun. 

PM juga menarik perhatian tentang penekanan pemerintah untuk menghargai setiap individu berdasarkan sumbangannya dan bukan hanya kelayakannya. PM mengumumkan pembentukan Jawatankuasa ASPIRE yang akan bantu rakyat menggilap potensi mereka melalui pembelajaran sepanjang hayat dan latihan kemahiran khususnya buat pelajar ITE dan politeknik. Ini agar setiap rakyat berpeluang untuk majukan diri dan perbaiki kehidupan mereka.

Menggulung ucapannya, PM yakin masyarakat Melayu/Islam akan mencatat kejayaan demi kejayaan jika mereka terus bersatu-padu. PM menyeru agar masyarakat Melayu/Islam menjunjung semangat golongan Perintis, perkukuh masyarakat berbilang kaum kita dan memperteguh komitmen untuk membentuk Singapura yang lebih baik buat semua.

Ten years ago today, I was sworn in as PM. 

I am grateful for this opportunity to serve my country and fellow citizens. I learn much from the people I meet, those who write to me, and those following me on social media.  Your views and insights have shown me what we are doing well, and where we need to do better. Your support and engagement means a lot to me.

Thank you too, to the volunteers, grassroots leaders, and supporters who give so generously of your time and energy. You make it much easier for me and the government to do things for Singaporeans. 

Thanks also to ESM Goh, who handed over to me a ship in good shape, and has continued to help me guide it safely, through fair winds and stormy seas.

My team and I will continue to do our best for Singapore. 

- LHL

People often joke that Singaporeans like being first. Last night, I spent time with ones who were first, and truly deserve to be first – 100 members of our Pioneer Generation. They are the first recipients of the PG card, which we launched yesterday. 

The PG card entitles holders to medical benefits for the rest of their lives, and relieves them of any worries over healthcare costs. We will be mailing the card to 450,000 PGs all over Singapore by 1 September, when the scheme begins. 
 
Thank you, pioneers, for building today’s Singapore. - LHL

In the last week, the armed conflict in Gaza has hotted up. Hundreds of people have been killed, mostly civilians, including many children and infants. The loss of innocent lives is tragic and painful. The Middle East is far away, but still we empathise with the pain and suffering of the Palestinian people, because of our common humanity.
 
Alas there is no easy solution. The Israel-Palestinian problem goes back almost a century. The distrust and enmity are mutual, and deep. Yet there is no future in this endless cycle of violence and retribution. 
 
Any lasting solution must begin with restraint and an end to violence, by both sides. I hope all parties will work together to stop this latest episode of violence. 
 
Let's keep the victims of the ongoing conflict in our thoughts and prayers. MUIS is collecting funds for humanitarian assistance to Gaza. Singaporeans have donated generously, and not only Muslims. I hope more concerned Singaporeans will continue showing support in this way. - LHL
 
Konflik bersenjata di Gaza semakin meruncing sepanjang seminggu ini. Ratusan nyawa terkorban, kebanyakannya orang awam termasuk ramai kanak-kanak dan bayi. Korban jiwa mereka yang tidak bersalah dalam jumlah yang besar ini, amat menyayat hati. Walaupun Timur Tengah begitu jauh, kita dapat rasakan kepahitan dan kesengsaraan yang ditanggung rakyat Palestin kerana ikatan kemanusian yang kita semua kongsi bersama.

Tiada huraian mudah. Masalah Israel-Palestin berakar umbi hampir seabad lamanya. Mereka saling tidak mempercayai dan permusuhan begitu mendalam. Lingkaran keganasan dan tindak balas yang tiada penghujung tidak menjanjikan masa depan yang baik untuk rakyat. 

Sebarang huraian jangka panjang mesti bermula dengan kedua-dua pihak menghentikan keganasan. Saya harap semua pihak bekerjasama untuk akhiri gelombang keganasan terbaru ini. 

Marilah kita sama-sama mendoakan kesejahteraan mangsa-mangsa konflik yang sedang berlaku ini. MUIS mengumpul dana bagi bantuan kemanusiaan untuk Gaza. Rakyat Singapura telah menyumbang dengan murah hati termasuk bukan Muslim. Saya harap rakyat Singapura yang prihatin akan terus memberi sokongan mereka melalui cara ini. - LHL

(Those who wish to contribute can do so at donation boxes placed at all mosques till 24 July, or donate online via MUIS' website. / Photo courtesy of MUIS)
Congratulations to Jokowi on his election as Indonesia’s next president. Looking forward to working with him to strengthen Indonesia-Singapore friendship. – LHL

It's the final week of Ramadan. I broke fast with congregants at the Mujahidin Mosque in Queenstown yesterday. The mosque was recently upgraded. The main prayer hall now has more prayer space, and there are better classrooms, and a new lift and ramps.

I was happy to meet CPT (Ret) Hj Shamsudin Shadan, my old SAFTI RSM, again. He is Chairman of Qaryah Kampong Holland, which moved its activities to Mujahidin Mosque from Holland Village. He is 82, but still active!

My appreciation to Mr Khairul Jameel, Chairman of Mujahidin Mosque, his staff and volunteers who hosted my visit. - LHL  

Ramadan sudah masuk minggu terakhir. Saya sertai jemaah di Masjid Mujahidin berbuka puasa semalam. Masjid itu baru dipertingkatkan. Ruang solat utamanya kini boleh menampung lebih ramai jemaah. Ada bilik darjah lebih baik, juga lif dan tanjakan yang serba baru. 

Saya gembira dapat bertemu lagi dengan Kpt (Bersara) Shamsudin Shadan, mantan Sarjan Mejar Regimen SAFTI saya. Beliau adalah Pengerusi Qaryah Kampong Holland, yang kini beroperasi di Masjid Mujahidin dari Masjid Kampong Holland. Usianya 82 tahun tetapi masih tegap!

Terimakasih kepada En Khairul Jameel, Pengerusi Masjid Mujahidin, para pegawai dan sukarelawan masjid yang telah menerima kehadiran saya dengan begitu bersemangat dan baik sekali. - LHL

Happy Racial Harmony Day!

I’m thankful that our society can be diverse and yet cohesive, with people of different races and religions living, working and playing together. The harmony we enjoy is unique and precious. We must never take it for granted. 

A big thank-you to Regentville residents for welcoming me so warmly at your Harmony Night event, and to volunteers participating in the Emergency Preparedness Exercise at Hougang Street 92. Hope all of you will get to know your neighbours better and make your estate a happier and safer place to live in. – LHL

“Not for myself alone” in Latin “Non Mihi Solum”, is Anderson Junior College’s motto. It captured the spirit of Yio Chu Kang Youth Time at AJC.

I met 6 Breakthrough Awards recipients. They included social entrepreneurs (Anders and Daphne), a sportsman scholar (Brandon), an educator (Nizamudeen), a youth volunteer (Yong Hui) and a budding singer (Kexin). I enjoyed talking to them. They shared common traits - daring to dream, being active, seizing opportunities and being selfless. 

The recipients joined me for a dialogue with students and alumni of AJC, plus students from ITE Central. We discussed their concerns and their aspirations for the future. It was a lively hour.

A big thank you to Seng Han Thong for bringing together this youthful energy. – LHL

Low Yen Ling and her residents in Bukit Gombak can look forward to their new ‘home’ in Hillview in 2016. They have worked hard to raise funds to build the new Community Club, and donors and supporters pitched in. Their fund-raising dinner last night raised $2,245,000, exceeding their target.

The Singapore Sports Hub looks great!

Our synchronised swimming team were practising in the Aquatic Centre. One couple was getting a good workout, playing an Xbox Kinect Adventures game in the library. 

Do go down with friends and family one day to check out the facilities. After a game, you can grab a bite at the Kallang Wave mall, and shop at the FairPrice Xtra hypermart. - LHL

Just called Malaysian PM Najib Razak to offer condolences and assistance in the #MH17 crash. It is a terrible tragedy, especially coming after MH370, and we stand in sorrow and solidarity with Malaysia. – LHL

P.S. Have called PM Rutte of the Netherlands to express my condolences too. As several of you pointed out, the flight was code-shared with KLM (as KL4103). 189 of the victims were Dutch. In a country of 16 million, everyone either knows someone on the plane, or knows someone who knows someone. President Barack Obama has said that the aircraft was shot down by a surface-to-air missile from a rebel-held area in East Ukraine. I hope the investigation will establish the cause of the crash soon. – LHL

SSO surprised us with an encore: a vivid orchestral rendition of “Home”, arranged by Kelly Tang. Truly a homecoming. - LHL

The Central Singapore Community Development Council Councillors were appointed today. 

The new Mayor, Ms Denise Phua, showed off some of the CDC’s work with youth. Singapore Polytechnic students regularly visit seniors in Redhill. Peirce Secondary School students learn values through action, doing community projects.  
 
Others like 11-year-old Muhammad Khidhir have blossomed through the CDC’s Free Kicks programme. He was a shy boy, but is now captain of the soccer team and a prefect at Chaoyang School.

The Diplomatic Academy of the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs conferred an honorary doctorate on Mr Lee Kuan Yew two months ago. The Academy’s Rector, Evgeniy Bazhanov, recently wrote about the changes he witnessed first-hand in Singapore. He first came in 1968, as a student learning Chinese at Nanyang University. He returned 20 years later to see a completely different Singapore. The piece (http://bit.ly/1qsHw6T) gives a glimpse of how an outsider sees Singapore’s challenges after Separation, and how he assesses Mr Lee and his government. It is an interesting read. – LHL

(L – R: Prof Bazhanov, Singapore's Ambassador to Russia Ms Lim Kheng Hua, and Chairman of the Association of Russian Diplomats Mr Igor Khalevinsky standing in front of photos of several recipients of the award. Ms Lim had accepted the title on Mr Lee's behalf from Prof Bazhanov in a ceremony held in Moscow./ Photo courtesy of Russian Diplomatic Academy)

Happy 75th birthday Chung Cheng High!

Chung Cheng High has nurtured generations of bilingual and bicultural Singaporeans. They excel in many fields, and have contributed much to Singapore, like artist Mr Lim Tze Peng, banker Mr Wee Cho Yaw and ultra-marathoner Mr Lim Nghee Huat.

We also gazetted Chung Cheng High’s Administration Building and Entrance Arch as national monuments. The Chung Cheng community raised funds over 20 years to build them. These beautiful structures now have a permanent place in our architectural heritage. - LHL

We will consider their views in working out the scheme, so that all Singaporeans are well protected for life. - LHL

DPM Tharman Shanmugaratnam and Minister Tan Chuan-Jin made good speeches on the CPF in Parliament today.

DPM Tharman gave a full account of our CPF returns and investments. It was a comprehensive statement, but the main points are that our CPF monies are safe and earning good returns. Do click on the link below to watch DPM Tharman's replies, or read his speech at http://bit.ly/TPHBGL.

Chuan-Jin explained how the CPF Minimum Sum gives Singaporeans a steady stream of income in retirement. He dispelled some common misunderstandings about the Minimum Sum. e.g. did you know that if you own a house, you don’t need to set aside $155,000 - the full Minimum Sum – in cash, but only half - $77,500, and that you could cover the rest with a property pledge? You can watch Chuan-Jin by clicking on the playlist below, or read his speech at http://bit.ly/1owFDF5.

Our CPF system is sound, and has helped Singaporeans save for their old age. Many countries want to learn from us. But we are not resting on our laurels. We are improving our system to give all Singaporeans peace of mind in their silver years. - LHL

Mr Ee Boon Lee, a veteran journalist, passed away on Sunday. I paid respects at his wake last night after Mr Lim Kim Woon's wake. 
 
Boon Lee spent his life in the media industry. As a young reporter, he accompanied my father overseas, including an epic month-long journey in 1964 to Africa to explain Malaysia to influential African leaders, and another trip to Eastern Europe after Separation to brief them of Singapore’s independent, sovereign status.

He later ran NTUC News and edited the PAP publication Petir. He was a professional journalist, with a good feel for the ground and a knack for getting on with people.
 
I last met Boon Lee at the Pioneer Generation Tribute event in February this year. He was in good spirits; I did not even realise that he was already ill.
 
May Boon Lee rest in peace. – LHL 
 
(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

Very saddened that my old principal, Mr Lim Kim Woon, has passed on. 
 
Mr Lim belonged to our pioneer generation of educators. He was the founding principal of National Junior College. My wife and I were his students in the first two batches. Like many others, we were inspired by his energy, enthusiasm, and concern for our well-being and moral upbringing. Mr Lim left a deep impression on us all, and we stayed in touch with him for decades.
 
I’m glad NJC has set up a “Lim Kim Woon Award”, for the student who best exemplifies NJC’s motto of “Service with Honour”. It is a fitting tribute to Mr Lim’s lifelong passion for serving the community with honour and integrity. 
 
Rest in peace, Mr Lim. - LHL

2014年讲华语运动推展仪式演讲
Speech at the launch of Speak Mandarin Campaign 2014

There is a Chinese saying: “Learning is like sailing against the current; if you do not advance, you will be pushed back.” (学如逆水行舟，不进则退)

It has been 35 years since we launched the Speak Mandarin Campaign. Thanks to the hard work of teachers, Chinese Clans and Associations, our media and many partners, most of our young Chinese Singaporeans can speak Mandarin today. But we must keep at it, and help our children to master two languages – English and their mother tongue. Then they can connect to the world, yet be anchored to their culture. 

With the Internet and online tools, we can easily access all sorts of materials, and get help at our fingertips. I encourage you to make full use of these to learn and improve our Chinese. Do not be pushed back. – LHL

今年是”讲华语运动“的第35周年。我们的双语政策，经过35年的耕耘，取得了相当不错的成绩。有句话说：“学如逆水行舟，不进则退”。因此，我们不能满足于现状，而必须再接再厉，继续推行双语政策，贯彻到底。

现在学习华语再也不单调或枯燥。科技不断的进步，我们可以通过互联网，一点击就能看尽天下的中文材料。同时，碰到生字时，轻轻用滑鼠点击，马上可以看到字的定义、发音、用词、造句等等，不用再翻字典，找部首，算比划，猜四角号码。

有这么多种学习华语的方式， 希望大家会把握机会学好华语！ - 李显龙

We celebrated Mr S R Nathan’s 90th birthday last night.

I have known SR for close to 40 years. Grateful for his friendship, guidance and contributions to Singapore.

SR sowed many seeds which have grown into enduring legacies for Singapore, in the trade union movement, in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and in the young people he took an interest in and groomed. 

One real tree SR planted was this beautiful antique Littleleaf Japanese Maple at our Washington embassy. SR was Ambassador when we moved to this new building. (Snapping a photo to show SR at his birthday dinner. :) )

Happy Birthday SR. May all your trees continue to grow tall and strong. - LHL

The Government has accepted the MediShield Life Review Committee’s proposals. This is a major improvement to our social safety nets. Singaporeans will have more assurance for their medical needs. 

Affordability will not be an issue. Medisave contributions will be enough to pay for MediShield Life premiums. The Ministry of Health will also keep a close eye on medical costs. 

Parliament will debate MediShield Life next week. Looking forward to hearing views from different groups. 

Finally, thank you to Bobby Chin and the MediShield Life Review Committee for a job well done! – LHL

The world is so much more interesting when we are curious.

Learned some fascinating facts and developments on my visit to the Earth Observatory of Singapore today. EOS seeks to understand better how our dynamic planet works, to help us cope with natural disasters. It studies climate, volcanoes, earthquakes, and tsunamis. 

EOS will help Singapore to prepare for climate change. It collaborates with partners in the region, e.g. Indonesia, Myanmar, and the Philippines. We make friends, and also make the world safer for all of us.

Do click on the link to check out some of their interesting projects. :) - LHL

Met President Barack Obama, Vice President Joe Biden, National Security Advisor Ms Susan Rice, and Senators and Congressmen yesterday in D.C. before coming to New York. We reaffirmed our good bilateral ties, and talked about what is happening in our region.
 
New York is abuzz. Its influence is different from Washington's. DC is about political power, but NYC exudes soft power.
 
Singaporeans have been quietly building mindshare and influence here. The Singapore Embassy in Washington DC runs Singapore film showcases and school outreach programmes. These programmes cultivate goodwill among Americans.
 
Will be meeting business leaders and launching the Temasek Holding Office in NYC, before flying back home. :) It has been a productive trip. -  LHL

Speech at reception held to mark the 10th Anniversary of the US-Singapore Free Trade Agreement.

A dark and stormy night isn’t always a bad omen.

In Brunei in 2000, President Bill Clinton and ESM Goh Chok Tong arranged a game of midnight golf after the APEC meetings, but the game was almost washed out by a thunderstorm. Thankfully the skies cleared, and during the game, they agreed to launch the US-Singapore FTA negotiations. 
 
10 years on, the FTA has greatly benefited both countries. We have good reason to celebrate the anniversary. - LHL

Spoke at the Council on Foreign Relations in D.C. on Tuesday. The host for the dialogue was Amb Stapleton Roy. He was US Ambassador to Singapore in the 1980s – an old friend. We talked about security problems, prospects for TPP and Singapore’s role in the region, among other issues.
 
Check out the link below. - LHL

Singapore and the US share many common interests and strong ties.

I spent Monday meeting officials past and present, senators and congressmen. We talked about our bilateral cooperation, and more broadly about the US role in Asia and the world. I welcomed the US deepening its engagement of the Asia-Pacific, including pursuing the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) negotiations.  

The US and Singapore face many challenges. But as President Franklin Roosevelt wrote, just before he died: “The only limit to our realisation of tomorrow will be our doubts of today. Let us move forward with strong and active faith". - LHL

Paid respects to my friend and classmate, Lieutenant General Timothy Maude at the National 9/11 Pentagon Memorial today. He died in the attack on the Pentagon. We attended staff college together at Fort Leavenworth years ago.

Leaving tonight for a week-long trip to Washington DC and New York. The US plays a vital role in the Asia Pacific. We need to nurture our ties with them, and encourage Americans, in government or outside, to remember their many friends and interests in the region.
 
One reason the US is influential and welcome in Asia is its soft power. Other countries admire the US, like their people, and enjoy their culture. Here is a light-hearted example. The New Yorker magazine is famous for its well-written articles and droll cartoons. This piece about a New Yorker cartoonist who has just passed away made me smile. I hope you like it too. – LHL

Congratulations to all the Mayors who swore-in today! Teo Ho Pin, Teo Ser Luck and Maliki Osman have been reappointed. We welcome two new Mayors: Low Yen Ling and Denise Phua, who take over from Amy Khor and Sam Tan. 

CDCs do much to assist the needy, bond the people, and connect the community – “ABC”. Many volunteers serve with CDCs, making a difference to our society. They keep the CDCs close to residents, and help CDCs to run programmes tailored to local needs. 

The Brisk Walking programme of North West CDC is a good example of CDC’s work. Started by Mayor Teo Ho Pin, it has 80,000 members, many of them senior citizens. They enjoy the exercise, the friendship, and the sense of community.

I circulated this article to my colleagues, to remind ourselves to be simple and direct when we communicate with the public. Whether it is an informal conversation, a speech, or a press statement, say what we mean. Avoid management speak or big words which will not impress anyone. Use simple language which people can understand.

On Facebook I always make my posts as simple and clear as possible. Even then from time to time after something has been posted I notice ways to say it better. Then I will change it, which is why you sometimes see that my posts have been edited after posting. (e.g. this one :))

Ministers and the govt have tried hard to be direct and clear in our comms, but once in a while we still fall short. Perhaps someone can set up a website which collects examples, and help us do better! 

– LHL

Came across this thoughtful piece by Andy Mukherjee over the weekend. It explains clearly the issues and trade-offs Singapore faces in building our ideal society, while ensuring that Singaporeans have jobs and economic opportunities to build better lives and a brighter future.
 
As the article points out, we do enjoy important advantages compared to other countries, but it will still not be easy. There are serious trade-offs, which we must be willing to acknowledge and address. If we just pretend that everything can be better, and no hard choices are necessary, we will get into trouble. Mukherjee calls this “please-all economics”, and expresses confidence that Singaporeans are too pragmatic to fall for it. We must make sure that he is right. – LHL

Spent the evening with Dr Intan Mokhtar and her residents at Jalan Kayu Day. Fellow MPs Dr Lam Pin Min and Mr Yeo Guat Kwang also joined us for the festivities. 

We had the famous Jalan Kayu roti prata, of course. But Jalan Kayu is also rich in history. Some residents shared Jalan Kayu’s heritage through a “Memory Lane” exhibition and traditional cultural demonstrations. 

Others, like Ezane and Vincent, are creating new memories and experiences through their photos and paintings. Their creations are inspired by this beautiful mantra: “Let there be love in our hearts, harmony in our homes and peace in our land.” May this hold true not just for Jalan Kayu, but for all of us. 

Thanks Dr Intan for inviting me. I really enjoyed myself. :) -  LHL

Checked out the newly refurbished Victoria Theatre and Concert Hall yesterday. It will be reopening next month, after four years of restoration works. 
 
Victoria Theatre was built in 1862 (as the Town Hall). The Concert Hall was built in 1905 (as Victoria Memorial Hall). The two buildings have been in constant use since colonial days, through the Japanese Occupation, and after Singapore became independent. 

Did you know that Mr Zubir Said originally composed Majulah Singapura for the reopening of Victoria Theatre in 1958, after a major renovation? He then adapted it to become our National Anthem in 1959.
 
The restored venue is now more spacious, with better acoustics. NAC has created modern spaces while retaining the historical elements of the venue. 
 
Looking forward to attending performances at the Victoria Theatre and Concert Hall again soon! – LHL

Happy 45th Birthday NJC!

Caught up with old friends and teachers at National Junior College’s 45th anniversary dinner last night. NJCians have contributed to nation-building over the last four decades.  Some of my classmates are moving into the third age of their lives, becoming grandparents, enjoying retirement and giving time and energy to good causes. 
 
As the first junior college in Singapore, NJC had to overcome many challenges. I was reminded of the old Chinese saying 山不在高，有仙则名；水不在深，有龙则灵。It is not the external form that matters but the substance that counts. NJC still maintains that spirit today.

I joined the pioneer batch of students in their second year in 1970.  You could say I was a “pioneer generation” too (although the NJC pioneer students don’t qualify for the PGP)! :)

NJC exemplifies our efforts to keep paths upwards open to all, and to promote an open and egalitarian society. The college actively seeks out talented students from humble backgrounds, and has no affiliations to primary or secondary schools. It promotes a culture of moderation and restraint, so all students and staff feel comfortable and interact on equal terms with one another. 
 
I wish NJC the very best. May NJC students continue to serve with honour! - LHL

Rest in peace Victor Khoo.

Victor was a well-loved ventriloquist and entertainer. Very sad to learn that he passed away after a long battle with cancer. Victor and his puppet, Charlee, often performed at events I attended, and  I always enjoyed the shows. Charlee was cheeky but remarkably well informed. Racial and religious harmony is Singapore’s precious treasure. 

I was reminded of this today when I met two visitors from Egypt: Sheikh Dr Ali Gomaa, former Grand Mufti of Egypt, and Dr Mouneer Hanna Anis, the Anglican Archbishop (his full title is  Archbishop of the Episcopal/Anglican Diocese of Egypt with North Africa and the Horn of Africa). They are here for the Inter-Religious Relations in Plural Societies programme at S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies, NTU. 

We talked about maintaining harmony in a multi-racial and multi-religious society. Singapore has worked hard at this, as has Egypt. Just from my little time with them, I could see that Sheikh Dr Ali Gomaa and Archbishop Dr Mouneer are good friends, working closely together to promote peace and harmony between Muslims and Christians there. They are a good example of how different faiths can work together for the common good. – LHL

Last night, I attended the Reunion Dinner of the first three batches of the Reservist Officers’ Staff Course. The ROSC was started back in 1982 when I was serving in the SAF. Many of the graduands are old friends and comrades, whom I had not seen in a while. We told old army stories and recalled those we served with, as tends to happen at such affairs. :) The evening ended with a toast to the Republic of Singapore, and Auld Lang Syne.  

We started the ROSC to train reservist (NSmen) officers to take on senior leadership roles in the SAF. Thanks to COL (NS) R Menon, the Commandant of the Singapore Command and Staff College, and his team of directing staff, the ROSC was a resounding success. 

Today the ROSC has become the Command and Staff Course (NS), and the staff college has been named after Dr Goh Keng Swee. But what hasn’t changed is the capability and resolve of our NSmen, and our commitment to them. 

MINDEF recently announced the recommendations of the Committee to Strengthen National Service, including the revamped NS HOME Awards, which will support our NSmen in housing, healthcare and education, and accident insurance. These are small gestures to thank our servicemen for their loyalty and service.  

A big thank you to all! - LHL 
 
(MCI Photo by Kenji)

You may think trolling and flaming is a problem unique to Singapore, but it isn’t. 
 
In Europe, freedom of speech is considered almost a sacred virtue. Yet recently the European Court of Human Rights ruled that when a website publishes a controversial story that may attract defamatory or insulting comments, the website must anticipate this trolling and flaming, and be ready beforehand to remove these comments promptly. 

It is not the last word on the matter. But it reflects how societies are still finding the right balance between freedom of speech and responsible online behaviour. I agree with Minister Yaacob Ibrahim that freedom of speech does not come free from the need to be responsible for what one says, either online or offline. 

This is a tough problem to solve, but we need to develop our own ways to keep online conduct civil and constructive. – LHL

Attended the Opening Ceremony of the World Cities Summit, CleanEnviro Summit Singapore and Singapore International Water Week. This year, the events focused on developing liveable and sustainable cities.

We make modest contributions at these forums by sharing our experience. But we were actually just solving our own problems. :) If others find our solutions interesting, we are happy for them to come take a look. We share our knowledge willingly, because there are no secrets in running cities.

That’s what we did in Suzhou. In 1994, we started a partnership with the Suzhou municipal government to build the Suzhou Industrial Park. This included not just industrial estates, but also housing, infrastructure, urban development and commercial areas. The Park became a very successful model and is celebrating its 20th anniversary this year.

I’m happy Suzhou has won the Lee Kuan Yew World City Prize this year for its outstanding achievements in creating liveable, vibrant and sustainable urban communities. Congrats to Suzhou Mayor, Mr Zhou Naixiang, (shaking hands with me in photo) and the people of Suzhou! - LHL

(MCI Photo by Chwee)

Pleased that Japanese PM Shinzo Abe accepted my invitation to address the Shangri-La Dialogue. Last night, he spoke about Japan’s desire to make proactive contributions to peace. 
 
Today, we met to exchange views on many issues, bilateral and regional. I told him that Singapore would immediately lift restrictions on food imports from Japan. Fukushima peaches and other produce will soon be back in supermarkets. :)
 
Then we had lunch – chicken rice, bento style. Over lunch PM Abe talked about his visit to our two Integrated Resorts yesterday. He is considering legislation to allow such IRs in Japan. I explained how we used social safeguards like the $100 entry levy to protect Singaporeans. 
 
Our ties with Japan are in good shape.
 
- LHL

(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

The Parliament rounded up the debate on the President’s Address today. 
 
When governing a country, we are seldom lucky enough to have simple problems to solve. Usually the problem is complex, and has no perfect solution. Then we need to compromise and accept trade-offs. 

Take the CPF for example. As Tan Chuan-Jin told MPs yesterday, the CPF has served many of our housing, medical and retirement needs. But people are living longer, and their retirement needs will grow. How can CPF provide adequately for them? Who will bear the costs? We have been thinking about this for some time, together with the Pioneer Generation Package. By the National Day Rally, I should be ready to share more. 
 
Thanks to all of you who have written on this page to express your support (e.g., Suhana Ismail, Chun Zheng), especially those who wrote on the vital question of keeping politics constructive. 

The debate is over, but we will continue discussing and working on these issues outside of Parliament. I hope more people, including our youths, can be part of the “problem-solving-democracy” Lawrence Wong talked about. That is the way to build a better Singapore for everyone. 
 
- LHL

Spoke in Parliament this afternoon. I reported the progress we had made since the 2011 elections. We have stabilised house prices, improved public transport, and managed the inflow of immigrants and foreign workers. 

I explained our agenda for the rest of this govt’s term. We will keep Singapore a leading city in the world, where every citizen can lead a fulfilling life. We are strengthening social safety nets, such as with MediShield-Life, and improving retirement adequacy. We must also remain an open and mobile community, so every citizen has the opportunity to do well whatever their family backgrounds. 

I also explained what constructive politics means: effective policies, good leaders, robust debates, high standards of integrity, and staying united despite our differences. Leaders must take a stand, and take responsibility for what they say and do.

After my speech Mr Low Thia Khiang rose to contest what I had said. We had a vigorous exchange. I explained my view that the opposition fell short of their role in Parliament. Naturally Mr Low found reasons to disagree.

My government will keep on working with Singaporeans to build a better future for ourselves and our families. - LHL

Glad many MPs spoke in support of the President’s Address on the first day of the debate. Many, especially govt MPs, offered ideas to improve or change policies.

MPs generally supported the Government’s plans to improve people’s lives. But they had specific suggestions to help different groups of people. Some wanted more support for professionals, managers and executives (PMEs). Others suggested improvements to the CPF system to give older Singaporeans peace of mind in their retirement. Several urged more help for the lower-income and disadvantaged groups. We will look into these suggestions carefully.

Constructive politics is key to realising our dreams. The purpose of politics is to make a difference to people’s lives, to build a better Singapore. Politics purely for the sake of power, without any notion of what we want Singapore to become, will lead us to disaster.

This clip shows an exchange between Mr Low Thia Khiang and SMS Indranee Rajah on this important point.

Look forward to hearing more views tomorrow. I will be speaking on Wednesday. - LHL

A ship sailing off for a weekend cruise. Took this from Labrador Park, whose Malay name is Tanjong Berlayer. Tanjong means land’s end or a cape, and Berlayer means to sail. 

 For hundreds of years ships have been leaving Singapore harbour past Tanjong Berlayer, and people on shore have been watching them sail off, and wishing them a safe voyage. – LHL

P.S. Some of you have asked about the spelling of the Malay name. The modern (baku) spelling is indeed “Tanjung Berlayar”. But traditionally the placename was written as “Tanjong Berlayer”, and I followed this. – LHL

I saw this piece about telcos in the US offering a Text-to-911 (like our 999) service, so that instead of calling 911, people can SMS emergency call takers (http://tcrn.ch/1vfatqR). This will be very useful to callers who can’t speak or hear.  
 
I asked if we could do the same, and was glad to learn that we are already doing so. The Singapore Police Force has the SMS 70999 Emergency Service (http://www.spf.gov.sg/sms70999/). Those with hearing and speech impairments can register for it.

Spent the weekend at the ASEAN Summit in Myanmar. We reviewed the progress of the ASEAN community, which we aim to achieve by December 2015.

We also discussed the maritime disputes in the South China Sea, including the latest incidents involving Vietnam and China.

I am glad the Foreign Ministers issued a statement on this. ASEAN cannot ignore major events happening on its doorstep, and still expect to be taken seriously by the world. 

Transboundary haze was another item. We need to work together in ASEAN on this and other shared problems, even though progress is not always easy. 

A big thank you to President Thein Sein and the people of Myanmar for their gracious and warm hospitality. This is Myanmar’s first time hosting an ASEAN summit. They’ve done a great job, and we’ll continue to support them in any way we can. - LHL

Met Phua Yoke Swee, my PMO staff, this evening to thank him for his long service. He is retiring after serving for 48 years, the last 22 in PMO. (But only half – he will be back on a half-time basis, to continue helping us out.)

Yoke Swee is one of the pioneer generation civil servants who helped to build Singapore from our early years. He started work as a clerk aged 18 in 1966, a year after Singapore became independent. He upgraded himself attending part-time courses in the Adult Education Board, and became an Executive Officer.

Deeply saddened by the passing of Ustaz Ibrahim Kassim. He contributed much to the Muslim community and Singapore. 

When I held a dialogue with Malay/Muslim leaders on the tudung issue in January, Ustaz Ibrahim made a special effort to attend, even though he was ill. I was touched when he later wrote to me to support what I had said, and to reaffirm his commitment to serving the community despite his health. 

I met him again at the Pioneer Generation Tribute event in February – frail but happy to be there. That was our last meeting.

Like others of his generation, Ustaz Ibrahim overcame difficult circumstances to help build a harmonious, multi-racial society. He was a strong supporter of the Religious Rehabilitation Group, serving as a counsellor for more than a decade.

His passing is a great loss to us all. May he rest in peace. – LHL

I came across this interesting piece about how the Chinese language is changing in China. People are using English words in spoken and written Chinese directly, without translating them into Chinese equivalents, or even transliterating them into similar sounding Chinese characters.  It is easier to say GDP than 国内生产总值, and Wifi is Wifi. 

This is causing controversy in China. Some think it is the practical thing to do – everybody knows what Wifi is, so why invent some unfamiliar Chinese term for the same thing? But others feel that the pure Chinese language is being polluted with foreign words. After all, some translations have been successful – Coca Cola 可口可乐 has a very appropriate meaning, and translating email into 电邮 is neat and succinct.

The same thing is happening to other languages too. If you listen to Malay spoken in Malaysia, or Tamil in India, you will often hear English words mixed in.

The reality is that a language is a live, changing thing. It constantly absorbs words, concepts and usages from foreign languages, so long as people are using it in their daily lives. Otherwise it becomes a dead language, studied by scholars but not spoken by ordinary people anymore, like Latin or Sanskrit.

We pay a lot of attention to languages in Singapore. We are doing our utmost to keep our mother tongues alive. These are live languages to be used, so we should accept that they will evolve and change over time. We need to speak and write them correctly, but also colloquially. Then we will really be cool, or as we say in Mandarin, 酷! :)

- LHL

Saddened to learn that Dr Dixie Tan, former MP for Ulu Pandan, had passed on. 
 
Dixie and I were from the same batch of MPs. We entered Parliament together in 1984. For many years before that, all the MPs had been male. Dixie, along with Dr Aline Wong and Mdm Yu-Foo Yee Shoon, were the only female MPs elected that year. They more than held their own, and stood out in the House.
 
Dixie was a hardworking MP who cared for her residents and spoke up for them in Parliament. She retired in 1991 to pursue a second career as a family and marriage therapist. She told me she derived great satisfaction from this. It was in keeping with her temperament and concern for others.
 
She was also an active volunteer. She founded the Association for Educationally Subnormal Children (later renamed the Association for Persons with Special Needs), and was Adviser to the Singapore Bank Employees’ Union. She received the Public Service Star for her community contributions, before she became an MP.
 
Dixie impressed with her quiet self-confidence, good sense, and gentle resolve. She spoke softly, but pressed with conviction for what she believed in. Although her sons had special needs, and needed her love and care, she was able to fulfil her public as well as family roles amply.
 
May Dixie rest in peace.
 
- LHL

[With Dr Dixie Tan (left) in September 1984, when we were preparing to stand for election. The late Mr Ong Teng Cheong had invited us to dinner at his home, where the picture was taken. / Photo credit: Ong Teng Cheong Collection, courtesy of National Archives of Singapore]

Started the day with a pleasant walk and breakfast at Gardens by the Bay with HM the Sultan of Brunei.

When I visited Brunei in 2012, the Sultan took me up a hilltop tower to take in a spectacular view of Tasek Lama Park. Today, I returned his favour with a bird’s eye view of the Marina district from the Gardens by the Bay Skyway and Cloud Forest. Glad he enjoyed it. 

The Sultan is here on his third state visit. His visit reaffirms our warm relationship and cooperation in finance, education, defence, health, and other areas. 

May our ties continue to grow and strengthen in future generations, like the Kapur Paji tree that the Sultan and I planted this morning! - LHL

Met Hu Chunhua, the Party Secretary of Guangdong Province, for the first time today. He is spending three days here. He has visited Buona Vista community club, attended a Meet-the-People session with Chan Chun Sing and toured the Marina Bay Sands. He told me his visit has given him a better sense of how Singapore works, and what makes us tick.

Guangdong has transformed itself in the last 20 years. They talk about 腾笼换鸟 – clearing the cage and changing the bird, meaning changing from old industries to new ones; and 凤凰涅磐 – being reborn like the Phoenix from the ashes, meaning reinventing and upgrading the economy. Singapore is travelling on this path too. So I had a very good discussion with Hu, sharing our experiences and exchanging notes. 

Singapore enjoys extensive cooperation with Guangdong province. The Sino-Singapore Guangzhou Knowledge City project is progressing well. A large part of our trade and investment with China is actually with Guangdong. 

I look forward to visiting Guangdong in September, and seeing its progress since my last visit in 2006. – LHL

今天很高兴与广东省委书记胡春华初次见面。胡书记这次的三日行，是要进一步了解新加坡在治国和发展方面的具体情况。在陈振声部长的陪同下，胡书记参观了波那维斯达民众俱乐部，观察了议员接见选民，也到滨海湾看一看。过去20年，广东不断的改进，好比腾笼换鸟，凤凰涅磐。这也是新加坡的发展经历。胡书记和我谈得很投入，我们互相交换意见，分享不同的经验。

新加坡和广东省有密切的合作关系，中国与新加坡的重点合作项目中新广州知识城,进展顺利。新加坡在中国的贸易还有投资，有相当大的部分是在广东省。我今年九月将有机会再走访广东。上一次到广东是2006年，我很期待看到新的广东。

I was appalled to read about those who harassed the organisers of the Philippine Independence Day celebrations, and spammed their Facebook page. They are a disgrace to Singapore.

Fortunately this appears to be the work of few trolls. Heartened that many sensible Singaporeans condemn this thuggish behaviour, and support Tan Chuan-Jin’s stand on this issue <http://on.fb.me/1ml0Y4u>. 

We must treat people in Singapore the way we ourselves expect to be treated overseas. Many Singaporeans live overseas, and are warmly welcomed in their adopted homes. I just attended our Singapore Day in London. How would we have felt if British netizens had spammed our website, and abused Singaporeans living in Britain?

We must show that we are generous of spirit and welcome visitors into our midst, even as we manage the foreign population here. Otherwise we will lower our standing in the eyes of the world, and have every reason to be ashamed of ourselves. – LHL

The Yong Siew Toh Conservatory of Music turned 10 this year. It has nurtured many budding musicians, who put on exciting performances of Beethoven’s Triple Concerto & Mahler’s Fifth Symphony at the Esplanade Concert Hall last night.

Today is Good Friday, and the beginning of Easter weekend. Christians commemorate the death of Jesus Christ today, and his resurrection on Easter Sunday. 

I took this pic in the Church of Our Saviour on the Spilled Blood in St Petersburg, Russia, whose walls are covered with intricate mosaic pictures of biblical scenes. It is of course a Russian Orthodox Church, which in some years celebrates Easter later than the Western churches, because it uses a different calendar. But this year the two dates for Easter coincide. 

I wish all Christians a blessed Easter weekend. - LHL

Parliament prorogues (i.e. takes a mid-term break) today until 16 May. 

Parliament has been busy these past 2½ years. We have had vigorous and valuable debates on our White Papers on Ministerial Salaries and Population. We have passed Budgets that include major economic and social policies, including the Pioneer Generation Package, GST Vouchers, and Workfare enhancements. MPs have filed many questions to obtain information, press for actions, and solve their voters’ problems.

Parliament is where the most important national issues are debated and decided. Our sittings are not as fiery as some other legislatures, but the duty of government is to manage affairs responsibly and soberly, and not to create entertainment and excitement.

Singapore is in transition. We are adjusting to new domestic needs while navigating an uncertain international environment. When Parliament re-opens on 16 May, we will hear the President’s Address, and discuss strategies for creating a brighter future and a better Singapore for all. - LHL

Had an engaging dialogue yesterday on the Budget with 200 YEC members, and students from secondary schools, ITE, Polytechnic and JC from AMK GRC and Sengkang West. My fellow MPs Lam Pin Min, Seng Han Thong, Intan Mokhtar and Ang Hin Kee were on the panel too. 

The students had interesting perspectives on this Budget and shared ideas on what they would like to see next year.

I explained to them that the purpose of the Budget is to decide on where and how the Government is going to raise and spend its money for the year. 

This year, we had two main goals:

First, we want to grow our economy, to create more and better jobs for Singaporeans, and to give citizens more opportunities to upgrade themselves and improve their lives.

Second, we are building a fair and equitable society. The Budget contains schemes to help people afford medical treatment, public transport, education, housing, etc. It also recognises our Pioneer Generation through a special healthcare package (http://www.singaporebudget.gov.sg/budget_2014/pgp.aspx). 

I’m glad to see our youths taking an interest in the Budget and participating in this dialogue. I hope they found the Sunday afternoon well-spent, as I did. Thank you to Cheng San CC Youth Club for hosting our session. - LHL

Was saddened to hear of the passing of Abdul Ghani Abdul Hamid, a member of our Pioneer Generation. 

Pak Ghani made significant contributions to Singapore’s arts and cultural heritage. He was an accomplished writer, poet and artist. Several of his works have been translated into English and Chinese. He helped set up Perkumpulan Seni and Angkatan Pelukis Aneka Daya (APAD), both well-known names in the Malay visual and performance arts scene.
 
For his contributions, Pak Ghani was conferred the prestigious Anugerah Tun Seri Lanang in 1998 and the Cultural Medallion in 1999. 
 
My condolences to the family during this sorrowful time. – LHL

Saya sedih menerima berita pemergian Encik Abdul Ghani Abdul Hamid, salah seorang anggota Golongan Perintis kita. 

Pak Ghani telah membuat sumbangan besar, mencorak dan memperkaya warisan budaya dan kesenian Singapura.
 
Beliau adalah seorang penulis, penyair dan pelukis tersohor yang amat disegani. Beberapa karya beliau telah diterjemahkan ke Bahasa Inggeris dan Cina. Beliau juga telah membantu mengasas Perkumpulan Seni dan Angkatan Pelukis Aneka Daya (APAD), kedua-duanya pertubuhan penting yang mewarnai arena seni persembahan dan seni lukisan Melayu.
 
Pengorbanan dan sumbangan Pak Ghani telah mendapat pengiktirafan tertinggi melalui Anugerah Tun Seri Lanang (1998) dan Pingat Budaya (1999) 
 
Dengan seikhlas hati, saya mengucapkan salam takziah kepada keluarga Pak Ghani atas pemergian beliau. – LHL

I visited the School of Science and Technology, Singapore (SST) this morning. Made me wish I was back in school again!

SST is a specialised independent school. It offers students an active applied learning environment, with many ‘hands-on’ experiences. 

I joined students in a maths class in measuring the cooling curve of a potato in ice water, using a temperature probe and a graphic calculator.

Students study applied subjects such as Biotechnology, Media Studies, Fundamentals of Electronics and Design Studies. SST is one of many paths open to our students, depending on their interests and talents.

The students who showed me their projects were confident and enthusiastic. Glad they are having such fun in school! – LHL

Who says Singaporean students are rote learners? The OECD's PISA study ranked us tops in problem solving, meaning our students can handle complex challenges creatively and well. 

Congratulations to our students, as well as to the teachers and principals who are educating them! It shows that we are on the right track, but I don’t think we can afford to relax. 

Students need to make the most of what schools offer, to gain not just deep skills, but also the tools to think flexibly. These will help you to tackle many uncertainties and unexpected problems in life.

Visited Luxembourg for the first time today. It is a beautiful country with many historic buildings. 

PM Xavier Bettel gave me a very warm welcome. After lunch, he took me on an impromptu walking tour of the city. He knew it well, and was very proud of it. He had been mayor of the city until he was elected PM just three months ago.

Luxembourg has four times our land area but one tenth our population. Its neighbours are much larger - Belgium to its west and north, Germany to the east, and France to the south. 

Luxembourg depends on many foreign workers who live in these neighbouring countries. In fact, for every worker of its own, Luxembourg has two foreign workers! 

As small states, Luxembourg and Singapore share similar views of the world. PM Bettel and I agreed that we can do much more together. I look forward to working with him to enhance our bilateral relations. - LHL

The Nuclear Security Summit ended today. We are doing our part to strengthen the international framework for nuclear safety and security. We will accede to the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material (CPPNM). We are also committed to counter-proliferation and preventing the illicit trafficking of Weapons of Mass Destruction (WMD) and their means of delivery.

Had good discussions with several leaders on the sidelines of the Summit, including US President Barack Obama, Chinese President Xi Jinping and German Chancellor Angela Merkel.

My first meeting this morning was with Chancellor Merkel. I thanked her for Germany’s support for the EU-Singapore FTA. She invited me to visit Berlin next year, to mark the 50th Anniversary of diplomatic relations between Singapore and Germany. I immediately accepted. 

Off to Luxembourg tomorrow morning. – LHL

Mr Lee Kuan Yew said in 1962: “The acid test of any legal system is not the greatness or grandeur of its ideal concepts, but whether in fact it is able to produce order and justice in the relationships between man and man and between man and the State”. 

This is still true today. 

Last night I attended the Legal Service Dinner. These officers support our ministries, staff the Attorney General’s Chambers, and run the courts. Their work has become heavier and more complex over time. We now have nearly 600 Legal Officers.  

We are introducing two separate career tracks for mid-level officers to specialise – a Legal Track (ministry and AG’s Chambers work) and a Judicial Track (court work). 

I hope that our Legal Service will remain firmly anchored to our values, understand our circumstances and needs, and contribute to Singapore’s continued success. – LHL

Received this heart warming message and photo from Rowan (age 6). Kindness is alive and well in Singapore.

Thank you to all who have written thoughtful comments, and shared your positive (as well as not so positive) experiences in response to my post on graciousness. 

Some have offered useful advice: if you really need a seat, just ask for it, and if someone gives up a seat for you, please smile and say thank you. 

Being kind goes beyond giving up seats. It is about adopting a mindset to be considerate and sensitive to others’ needs, and showing appreciation when others have been kind to us. 

Better still, pay it forward. Rowan’s message made me smile, just like the elderly woman who shared her seat with him put a smile on Rowan’s face. Do something nice for someone today, and put a smile on their face! :) – LHL

I shared this BBC article (http://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-26546169) with my colleagues. The writer described how when she was pregnant and had severe morning sickness in an MRT train, people ignored her and nobody offered her a seat. Tan Chuan-Jin (http://on.fb.me/NgHila) and Lawrence Wong (http://on.fb.me/1cIUbk1) commented on the article yesterday.

We needn’t accept everything the writer says. But her article is still a good reminder to us to be kinder and more gracious to one another.

It takes effort from each of us, but it is important and worthwhile. Our pace of life is fast, and we all feel the pressures of living in a city. But all the more we should try harder to respect and help one another. It will make life more pleasant for all of us. – LHL

Met Residents’ Committee volunteers from all over Singapore this afternoon at the National Residents’ Committee (RC) Convention.

We wrapped up the Committee of Supply debate today. MPs spent 7 days going through the Ministries one by one, questioning ministers, raising issues, and championing ideas they feel passionate about. 

My thanks to all MPs for their active participation, and to ministers for working hard to listen, reassure, and explain. I am heartened by the general support for Budget 2014. 
 
Yesterday and today, Gan Kim Yong and Chan Chun Sing explained how we are strengthening social safety nets so that no one gets left behind. One key initiative is MediShield Life, which will cover every Singaporean, throughout his or her life.

Premiums for MediShield Life will be affordable for all, especially the elderly and the low-income. 
 
The Govt will bear most of the initial costs of universal coverage under MediShield Life. We will also introduce permanent subsidies for lower- to middle-income groups. For those who despite this help can’t afford their remaining share of premiums, Medifund will provide additional assistance. 
 
After all the subsidies, most households should be able to pay their MediShield premiums using just half of their Medisave contributions. 

Lower- to middle-income households should pay either the same or less premiums for MediShield Life as they are paying for MediShield today. 

The Pioneer Generation will be fine too. Effectively, those aged 80 and above today will have their premiums fully covered. Younger Pioneers (aged 65 – 79) on MediShield today will pay half of current premiums, but get better coverage. 
 
MediShield Life depends on everyone chipping in to share the burden, to take collective responsibility to protect one another. While MediShield Life gives us peace of mind for our health costs, let’s all do our part to stay healthy and avoid getting sick. This is the best way to keep health costs low, live long and live well.
 
- LHL

(Families enjoying one of our parks. / Photo courtesy of www.singapore.sg)

MPs discussed housing, transport, arts and heritage, and the environment yesterday and today in the Committee of Supply. Here are a few highlights.

Khaw Boon Wan shared plans to look into more ways for elderly residents to monetise their HDB flats, to support vulnerable families (e.g. divorcees with children), to enable more extended families to live near one another. MND had fewer cuts (items raised by MPs for discussion) this year than previous years, which hopefully shows that people are less worried about housing!

Lui Tuck Yew described what we are doing to reduce train disruptions, and cut waiting and travel time. We have bought more trains and will put more buses on the road, so as to service commuters better, especially during peak periods. 

Lawrence Wong announced plans to build more sports facilities all over the island, so that most Singaporeans will have sports facilities a short walk from home. The National Museum will have a new Wing, Play@NMS, dedicated to children and young families. We hope young Singaporeans will visit the Museum often, and grow up with fond memories of the Museum. (As I do – my grandmother used to regularly take me and my siblings to the National Museum. :) )

Vivian Balakrishnan announced an updated PSI index that takes into account PM 2.5 pollution, and an International Advisory Panel to advise the Government on what it can do about the haze under international law.

These are not easy issues, but if we continue working at them, we’ll continue improving our living environment and keeping Singapore a liveable city and an endearing home. 

- LHL

Paid my respects at the wake of Mr Lee Gek Seng, a founding member of the PAP.

Mr Lee was a union leader of the Singapore Postal and Telecoms Employees Union. He had helped to found the union in 1947. 

During the postmen’s strike in 1952, he worked with Mr Lee Kuan Yew, who was the union’s legal advisor.

So when Mr Lee Kuan Yew launched the PAP in Nov 1954, Mr Lee Gek Seng was in the first pro-tem Central Executive Committee, and later served as Deputy Secretary General.

Mr Lee was a community leader for many years in Jalan Besar, and later in Toa Payoh. MPs he worked with included Mr Chan Chee Seng and Dr Lee Boon Yang.

I had just met Mr Lee at the Pioneer Generation Tribute at the Istana last month. He came in a wheelchair, but was clearly very happy to be there. Now he has left us. 

– LHL

To create better jobs paying higher wages, and to build a fair and equitable society, we are restructuring our economy.

We are tightening up on foreign workers, and helping businesses to improve productivity. It is not always easy for businesses to keep up, especially our small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). 

But we must press on. We are helping our businesses upgrade in practical ways. Here are some schemes we talked about in Parliament.

(Lim Hng Kiang) The Nanyang Additive Manufacturing Centre at NTU has the latest 3D printers which can print metal objects and even human tissue. It will do R&D projects together with businesses, to develop commercial applications for this technology. 

(Teo Ser Luck) JTC is developing a hub for incubators and start-ups in promising industries like biomedical sciences, electronics and engineering. JTC LaunchPad@one-north will be a common space for like-minded entrepreneurs to share ideas and make deals. 
 
(Tan Chuan-Jin) New technologies like data analytics, robotics and 3D are taking off. We will educate and train you, to master the knowledge and skills, seize the opportunities, and build rewarding careers. 

Singapore will always be a nation of opportunity for all of us. - LHL
