During the Budget debate, we always pay attention to local issues – healthcare, housing, public transport. But we must not lose sight of what is happening in the outside world, and how faraway events can affect us. Take for example the crisis in Ukraine, which Minister K Shanmugam Sc talked about in his speech yesterday (http://bit.ly/1e1SDg7). 

Ukraine is bigger than Singapore, but much smaller than its neighbour, Russia. For the last few months, the country has been in turmoil. Two weeks ago, President Yanukovich fled, and his pro-Russian government collapsed. Russian troops then intervened in the Crimea, a part of Ukraine that used to belong to Russia, and where Russia still has a naval base. 

If war breaks out in Ukraine, the global economy will be affected, and so will ours. We condemn any unprovoked invasion of a sovereign country, whatever the pretext. All countries, big and small, must observe international law. This is vital to a small country like Singapore. 

Russia is a nuclear power. Ukraine signed a treaty in 1994 with Russia, the US and UK to give up its nuclear weapons, in exchange for which the US and Russia agreed not to use force against Ukraine. Yet Ukraine is in this predicament today. 

The Ukraine crisis reminds us that small countries must defend themselves, and cannot rely solely on international treaties or the promises of others. That is why we must always maintain a strong SAF and Home Team. We must also have a capable MFA to strengthen our ties with friends and allies. Only then can Singapore be safe and secure.

- LHL

Read transcript of Budget 2014 Debate Round-Up Speech by DPM & Minister for Finance Tharman Shanmugaratnam at http://bit.ly/1ncyERW or watch the speech at http://bit.ly/1q8OyiG

I’m glad this year’s Budget has been well received. MPs from both sides of the House supported the Budget, especially the Pioneer Generation Package. They shared stories of their own parents or grandparents, who belonged to the special generation which built Singapore. They made useful suggestions to improve the Package and other Budget initiatives. We will consider their ideas carefully.

The govt can afford the Pioneer Generation Package because we have been careful with our finances. But govt spending is going up – on healthcare, infrastructure, and an ageing population. We are alright for the next few years. Beyond that, we must think about raising more revenues. 

We must never fall into the same hole as so many other countries, spending more than they earn, dragging down the economy and burdening future generations. If we keep our economy vibrant, and live within our means, we can continue providing assurance to all, while keeping ours a nation of opportunities. – LHL

Was saddened to learn of the passing of another Pioneer Generation leader, Mr Chua Sian Chin, who was an MP and Minister for many years. 

Like quite a few others, he was born in Malaya, in his case Malacca, but came to Singapore to seek his future and make his home. While studying law in London, he met Mr Lee Kuan Yew, who was speaking to the Singapore and Malayan students there. Later he recounted what a profound impression Mr Lee made on him and his fellow students.

Mr Chua held several important appointments in the Cabinet from 1968 to 1984 – Health, Home Affairs, Education. As MP for MacPherson for 23 years, he groomed many grassroots volunteers, including several who have continued serving till today.

Mr Chua’s passing is a sad loss to us all. Our thoughts are with his family during this time of sorrow. – LHL

Was sorry to learn of the passing of Haji Mohamed Ariff Suradi. He belonged to our Pioneer Generation of leaders, who set Singapore on the path of growth and success.

Hj Mohamed Ariff was a Legislative Assemblyman while we were in Malaysia, and then a Member of Parliament after we became independent. He served in Ulu Pandan and later Kampong Kembangan. Those were tumultuous times, with racial riots, and strong ethnic tensions. Because Hj Mohamed Ariff and the other PAP Malay leaders of his generation stood firm, and supported the PAP’s vision of a multi-racial Singapore, we were able to build the harmonious society that we have today.

When we held the Pioneer Generation Tribute event at the Istana a few weeks ago, I had asked if Hj Mohamed Ariff could come, but was told that he was unwell and could not make it. His passing marks another step in the passage of generations.

Our condolences to Hj Mohamed Ariff’s family. May he rest in peace. – LHL

Saya berdukacita dengan pemergian Haji Mohamed Ariff Suradi. Beliau tergolong di kalangan Generasi Pemimpin Perintis kita yang mengorak langkah untuk Singapura mencapai kemajuan dan kejayaan.

Hj Mohamed Ariff merupakan Anggota Dewan Perundangan ketika kita sebahagian dari Malaysia dan kemudian seorang Anggota Parlimen selepas kita merdeka. Beliau telah berkhidmat di Ulu Pandan dan kemudian Kampong Kembangan. Keadaan begitu getir ketika itu dengan rusuhan kaum dan hubungan antara kaum yang tegang. Namun berkat keteguhan Hj Mohamed Ariff dan para pemimpin Melayu PAP lain yang seangkatan dengannya, menyokong visi Singapura yang berbilang bangsa, kita mampu membina masyarakat harmoni yang kita nikmati hari ini.

Ketika kami mengadakan majlis menjunjung budi Generasi Perintis di Istana beberapa minggu lalu, saya bertanya jika beliau boleh hadir tetapi saya diberitahui beliau uzur dan tidak dapat hadir. Pemergian beliau adalah satu lagi petanda peralihan generasi.

Opened the Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) Terminal at Jurong Island yesterday. We first decided to import LNG in 2006 – both to fulfil our growing demand, and to make us less vulnerable by diversifying our sources. 
 
More than 90% of our electricity is now generated from natural gas. Previously, when the gas came by pipeline, we only had two sources – Malaysia and Indonesia. With the LNG Terminal, we can now ship in natural gas from around the world, and obtain better prices.
 
Singapore LNG Corp (SLNG) operates the terminal. SLNG is sponsoring employees for further studies, and will also offer scholarships for ITE and Polytechnic students. I met some of their young engineers yesterday. They were enthusiastic about this pioneering project, and proud to have developed the Terminal from scratch and helped grow the business. - LHL

King Abdullah also met business leaders, academics, educators and civil servants here. His visit has taken the excellent relations between Jordan and Singapore another step forward. - LHL

DPM Tharman Shanmugaratnam presented Budget 2014 this afternoon. It acknowledges our debt to the Pioneer Generation, and helps to prepare our economy and society for the future. 

The Budget gives specifics of the Pioneer Generation Package that I announced two weeks ago. These men and women made great sacrifices to build today’s Singapore. Now, it’s our turn to take care of them. 

There are enhanced schemes to help companies (especially SMEs) upgrade, adopt IT, and raise productivity.

Employer CPF contributions will go up, to help build up our Medisave savings. 

Healthcare will become more affordable. Lower- and middle-income patients will enjoy higher subsidies for outpatient care at polyclinics and specialist outpatient clinics.

We will give more support to disabled children and their families, through early intervention programmes. 

A GST voucher – Cash for Seniors, U-Save top-ups and S&CC rebates, will help households with the cost of living.

I hope we can work together and embrace the “can-do”, resilient and united spirit of our Pioneer Generation to achieve the best for Singapore. 
 
Budget 2014 contains much more. Visit www.Singaporebudget.gov.sg for more details of the schemes and incentives, and how you can benefit from them. – LHL

Happy to be back in NTU to speak at the Ministerial Forum organised by the Students’ Union. With Singapore's 50th birthday around the corner, I shared with the students what I felt the future held for them and for Singapore, especially with the opportunities presented by a rising Asia and new technology breakthroughs.  The possibilities are limitless but so there will be challenges too, including to our social and cultural norms. 

I told the students that many of them would be here to witness Singapore's 100th anniversary. I asked them to think how they could make the most of their next 50 years. 

Some students I met are already making a difference, like Sally Yap, an NTU PhD student who is helping to develop a vaccine for malaria, and four Communication Studies students who’ve started The Real Reunion, a campaign to encourage families to bond over meals. Keep up your good work!  

To all who attended, thank you for your frank and lively views. Seize the day, and let’s work together to build a Singapore which we can all be proud of. Thanks too to NTUSU for inviting students from other universities to the forum. – LHL

PM Lee Hsien Loong speaking to the media, after his dialogue with Malay/Muslim community leaders on the tudung issue, on 25 January 2014.
PM Lee Hsien Loong bercakap kepada media di akhir sesi dialog dengan wakil masyarakat Melayu/Islam mengenai isu tudung pada 25 Januari 2014.

The issue of wearing the tudung (headscarf in Malay) by Muslim women is an important matter for many Muslims in Singapore. This evening I met community and religious leaders, together with some Ministers and MPs, for a candid and fruitful dialogue. Snapped this pic of the participants at the end – all in good spirits! 

I told the group that I fully appreciate their desire to allow Muslim women in uniform to wear the tudung. But a larger issue is at stake: the sort of society we aspire to be. Singapore is a multi-racial, multi-religious and harmonious society. Minorities are fully integrated into the mainstream, but have full opportunities to maintain their identities and practise their faiths. So I am also mindful how crucial it is for us to strengthen our cohesion, and maintain the relaxed confidence and trust that benefits us all, especially the minorities.

On the tudung issue, the position is not frozen. Attitudes will shift and arrangements will get updated. We have gradually evolved over the last decade. Many statutory boards now have uniforms that allow Muslim staff to wear the tudung, e.g., LTA, NEA. In 5, 10 years’ time, I am confident that we will not be in the same situation as today.

It is best that we continue evolving gradually and carefully. The racial harmony we enjoy is not perfect, but it is more precious and more fragile than we think. Let’s work hard to strengthen it, so that all races can live happily together as one united people. – LHL

Isu tudung adalah isu penting bagi ramai orang Islam di Singapura. Petang tadi saya dan beberapa Menteri serta Anggota Parlimen telah bertemu dengan wakil-wakil masyarakat dan pemimpin agama. Perbincangan kami berlangsung secara terus terang, dan dari hati ke hati. Lihat gambar para peserta yang saya petik di akhir sesi – semuanya dalam semangat muhibbah! 

Saya tekankan kepada para peserta bahawa saya akur hasrat mereka untuk membenarkan wanita Islam di sektor seragam memakai tudung. Tetapi isu lebih besar harus difikirkan: Apakah bentuk masyarakat yang kita inginkan? 

Singapura adalah sebuah masyarakat berbilang bangsa dan agama yang harmoni. Kaum minoriti sebati dengan masyarakat lebih besar tetapi memiliki peluang sepenuhnya untuk kekalkan identiti dan amalkan agama masing-masing. Jadi saya sedar betapa gentingnya untuk memperkukuh ikatan kita bersama dan mengekalkan keyakinan dan kepercayaan yang mendatangkan manfaat untuk kita semua, lebih-lebih lagi kaum minoriti.

Dalam isu tudung, keadaan yang kita lihat hari ini tidak akan kekal begini. Sikap akan berubah dan dikemaskinikan. Sepanjang sedekad lalu, ada kemajuan yang bertahap dalam isu ini. Kini, banyak badan berkanun membenarkan kakitangan mereka memakai tudung bersama pakaian seragam misalnya LTA, NEA. Dalam 5, 10 tahun lagi, saya yakin keadaan akan berubah, tidak seperti hari ini. 

Sebaiknya kita terus bergerak secara bertahap dan berhati-hati. Sesungguhnya keharmonian kaum yang kita nikmati tidak sempurna, ia sebenarnya lebih rapuh dan berharga dari apa yang kita sedari. 

Ayuh kita berusaha gigih untuk memperkukuhkannya supaya semua kaum boleh hidup bersama-sama dengan selesa sebagai satu warga yang bersatu-padu. - LHL

Pongal starts today! Pongal is a traditional harvest festival in South India. It also marks the start of the Tamil month of “Thai”. Families celebrate by cooking sweet rice in new pots until it boils over (a sign of prosperity), when everyone shouts “Pongalo, Pongal!”. 

The pic shows the 2013 Pongal celebration at Cheng San CC. I can’t make this year’s celebrations, but will try hard to be there next year. Happy Pongal to all! – LHL

பொங்கல் இன்று தொடங்குகிறது! பொங்கல் தென் இந்தியாவில் ஒரு பாரம்பரிய அறுவடைப் பண்டிகையாகும். அது தமிழ் தை மாதத்தின் தொடக்கத்தையும் குறிக்கிறது. குடும்பங்கள் புதிய பானைகளில் இனிப்பான பொங்கல் சமைத்து கொண்டாடுகின்றனர். பொங்கும் பொங்கலைப் போன்றே வாழ்விலும் வளம் பொங்க அனைவரும் “பொங்கலோ பொங்கல்!” என்று உரக்கக் கூவி மகிழ்கிறார்கள்.

அந்தப் படம் செங் சான் சமூக மன்றத்தில் நடந்த 2013 பொங்கல் கொண்டாட்டத்தைக் காட்டுகிறது. என்னால் இந்த ஆண்டின் கொண்டாட்டங்களில் கலந்துகொள்ள இயலாது, ஆனால் அடுத்த ஆண்டு அங்கிருக்க முடிந்தவரை முயற்சிக்கிறேன். அனைவருக்கும் இனிய பொங்கல் நல்வாழ்த்துகள்! – LHL

My condolences to the people of Israel on the passing of former Prime Minister Ariel Sharon. 

Mr Sharon was a respected leader who dedicated his life to the security and well-being of Israel and its people. He embodied courage and resourcefulness, and served his country with honour and distinction. His passing is a great loss to Israel.

Singapore and Israel enjoy a longstanding friendship. Our ties have been strengthened over time by the efforts of leaders like Mr Sharon. Our thoughts are with the people of Israel during this time of sorrow. - LHL

Many of you wrote to me via Facebook to complain about racially offensive remarks by “Heather Chua”. I’m glad that the Singapore Police Force has established the identity of a 22-year-old man who is believed to be behind the fictitious profile. He is currently assisting the Police with investigations.

The Internet allows us to share information and connect easily with one another. We should harness this powerful tool positively and responsibly. Let’s remember to be mindful of our words and to respect one another. We must uphold our racial harmony and social cohesion. – LHL 

(PMO Photo by Alex Qiu)

Great job by the Singapore Police Force, who arrested the two suspects who kidnapped Mdm Ng Lai Poh on Wednesday so quickly.

Glad Mdm Ng is safe and sound. Also glad that her son, Mr Lim Hock Chee, alerted the police as soon as it happened, so that the police could rescue Mdm Ng and solve the case.

Kidnapping is a very serious crime. The punishment is life imprisonment or death. We will deal with the perpetrators to the full extent of the law.

Welcomed Turkish PM Recep Tayyip Erdoğan this morning. We last met in St Petersburg (G20 Summit) in September. Our ties with Turkey are growing, and the PM’s visit will give them another push.

We agreed to do a Singapore-Turkey Free Trade Agreement, and also signed an MOU to cooperate against international terrorism. 

I was happy to accept PM Erdoğan’s invitation to visit Turkey, and hope to take it up before long. – LHL

ExxonMobil Singapore built its first Singapore refinery in 1966, soon after independence. It created badly needed jobs, and helped our economy grow.

In 1998, in the midst of the Asian Financial Crisis, ExxonMobil decided to build the Singapore Chemical Plant. It was a success, and the company decided to expand it. I broke ground for the expansion in 2007, and was very happy to be back to open the completed plant today. It is Singapore’s biggest manufacturing investment, and ExxonMobil’s largest integrated refining and petrochemical facility in the world.

We have built a thriving energy and petrochemicals industry which offers the best paid manufacturing jobs to workers of all education backgrounds. Glad that we are creating more fulfilling and challenging job opportunities for Singaporeans. - LHL

Saddened to hear of the passing of Sir Run Run Shaw, at the ripe old age of 107. He lived in Hong Kong, but was a good friend of Singapore. The Shaw Brothers (Run Run and Runme) were a major player in our movie industry. Generations of Singaporeans enjoyed their movies and TV shows. The Shaw Foundation has contributed to many charitable causes here.

I first met Sir Run Run in 1985, when I chaired an Economic Committee to review our economy. He flew in specially to share his ideas on growing media-related services with Dr Tony Tan (then Minister for Trade and Industry) and me. Subsequently when I visited Hong Kong, I would often meet Sir Run Run for a meal, and to learn from his thoughtful views about Hong Kong and the world.

Sir Run Run will be fondly remembered by Singaporeans. My deepest condolences to Mrs Mona Shaw and her family. – LHL 

(Source: ST © Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Reproduced with permission.)

Phase 1 of the Downtown Line (DTL1) is open! The ceremony at Downtown Station this morning marked the completion. I enjoyed checking out the new trains and beautiful facilities (will be uploading a video on the visit later). 
 
Our MRT system has grown greatly since we opened the first five stations on the North South Line in 1987. The DTL is our 5th major line, and will make travelling in the city a lot easier and faster (you can now get to Bugis from Chinatown in 10 minutes or less, for food or entertainment :) ). 
 
When we ride on buses and trains, we should think of the people who built the network, maintain the systems, and keep everything running. A big thank you to all LTA, SMRT and SBS Transit staff for taking on this tough challenge, and doing a very good job. - LHL

Healthcare has come a long way since 1913, when the St. Andrew’s Medical Mission was founded. The Mission and similar community initiatives helped and saved many people, especially the poor and uneducated, in early 20th century Singapore. 

Last night we celebrated the centenary of its successors, the St. Andrew’s Mission Hospital and Singapore-Anglican Community Services.

Singaporeans today enjoy good, affordable healthcare. The Government plays a much more active role, but community partners like St. Andrew’s remain invaluable. Besides running several hospitals, St. Andrew’s is also doing a lot with the elderly and needy. Happy 100th birthday, and thank you for hosting me last night! - LHL

Visited the Centre for Quantum Technologies (CQT) at NUS this morning. We set up CQT in 2007 as part of our national R&D effort. It applies quantum mechanics to secure communications (cryptography), ultra-precise measurements and new types of computing devices. 

CQT has become one of the leading research centres in its field in the world. The researchers were a good mix of Singaporean and international talent. It was fun to listen to them explain their projects, and to see their enthusiasm and passion. (Here I am trying to see the laser source of entangled photon pairs.)

There are many potential uses for CQT’s research, e.g. for online banking and secure internet transactions. I hope talented young people interested in physics and computing will learn more about these subjects, do research and make new breakthroughs one day! – LHL

(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

Well done #ourteamsg!  I have been following our athletes’ progress, and am so happy to see young Singaporeans overcoming the odds with sheer grit and hard work. The winning performances by cyclist Dinah Chan and swimmer Samantha Yeo (who had both sustained injuries before), our first ever men’s marathon Gold by Mok Ying Ren, and young Alfian who clinched a Gold for silat at his debut Games, are among the many inspiring examples. 

And not to forget James Wong, our national thrower, who missed a medal this time, but won an exceptional ten Golds (nine for the discus and one for the hammer throw) in his career. Thank you to all our athletes who are giving their best, and setting an example to all sportsmen! - LHL

All’s well in Japan, despite a minor earthquake offshore near Tokyo this afternoon. We were at Keidanren having lunch. I noticed standing waves (ripples) in three glasses of wine on the trolley, though I felt nothing and didn’t know it was an earthquake. Pity I did not get a pic! :(

My meetings with PM Shinzo Abe and business leaders, and the ASEAN-Japan Commemorative Summit all went well. Our ties with Japan are strong. I told Mr Abe that we would like to do more together, by enhancing our economic partnership agreement and further liberalising air services.

For ASEAN, Japan has been a good friend for 40 years. I encouraged ASEAN and Japan to further promote trade, implement connectivity projects, liberalise air services and grow our people-to-people links.

It has been a good trip, but I am looking forward to going home, as always. – LHL
Beautiful morning in Tokyo. Arrived last night, all set for work today. – LHL

A productive start to my visit to Korea today. Met President 박근혜 Park Geun-Hye and DPM Hyun Oh-Seok to reaffirm our strong bilateral and economic ties. Also spoke to Korean business leaders at a lunch hosted by the Korean International Trade Association. 

We can learn much from Korea’s strengths as we reshape our own economy. Korea has world-class companies and innovative start-ups, not to mention ‘soft power’, thanks to the popularity of K-Pop and K-Drama! 

So there are many areas where Singapore and Korea can work together. I am glad that Korean companies are keen to use Singapore as a regional base, and Singapore companies like Yakun and Charles & Keith are expanding in Korea.

Will be visiting Samsung tomorrow, before going to Tokyo. - LHL

Touched down at Incheon airport a while ago (it’s cold here!). Beautiful sunset drive into Seoul. Looking forward to meeting President 박근혜 Park Geun-Hye and ministers and business leaders.

P.S. Keeping track of follow up to the Little India riot. It is in good hands.

I have ordered a Committee of Inquiry (COI) to look into the Little India riot. The COI will review the factors that led to the incident, how the incident was handled, and how we manage areas where foreign workers congregate. 

This was an isolated incident caused by an unruly mob. The vast majority of foreign workers here obey our laws. We must not let this bad incident tarnish our views of foreigner workers here. Nor should we condone hateful or xenophobic comments, especially online.

Let us remain calm and continue with our daily lives. Support our Home Team officers on the front line, and share with them any leads you may have. We must unite to deal with this unfortunate incident, to keep Singapore  orderly and safe. - LHL

The Little India riot last night was a very grave incident. Several police officers were injured, and vehicles damaged or destroyed. The situation is now under control, and investigations are underway. Whatever events may have sparked the rioting, there is no excuse for such violent, destructive, and criminal behaviour. We will spare no effort to identify the culprits and deal with them with the full force of the law. 

I urge all Singaporeans to stay calm. Do send the Police any information, photos or videos of the incident that you may have. I also wish the injured officers a full and speedy recovery. - LHL

Spoke at the #PAPConvention this morning. To stay abreast of the changing times, the People's Action Party adopted a new Resolution outlining its goals and aspirations for Singapore. 
 
One key thrust in the Resolution is to build a fair and just society. We must strengthen social safety nets to make sure that no one gets left behind. The elderly particularly need attention. We are setting up the PAP Seniors Group – PAP.SG, chaired by Speaker Halimah Yacob with ESM Goh Chok Tong as its Advisor. It will champion elderly causes and issues. 
 
Let us continue to work together to bring Singapore to greater heights. – LHL

What makes Singapore our home? Some things that matter: living with or near our loved ones, spending more time with friends and family, and enjoying green spaces at our doorsteps.

How to allow new development, while protecting space for green living and conservation on our little island, is a constant challenge. 
Urban Redevelopment Authority’s team has come up with bold ideas to strike a good balance, and improve our quality of life. It envisions more jobs closer to our homes; 90% of households to live within 400 metres of parks; 700km of cycling routes integrated with our public transport network; and more. Khaw Boon Wan has shared some details on his blog, so take a read and check out URA’s videos at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pq7SOYpCUeo&list=PL8uwWxk88HcTaucRtkafpIlI2WHwPCSRj 
– LHL

Some highlights from the visit to Ang Mo Kio Town Centre yesterday. - LHL

(PMO Video by Chiez How)

Great to see so many active and cheerful seniors at the Active Agers Carnival in AMK yesterday evening. They are living full lives, and keeping active through photography, cycling, basketball and gateball (a Japanese game that’s a bit like croquet) and many other pursuits. Certainly role models for the rest of us on how to grow old gracefully, and stay healthy and connected to the community. 

Visited the Ang Mo Kio Town Centre too. Caught up with residents and shopkeepers, some of whom have been here for decades! AMK has certainly been transformed over the years. The amenities have improved but the sense of community and kinship is crucial - friendly shopkeepers, people volunteering their time to help others, and families enjoying their Sunday evening together. - LHL

前人种树，后人乘凉 . Our forefathers planted trees all over Singapore, so today we are enjoying the shade.  We must keep on planting, for the sake of our children.

I planted a tree in Singapore Botanic Gardens this morning. My parents often took me there as a child. I still enjoy walking through the Gardens, like many other Singaporeans and visitors. It is an icon of Singapore.

The Botanic Gardens is a living, breathing ecosystem, rich in biodiversity. We have nominated it as a UNESCO World Heritage site, and will continue to expand and nurture it, to keep it a beautiful landmark for always. - LHL

Presented Mr Liang Baohua with the Business China Excellence Award for his contributions to Singapore-China cooperation, particularly in the development of Suzhou Industrial Park (SIP). I have known him for 15 years, first as Party Secretary in Suzhou, then as Governor and Party Secretary of Jiangsu Province. We last met in 2010 when I visited SIP, which has fulfilled all our expectations. He is an old friend of Singapore.

China’s reforms and development will create many opportunities for Singapore companies.  But they will face tough competition - not only from Chinese companies, but also from firms from around the world.  So we need to build up our knowledge of the business environment, and improve our grasp of the Chinese language and psyche.   Business China’s mission is to help them succeed.  

– LHL

梁保华先生对苏州工业园区的成功以及新中两国关系有很大的贡献。15年前就认识了这个有魄力的领导。当时梁先生是苏州市委书记，后来当江苏省领导时也不断推广中新友好关系。他可说是新加坡的老朋友了！上一次见面是在2010年，一起参观苏州工业园。所以昨晚很高兴能将通商中国成就奖颁给梁保华先生，答谢他多年对新加坡的支持。 

中国的改革发展给新加坡企业带来新机遇与挑战。因为要在中国市场立足，不单要跟中国公司比拼，也要经得起世界其他公司的竞争。因此我们必须掌握中国市场的动脉，并提升我们的华语和华族文化习俗的了解。通商中国的宗旨就是要为新加坡企业助一臂之力。大家齐心协力，希望能有卓越的成绩。

- 李显龙


(Top photo: Lianhe Zaobao© Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Reproduced with permission; Bottom photo: MCI photo by Chwee)

Got a warm welcome from the residents of Kampong Lorong Buangkok when Dr Intan Mokhtar, Ang Hin Kee, Seng Han Thong and Mah Bow Tan and I visited yesterday. The kampong spirit is strong among the small Malay and Chinese community who have lived here for decades. On weekends, their children and extended family come back to visit. Many of the houses are well maintained by their owners who also grow all sorts of fruit trees. 

Was happy to join a birthday celebration for Mdm Absah who had just turned 81, and meet the volunteers from Hwi Yoh YEC who have been helping to repair and smoothen the road in the kampong with students from ITE West. - LHL

A reunion at Ang Mo Kio CC last night for the pioneer team in AMK. In 1977, AMK was a brand new town still being built. Mr Yeo Toon Chia (standing, second from left) went to AMK from Kampong Kapor, to be its MP. His key helpers included George Tan (standing, first from left) as branch secretary, Lim Yok Tiong (second from right) as Citizens' Consultative Committee and Community Centre Management Committee chairman, Liang Chye (first from right) as Organising Secretary in AMK CC. They had the support of their families, including Ann Tan (standing, third from left), George's wife. 

The pioneers built up the grassroots network in AMK to look after residents. They built AMK CC – the first CC in the town. As AMK grew, it split off Chong Boon, Kebun Baru, Yio Chu Kang, Teck Ghee, Bo Wen -- each with its own MP. When I went to Teck Ghee in 1984, I found grassroots leaders, kindergartens, resources already organised, for me to take over. All this was the good work of Toon Chia and his team.

We are forever indebted to the pioneer generation, for all that they have done for us. – LHL

(MCI Photo by LH Goh)

Heartiest congrats to Anthony, Yann Yann, and the cast and crew of ILO ILO 爸妈不在家! for winning four Golden Horse awards last night.  Singapore celebrates your impressive achievements. I hope this success will spur you and our other local film-makers to continue telling great stories. - LHL

Congrats to Zaobao on its 90th anniversary! One of the world’s oldest Chinese papers, it launched zaobao.sg this evening for Singaporean readers.
 
The changing media landscape brings challenges to all of us. Cyber bullying and trolling are serious problems. We must encourage people to engage constructively online and protect them from bad behaviour. – LHL
 
恭贺早报创报90周年！早报是世上历史最悠久的华文报纸之一。它客观的报道及对华社的关注，赢得了新加坡人的信赖。早报的国外读者也不少， 因为它不仅透视了新加坡的观点，也提供了完整且可靠的区域报道。

在新媒体带来的迅速发展下，传统媒体如早报必须与时并进，以保持它的相关性。因此早报在今晚的“国是论坛”上便推出了新加坡版的早报网 – zaobao.sg。 这个网站是特地为新加坡读者量身定做的。
 
祝 zaobao.sg 成功！ - 李显龙

Will be speaking on the new media landscape at Zaobao Forum 2013 this evening. Look forward to interacting with the forum participants during the dialogue later. You can watch my speech live at http://www.zaobao.com.sg/ from 7.45pm. – LHL

(MOE Photo)

Found a surprise visitor in my office this morning. A beautiful barn owl had flown into the building overnight, and perched itself comfortably high up out of reach. We called the AVA and Bird Park for help (but not the police :) ). They managed to capture the owl, and released it unharmed behind Sri Temasek.

The Istana grounds are a green refuge for many species of birds and animals. We should preserve and create many such green spaces all over our island, so that in our urban environment we can enjoy the natural flora and fauna of Singapore. – LHL

(Pic by Adeline Teh, my SO)

Congrats to CHIJ St Nicholas Girls' School on the opening of your campus and your 80th anniversary! I met many St Nicks girls – past and present. The SAP school has groomed generations of bicultural and bilingual students. Glad that they are also learning about our multi-cultural society. We hope SAP students will master Chinese culture, while understanding the other cultures in Singapore too.

I found a strong sense of unity among the students and alumni, and more importantly, a tradition of service to the community. It’s clear the St Nicks girls hold true to the philosophy emblazoned on their shirts: “姐妹同心，饮水思源”. The St Nicks family – teachers, students, parents and alumni – have reason to be proud of their school. Well done! - LHL

恭贺特选学校圣尼各拉女校建校80周年！今天在新校舍的开幕典礼，跟学生们交流，感受到了她们对母校的一份浓情。圣尼各拉的大家庭也继续为我国培养多位双语人才，在各个领域做出贡献。

希望同学们不但能够掌握好华族文化传统，也了解华族文化在我国多元社会里所扮演的角色， 多与其他种族交流，配合，维持我们的社会稳定与种族和谐。- 李显龙

Had a good exchange this morning with former US Secretary of State George Shultz, together with William Perry (former Secretary of Defence) and Sam Nunn (former Senator). They are here for the Nuclear Threat Initiative conference. In the evening Mr Lee Kuan Yew hosted dinner for Dr Shultz and his wife Charlotte, and invited me and a few others too. My father and Dr Shultz have been good friends for more than 40 years. - LHL

(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

Venerable Master Hsing Yun of Fo Guang Shan led 10,000 devotees this evening in a special Buddhist ceremony – The Refuge-taking and Five Precepts Ceremony – to pray for blessing for Singapore. Refuge-taking and the Five Precepts are central to the Buddhist faith. This was an important ceremony which reminds devotees of the values of tolerance and humility.

Glad that people of all faiths can live in harmony with one another in Singapore. Everyone can practise their religion freely and peacefully because we accommodate one another’s beliefs and customs. Let’s not take our religious harmony for granted.

Fo Guang Shan helps the poor and provides free medical care for the elderly of all religions. I thank Venerable Master Hsing Yun and the Fo Guang Shan devotees for their prayers this evening, and for their good work for our community. – LHL

佛光山开山宗长星云大师带领约10，000名善男信女在"三皈五戒暨为国家大众祈愿祝祷”的盛会为新加坡祈福。这重要的仪式提醒佛徒遵守五戒，持有宽容和谦卑的心。

新加坡享有的和谐社会来的不容易，希望大家会继续珍惜。每个人都可以自由从事宗教信仰，和平共处，互相包容因为我们都适应了彼此的信仰和习俗。

佛光山以慈悲的心扶贫济老，为各种族的乐龄人士提供免费医疗服务。在此感谢星云大师和佛光山会员的祈愿祝祷，还有为新加坡做的的贡献。谢谢！－ 李显龙

(MCI Photo by Chwee)

Spent two useful days at CHOGM. At the Leaders' Retreat, I spoke on why countries must have economic development and growth, and then make sure that growth benefits the people broadly. It was also a good chance to renew old friendships and make new ones. 

A big thank you to our host, Sri Lanka, for the warm welcome. The opening ceremony was dramatic and spectacular, reflecting the rich culture of Sri Lanka. - LHL
Backstage with Najib Razak, waiting to join our Commonwealth colleagues for the Opening Ceremony. - LHL #CHOGM

Arrived in Colombo, Sri Lanka early this morning for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM). Will be here for 2 days. Look forward to meeting the other leaders, both in the main meetings and on the sidelines. More tomorrow. - LHL

(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

Happy to welcome Prime Minister Sheikh Abdullah of Qatar for a two-day visit. The Emir appointed Sheikh Abdullah to co-chair the Qatar-Singapore High Level Joint Committee, together with DPM Teo Chee Hean. 

Qatar and Singapore are small countries. We both have to get on with larger neighbours, and make friends around the world. We can learn much from each other, and do much more together. 

Hope our bilateral ties and the Dendrobium Sheikh Abdullah (orchid named in honour of PM Sheikh Abdullah) will continue to thrive for many years. – LHL

(Top: MCI Photo by Kenji Soon; Bottom: PMO Photo by Alex Qiu)

Met Yvonne from the Singapore embassy in Paris on my recent trip. She dreams of running 7 marathons in 7 continents. She has already completed 6, and will be running her 7th - in Antarctica! - come 20 November. ( Yvonne's 7 Marathons on 7 Continents) Today is 7 days to her 7th marathon in the 7th continent.

Inspired by her grandmother, Yvonne is running for a cause. She is raising funds for the Tsao Foundation to help the elderly. 

I admire this young lady’s mental strength, determination and compassion as she pursues her dreams. I wish her all the best in her fundraising campaign and her upcoming run in Antarctica! - LHL 

(PMO Photo by Alex Qiu)

Those who have done well in Singapore should give back to society. I’m glad the Singapore Business Federation has taken this message to heart, and launched the SBF Foundation today. 

The Foundation is off to a good start, helping to send 150 ITE students abroad for month-long training programmes. I’m sure this will mean a lot to the students, who might not otherwise be able to afford the trip. Helping less privileged workers is also on the Foundation’s agenda. 

The Foundation has received $18 million in donations. The Far East Organisation was particularly generous, gifting the office space for the Foundation in the SBF Centre. Hope the business community will continue to support the Foundation. A big thank you to all! – LHL

Yesterday evening, we recognised and thanked people who have rendered exceptional service to the nation. The National Day Award recipients have served in many fields – the civil service, the SAF and Home Team, the community, business groups and unions. Let's continue to excel and build a better Singapore for all of us. - LHL

Had a blast at dinner last night for active agers in Teck Ghee. Nanyang Polytechnic students put up great performances for the residents. One old lady enjoyed it so much that she stood up at her table and danced along with them! :)

Such a joy to see senior residents keep active and healthy. The Government will do our part to help them enjoy their golden years. Last night, we presented walking aids and wheelchairs to residents who needed them, and CHAS cards to those joining the scheme. I hope to see the senior residents as healthy and happy at our next event. – LHL

We cannot tell when we will encounter a crisis. But sooner or later something will happen, and then we should prepared, ready, and know what to do. Joined residents and Dr Intan in Jalan Kayu today for Emergency Preparedness Day. Through the exhibitions as well as the exciting “live” fire demonstration conducted by SCDF officers, residents also learnt about basic safety practices and what to do when there is a fire. 

Many residents volunteer in the Community Emergency Response Team, or CERT. They are trained in civil defence and first aid, to provide medical help to neighbours or family members in times of crisis. Many thanks to all the volunteers who spend time and effort to keep our communities well prepared. Hope more will join them. - LHL

Congrats to ITE on the official opening of ITE HQ & College Central! I’ve visited the College several times already, including for the National Day Rally in August. Always impressed by the enthusiasm of the students and staff.

ITE and poly students find good jobs quickly after graduation, because the ITE and polys have focused on acquiring skills and applied learning. We will help our students to pursue careers and further their education in areas which they are good in, or have strong interest in. 

After our students graduate, I hope they will work for a while first, and gain some experience before taking up further courses relevant to their work, and advancing their careers. I wish ITE College Central and its students all the best! - LHL

Technology can make a big difference to our lives. 

The Titan Arm is a robotic arm for people to wear. It can help people to lift heavy things, or to rebuild their muscles after back injuries. It was produced cheaply using 3D-printing and ordinary materials like aluminium, and won the James Dyson Award. 
 
Btw, the team of engineering students from UPenn who built the Titan Arm included one lady (see picture in the BBC article). Bravo to her - too few women do engineering, including in Singapore! – LHL

Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong observing Exercise Highcrest on 6 November 2013.

(PMO Video by Alex Qiu and Chiez How)

MINDEF, MHA and many other ministries have just conducted Ex Highcrest, a joint exercise to test our National Maritime Security System. Yesterday I watched the counter-terrorism operation which was the climax of Ex Highcrest. It was conducted both on land and at sea. The coordination, realism and professionalism were impressive.
 
It's not easy to coordinate a response to such multi-pronged attacks. Glad that we have been preparing hard for such a situation. We hope it will never happen here, but we must prepare ourselves to deal with it if ever it does. A big thank you to everyone involved in the exercise! - LHL

PS: Hope the realistic (and loud) gunshots, flares and pyrotechnics at Tanah Merah Ferry Terminal didn’t alarm anyone. :)

The marine and offshore industry is one of our success stories. We produce no oil, and have no major oil companies of our own. Yet the two leading marine and offshore companies in the world are Singaporean: SembCorp Marine and Keppel Offshore & Marine.
 
Today I opened the first phase of SembCorp Marine's new Integrated Yard at Tuas. When all three phases are fully completed in 2024, SCM will integrate all its operations in one site, and operate much more efficiently and productively.

We will continue to upgrade the marine & offshore industry, just as we are upgrading other sectors of our economy. This will ultimately create more opportunities and better jobs for our people. - LHL
Had a meeting with Yaacob and Malay PAP MPs this afternoon. - LHL

1,000 people from AMK and Sengkang West came to the old Seletar Range to plant 300 trees this morning. This is the first time that we are doing reforestation together, and I’m sure it won’t be the last.  
 
Reforestation restores damaged and degraded secondary forests into habitats for native animals and plants. Here, we are doing reforestation with a twist – establishing an Eco-link, reconnecting Bukit Timah Nature Reserve to the Central Catchment Nature Reserve. 
 
Let’s all do our part to protect our nature reserves and parks – take only pictures of the beautiful scenery but leave only footsteps. :) 
 
- LHL

Concluded my visit to Poland today in Gdańsk. I’m impressed with the enthusiasm of its people as well as the beauty of its old buildings. 

Grateful to PM Donald Tusk and Mayor Pawel Adamowicz for their warm hospitality, especially as today is All Saints’ Day, a very important family holiday for Poles. 
 
This visit has helped PM Tusk and me to get to know each other better. The businessmen travelling with me have made useful new contacts. Our ties with Poland are growing. We are collaborating more in research and science, education and culture.
 
I’m sure many Singaporeans will enjoy Poland, and hope Polish tourists and businessmen will also make a stop in Singapore when they visit Southeast Asia. – LHL

Happy Deepavali to all who celebrate this festival of lights! தீபத் திருநாளைக் கொண்டாடும் அனைவருக்கும் இனிய தீபாவளி நல்வாழ்த்துகள்! -  LHL

(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

My first visit to Poland has been a meaningful one. The welcome ceremony at the Prime Minister’s Chancellery was simple but dignified. Will give a fuller update tomorrow. – LHL
 
PS. I had said, “I salute you!” (in Polish) and the troops replied “We salute you, Commander-in-chief!”
 
(Channel NewsAsia video. Reproduced with permission. )

Arrived yesterday afternoon at Warsaw Chopin Airport and walked around the Old Town – the city’s historic district. Its cobblestoned streets and rows of houses are so clean and picturesque. It’s hard to imagine that the Old Town was completely destroyed during the War, and its people nearly wiped out. After the War, the survivors painstakingly and lovingly recreated the original streets and buildings, based on old plans. 

Today, Poland is one of the bright lights in Europe. Look forward to meeting our host, PM Tusk and President Bronislaw Komorowski later.
 
I also met (unplanned) seven energetic young Singaporeans on exchange programs in Warsaw. One of them (Pei Ying) had written to me on Facebook after reading that I would be in town. Didn’t realise Poland was such a popular destination for students from SMU, NUS and NTU. They are enjoying their stay here and learning about Polish history, culture, language (one of the most difficult), food (Polish dumplings), and its growth story. They were catching a train to Prague after our meeting, for the long weekend! Heartened to see the spirit of adventure alive in these 20-somethings.  – LHL

Had a very good meeting and dinner with PM Jean-Marc Ayrault. We reviewed our partnership across all fields. PM Ayrault expressed France’s support for the EU-Singapore FTA, and expressed French interest in Singapore’s expansion of the MRT network. We both look forward to celebrating 50 years of our diplomatic relations in 2015. 
 
Also had several meetings with business leaders on this trip. One of their main concerns was Singapore’s long-term foreign talent strategy. I assured them that Singapore will always be open to foreign expertise but the inflows must be sustainable in the long run and not overwhelm our Singaporean core.
 
It’s been a very fruitful visit. Off to Poland later today for a three-day visit. – LHL

Happy to meet President Francois Hollande today. We discussed ways Singapore and France can do more together, e.g. using the EU-Singapore FTA to boost trade and investments between our two countries, and having more academic and student exchanges.  We encourage Singaporean students to go to non-English-speaking countries, so that they gain different perspectives on the world.
 
Expressed my appreciation to President Hollande for hosting our RSAF training facility in Cazaux. Other highlights from Day 2 of my visit are in this video. – LHL

Had an interesting time before dinner meeting Singaporeans living in France. Several worked for large firms such as LVMH, Nielsen and Alstom as well as Singapore companies Ascott and SIA. Some have young children who go to local French schools, including one bilingual school where students learn both French and Chinese! 

A bunch of young Singaporean students came too - not all speak fluent French (yet) but that hasn’t stopped them from venturing here to study. Glad Singaporeans are seizing learning and work opportunities in this globalised world.  

Also took some time today to soak in the city, and walk down the revamped Berges de Seine quaysides. – LHL

Arrived in Paris early this morning for a three day visit. Not too cold, but rather windy! I’ll be meeting French President Francois Hollande, and catching up with PM Jean-Marc Ayrault, who visited us a year ago.  Also meeting some Singaporeans this evening, who work or study here. Meanwhile, here’s the view from my hotel window. :) - LHL

Highlights of Launch of Clean and Green Singapore 2014.

(PMO Video by Chiez How)

Many Singaporeans are actively caring for the environment and keeping it clean. I met some of them this morning at the launch of Clean & Green Singapore 2014.

Unfortunately a minority do not respect our environment. We must stop people from littering, leaving dirty tables at hawker centres and abusing enforcement officers. This is why NEA is empowering community volunteers to act against litterbugs. We need to work together to make Singapore a city we can proudly call home. – LHL

#CGS2014

Chaired a Research, Innovation and Enterprise Council (RIEC) meeting to review our progress in R&D. One priority is to get good people. We need international talent, but also a strong core of Singaporean scientists. 

Hence we are launching a Returning Singaporean Scientists Scheme. It will attract back Singaporeans who have established themselves overseas, to contribute to the local R&D scene. 

We are making progress with R&D, but we must be patient. A breakthrough often takes many years – NEWater is an example. We will continue to invest in this long-term effort. – LHL

(MCI Photo by LH Goh)

Xinmin Secondary School is a great example of an active community. It was founded in 1945 by Mr Yap Fun Fong, who sold 5 pigs to rent 3 bungalows and start the school. Over the years, its principals, teachers and alumni have contributed much time, effort and funds to help build the school. 
 
The school has many creative arts programmes – drama, guzheng, ensemble, dance, Chinese opera, photography, painting. The students are a talented bunch!

Tonight’s dinner raised funds for a Creative Arts Complex, besides celebrating the anniversaries of the school (68 years) and the Alumni Association (20 years). 

Thank you to all who have come forward to give back to the school in so many ways. - LHL

Happy to meet Chinese Vice-Premier Zhang Gaoli, who is here to co-chair the Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation with DPM Teo Chee Hean. We last met in Tianjin in Sept 2012, where Zhang was Party Secretary. We discussed expanding our bilateral cooperation. I’m confident that our relations with China will continue to grow under its new leaders. - LHL

(MCI Photo by LH Goh)
A year from NS45

These young graduands from PCF Teck Ghee put up a wonderful concert yesterday afternoon! I hope they have enjoyed their kindergarten journey and will not miss it too much as they move on to primary school.

Every child deserves a good start in life. Hence we are building more pre-school places, and raising pre-school standards. Parents often worry about their children’s academic performance. But we need to strike the right balance between studying, playing and spending time with the family. Don’t pressure your children too much, and do let them enjoy their childhood and have fun. :) - LHL

Broke ground for the new Ci Yuan CC in Ang Mo Kio - Hougang this morning, with Yeo Guat Kwang. Met the skilled excavator operator who actually dug the first scoop of soil. He hails from Tamil Nadu in India, and he’s been working in Singapore for 18 years. Grateful to him and the many more like him who help us to build our CCs, homes, roads and train lines. - LHL
 
(MCI Photo by LH Goh)

Community leader Peter Leow was moved to form the Angel Committee after he came across a resident studying on a staircase. The Committee helps needy residents in Sengkang West, particularly those living in rental flats, e.g. through bursaries, food distribution, financial assistance. Tonight’s dinner was to thank benefactors who had generously donated over $400,000 to this good cause. I was glad to meet the Angel Committee and the community leaders and volunteers involved. I salute their passion and compassion for their fellow citizens. – LHL

Congrats to Alfred and Natalie on graduating from UniSIM! I first met them at UniSIM last year. They were busy with work and family (Natalie even had a baby halfway through the course), but were determined to complete their degrees. Both have done brilliantly – Alfred won the McGraw Hill Education Asia Gold Award and Natalie obtained First Class Honours. Well done! They prove that in Singapore, anything is possible if you work hard. - LHL

(Alfred and Natalie with their sons Zhi Xuan and Zhi Xiang (the UniSIM baby). / Photo courtesy of Alfred and Natalie.)

National University of Singapore students are full of energy and excitement! Met many of them at the opening of UTown tonight. They live and study in colleges, their diverse backgrounds enriching each other’s experiences.

UTown is one of many projects to improve our universities, and give all our students full opportunities to develop their interests and talents. Campus life is not just about studying – it is an opportunity to foster lasting friendships, to hone character and to develop a social conscience. I hope NUS students will enjoy all that UTown has to offer and make many wonderful memories there before entering the working world! - LHL

National University of Singapore students are full of energy and excitement! Met many of them at the opening of UTown tonight. They live and study in colleges, their diverse backgrounds enriching each other’s experiences.

UTown is one of many projects to improve our universities, and give all our students full opportunities to develop their interests and talents. Campus life is not just about studying – it is an opportunity to foster lasting friendships, to hone character and to develop a social conscience. I hope NUS students will enjoy all that UTown has to offer and make many wonderful memories there before entering the working world! - LHL

Singaporeans can look forward to new MRT lines, more trains and buses, and more cycling paths. The major projects will take time but we are steadily improving public transport for all. Coming soon: the new Downtown Line, opening in December. This LTA video sets it out neatly. Do take a look. - LHL
Took a walk at Gardens by the Bay this evening. Lots of visitors, enjoying the sunset. - LHL

Selamat Hari Raya AidilAdha to all our Muslim friends!

Millions of Muslims have gathered in Mecca to celebrate Prophet Ibrahim’s faith in God, including 680 pilgrims from Singapore. Not all could make the pilgrimage, but we are grateful to Saudi Arabia for restoring our Hajj quota and happy that 136 could leave for the holy city at the last minute.   

Muslims also perform the korban rites (sacrifice) today. For the first time, this year we have imported lambs from Canada, as an alternative to Australian livestock. Glad that all preparations are on track and Muslims can continue carrying out korban rites here, to celebrate the spirit of compassion and charity. - LHL

Selamat Hari Raya Aidiladha kepada semua umat Islam!

Jutaan umat Islam termasuk 680 jemaah haji Singapura, kini berada di kota suci Makkah untuk menyusuri jejak Nabi Ibrahim. Tidak semua berpeluang menunaikan ibadah haji. Jadi kita berterima-kasih kepada kerajaan Arab Saudi kerana mengembalikan kuota rasmi Singapura dan gembira 136 jemaah berjaya berlepas pada saat-saat akhir. 

Umat Islam juga membuat ibadah korban hari ini. Buat kali pertama, kita mengimport kambing dari Kanada tahun ini sebagai alternatif kepada kambing Australia. Lega semua persiapan berjalan lancar dan umat Islam boleh terus menunaikan ibadah korban di sini, demi menyebarluaskan sifat ihsan, belas dan kasih sayang. - LHL

(Photo courtesy of MUIS)

Glad to read in Berita Harian today about Muhammad Noh Arjuna, whom I mentioned in a recent post on Pathlight’s 10th Anniversary. Muhammad Noh is a Pathlight alumnus who is an award-winning artist. He is now doing animation at NYP. His pictures look pro! – LHL

Gembira membaca laporan Berita Harian tentang Muhammad Noh Arjuna. Saya sentuh tentang bakatnya baru-baru ini sempena ulang tahun ke-10 Sekolah Pathlight. Beliau adalah bekas pelajar Pathlight dan seorang artis yang berbakat. Kini, beliau mengikuti jurusan animasi digital di NYP. Lukisannya seperti seorang professional! - LHL

Image Source: BH © Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Reproduced with permission.

Chatting with Siglap community leaders, together with Dr Maliki Osman.

(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

Congrats to Team T-Net Geylang West for winning this year’s National Street Soccer League under-14s! 
 
The teams played hard and fair. Hope you had fun and do encourage your neighbours and friends to take part as well! :) – LHL

(MCI Photo by Kenji)

Experienced Siglap’s remarkable community spirit when I visited yesterday. Through projects like Citizen on Patrol and the Siglap Silver Blueprint, they care and look out for one another, especially the elderly. At the CC, the Siglap Homework Café helps children from disadvantaged homes. Glad it has made a difference to Nazirah and Raykib – two students with the most improved results!

Was also glad to meet several old friends, including my old Officer Cadet School instructor - Pak Abdul Majid Sulaiman, now Vice-Chairman of the CCC.  

My thanks to MP Dr Maliki Osman, volunteers and residents of Siglap for making this community stronger and better. – LHL

Old photo of Tan Chuan-Jin and me from 1989. Appreciate his many years of service – first in the Army, and now in my team.  :)  - LHL

#nostalgia

Mr Ngiam Tong Dow’s recent interview in the Singapore Medical Association’s newsletter attracted some attention. I am glad that he has clarified the statements he made, especially his comments about my ministers. Mr Ngiam served as my Permanent Secretary in MTI years ago. I hope that in retirement he will continue to support the institutions and systems that he helped build during his long and illustrious career. - LHL

Great to be home after a week at the APEC and ASEAN Summits!
 
ASEAN leaders have acted to tackle the haze problem. Yesterday, we adopted the ASEAN Sub-Regional Haze Monitoring System (HMS). When land concession maps are available, affected countries will be able to pinpoint exact hotspots and deal with the culprits. This is useful progress. The next step is to get the maps and run the system.
 
We also discussed our vision of an ASEAN Community by 2015. ASEAN is close to achieving a competitive and integrated regional market but the work is not complete yet. 
 
I thank His Majesty the Sultan and Brunei for their excellent chairmanship this year and for being great hosts! Myanmar is the next ASEAN chairman. I look forward to visiting Nay Pyi Daw for the next summit in 2014. – LHL
The Mulia Resort at night, where we stayed in Bali. - LHL

APEC has wrapped up. We had useful discussions on promoting trade and economic integration. Also met other Leaders, including Australian PM Tony Abbott, HK Chief Executive C Y Leung, Peruvian President Ollanta Humala and Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto. 

My thanks to Indonesian President Yudhoyono and our Indonesian hosts for their warm hospitality.

Now in Brunei for the ASEAN meetings. – LHL

A productive day at APEC. Took part in a panel discussion at the CEO Summit, and had bilateral meetings with the President of Peru and President of Mexico. APEC is an useful platform for leaders to engage one another, and to connect with business leaders too. 

Such discussions can start from an early age – today our Youth Delegates from APEC Voices of the Future also came for tea, to share their views about APEC. Hope you learnt a lot during your visit! – LHL

Caught up over tea with our old friends Vincent Siew and his wife Susan from Taiwan on the sidelines of APEC. It was good to see them again. - LHL

(MCI photo by Terence Tan)

Landed in Bali this evening to this beautiful sunset. Will be speaking at the APEC CEO Summit tomorrow and attending the APEC Economic Leaders’ Meeting (AELM) on Monday and Tuesday.
 
The newly renovated and expanded Ngurah Rai International Airport has a sea wave-like rooftop that also collects and recycles storm water. The Indonesians have certainly made immense efforts to welcome their APEC guests! - LHL

(MCI photo by Terence Tan)

The Jalan Kayu community spirit is thriving! Glad to see residents enjoying the fun and meaningful activities at the JK Community Day. We also presented awards to our hardworking cleaners, and angpows and hampers to those on HeartString support.  
 
Enjoyed the stylish and energetic dances by competitors in the 1st PAssionArts DanceSport Championship - they must have spent hours practising! 
 
Thanks to the Community Day organisers, The DanceSport Academy and Intan for bringing residents such a fun-filled morning! – LHL

Happy Children’s Day! How are you making this occasion special for your kids?  – LHL

(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)
Came across this meaningful message from the Disabled People's Association Singapore. Let's do our part! - LHL

Congrats to Pathlight School on its 10th anniversary! Celebrated their journey and achievements with the Pathlight family in their beautifully decorated school hall today. 

Pathlight has transformed the lives of many children with autism. It reflects the Government’s commitment to help every child achieve his potential through education. But it also depends on the support of the families, and the passion and energy of the teachers, school and community activists. Many individuals and businesses have provided training and work attachments for the students, and donated generously to the school. 

We must each do our part to treat persons with disabilities with dignity, and embrace them as equal and important members of our community. Pathlight’s journey is a story of possibility and potential. I wish the school and its students all the best. Go forth and continue to do well! - LHL
You can watch the full speech from this morning’s Public Sector Leaders Advance planning retreat here.

At a planning retreat this morning, I told public sector leaders that a good public service is critical to maintaining public trust in our system, and reminded them of our commitment to serve and improve the lives of Singaporeans. 

The public service must always see things from the viewpoint of those we serve, and stay in close touch with the ground. We expect our frontline service staff to give good and courteous service to the public. Of course the public should also be proper and courteous in return. 

We have zero tolerance for corruption. Public service leaders are personally responsible for upholding high standards of integrity in their organisations. They cannot delegate this responsibility to subordinates.

Thank you to all public servants for your hard work. I look forward to continue working with you to build a better Singapore. - LHL

(PMO Video by Alex Qiu)

The Church of St Vincent de Paul (SVDP) celebrated its 50th Anniversary yesterday evening. Enjoyed meeting the parishioners young and old, who have a long tradition of community service. 

SVDP does good work with the needy and youth. The Catholic Church has contributed much to Singapore, helping Singaporeans of all races and religions with social services and good education. My own years at Catholic High made all the difference to me. :) 

Hope more Singaporeans follow the SVDP’s lead and roll up their sleeves to support worthy causes in the community. Many thanks to my hosts - Father Michael Sitaram of SVDP and His Grace Archbishop William Goh. – LHL

Little India was sparkling after the Deepavali Light-Up, with 55,000 recycled CDs creatively incorporated into this year’s decorations. Each CD carries a traditional Rangoli design by a resident of a special needs home or an old aged home. I put the final touches to a Rangoli piece marking my father’s 90th birthday.
 
Met and thanked the generous donors to the President’s Challenge and Project Give. Their donations will provide bursaries for needy children.
 
A big thank you to the organisers, performers and participants for a meaningful evening.  – LHL

P.S. Rangoli is a decorative design, traditionally created with coloured rice, flour or coloured sand. During festivals, Hindus make Rangolis for decoration and also for good luck.

Saddened to hear of the passing of Mr Tang I-Fang. Mr Tang was not born a Singaporean. He came here as part of a United Nations team to help us develop our economy. He later adopted this island as his home, and became a citizen.

Mr Tang served as chairman of EDB and JTC, and contributed significantly to Singapore’s development. I knew him when he was in JTC. He pushed for the idea of a regional centre in Jurong, years before we built it. 

Singapore is lucky to have had Mr Tang. We will miss him.– LHL

Thanks for all your questions and comments through Facebook and Twitter, before, during and after my live forum on Channel NewsAsia on Tuesday. They are too many to answer individually, but I want to address some of the key themes.

Many tweeted about stress in the education system (e.g. @Joshyy_Tingg, @RovinNation, @ShaeAtSix). Richard Chan and Benny Chee wrote about the need to do more in terms of values, ethics and social awareness. I understand these concerns. But we do need to study and work hard, to give ourselves the best start in life. We are making every school a good school, and providing every student with many paths through the education system. But there is a lot of competition to get into the most popular schools. Some competition is good, but too much becomes counter-productive. 

Students, parents and teachers must not lose sight of what education is about. Yesterday, Heng Swee Keat outlined MOE’s plans to continue providing values-driven, holistic education, to help every student achieve success in his own way, at his own pace (http://bit.ly/1bFvVO3). But whether this reduces stress depends also on our attitudes towards success and examinations. 

Several of you worried about housing affordability (e.g., @ZeeFriday, Zack Drz, Siu Lin). Housing is becoming more affordable, because we have increased grants for lower- and middle-income families, and are building more flats. We will track this closely and do more if necessary to keep HDB flats always within reach of Singaporeans.

@hpility asked if being Prime Minister is stressful. I suppose sometimes it is, just like any other job. But it is a great honour for me to serve. My team and I will continue to do our best to improve your lives. :)

- LHL

Sorry to learn of the passing of Tuan Haji Abu Bakar Maidin this evening.  As President of Jamiyah Singapore (a Muslim missionary society), Haji Abu Bakar was a stalwart of the Malay community. Haji Abu Bakar also championed inter-religious harmony, and forged a strong partnership between Jamiyah and the Singapore Buddhist Lodge Foundation to help the needy. He was a role model not just for the Malay/Muslim community but for all Singaporeans.
 
Ho Ching and I offer our deepest sympathies to his family. - LHL

In Shenyang, Liaoning, for the last leg of my China trip. Since my last visit in 2005, it has become visibly more vibrant and developed, with many new high-rise buildings and malls.
 
Toured the restored mansion of Marshal Zhang Zuolin (who controlled Manchuria, was assassinated by the Japanese, and succeeded by his son Zhang Xueliang) and the 9.18 museum (about the Mukden Incident and the Japanese invasion of Manchuria in 1931) yesterday to learn about China’s history.
 
After lunch I visited Sembcorp’s water treatment plant, which supplies the factories and residents in Shenyang’s new Tiexi industrial district. Also visited Yuanda Group, the world’s largest producer of glass facades. Its regional headquarters are in Singapore, and it has outfitted several buildings including Biopolis and LaSalle College.

Liaoning Party Secretary Wang Min knows Singapore well, having served in Suzhou and been involved in our Suzhou Industrial Park project. Under him Liaoning’s trade and investment with Singapore have grown. I look forward to strengthening business ties with Liaoning. - LHL

Bumped into Ng Ser Miang at breakfast in Shenyang. He is here for China's National Games, which start tomorrow. Wished him all the best as he runs for the Presidency of the International Olympic Committee. - LHL

In his conclusion, PM said that all these are not merely plans but acts of faith – in Singapore and in ourselves: that a generation from now, Singapore will still be here; that we can thrive in the world and hold our own against bigger and stronger competitors; that we can get our politics right and have honest, capable, trusted people to lead our country well; that we can stay together as one united people and make our dreams come true.

PM called on Singaporeans to work with him and with one another. “Together, let us forge our new way forward, to create a better Singapore for all of us.”

#ndrsg

(Photo courtesy of Mr Jimmy Chan)

PM: We must pass on to our children a better Singapore than the one we inherited. We owe it to them to do so, just as we owe what we have today to our founding generation. PM said his responsibility is to help our young build the Singapore of their dreams: A Singapore with Opportunities, Purpose, Assurance, Community Spirit and Trust, a home where we celebrate our many talents, and above all, a society where the human spirit flourishes.

To realise these dreams, we need to do tangible things to build our city and improve our living environment. We are upgrading Changi Airport with a new complex codenamed Project Jewel, two new terminals and a fourth runway, to maintain our position as an international hub and create more opportunities for Singaporeans in future. We will move Paya Lebar Airbase to Changi. This will free up a big plot of land (bigger than Bishan or Ang Mo Kio) for new homes, offices, factories, parks and more in Paya Lebar. Relocating the airbase will also remove height restrictions on a large area around Paya Lebar, and allow us to redevelop eastern Singapore in new and exciting ways. The Government is also building a new port in Tuas and will move all container ports from Tanjong Pagar there eventually. This will free up prime land in Tanjong Pagar for a brand new Southern Waterfront City.
 
PM said these longer-term plans reflect our fundamental mindset and spirit – to be confident, to look ahead, to aim high. He said if we can carry off these plans, we will not have to worry about running out of space or possibilities in Singapore. We are creating possibilities and opportunities for the future, for our children and theirs to continue building, upgrading and reinventing our city for many more years. 

#ndrsg

(Photo courtesy of Changi Airport)

PM said the new policies in housing, healthcare and education are significant shifts, and part of our new way forward. But he emphasised that Government’s core purpose has not changed, and that is to ensure every Singaporean shares in the nation’s progress, to support the less fortunate and vulnerable, to create opportunities for Singaporeans to do their best, and to build a stronger Singapore. It will take some time to work out policies and programmes to realise the new balance between Government, Community and Individual, and Government will take further steps as we gain experience. 

PM stressed that the new strategic direction will take us down a different road from the one that has brought us this far. There is no turning back, PM said, but he believes this is the right thing to do given the changes in Singapore and the world. “We proceed. But let me sound a caution: All this is not without risk.” Hence, we have to tread carefully, and beware the pitfalls.

#ndrsg

(MCI Photo by LH Goh)

PM stressed that the Community will have to do more to complement individual effort and Government programmes, and some have indeed shown that spirit during the recent haze crisis. 

PM was encouraged that many young people are doing good work. The Government will encourage more youths to build a better world and a better Singapore. A volunteer youth corps will be formed. The Govt will provide funding for youth corps members to start and do their own community projects. The youth corps will also match youths with critical community needs to help them make a meaningful contribution to our nation. “You are our future. Go forth, and change Singapore and the world for the better,” PM said.

#ndrsg

(Photo courtesy of Ministry of Education)

PM said the Government will create flexibility in secondary schools for students to tailor their education to their abilities and development. Secondary 1 students will be allowed to take a subject at a higher level if they have done well in that subject in PSLE. Secondary students who are strong in some subjects but not others can then learn each subject at a pace appropriate to them, and build their confidence. 

PM said it is good that we have outstanding schools in our system, but we need to keep admissions to these top schools open. These schools must not take just students with outstanding academic results but also very good students with other special qualities such as character, resilience, drive and leadership. They must make sure that those from low-income backgrounds are not put off from applying for fear they cannot afford it, or cannot fit in. MOE will broaden the Direct School Admissions scheme to do this, and enhance Financial Assistance and Bursary schemes substantially so that students who qualify and want to attend these schools can do so confidently.

#ndrsg

(Photo courtesy of Ministry of Education)

PM promised to take special care of our Pioneer Generation. They worked hard to build today’s Singapore and paved the way for us to live better lives than themselves. 

The Government will introduce a Pioneer Generation Package to help this group of elderly pay for their premiums under Medishield Life. This will make sure they are well-covered and will not need to worry about healthcare in their old age. 

#ndrsg 

(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

PM said that the Government will improve healthcare financing to give all Singaporeans peace of mind. It will provide more help with outpatient care. It will remove the age floor (currently 40) in the Community Health Assist Scheme (CHAS) and increase subsidies for lower- and middle-income patients at Specialist Outpatient Clinics.

MediShield will be revamped to become MediShield Life. It will cover people for life (not up to 90) and be universal (covering every Singaporean, including those not currently covered, the elderly and those with pre-existing conditions). MediShield Life will also give better protection for very large bills. Because benefits and coverage are better, premiums will be higher. The Government will subsidise premiums for those who can’t afford it. MOH will conduct a public consultation exercise on this major change.

#ndrsg 

(Photo courtesy of SPH)

PM emphasised that home ownership has been and will continue to be an important way to share the fruits of our progress with all Singaporeans, and to level up the poor. 

PM said he will make sure every Singaporean working family can afford an HDB flat - a family today earning $1,000 per month should be able to afford a 2-room flat; $2,000 per month a 3-room flat; and $4,000 per month a 4-room flat. Flat prices will be kept affordable so that people can use mostly CPF to pay off their loans, and have a 25 year loan instead of a 30 year loan.

Families in 2-room flats can look forward to more help to upgrade to 3-room flats later, as they improve their lives, through Step-Up Housing Grants. Lower- and middle-income households buying 3-room and 4-room flats for the first-time will also get more support – the Government will extend the existing Special CPF Housing Grant (SHG) to purchases of 4-room flats, extend it to middle-income households, and increase the SHG quantum.

PM: "We will always make sure that an HDB flat is always within reach - affordable and available to Singaporeans."

#ndrsg

(Photo courtesy of SPH)

PM said we must make a strategic shift in our approach to nation building. Individuals must still do their best, but the Community and Government must do more to reduce the pressures on individuals.

The Community must take more initiative to solve problems and get things done. As Mr S Rajaratnam, one of our founding fathers, said, we must be a “democracy of deeds, not a democracy of words”.

The Government will also do more to support individuals and community. It will make 3 important shifts: (1) Do more to give every citizen a fair share in the nation’s success, raise incomes and wealth of the low-income; (2) Strengthen social safety nets, so that whatever happens to you, you can get the essential social services that you need; (3) Do more to keep paths upwards open to all, by bringing every child to a good starting point, and ensuring the less privileged are not shut out. 

#ndrsg

(MCI Photo by LH Goh)

PM began his English speech recapping the OurSGConversation (http://bit.ly/1cJT4ij) process. He said the OSC has been a very meaningful exercise. “We have listened to one another and created a firmer, shared basis to discuss and plan our future.”

PM said that to achieve our aspirations, we need to take into account the world around us. He knows Singaporeans feel uncertain and anxious - technology and globalisation are widening income gaps, our population is ageing, and Singaporeans are worried about the cost of living, public transport, and other day-to-day problems.  PM said: I understand your concerns, and I promise you - you will not be facing these challenges alone because we are all in it together. We will find a new way to thrive in this new environment.

总理华语群众大会演讲2013 

总理说我们应该再接再厉，延续成功的故事，使一代比一代好。我们也必须要有新的构想，新的策略，才能不断的进步。

总理说政府会继续帮助人民减轻压力，更在近几年推出了一系列社会措施来帮助中下层人民。政府已经推出的措施包括消费税补助券，就业奖励计划，特别就业补贴计划等措施来加强社会安全网，使老百姓的生活更有保障。除此之外，政府也非常关注中小型企业的困境，并强调政府正尽力帮助它们提升和转型。所以他希望企业和政府能多多沟通与对话。

这是政府的新理念、新思路。未来的几年，政府将沿着这个新思路走下去，使政策更贴近人民的意愿，更切合社会情况的改变。

总理强调我们必须调整政府、人民和民间团体三者之间的责任和角色，以取得一个新的平衡点。原本由个人承担的一些生活担子，现在由政府承担得更多，或者由民间团体分担。重新平衡政府、个人和民间团体的角色需要多年的努力，按部就班的进行。政府将先处理一些迫切的民生问题，包括教育、医疗保健和住屋，也会尽量减少人民所承担的生活风险，特别是医药费的风险。总理将会在英语的演讲中进一步地解释这些政策。

总理说我们必须做好扶贫济困的工作，以维持社会的凝聚力。其中，政府会尽力保持社会的流动性，通过教育的途径让每个阶层的人民都有机会提升，让人人都有机会能出人头地。政府也将确保较贫困的孩子能够处于更好的起跑点，而不会因为生活条件差落于人后。所以，政府去年决定大规模的资助幼儿所，托儿所，为中低收入家庭提供更多津贴，使他们的孩子得到良好的启蒙教育。在未来五年内，政府也计划增设两万个幼儿所名额。

除了援助比较贫困的家庭，政府将特别照顾较年长的新加坡人。政府会调整医药制度，为老年人制定一个特别配套，大大减轻他们的医药负担。

总理强调我们在处理问题的时候，也应该着眼未来，继续建设，寻求发展。他说华族根深蒂固的思想意识是 “前人种树，后人乘凉”，而现在是我们为后人种树的时候了。所以我们应该继续不断积累成就和资源，为子孙后代造福。

政府已在治国的理念上，做了重要的调整，并且已经根据新理念，重新制定民生政策。总理强调政府的目标是：不论贫富，人人受惠。而要做到这点，我们必须特别照顾生活比较困难的社群，尤其是低薪家庭和年长一代。总理承诺政府将全力以赴，也鼓励人民全力的支持和配合。

总理说人民可以期待明天会更好，因为政府就在新加坡人左右。

Rapat Hari Kebangsaan 2013 – Ucapan Bahasa Melayu 

PM memulakan ucapannya dengan   melahirkan rasa kagum dengan semangat gotong-royong masyarakat Melayu/Islam yang dipamerkan anggota jawatankuasa dan relawan Masjid An Nur. Beliau berharap semangat ini akan terus mekar . 

PM gembira dengan penyertaan orang Melayu dalam Perbincangan Singapura Kita dan Suara Musyawarah. Beliau menarik perhatian tentang bagaimana orang Melayu berkongsi kebimbangan dan aspirasi dengan warga Singapura yang lain. Beliau menegaskan bahawa Singapura kini berada dalam satu titik peralihan. Namun PM memberi jaminan bahawa setiap warga ada peluang untuk maju dan tingkatkan diri dan tidak perlu bimbang tentang soal jagaan kesihatan, hari tua atau perumahan.   

Pemerintah juga bersedia untuk mengubah beberapa dasar dan pendekatan supaya dapat meningkatkan mobiliti sosial masyarakat Melayu/Islam dan membantu golongan susah keluar dari lingkaran kemiskinan. 

Mencerminkan komitmen pemerintah untuk menghargai setiap anak dan memupuk semangat perpaduan yang kukuh di kalangan generasi akan datang, PM mengumumkan perluasan akaun dan sumbangan Edusave untuk murid-murid di luar sekolah nasional termasuk pelajar madrasah. 

Sambil menekankan bahawa masyarakat Melayu/Islam telah mencatat kemajuan yang ketara dalam sistem meritokrasi Singapura, PM menggalakkan masyarakat Melayu/Islam agar gandakan usaha dan manfaatkan sepenuhnya sokongan pemerintah dengan menggunakan CLF atau wadah lain yang sedia ada.

Menggulung ucapannya, beliau yakin masyarakat Melayu/Islam boleh terus tingkatkan diri dan berjaya. PM menyeru supaya warga berganding bahu untuk membina Singapura yang jauh lebih baik untuk semua.

This Sunday is Racial Harmony Day. Schools across Singapore celebrated it today. Last weekend at the ISD Exhibition at Chong Boon Secondary School, a student asked me if I celebrated it as a student myself. I replied no I did not. In fact a race riot broke out on this date in 1964, which is why years later we chose the date for Racial Harmony Day.

Racial harmony is possible because we accept and appreciate one another’s cultures and practices. We must never take it for granted, and should work hard to preserve it for our next generation.  – LHL
