Had a good time with residents new and old, at the Teck Ghee FAB! (Familiarisation and Bonding) Party this evening. Part of building a strong community, where we have many friends and look out for one another. - LHL

The number of hotspots in Sumatra has fallen steadily over the last few days. This is good news! I hope the situation continues to improve over the next few weeks. 

www.haze.gov.sg will post this chart, and update it regularly. This will give us a good idea of the haze outlook. If hotspots are few, we should be alright. But if hotspots are many, then it depends on which way the winds blow! – LHL

Launched Unilever’s beautiful Four Acres Singapore campus at Nepal Hill today. This is Unilever’s first corporate university outside London for its managers. 

Happy that Unilever is doing more in Singapore, and creating good jobs for our people. The Singaporean management trainees I met were all excited about their work in Unilever. We will create more such opportunities for Singaporeans. - LHL

Hosted Prince Alois of Liechtenstein to dinner. Liechtenstein is a small country of 36,500 people between Switzerland and Austria. It just opened a Consulate here to strengthen ties with Singapore. 

Art enthusiasts would be happy to know that Prince Alois lent our National Museum 91 masterpieces from his family’s “Princely Treasures from the House of Liechtenstein”, one of the most fabulous private art collections in the world. (http://bit.ly/12mdacm)  Hope Singaporeans enjoy them! – LHL

#PrincelyTreasures

I’ve chosen a new venue for this year’s National Day Rally — the ITE College Central. This beautiful new campus reflects Singapore’s commitment, and my longstanding priority, to invest in our young, and nurture every Singaporean to their full potential. - LHL

It was gracious of President Yudhoyono to apologise to the people of Singapore and Malaysia for the current haze situation. We accept his apology wholeheartedly, and welcome his promise to tackle this serious problem which has caused suffering to the people of Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia.  

President SBY and I had agreed to cooperate on environmental protection, when we met at our Retreat in April. Singapore’s offer of help to Indonesia stands. I hope that Indonesia will take swift and sustained action to put out the forest fires and stop the illegal land clearing practices. We need a permanent solution to prevent this problem from recurring annually. - LHL

#sghaze

File photo of Singapore-Indonesia Leaders’ Retreat 2013 dated 22 April.

Showing a resident in Ang Mo Kio how to correctly put on the N95 mask. – LHL

Find out how to put on the N95 mask correctly at http://www.hpb.gov.sg/HOPPortal/article?id=HPB051227.

(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)
Highlights video of PM’s distribution of masks to residents of rental flats in Blk 217

Held a dialogue with Ang Mo Kio residents this morning. Some residents raised local issues, but many were naturally concerned about the haze. 

After the dialogue, I visited some residents living nearby, and distributed N95 masks to them. We are giving 1 million masks to low-income families. We are also delivering masks to pharmacies and retailers. Do not worry: we have enough masks to go around. 

Government agencies, the SAF and PA worked around the clock to get the masks to those who need them. Many thanks to all those who have worked so hard over the past few days! 

I told my residents that thankfully, blue skies are out again today, but we must expect the haze to come back.  Look out for one another and help your neighbours, especially older Singaporeans and young kids. I think that applies to all of us - LHL 

#sghaze

Sent Minister Vivian Balakrishnan as my Special Envoy to deliver my letter to President SBY today. I shared Singaporeans’ grave concern over the haze, urged Indonesia to take action, and offered our help, including aircraft for cloud seeding. 

Indonesia’s Environment Minister Prof Dr Balthasar Kambuaya promised Vivian that Indonesia would consider our offer and explore how to follow up on our suggestions.  

Meanwhile we are making sure that Singaporeans who need N95 masks can get them. Most of us don’t need to use masks, unless we have medical conditions like asthma, or have to do strenuous work outdoors when the haze is bad. We will distribute 1 million N95 masks free to low-income households, and push out more masks to retailers. There are enough masks – please do not panic buy or hoard. 

The Haze Inter-Ministerial Committee has also issued guidelines on what to do at each PSI threshold – please read them. (http://www.e101.gov.sg/haze/)

I’m heartened by the kindness of Singaporeans when faced by the haze. Some are distributing herbal tea and masks to needy residents, while others are opening up their air-conditioned homes to strangers! We will create more air-conditioned “haze shelters” in our RCs and CCs for the public. 

Let’s unite and help one another through this difficult period. Thank you all. - LHL

#sghaze

(Photo by Channel NewsAsia)

More details from MOH on the availability of N95 masks: 

“There is sufficient stock of N95 masks nationally to meet anticipated needs. N95 masks should be bought only when needed, there is no need to stockpile.  The large retail/pharmacy chains (Guardian, Unity, Cold Storage and Giant) will have N95 masks available for purchase on their shelves by this evening.”

“Use N95 masks as appropriate, depending on (i) health status, (ii) PSI level, (iii) physical exertion and (iv) time spent outdoors”

#sghaze

*Corrected link: http://www.moh.gov.sg/content/moh_web/home/pressRoom/Current_Issues/2013/haze.html
PM Lee’s remarks at this afternoon’s press conference on the haze situation. #sghaze

PM: I ask Singaporeans to remain calm and look out for one another. Watch out for your neighbours, especially older Singaporeans and young kids.  If any of them have respiratory problems, bring them to the clinic immediately. Contact your RCs and MPs if you have any questions. I am confident we can manage this problem, and get through if we stay united and work together.

#sghaze

PM has set up a Haze Inter-Ministerial Committee (HIMC) chaired by Minister Ng Eng Hen with representatives from MEWR, MFA, MCI, MOH, MSF, MOE and MOM.

#sghaze

PM said his priority is to protect the health and safety of Singaporeans especially vulnerable groups, such as the young and elderly and those with heart or lung diseases. He urged Singaporeans to see the doctor or GP promptly if they fall ill. 

Financial Help: PM said MOH will implement a special scheme for young Singaporeans, elderly Singaporeans, CHAS card holders, Public Assistance and MFEC card holders suffering from respiratory problems and conjunctivitis because of haze. They can see their GPs for $10. MOH will settle the rest of the medical bill. 

Starting later today, the Government will hold a daily press briefing to update Singaporeans of the haze situation and recommend protective measures for the day ahead, PM said. 

#sghaze

PM requested Indonesian officials to provide evidence that Singapore companies are linked to haze. If any Singapore-linked companies or companies present in Singapore are involved, the Government will take it up with them. 

#sghaze

PM said that haze is not a new problem for Singapore but this episode is more serious than in recent years. Wind and weather conditions are expected to stay the same over the next few days, and hence the haze will persist. 

PM will be writing to Indonesian President Yudhoyono to register Singapore’s serious concerns and reiterate our offer to help. 

#sghaze

The press conference by PM Lee on the haze situation will be starting soon.

#sghaze

Just back from my Meet-the-People Session. We were all tracking the PSI during the MPS, and dismayed that for a time it went above 300. Minister Vivian has briefed the press to explain what we are doing, and guide the public on how to respond (http://bit.ly/10xFN8c). 

Cabinet had discussed the haze situation fully when it met this afternoon. But as the haze has worsened, I am meeting the relevant ministers again first thing tomorrow, and will brief the press after that. 

Meanwhile, if the PSI reading stays high, please stay indoors where possible and avoid heavy outdoor activities. Look out for one another - we will get through this together. - LHL

PM Lee Hsien Loong at Press Conference on Haze, 20 June 2013

(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

Sharing a photo of the haze taken from Istana. The city in the distance is barely visible.

We are all affected by the haze. Farmers and plantation owners in Sumatra are burning crops to clear land in the dry season, and unfortunately the winds are blowing the smoke all the way to Singapore. Ministers Vivian and Shanmugam have called their Indonesian counterparts to register our serious concerns and offer our help to fight the fires. 

We are monitoring the situation closely and will stay in close touch with the Indonesian authorities. Meanwhile, please stay indoors whenever you can, especially children, seniors and those prone to respiratory problems.  And do monitor NEA’s website (or use their myEnv app) for the latest updates. - LHL

http://app2.nea.gov.sg/corporate-functions/newsroom/advisories/update-on-haze-situation-17June2013

Celebrated the 25th Anniversary of the Lions Food Collection and Distribution Project last night. Lion Looi Im Heok started the project in 1988, single-handedly collecting and distributing food to the needy. Many stallholders, Ang Mo Kio residents and Lions volunteers were inspired to join him. The Project now benefits hundreds of people every week. Now 85, Mr Looi still goes to the collection site every Friday! What an inspiration to all of us to serve our fellow Singaporeans! - LHL (http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/pm-lee-hsien-loong-lauds-efforts-feed-needy)

Happy Father’s Day to all dads out there!

Today, we celebrate our fathers and all that they’ve done for their children and families. Nowadays many young fathers are much more involved in their children’s lives. They believe in spending time with their kids and so strengthening their families. Was especially touched by this story of Mr Kelvin Aik (http://bit.ly/11Qrg5q) , who did not let his disability stop him from being very involved in bringing up his son. Hats off.

My best wishes to all fathers … have a great day celebrating with your families. - LHL

(MCI Photo by LH Goh)

In Japan on holiday, I visited Mt Fuji (the Japanese call it Fuji-san) today. Met many Singaporeans on holiday there, including these two families. We went as tourists, but the mountain is sacred to many Japanese, and people have been making pilgrimages to the summit for a thousand years. - LHL

Always heartened to read of Singaporeans who help others, whether providing food to the poor like Mr Toh, or doing a something extra for our NSmen like Mr Tan (featured in ST http://bit.ly/161Yfod). There are many ways to help, and Mr Toh and Mr Tan do it the way they know best. I hope they inspire others to step out and spread this spirit of generosity. – LHL
We may be a densely built-up city, but we have many beautiful spots, and will take care to protect them as Singapore develops. - LHL

Very happy to see my father receive an Honorary Doctor of Laws degree from NUS today. – LHL

(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

Hosted Timor-Leste PM Xanana Gusmão today. Singapore and Timor-Leste have been good friends since 1975, when Timor-Leste declared itself independent of Portugal. Was happy we signed the bilateral Air Services Agreement – it will help bring our people closer together. I wish Timor-Leste every success. – LHL

(MCI photo by Kenji Soon)

Enjoyed the “Welcome to My World 2013” concert presented by Very Special Arts Singapore. The performers were Persons with Disabilities, and they put up an inspirational show. Thanks to VSA Singapore for helping Persons with Disabilities participate in and enjoy the arts! Do support such initiatives, to build a caring and inclusive society. – LHL
Today is the start of the June holidays. Happy holidays to all students.  Enjoy yourselves, and don’t do too much homework! :) – LHL

Glad that Vietnamese PM Nguyen Tan Dung accepted my invitation to speak at the Shangri-La Dialogue. He talked about building strategic trust between countries to keep the region peaceful and stable, and keeping ASEAN strong and united. - LHL

(Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung's Keynote Address: http://bit.ly/10Egakg)

Today marks the 10th anniversary of our fight against SARS. SARS was a difficult trial, but we overcame it as one people and emerged a stronger nation. We will never forget the 33 who succumbed to SARS. Our deepest appreciation goes to our brave healthcare workers, who risked their lives caring for SARS patients. – LHL

(Observing a minute of silence for those who succumbed to SARS./MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

With my volunteers who helped out at my Meet-the-People Session last night, after we finished our cases. They are the heartbeat of the constituency – organising events, solving residents’ problems, helping out at MPS, etc. Thank you for your passion and service! – LHL (http://instagram.com/p/Z6ytd3GJ09/#)

Met several of my FB readers over tea. It was a very diverse group. Nur’rahmahdiah saved her colleagues in last year’s Jurong Shipyard incident. Shabir, Galvin, Siang Yu and Jeremy have written songs or produced videos about Singapore. Social worker Fareez helps the less fortunate in Ang Mo Kio. They are excellent examples of Singaporeans with hope and heart.   

We discussed all sorts of issues, from housing and cars to technology and social media. Everyone agreed that the social media was an integral part of our lives. That is why I am launching my Instagram account (http://instagram.com/leehsienloong) today, to reach more Singaporeans, especially younger ones. Hope for your support!   

Looking forward to my next tea! – LHL
Enjoyed my tea today with 15 people from my Facebook page & Twitter account. Look forward to more such meetings! - LHL @baeyyamkeng @jeramzee @aspirantsg @anywool (http://instagram.com/p/Z0TGOiGJ_I/)

ILO ILO 爸妈不在家 has won the Camera d’Or at Cannes! It was judged the best first feature film of the festival. Congratulations to Anthony Chen, the cast and crew. This is the first time a Singaporean has won the award. Well done indeed! – LHL
Visited Mount Faber this evening. It had rained earlier, but after the skies cleared the city looked clean, green and beautiful. - LHL

Lively session at the Nikkei Conference in Tokyo. In my speech (http://bit.ly/13MXK1f) and Q&A, I shared my thoughts about Japan's international role and its relations with neighbours, where memories of the Second World War still linger. I also met some business leaders and could sense a mood of hope: that at last the Japanese economy is picking up. - LHL

(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

It has been a beautiful sunny day in Tokyo! Had good meetings with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, Deputy PM Taro Aso, and other LDP and DPJ leaders. We discussed ideas to strengthen Singapore-Japan relations, and talked about regional issues like the South China Sea and the Senkaku / Diaoyu islands. Look forward to the Nikkei Conference tomorrow. - LHL

(Kanpai! Toasting good Singapore-Japan relations with Mr Abe./MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

This being Public Service Week, let me thank all public officers for their good work every day. They work quietly, serving the public, making sure that everything goes well. Four of them appear in this video done by Republic Poly students for the Public Service Division. Thank you all for your commitment and dedication! - LHL

Singaporean director Anthony Chen’s film, ILO ILO 爸妈不在家, received a 15-minute standing ovation when it premiered at the Cannes Film Festival. It is also in the running for the Caméra d'Or (given to the best first feature in the Official Selection, the Director's Fortnight or International Critics' Week). Congrats to Anthony! You are a great encouragement to our budding directors! - LHL

Launched the national Workplace Safety and Health Campaign today. 

Workplace safety is very important. Every injury means pain, suffering and perhaps disability for the victim, every death a family broken. It is our duty to do all we can to avoid these accidents and take care of every worker.

We have made good progress improving workplace safety and health, but we have a long way to go. Every life counts, and every worker matters. Let us work together to keep our workplaces safe and healthy! – LHL

(Congratulating students Priscilla Bay Wei Ling (Xing Nan Pri), Teoh Yong Han (Westgrove Pri) and Teo Soon Hang (North View Pri) on winning the ‘Safety Starts With Me’ poster competition! Their poster designs were colourful and most impressive./MCI Photo by Chwee)
Took a walk at Sentosa this evening. Happy to see many families enjoying the beaches. It was a hot day, and these children were having fun with the fountains! - LHL

Sharing a BBC article on something close to our hearts – hawker food! :) Like all Singaporeans, my family and I enjoy hawker food – Tiong Bahru tau huay and Zion Road char kuay teow are some of our faves. 

The Government is building new hawker centres over the next few years. I hope Singaporeans try their hand at the hawker trade so that we can keep this unique aspect of Singapore life alive. - LHL

Officially opened the Marina Bay Financial Centre (MBFC) this afternoon. 

I felt good to see this project completed. I was involved in its inception in the late-1990s, when I was in MAS. Banks and financial institutions here were expanding rapidly. We decided to build a world-class business and financial hub in Marina Bay. The MBFC was the largest land parcel the Govt had ever sold at that time, and big risk for the developer to take. But the economy revived strongly after 9/11 and SARS, and the MBFC took off. Today 30,000 people work at the MBFC, and it is a beautiful addition to Marina Bay. - LHL

Happy Mother’s Day to all mums!

Being a mother is not easy. So often mothers have to put aside their own needs to look after their children. They support us through good times and bad, and patiently guide us through the years with love and care. We love them while they are here, and miss them when they are gone.

My warm wishes to all mums in Singapore and overseas! – LHL

Ellen Lee invited me to launch her new Woodlands Galaxy CC tonight (http://woodlands.oneconnect.sg/).  CCs have come a long way, from the days when they drew crowds with just black & white TVs and table tennis tables. The CC has an astronomical observatory (http://home.galaxyastro.sg/), good fitness facilities, and a handsome hall that is a very popular wedding venue. Hope residents use these facilities fully, and keep the kampong spirit alive in Woodlands! - LHL

Glad to support the Singapore Wushu, Dragon & Lion Dance Federation’s (aka Wuzong) fundraising dinner tonight.   Wuzong has popularised wushu, dragon and lion dance in Singapore. Many Singaporeans practise taichi and qigong, and students are taking up the sport in schools. Wuzong athletes have also won medals at the World Wushu Championships and SEA Games. Well done Wuzong! – LHL                                                                                                     

我今晚出席了我国武术总会的筹款晚宴，接触到各门各派武术团体的代表，好比是出席了一场武林大会 ! 过去四十多年，在政府的支持下，武总推广武术和舞龙舞狮的努力很有建树。在学校里，选择武术作为课外活动的学生增加了。我国武术选手在世界武术锦标赛、东运会中赢得不少奖牌，为国家争光。在邻里和社区，随处可见练习太极、气功和其他武术的人们。这是可喜的现象。希望武总和我国武术界百尺竿头、更进一步！- 李显龙
Came across this interesting time-lapse video produced by Yeo Wee Han. A refreshing and fun perspective on daily life in Singapore! Hope you enjoy it too. – LHL

Congrats to PM Najib Razak for leading the Barisan Nasional to a hard-fought and well-deserved victory at the Malaysian General Election, and on his own re-election in Pekan! 

Called PM Najib this morning to say that I looked forward to working with him again. We both agreed to continue our cooperation and further strengthen our bilateral ties. – LHL

(PMO Photo by Alex Qiu)

Had a great time with Active Ageing Committee teamleaders at the Outward Bound Singapore East Coast Campus.They were energised and in high spirits after the teambuilding exercise. 

The teamleaders work hard to keep our seniors active in the community under the PA Wellness Programme – organising qigong exercises, rummy-o games, fun excursions and much more. Our elders thus make more friends, and stay healthy and well in their silver years. Let us continue to do more for our elders, and give them peace of mind in their old age. - LHL

Congrats Ngee Ann Polytechnic (NP) on your 50th Anniversary! 

Polytechnics like NP are a jewel in our education system. They provide first rate tertiary education. Their students graduate as confident and skilled adults, who do well in many fields. We will be investing heavily in our polytechnics over the next few years. 

I was at the NP50 Celebration Dinner last evening, and enjoyed the commemorative exhibition as well as the vibrant student performances. Thank you NP! – LHL
Excerpts from the May Day Rally Speech 2013.
祝大家劳动节快乐！我早上出席职总举行的五一劳动节群众大会，在演讲中谈到我们的愿景：我们要保持经济稳健增长，并且让全体工友从中受益。我们正提升和重组经济，希望为新加坡人带来更好的、优质的工作。新加坡人受过良好的教育，加上我们过去曾经成功地改革经济，我因此相信我们这次也一定能成功，使新加坡成为一个充满希望的家园。– 李显龙

Happy May Day! On behalf of all Singaporeans, a big thank you to all workers for your hard work and contributions!

We want to improve workers’ lives, and are especially concerned with older workers, lower-wage workers and PMEs. We have programmes to help older workers continue working after turning 62, to top up wages through Workfare and the Wage Credit Scheme, and to make workplaces fair and inclusive.

We also need to grow the economic pie and share the benefits of growth widely. This means welcoming good investments that create better jobs. We must also continue to raise productivity of our companies and workers, and invest in our future, especially through education.

Tripartism will help us thrive in an uncertain world. It is our national treasure and a unique advantage which we must never lose. Employers, unions and Government must work together to strengthen tripartism and build a brighter future for all Singaporeans. – LHL

I’m speaking at the NTUC May Day Rally 2013 later this morning at 10:20. To see me live please go to http://bit.ly/fIyy40 or download the MyNTUC app at www.ntuc.org.sg/myntuc1(for iPhone) or www.ntuc.org.sg/myntuc2 (for Android). - LHL

Launched the “Do the Mozzie Wipeout” campaign today at Kebun Baru’s Inter-Generational Sports Day. Then visited the Mayflower Market/Food Centre and three blocks in Teck Ghee, to ask residents to help us stop mosquito breeding and dengue fever.   

We have already had 5,000 cases of dengue so far this year –more than the whole of last year. Public health inspectors are going round to check for mosquito breeding, but they need help. Thank you to the 30,000 volunteers in the Dengue Prevention Volunteer Groups!   

Each of us can do our part to reduce mosquito breeding and prevent dengue. Remember to change the water in vases, turn over water storage containers and cover bamboo pole holders that are not in use. Let's do the Mozzie Wipeout together, and protect our families! - LHL

This Sunday (28 April) is World Day for Safety and Health at Work. Singapore takes occupational safety and health very seriously. I have taken a personal interest in this matter, because it troubles me that our accident and fatal injury rates are higher than they could be. Every injury means pain and suffering for a worker, every death is a family distraught, bereft, and deprived of a breadwinner. It is our duty to reduce these to the absolute minimum, by instilling safety consciousness and safe work practices in workplaces.

Over the past decade, we have reduced the rate of fatal workplace injuries by more than half. We will continue to raise safety and health standards in our workplaces, to safeguard our workers’ well-being. I was happy to share our experience in my Message to the International Labour Organization (ILO) to commemorate World Day. – LHL

Back home from the 22nd ASEAN Summit in Brunei. 
 
ASEAN countries are working towards an ASEAN Economic Community by 2015. We also need to maintain ASEAN unity and promote regional peace and stability. Congratulations to His Majesty the Sultan for chairing a successful meeting!
 
Happy to make a side trip to visit our troops in Temburong. I first visited Temburong in 1982, before our present camp was built. Generations of SAF servicemen have since trained there, and learnt about fighting in the jungle. I thank His Majesty and the people of Brunei for allowing our servicemen to train in Brunei. 
 
Look forward to visiting Brunei again for the next ASEAN Summit in October. – LHL

Happy to receive this replica of the Singapore Artillery’s 125th anniversary painting. It is a beautiful piece. 

The Singapore Artillery has transformed itself beyond recognition. I remember fondly my time in the formation. The 120mm mortar was our main weapon, and we manually plotted firing data on charts, using rulers and protractors. Today, we have a high-tech force of sensors, shooters and systems, operated by highly-trained Gunners, integrated into the 3G SAF. I wish the Singapore Artillery every success for the future! Once a Gunner, Always a Gunner! - LHL

Hosted President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono today for our annual Leaders’ Retreat. The President and I welcomed the progress in our bilateral cooperation, and agreed to build on our excellent ties. I also congratulated President Yudhoyono on being conferred an honorary doctorate by NTU.  

Rounded off the evening by hosting President Yudhoyono, Ibu Ani, and the Indonesian delegation to dinner at the Istana. The band played several songs composed by President Yudhonoyo – Kembali, Untuk Bumi Kita and Berkelana Ke Ujung Dunia. I look forward to our next Retreat in Indonesia next year. – LHL
Saddened by the earthquake in China that struck Sichuan on Saturday. Wrote to Premier Li Keqiang to offer sympathies and support. – LHL
Ho Ching and I welcoming President Yudhoyono and Ibu Ani at the Istana. (MCI Photo by LH Goh)

Dropped in at Fernvale to visit the residents of Sengkang West this morning. Once upon a time Sengkang was a fishing village. Now it is a vibrant young residential town, with lots more HDB flats still being built. Took a walk around Fernvale Point, with the Fairprice store and food centres. Met and chatted with residents young and old (and even their pets) who were up and about on Sunday morning. Also visited the popular new complex of three Taoist temples and  one Buddhist temple. 

TQ to Dr Lam Pin Min and his team for hosting me! – LHL
With the Zones F & H Residents’ Committees, including some (very) young volunteers! (MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

Relieved that the terrorists who planted the bombs at the Boston Marathon have been found. My deepest condolences to the families of those who were killed or maimed. 

The events were on the other side of the world, but a good number of Singaporeans study or work in Boston. 18 Singaporeans participated in the Marathon. I am sure their families here were following events closely, and are greatly relieved that their loved ones are safe. 

Watching the news, I was inspired by the many stories of people behaving selflessly when facing fear and danger: spectators rushing to help victims instead of running away, healthcare workers working extra shifts to treat the injured, shopkeepers offering free food and drinks to comfort the public. Whatever our differences, we are all bound by a common humanity. 

The events this week remind us that we cannot take peace and security for granted, and must always remain vigilant. If ever Singapore encounters an incident like this, may we have the courage and the humanity to respond with the same grace and unity as the Bostonians. - LHL

I started this FB page a year ago today. It has been a fascinating and fun journey. I have learnt a lot from you, and greatly appreciated your comments and private messages. Many of you have candidly shared your thoughts, concerns, heartfelt messages and words of encouragement. Thank you very much for your support, and I look forward to sharing more with you and to hearing more from you in the year to come. – LHL

(Photos by MCI and PMO)

Attended the NTUC Fairprice 40th Anniversary Dinner last night. Fairprice has grown from its humble beginnings to become one of the largest grocery retailers in Singapore. Fairprice assures Singaporeans of a reliable and affordable supply of household essentials, and gives back to the community. Congratulations to Fairprice on your 40th anniversary!  - LHL

(Above) Viewing a mockup of an old NTUC Welcome (precursor to Fairprice) shelf; (Below) With recipients of NTUC Fairprice’s donation to the needy. [MCI Photos by LH Goh]

A Happy New Year to all Indians! The Tamils, Bengalis, Gujaratis etc celebrate their new year during April, and the Sikhs also celebrate Vaisakhi, an important religious festival. Let's all join our Indian friends for this joyous occasion! – LHL

Opened PAssionArts With A Thousand Hearts at Cheng San CC. The place had been transformed into a vibrant arts hub, with singing and dancing, painting and pottery, and more, right in the heart of Ang Mo Kio. 

There are many more “PAssionArts Villages” all over Singapore. Do visit one of them this month, and experience the fun of the arts up close! – LHL

Had lunch with unionists twice this week to prepare for the May Day Rally. I thank them for sharing their members’ views, and their sense of the challenges of transforming our economy. Govt will continue to do our best for our workers, especially the older ones, lower-income earners and PMEs. We want all Singaporeans to thrive in the new economic landscape. - LHL

(MCI Photos by Terence Tan)

Opened the inaugural World Health Summit Regional Meeting-Asia this evening. Healthcare officials, practitioners and businessmen from 49 countries are here to exchange ideas on improving health for all. 
 
Singapore’s health outcomes are good, but we can do more to encourage healthy lifestyles, care for our elderly and combat infectious diseases. The Govt is also reviewing our healthcare financing to keep healthcare affordable for all, especially the poor and elderly. There is much that we can learn from other countries as we improve our health systems. - LHL

(With Professor Detlev Ganten, Founding President of World Health Summit/MCI Photo by Chwee)
One of the many adorable babies at Baby Singapore 2013. (MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

Glad to be home from the US, and to spend the morning with my residents in Teck Ghee. We were holding Baby Singapore 2013, which attracted more than 100 infant participants. Teck Ghee is one of the older estates, so I was very happy to see so many young families, babies and kids around the community. I encourage more residents, not just in Teck Ghee but across Singapore, to take the time to get to know their neighbours and share in these community experiences as well. - LHL

(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

Last year I made a donation to the School of the Arts (SOTA) to create a Valedictorian Award to recognise the school’s most outstanding student. The inaugural award was conferred on Ms Ong Shu Chen today. Shu Chen studied music and classical singing, and has already been offered places at Emory University, Yale-NUS and the Yong Siew Toh Conservatory.
 
I wish Shu Chen and all SOTA graduates the very best. I hope you all continue to pursue your passions! - LHL

(Photo: Copyright SOTA 2013)

Rounding up four productive days here (in NYC) and in DC. Looking forward to going home tonight on SQ.   

My meetings were good. We see eye-to-eye on many issues with the US. We always find it interesting and valuable to exchange views, both on Singapore-US relations and more broadly on developments in Asia and the world. Americans have an excellent impression of Singapore, which is very valuable to us. We must maintain and strengthen that reputation. - LHL
Looking East out of my hotel window, as the sun sets over middle Manhattan.

It is springtime in DC and cherry trees are starting to blossom all around the White House. President Obama gave us a warm reception in the Oval Office. US and Singapore enjoy friendly relations and deep cooperation. We look forward to hosting the US Navy's first Littoral Combat Ship in a few weeks’ time.   Also spoke at a dinner hosted by the US Chamber of Commerce and US-ASEAN Business Council (USABC), attended by many old friends of ASEAN and Singapore. Will be travelling by train to New York tomorrow. - LHL
Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel receiving me at the Pentagon steps. (PMO Photo by Alex Qiu)

Starting my four-day US visit at Washington DC. Honoured to stay in Blair House, the President’s guest house built in 1824. I was welcomed by its General Manager Mr Randy Bumgardner who had also received our 2 former PMs to Blair House. Looking forward to calling on President Barack Obama in the Oval Office, and catching up with old friends from the Administration and the business community. - LHL 

(PMO Photos by Alex Qiu)

Today is Good Friday. On this day and on Easter Sunday, Christians commemorate the death and resurrection of Jesus Christ. Easter is a moveable feast, i.e., one which does not occur on the same fixed date every year. I wish all those who celebrate this Christian festival a good weekend. For those who love their Easter eggs, enjoy! - LHL
Admiring the impressive new ITE College Central campus at Ang Mo Kio. The campus offers many varied courses and has great facilities. (MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

Spoke at the International Conference on Terrorist Rehabilitation and Community Resilience today. Singapore is lucky that we have not suffered a terrorist attack in recent years, thanks to the Home Team and the Religious Rehabilitation Group (RRG). 

The RRG turns 10 today. The Group comprises respected Muslim religious leaders (asatizahs), who have done much to counter radical ideology and persuade terrorism-related detainees that their beliefs are contrary to Islam. The RRG is chaired by Ustaz Ali Mohd and Ustaz Mohd Hasbi Hassan, and has helped to rehabilitate and reintegrate many such detainees into society. I thank all the RRG asatizahs for their service and contributions! – LHL

(MCI Photo by Terence Tan: Ustaz Ali and Ustaz Hasbi receiving a calligraphy from Sister Maria Lau and Mr Tan Thiam Lye, representing the Inter-Religious Organisation, thanking the RRG for their decade of good work.)

Enjoyed my visit to Queenstown this morning. The town is celebrating its 60th anniversary, and is named after Queen Elizabeth II (whose Coronation was in 1953). Queenstown remains a vibrant estate, with young couples and new flats in the neighbourhoods. The ABC Brickworks Hawker Centre and Tanglin Halt Market were packed with residents and visitors, there for breakfast and marketing. At Queenstown CC, students from CHIJ St Nicholas Girls’ School and Queensway Secondary School were having a carnival. Rounded off a fruitful visit with a good dialogue with grassroots leaders and community partners.   

Many thanks to MP Dr Chia Shi-Lu and his team for hosting my visit. – LHL

Proud to see the progress of the Malay/Muslim community. Young Malays have done well in education, sports, music, business, and many other fields. Minister Yaacob mentioned several outstanding individuals in Parliament last Friday. Berita Harian had a neat picture spread of them today. 

Our model of meritocracy has worked well. The government will continue to work with the community, to upgrade education standards and uplift families, especially those in need. This is essential as education is a key social leveller. Let’s continue to strive for excellence! - LHL 

Bangga melihat kemajuan masyarakat Melayu/Islam kita. Ramai anak muda telah berjaya dalam berbagai bidang seperti pendidikan, sukan, muzik, perniagaan dan lain-lain. Menteri Yaacob telah menyebut beberapa individu cemerlang di Parlimen Jumaat lepas. Hari ini pula, Berita Harian menyiarkan lebih banyak gambar berwarna berserta pencapaian mereka.  

Model meritokrasi kita memang amat berkesan. Pemerintah akan terus bekerjasama dengan masyarakat untuk meningkatkan lagi taraf pendidikan dan kehidupan keluarga, terutama mereka yang memerlukan. Ini adalah penting kerana pendidikan adalah kunci untuk menyamaratakan kedudukan sosial. Marilah kita terus berusaha untuk mencapai kecemerlangan! - LHL

(SPH - BH Graphic)

Visited the new ITE College Central campus at Ang Mo Kio yesterday. It looks striking from the road, but the campus is even more impressive.

One of its attractions is ITE Epitome, a public “mini-mall” run by students with companies like Far East Flora and Jean Yip Group. Another surprise was to see the real aircraft in the college, including a Boeing 737! Aerospace Engineering is a very popular course at the College, and students learn their skills on real aircraft and real engines. 

ITE has done a great job providing a high-quality technical education to our students. The teachers are dedicated and passionate, and the students are high spirited and ambitious. I am proud of both the teachers and students, who show us that nothing is impossible if we work hard and pursue our dreams. – LHL

It’s school holidays! Hope parents will find time to bring your children out this week. I particularly enjoy our parks, and recommend a visit to one of them. MacRitchie Reservoir is one of my favourites. Have a good week! - LHL

(Boardwalk at MacRitchie Reservoir. For more info on our parks, go to http://bit.ly/YlgJKG. Image courtesy of Singapore Tourism Board.)

Celebrated World Water Day at Marina Barrage this morning. We have made it a national priority to provide reliable and clean water. We must continue to conserve every drop of water and take care of our rivers and reservoirs. 

Glad that more than 35,000 people participated in today’s celebrations across the island, including community organisations and young students, especially from Hwa Chong Institution and the CHIJs who came in force to the Barrage. – LHL

57th SCCCI Council Installation Ceremony / 中华总商会第57届董事会就职典礼

Witnessed the installation of the 57th Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI) Council this morning. 
 
The SCCCI is a leading business and Chinese community organisation, advancing their members’ interests and promoting Chinese culture. It does good work to help us pursue quality growth and build an inclusive society - identifying new growth opportunities overseas, helping members upgrade, and working with the Govt to improve our policies. I look forward to a fruitful partnership as we navigate this new landscape together. 
 
Also wish to thank outgoing President Teo Siong Seng and the 56th Council for their many valuable contributions. My warmest congrats to incoming President Thomas Chua and his newly elected Council.
– LHL

我上午出席中华总商会第57届董事会就职典礼。新一届董事会由资深董事和商界新秀组成，延续了总商会近年来不断更新领导层的趋势。我向新任会长蔡其生先生和新一届董事表示祝贺，希望他们能继续为我国的商业，文教和社区事业作出贡献。我也向卸任会长张松声先生以及上一届董事会表示感激。他们热心公益和文教事业，也在政策的制定上为政府提供宝贵的意见和反馈。- 李显龙

(MCI Photo by Kenji Soon)

My warmest congratulations to President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Keqiang on their election as China’s leaders by the National People’s Congress. They are taking over at an important juncture of China’s development. I am confident that they will lead China to many more years of peace and prosperity.
 
Singapore and China enjoy excellent relations. I last met President Xi in Singapore in November 2010, and Premier Li in Beijing last September. I look forward to working with them to take our bilateral relations forward. - LHL
 
[Top (MCI Photo): Hosting Mr Xi Jinping during his visit to Singapore in 2010;
Bottom (ZaoBao Photo): Meeting with Mr Li Keqiang in Beijing in 2012]

Congrats to His Holiness Pope Francis on his election as Supreme Pontiff of the Catholic Church and spiritual leader of Catholics around the world. Relations between Singapore and the Holy See are warm. We have worked together to promote equity and development, and foster peace and religious harmony. I look forward to continue cooperating with the Catholic Church, the Apostolic Nuncio in Singapore Archbishop Leopoldo Girelli and our newly appointed Coadjutor Archbishop William Goh towards our shared goals. – LHL

Had dinner with the Rolls-Royce Board at Sentosa. Singapore’s partnership with Rolls-Royce goes way back to the 1950s. Since then Rolls Royce has put more and more investments into Singapore. Last year, I launched the Rolls-Royce Seletar Campus, which manufactures the latest Trent engines (used on A380 Airbus aircraft) and the very high tech, wide-chord fan blades that go into these engines. Singapore is the only place outside the UK to do so. The project has created many good jobs for Singaporeans (who make up most of the workforce) and helps us become a global aerospace hub. 
 
As we upgrade our economy, we must continue to welcome high quality investments such as Rolls-Royce’s, which create skilled, well-paying jobs for Singaporeans. May our partnership with Rolls-Royce continue for many more years to come! – LHL

(MCI Photo by LH Goh: (Right) Rolls-Royce Chairman Sir Simon Robertson and (middle) EDB Chairman Leo Yip)

Delighted to learn that three Oriental Pied Hornbills have hatched at the Jurong Bird Park, and just celebrated their full month. The three eggs had been abandoned by their mother at Pulau Ubin, were rescued by NParks Rangers, and then artificially incubated at the Bird Park (see http://bit.ly/XlVz4E for full story). This is a world first - never before have Oriental Pied Hornbill eggs been hatched in this way. 

Thanks to the conservation efforts by the Jurong Bird Park, NParks and Singapore Avian Conservation Project, the number of hornbills in Singapore has grown from 10 in 2005 to between 75 – 100 today. There are even two breeding pairs of hornbills on the Istana grounds, which I understand are expecting chicks soon! - LHL

(ST Photo)

Very saddened to learn that one of my oldest residents, Mdm Yeo Kheng Lien, 99, passed away this morning. When I met Mdm Yeo at the hongbao presentation last year, she was a spry old lady, in good health and good spirits, tickled to have her picture taken on my iPhone. I met her again at this year’s hong bao presentation. She was frail, having just been discharged from hospital, but had insisted on coming to meet me. My deepest condolences to Mdm Yeo’s family. May she rest in peace. – LHL 

(ZaoBao Photo)

In Parliament today, Minister Khaw Boon Wan reported on our progress in tackling housing issues. Singles will be able to purchase new 2-Room BTO flats from the July BTO exercise. We are also extending the Parenthood Priority Scheme to expectant mothers, and improving chances for married first-timer applicants to get BTO flats. Mr Khaw also spoke about the housing needs of second-timers, divorcees/widowed, as well as seniors. Meanwhile, HDB will continue to hold BTO prices steady, de-linked from the resale market, until the property market stabilises.
 
The Ministry of National Development also plans to hold public discussions to re-examine the fundamentals of our housing policies through OurSGConversation. Do share your thoughts with us! – LHL

Had a fruitful debate on Budget 2013 this week. In his round-up speech, DPM Tharman Shanmugaratnam explained how the Budget helps Singaporeans and businesses (video below).  
 
Our low-income workers will benefit through an expanded Workfare programme. The middle-income will be covered by the new Wage Credit Scheme. The Transition Support Package will help our SMEs raise productivity. We have made our taxes more progressive, so that the well-off bear more of the burden, but we must not go overboard and discourage hard work, entrepreneurship and success. We are studying how to make healthcare more affordable, especially for older people. If we work together, Singapore can achieve quality growth, and be an inclusive society. – LHL

Parliament will be sitting this week and next, until 15 March. We have been debating the Budget 2013 speech delivered by DPM Tharman these three days. After that, we go on to scrutinise the spending plans of the Ministries one by one (also known as the Committee of Supply). Look forward to hearing what the MPs will raise, and to Ministers answering their questions, considering their requests, and picking up their ideas. (MCI Photo by LH Goh)

Very proud of our three young talents who performed at Carnegie Hall in New York last Sunday. They had won prizes at American Protégé (http://www.americanprotege.com/) competitions last year. Charis Lim (9 years old, won International Flute Competition) performed Tchaikovsky’s ‘Barcarolle’. Dhyana Srinivasan (8 years old, second at the International Music Talent Competition) performed ‘Greensleeves’ (a Celtic folk song) on the flute. Lauren Yeo (9 years old, won International Vocal Competition) sang Andrew Lloyd Webber’s ‘Pie Jesu’. I met Lauren a week ago at the Istana CNY Garden Party. She has a beautiful voice! I hope they inspire more young Singaporeans to pursue their dreams. Well done, girls! – LHL

(PMO Photo by Alex Qiu)

What are your thoughts on this year’s Budget? 

Please share your views with us. REACH Chairman Dr Amy Khor, and MPs Baey Yam Keng & Zaqy Mohamad will be doing a live FB chat on the Budget this evening from 7.30pm to 9pm on the REACH FB page. I encourage you to join them.

You can read more about Budget 2013 here [http://bit.ly/BudgetinBrief]. – LHL

My best wishes to the over 14,000 students and private candidates who received their ‘A’ level results today! You have worked hard to get here, and will soon embark on different journeys in life – doing National Service, furthering your studies, working, or taking some time to find yourself. I wish you all success and fulfilment in your pursuits. – LHL
Hope to make Singapore an even better home for our families (MCI Photo by L H Goh)

DPM Tharman Shanmugaratnam presented Budget 2013 this afternoon. His theme was “A better Singapore: Quality growth, An Inclusive Society”. 

Our immediate priority is to solve the housing and transport issues. At the same time, we must upgrade our economy through productivity and innovation. Budget 2013 will help our businesses cope with much lower foreign worker growth over the next few years. It also contains schemes to enable every Singaporean to benefit from growth. For example, the Wage Credit Scheme will incentivise employers to raise salaries of their lower-income workers, as the Govt will pay 40% of these salary increases for three years. We will also focus on promoting social mobility, especially through education, so that children from less privileged backgrounds are not disadvantaged in our society. 

The Parliament will discuss Budget 2013 in the upcoming weeks. You can visit www.singaporebudget.gov.sg for more details about the Budget. - LHL

Hosted the Chinese New Year Garden Party this evening at the Istana with my Cabinet colleagues. I look forward to the Garden Party every year, to thank grassroots volunteers for their hard work and to catch up with old friends. They serve loyally and passionately, and help us build strong and cohesive communities. 
 
Today is also Yuan Xiao Jie (元宵节), also known as Chap Gor Meh, the fifteenth and last day of CNY. It is the Chinese equivalent of Valentine’s Day, so I hope many young couples are enjoying the festival! – LHL

(MCI photo by Kenji Soon)

Attended the Ordination Reception of Coadjutor Archbishop of Singapore, William Goh. 
 
The Catholic Church (Archdiocese of Singapore) is a key part of our diverse religious landscape. It has served the poor and needy of all faiths and races, provided excellent education and social services, and benefited many Singaporeans over the years. I have worked closely with Archbishop Nicholas Chia to promote religious harmony and understanding during his term as Archbishop, and thank him for his many contributions over the past 12 years. 

At the reception, Coadjutor Archbishop Goh explained to me his Coat-Of-Arms, which included his motto and other symbols that represent Singapore and the French Mission founding of the Catholic Church here. His Grace intends to lead the Church to continue contributing to a cohesive and compassionate society, peace and harmony in Singapore. 
 
I congratulate Coadjutor Archbishop Goh and look forward to working with him. I am confident that the Catholic Church and its 300,000 strong community will continue to flourish and make important contributions to Singapore under his leadership. - LHL

(MCI Photo by Chwee)

Thoroughly enjoyed the Chingay Parade (妆艺大游行) this evening! 
 
Chingay is a highlight of our CNY celebrations. It is now a multi-cultural parade, comprising performances by Chinese groups as well as other ethnic and international groups. This year’s theme is “Fire in Snow”, which connotes resilience. 

I see resilience in many Singaporeans - people who have encountered misfortune or survived cancer, people born with special needs who have overcome them to excel, people who push themselves to achieve daunting challenges. Many such Singaporeans joined the finale of the Parade tonight. Their grit and determination make them special, and make Singapore special. Resilience is a vital part of the Singapore spirit. 
 
A big thank you to the many Parade performers and volunteers, who have practised very hard for many months. I enjoyed chatting with several of them after the parade (including several from Teck Ghee). You can still catch the Chingay parade (http://www.chingay.org.sg/) tomorrow or watch it on Channel 8 this Sunday, from 8pm onwards. - LHL

(MCI Photo by Kenji Soon)

Held a successful Retreat with PM Najib Razak today. Singapore-Malaysia ties are excellent, and we both agreed to strengthen our partnership and cooperation further.

Temasek Holdings and Khazanah Nasional Berhad are jointly developing projects in Singapore and in Iskandar Malaysia. We witnessed the unveiling of three of the projects today – the Marina One development in Marina South, and the Urban Wellness Centre and Resort Wellness Centre in Iskandar Malaysia. These projects reflect the trust and goodwill between our countries.

PM Najib and I also agreed to build a High Speed Rail link between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore. This will be a game changer in our relations.  It will foster more people-to-people and business exchanges between Singapore and Malaysia, and create growth and prosperity for both countries. – LHL

Thank you all for your warm wishes for Mr Lee Kuan Yew’s recovery.

This evening, I celebrated CNY with Teck Ghee residents. CNY is a wonderful occasion to remember our families – thanking our parents for their sacrifices, and showering love on our own children. PMO Statement

Today is Total Defence Day, the anniversary of the surrender of Singapore to the Japanese invaders in World War II on 15 February 1942. We honour those who died in the war through ceremonies like the one at the War Memorial Park this morning. We also remember to be ready as a nation to defend ourselves against threats and dangers, even in peacetime. 

Each year, many individuals and organisations organise different activities to mark the occasion. MINDEF runs an animation contest called N.E.mation, and many creative schoolchildren produce excellent videos for it. You can watch the top 10 videos from this year’s competition here (http://bit.ly/UlZuvD), or check out www.standwithme.sg for some of the other novel ways that Singaporeans are showing support for Total Defence today. - LHL

(Photos courtesy of SCCCI)

Hosted my grassroots leaders and volunteers in Ang Mo Kio GRC and Sengkang-West SMC to an open house today. They play a valuable role in our communities helping residents to solve problems, organising social activities, and managing community facilities like Community Clubs, Residents’ Committee Centres, etc. I have veterans who have served for decades, and also new volunteers. Always enjoy catching up with everyone during this festive occasion. - LHL

新春献词 2013
Chinese New Year Message 2013

Dalam ucapan Melayu saya, saya bercakap mengenai keutamaan kita untuk menggalak rakyat Singapura untuk berkahwin dan memanfaatkan pakej Perkahwinan dan Keibubapaan yang terbaru sebagai insentif untuk mempunyai ramai anak. Saya juga menyatakan bahawa Pemerintah akan terus mengekalkan keseimbangan kaum dalam bilangan warga Singapura dan memberi keyakinan bahawa peratusan orang Melayu di sini akan kekal stabil. Pemerintah juga akan menjaga kepentingan warga Singapura dalam apa jua yang kita lakukan dan terus memberi keutamaan kepada warga Singapura, termasuk orang Melayu, dalam semua dasar kami. Dan kami juga akan terus menjaga mereka yang memerlukan. Masa depan kita bergantung kepada usaha padu kita untuk mengukuhkan semangat Singapura. Saya berharap masyarakat Melayu akan menyokong dasar-dasar kependudukan kita dan bekerjasama dengan Pemerintah untuk membina masa depan yang lebih cerah untuk semua rakyat Singapura. - LHL

过去五天，国会针对人口白皮书展开热烈的辩论。我今天下午也参加了这场重要的辩论。我在演讲时强调，这份白皮书是为了解决人口老化和生育率偏低所带来的长远问题，目的是使新加坡维持适度的经济增长，同时又能不断地改善生活的素质。白皮书是以新加坡人的利益为依归。我们无意将人口增加到690万，而是会尽量节制移民和外劳的流入。我们没有解决所有问题的方案，因此希望新加坡人继续关注这些问题， 继续为政府提供意见，使我们能够不断地改善政策。- 李显龙

Parliament has had an intense debate on the Population White Paper over the past week. Many MPs spoke passionately about this difficult issue. I joined the debate this afternoon. The White Paper is about mitigating the problems of our aging population and low birth rates, so as to secure Singapore’s future. Our priority is to maintain a strong Singaporean core by encouraging Singaporeans to get married and have children. We will reduce inflow of foreign workers, moderate flow of new citizens and maintain PR population at about present size. We are not aiming for 6.9 million population – it is just a basis for us to plan our infrastructure. 

The conversation on population does not end today, and we do not yet have answers to all the problems. I hope Singaporeans will continue to give us your feedback to allow us to improve our policies and Singaporeans’ lives. - LHL

Thereafter, we visited the market and hawker centre at Blk 341. Many families were having their breakfasts, and doing last-minute shopping for the upcoming celebrations. – LHL

Had lunch with Board members of United Technologies Corporation (UTC), an aerospace and building systems MNC (http://www.utc.com/). UTC has been in Singapore since 1983 (and as Otis Elevator even longer). Many Board members and executives had been based in Singapore earlier in their careers and remembered it fondly. 

Pratt & Whitney, a division of UTC, has just opened a plant at the Seletar Aerospace Park to manufacture high-tech aircraft engine components. They decided to do it here because of our excellent workforce, flexible labour markets, intellectual property protection and good relations with the US (so that UTC can get US permission to produce very high-tech products here). We must maintain these important advantages, so that our workers can always have good quality jobs. – LHL 

(MCI Photo by LH Goh)

Fully agree with Khaw Boon Wan's explanation that a 6.9m population is not a target, but just a worst case, aggressive scenario that we must prepare for. We need to plan consciously and responsibly for the future, so Singaporeans continue to enjoy a good quality of life, and Singapore continues to thrive. - LHL

The Ministry of National Development just issued its Land Use Plan, which outlines how Singaporeans can continue to enjoy good quality living, even with a bigger population (www.mnd.gov.sg/landuseplan).

Right now we are working hard building many more HDB flats, and improving our bus and train services. We should see significant improvements within 3-5 years. 

In the longer term (by 2030), we will build 700,000 new homes. They will be integrated with parks, childcare centres, healthcare facilities and recreational spots right at your doorsteps. We will double our MRT network, improve bus services, and bring offices nearer to homes to reduce commuting. Singapore will always be a City in a Garden. 

Confident that Singapore will continue to offer a good quality living environment, and be one of the most liveable cities in the world. - LHL

(HDB Photo)

Chinese New Year is round the corner, and families are busy preparing for the Year of the Snake. This is a time to celebrate with our loved ones, hold reunion dinners, and visit relatives and friends. I hope that we can all take time from our usual busy routines to bond with our families, and keep these important traditions alive. – LHL

(PMO Photo by Alex Qiu)

We just published the Population White Paper (http://population.sg/). It outlines how we intend to build a sustainable population with a strong Singaporean core.

Our goal is simple: To ensure Singapore continues thriving, for the sake of our younger generation. But our population challenges are difficult and complex. It is not just the headline number which matters, but getting the right mix of citizens and non-citizens, creating exciting opportunities for our people, and building a city that offers a high quality of life and a nation that is the best home for all of us. 

Parliament will be debating the White Paper next week. Do read the White Paper to understand what is at stake. 

I also wish to thank the many Singaporeans who contributed useful views to the White Paper. - LHL

(MCI Photo)

Saddened to learn of the terrible accident at Tampines involving two young brothers. So tragic that an evening cycle could end like this. My thoughts are with their family. We will render all the help they need to get through this difficult period. Meanwhile, let us continue to show sensitivity and respect for the family, especially online. – LHL

Did a lively dialogue at Singapore Perspectives, the flagship annual conference organised by the Institute of Policy Studies (http://bit.ly/YyYTsO). Participants asked about many issues: the political climate, the “new normal”, what the future holds, fundamental values of governance, and policy issues. The questions were pertinent, and I did my best to be open, sharing our thinking and considerations with them. 

IPS is celebrating its 25th anniversary this year. It has done a good job promoting better understanding of policy issues and good governance. I wish it all the best. - LHL

Called on Her Majesty Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands today. Our relationship with the Dutch goes back to the 19th century when Dutch traders first arrived here. Dutch companies like Shell and Philips have been here for many years.  
 
We have a road named after Dutch economist Dr Albert Winsemius, who was Singapore’s Chief Economic Advisor from 1961 to 1984 and laid the foundation for Singapore's economic progress and prosperity. Albert Winsemius Lane leads to the Aquatic Science Centre, a collaboration between PUB, NUS and Dutch research institute Deltares. It will soon be renamed the Van Kleef Centre, after the same man who donated money to build our old Van Kleef Aquarium. 

We will continue to strengthen our friendship with the Netherlands, and work together for the mutual benefit of our countries and our people. – LHL

(MCI Photo by LH Goh)

I know many couples and parents worry about childcare for their young children, especially when both adults are working. Many of you commented on this when I posted on the Marriage & Parenthood Package on Monday. 

We are increasing child and infant care subsidies, for families with a gross monthly income of up to $7,500 (http://sg.sg/UjFxV0). We are also expanding the number of good quality and affordable childcare centres. This will give parents with young children greater peace of mind, and hopefully encourage couples to have more children. – LHL

Hawker centres form an important part of our social landscape, and are pleasant communal spaces where families and friends come together to enjoy cheap and tasty meals. 

The Government will build 10 new hawker centres over the next few years. This will create more opportunities for young people with an interest in cooking to become “hawker-preneurs”. A group of four Nanyang Technological University students recently launched a photo exhibition to encourage young people to do this. It features eight talented youths (seven of whom are in this photo) who have found joy and success by this route. May they inspire more to start their own hawker stalls, and develop even more delicious and iconic Singaporean hawker fare! – LHL

At last year’s National Day Rally, I floated some ideas to encourage Singaporeans to have more babies. Today, DPM Teo Chee Hean announced the enhanced Marriage and Parenthood Package. This will include priority for first-timer married couples with children when they book HDB flats, more generous support for conception and delivery, bigger Baby Bonus, a new CPF Medisave grant for newborns and one week of Government-paid paternity leave. Please visit www.heybaby.sg for more details. 

I hope that the new package will encourage more couples to think of starting families, and we will see more babies soon! :) – LHL

(MCI Photo by LH Goh)

Hosted lunch for the Crown Princess of Thailand, HRH Maha Chakri Sirindhorn, an old and good friend of Singapore. We had chicken rice (her favourite Singaporean dish), wonton soup, cereal prawns and cheng tng. 

We talked about many things: the Crown Princess’ education projects in Southern Thailand, info technology (the Crown Princess uses Whatsapp but not Facebook), and the region. Her great grandfather King Chulalongkorn (Rama V) had been close to Mr Tan Kim Ching (the eldest son of Tan Tock Seng), and appointed him Thailand’s Consul-General to Singapore. Mr Tan helped the Royal Family to purchase “Hurricane House” in Orchard Road where the Thai Embassy still stands. King Chulalongkorn also donated $1,000 (in gold baht coins), a princely sum in the 19th century, to build the Tan Tock Seng Hospital. Today the hospital runs a training programme for senior Thai nurses selected by the Crown Princess’ office. Our friendship with Thailand goes back a long way. – LHL

Singapore enjoys a high standing among foreigners. Professor Martyn Partridge is a Brit who has been based here for 2 years, helping to set up the Lee Kong Chian School of Medicine at NTU. In a recent interview by The Guardian (a UK newspaper), he described Singapore as a “wonderful place to work, with excited, interested and well-trained colleagues”. This is the way we should always be. – LHL

Gave a thank-you dinner together with the GIC Board to Dr Richard Hu and Ng Kok Song this evening. It was a special occasion, because both have been with GIC since it was first formed in 1981. They have contributed much to Singapore – overseeing and managing our reserves through booms and crashes, growing them steadily year by year, and mentoring generations of younger officers. 

Richard was the first private sector member of the GIC Board. After he retired from Shell Singapore, he became the Managing Director of GIC (and MAS concurrently), before serving as Finance Minister. He continued serving on the GIC Board even after he retired from politics. He was widely respected for building up GIC and for his humble and fair disposition. 

Kok Song was GIC’s Chief Investment Officer. He was a key person, almost an institution, in GIC. He could have done well for himself elsewhere, but chose to stay in GIC because he found meaning and satisfaction in working for the nation, for a greater cause than a typical bank or fund manager. Besides his work in GIC, Kok Song also chaired the Wealth Management Institute and served on the Singapore Labour Foundation.

Many others like Richard and Kok Song work quietly out of the public eye, making Singapore a better place for us all with their talents and energies. They deserve our support and gratitude. 

I thank them both for all they have done for GIC, and wish them a long and contented retirement. - LHL

(MCI Photo by Kenji Soon)

Did my MPS last night. We compiled a profile of all the MPS cases we handled in Teck Ghee over the last year, which I thought you might find interesting. 

In 2012, we served nearly 2,800 residents (many of whom came more than once) and wrote over 5,500 letters of appeal, or more than 100 letters per week. Just under half the cases live in Teck Ghee itself, while the rest were from other parts of Ang Mo Kio GRC. More than half were older residents (aged 46 or older). Half live in 3-room flats, mirroring the housing profile of our estate. But I had a sprinkling (3%) from private estates too – these residents are generally able to handle problems themselves, though once in a while they too find they need their MP.

The most frequent appeals (more than a third) concerned housing, e.g. buying/selling flats or requests for rental flats. HDB has a tough job, but it is making progress building more BTO flats and shortening waiting times for rental flats. 

Other common appeals were for financial assistance (14%, including social assistance, or help with paying bills), followed by immigration matters (12%, including citizenship & PR, employment or social visit passes), and traffic/parking issues (9% of letters, mostly appealing against summonses). Education appeals (4%) popped up seasonally, especially during school or university / poly / ITE admissions season. 

Fortunately, we encountered not many requests for help to find jobs (3%) reflecting our low unemployment. Nor were there were many requests for help with medical bills (only 82 cases throughout the whole year, less than 2%), though I know that people worry a lot about healthcare costs and we will continue to monitor them closely. 

We always seek to give residents a full and sympathetic hearing, and to help them as best as we can. Even if we can’t fully solve all their problems, we can often at least lessen them. I always feel encouraged when residents come to thank us, like this one who brought me a special thank you card. I had written for Mr Koh Chek Heng to NUH a few weeks ago, and obtained a medical report which he needed to show to several government agencies. – LHL
The Singapore skyline. (Photo by Terence Tan, Courtesy of Ministry of National Development)

Happy that MPs elected Mdm Halimah Yacob to be the 9th Speaker of Parliament today. She has the skills and the experience to manage debates well, and I am confident she will discharge her duties with distinction. We all wish her all the best in her new role.

Today’s Parliament sitting was the first of the year. Ministers answered questions on issues like the Executive Condominium (EC) scheme, and MOE’s decision not to publicise the names of top PSLE students. We are off on a good start and I look forward to upcoming debates on the Population White Paper and Budget 2013. - LHL 

(MCI Photo by LH Goh)

One of the joys of living in multi-ethnic Singapore is that we celebrate festivals of other communities, and not just our own. Tomorrow is the start of the Tamil month “Thai” (which falls in mid-January), and the celebration of Pongal, a traditional Indian harvest festival that typically lasts four days.  In homes, families will gather to cook sticky sweet rice in new pots, allowing the milk to boil over (and shouting “Pongal! Pongal!”) as a sign of prosperity, ushering in better times for the family and the nation. Like all other festivals, such celebrations reinforce family bonds and generational ties. I wish all who celebrate it a Happy Pongal! - LHL

இல்லங்களில், குடும்பங்கள் ஒன்றுகூடி, புதுப் பானையில் சர்க்கரைப் பொங்கலிட்டு, பொங்கலோடு வளமும் நலமும் பொங்கிட, வீடும் நாடும் செழித்தோங்க அறுவடைத் திருநாளைக் கொண்டாடி வரவேற்கிறார்கள். மற்ற பண்டிகைகளைப் போலவே பொங்கல் திருநாளும் குடும்பப் பிணைப்புகளை வலுப்படுத்தும் இனிய தருணமாய் அமைகிறது. இந்த இனிய வேளையில், பொங்கல் திருநாளைக் கொண்டாடும் அனைவருக்கும் என் பொங்கல் தின நல்வாழ்த்துகள்! – LHL

Caught up with former Chief Justice Chan Sek Keong (on my right) over dinner tonight, with a few friends. He stays active, and still takes a close interest in the law. I thanked him again for his significant contributions over 26 years of public service. As CJ, he raised the standing of Singapore’s legal system at home and abroad, and laid strong foundations for CJ Sundaresh Menon to build upon. I hope his example will inspire many to step forward to contribute to Singapore’s Legal Service and Public Service. – LHL 

(MCI Photo by Kenji Soon)

My best wishes to those who got their ‘O’ level results today! The next phase of your life awaits – whether in poly, JC, or at work. Wherever you go, do your best. We will give you every opportunity to succeed and realise your dreams. Aim to be not just good students or workers, but also good citizens and people. I wish you success and happiness in your pursuits. – LHL

This morning I advised the President to issue the Writ of Election for Punggol East constituency. Nomination Day will be 16 January, and Polling Day 26 January. 

We have a busy national agenda this year. Immediate issues are the Population White Paper, Budget 2013, and Our Singapore Conversation. A continuing priority is economic growth and workers’ incomes, especially in a weak global economy. I have decided to hold a by-election in Punggol East to give the residents their own MP in Parliament, before we focus back on these national issues. 

I hope Punggol East residents will vote wisely for the candidate who can best represent them in Parliament, solve their problems and improve their lives. – LHL
I intend to nominate Mdm Halimah Yacob to be elected as the Speaker of Parliament when Parliament next sits on 14 Jan 13. See my statement to the media below. – LHL

Presented Edusave awards and Teck Ghee Bursaries to 1,500 students in Teck Ghee this afternoon. The Edusave awards now cover not only academic performance but also character, leadership, service and other non-academic factors. 

There are many deserving recipients today. Xavier did not let night blindness stop him from participating in Adventure Camp. Nurhidayah overcame asthma to captain her school hockey team. The Edusave awards reflect the Government’s commitment to meritocracy, and to help every student achieve their best. To the students, congratulations and keep on trying to do better! :) – LHL

Met this group of SUTD students at the Zion Road Hawker Centre, where I was having dinner with my family. They are the pioneer batch, enjoying the SUTD course. Hope they do well! - LHL
Had a memorable time welcoming in 2015 with residents at Bishan-Ang Mo Kio Park last night. Looking forward to #SG50 this year. – LHL

Took a walk along the Sungei Pang Sua Park Connector this evening. Lots of people jogging, cycling or walking their dogs, including these two joggers. A healthy, fun and family friendly way to spend New Year’s Day! - LHL
Beautiful display of fireworks at the Marina Bay Singapore Countdown. (Photo by Bryan van der Beek, courtesy of Esplanade – Theatres on the Bay)

Happy New Year everyone!

We’ve made steady progress this year, even though growth was slower. In our new phase, we need to strike a balance between the head and heart, whether in the Our Singapore Conversation, dealing with the population issue, or embracing the right values as we progress as one society. I talk about this in my New Year Message.

Thanks also to all of you for your support on FB and Twitter this year. I have greatly enjoyed interacting with all of you, and reading your comments and messages. Wishing all Singaporeans a successful and fulfilling 2013 and beyond :) 

– LHL
Getting ready for the Marina Bay Singapore Countdown. (PMO Photo by Terence Tan)

Attended the bersanding (wedding reception) of Syaiful Haq and Siti Hajar this afternoon. Syaiful is former Senior Parl Sec Mohd Maidin's son. Both bride and groom are working in SIA, and the groom is about to start flight school soon.  

Enjoyed catching up with old friends who were there, including Zainul Abidin Rasheed and MAJ Abbas, both former MPs. Was also delighted to meet veteran singer and actress Momo Latif, whom old-timers would remember seeing in many Malay films of the 1930s to 1970s. She celebrates her 90th birthday tomorrow!   

My congrats to Maidin, the newly weds and the two families! - LHL  

Saya telah menghadiri majlis persandingan Syaiful Haq dan Siti Hajar petang tadi. Syaiful adalah anak kepada mantan Setiausaha Parlimen Kanan Mohd Maidin. Kedua pasangan mempelai bekerja di SIA, di mana Syaiful akan memulakan sekolah penerbangan tidak lama lagi.   

Saya gembira dapat berjumpa dengan kawan-kawan lama seperti Zainul Abidin Rasheed and Maj Abbas, keduanya mantan AP. Saya juga berbesar hati dapat bertemu dengan penyanyi dan pelakon veteran Momo Latif, yang ramai tentu ingat melihat beliau dalam banyak filem Melayu 30-an hingga 70-an. Beliau juga akan meraikan hari jadinya yang ke-90 esok!  

Tahniah kepada Maidin, kedua mempelai dan kedua-dua keluarga! - LHL

Received this letter from reader Makiko Nukui today, expressing appreciation for the thoughtfulness shown by Singaporeans to her aged parents during their recent visit here. She cited two specific acts of kindness. On the MRT, two young ladies gave up their seats unasked to her parents. Then when her parents lost their way in an underpass, a young man took them to the correct exit. 

I’m sure these are just two of many gracious acts seen in Singapore daily. Thanks, Makiko, for writing. I hope your letter will encourage many more. :) – LHL

Took a walk at the Botanic Gardens this evening. Been a few months since the last time, and was happy to see the gardens improved, and dressed up for the season. There were lots of pretty Christmas trees done up by different groups, bringing joy to visitors. This Tree of Happiness helps put in perspective the recent debate about whether Singaporeans are happy or unhappy. - LHL

Merry Christmas everyone! For Christians, the day celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ. For others, it is a time for gift-giving and time with friends and family. To all those celebrating Christmas, may your day be filled with joy, peace and goodwill! - LHL

(PMO Photo by Alex Qiu)

Visited Gardens by the Bay yesterday evening with Ho Ching. Happy to see so many families and young couples enjoying the gardens, as well as the Flower Dome and Cloud Forest. But there were quiet spots too. The moment when the sun went down and the lights came on was quite magical. - LHL
Congrats to the Lions on winning the AFF Suzuki Cup for a record 4th time!! Well done! We’re so proud of you! – LHL

In New Delhi this afternoon, visited the Red Fort, where I met 10 Singaporeans who had just completed an 8,000 km journey from Indonesia to India. They visited eight of the 10 ASEAN countries, before arriving in India 2 days ago. They had been on the ASEAN-India car rally, to commemorate the 20th anniversary of India-ASEAN relations. Our team came from all walks of life - there were two teachers, a few entrepreneurs and a photo journalist. They shared exciting stories about their adventures as they travelled up to 400-500 km per day, performing cultural shows and dances at the stops. Congrats to the team for winning the Best Touring Team Award during the Indonesia leg! - LHL

In India for the ASEAN-India Commemorative Summit. We visited Gurgaon, a rapidly growing suburb of New Delhi yesterday morning. Saw lots of construction, both flats and commercial buildings. Many IT and telecom companies are there. We visited the HQ of Bharti AirTel, the biggest telco in India.  

Enjoyed a lovely Cultural Programme before dinner last evening. Our Indian hosts invited artistes from each ASEAN country to perform together with a matching Indian group. Singapore was represented by Flame of the Forest (www.krsnagovintan.com), comprising brothers Krsna (sitar), Govin (tabla) and their cousin Dexter (violin). A Chinese family group playing traditional Indian music – only in Singapore! - LHL
Just arrived in New Delhi and connected to Channel NewsAsia. Wow! Lions won 3-1 against Thailand. Well done! Look forward to the second leg on Saturday. - LHL

Our efforts to promote R&D and startup companies in Singapore are making some small waves. This BBC story describes three interesting projects: a gadget that lets your smartphone check your blood, a voice activated lock for smartphones to replace PINs and passwords, and (my favourite) an automatic bread maker called The Rotimatic. 

Government is fostering this, e.g. Plug-In@Blk71 (www.blk71.com) brings together entrepreneurs, investors and industry experts to network and take their innovations further. But most importantly we have to stay open and business-friendly, so companies and entrepreneurs from Singapore and the world over can startup and grow here and eventually contribute to Singapore. - LHL
Christmas decorations @ Orchard Road (Photo courtesy of Orchard Road Business Association)

Sent President Obama condolences over the horrific shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School. This grim incident reminds us of our common humanity - we all empathise with the children and staff who were killed, and with their parents and families. Our thoughts are with the American people during this time of mourning. - LHL

Attended the Ang Mo Kio and Sengkang West Active Agers’ Carnival at the Ang Mo Kio Library this morning. Heartened to see many role models for active ageing. Some join Interest Groups like bead decoration, hydroponics, photography, and kite flying. Others were learning about iPads and social media to keep in touch with grandchildren.   

Also heard reports from four Our Singapore Conversation groups, conducted in the official languages. The groups had different concerns, reminding us of diverse strands in our society. Am glad that Our Singapore Conversation is making progress and engaging Singaporeans from all walks of life. - LHL

Had a most interesting excursion to Pulau Semakau with my grassroots leaders this afternoon. We started Semakau Landfill in 1999 by enclosing part of the sea between two existing offshore islands, Pulau Semakau and Pulau Sakeng. This freed up much-needed space on the mainland for other developments.

Semakau has become a jewel of nature conservation and biodiversity. It is home to a vibrant marine eco-system with many species of coral, crabs, starfishes and sponges. We saw quite a few of them up close, pointed out by our sharp-eyed guides, when we took a walk on the sands and corals exposed at low tide. 

Many Singaporeans visit Semakau to enjoy the marine life, bird-watching, stargazing and sport fishing. At least three couples have had their wedding photos shot there! 

Urbanised Singapore contains a great wealth of plant and animal life, and unique ecosystems. We should respect and take care of nature and our environment - they are an important part of our heritage. – LHL
