Congrats to the Lions on reaching the AFF Suzuki Cup finals! Missed the game last night, because I was at my Meet-the-People Session. 

Not all the cases last night were easy to solve. One resident complained about being harassed by her neighbour. A few weeks ago her neighbour had seen me, and complained about being harassed by her! The Residents’ Committee will try to smooth things out, but such disputes can only be settled with goodwill and a big heart on both sides. Another resident told me: “You just have to sign a letter, and it will solve my problem”. I tried to tell him gently that the government does not work like that.

We finished the MPS past midnight as usual, and then I spent some time with my activists, discussing Speaker Mr Michael Palmer’s resignation. 

Whatever happens in the world, our volunteers serve faithfully day in day out, helping residents with their problems and making ours a better home. I salute them. 

- LHL

Following Mr Michael Palmer’s resignation as the MP for Punggol East, many FB readers and Singaporeans have asked me whether I intend to call a by-election and, if so, when. Please see below for my statement to the media on this issue. - LHL

It was with great sadness that I accepted Speaker Michael Palmer’s resignation today. He has worked hard as an MP and been a good Speaker. But all MPs and Grassroots Advisors must uphold high standards of propriety and personal conduct, especially when dealing with constituents, activists, and staff. Mr Palmer’s letter to me, and my reply, set out what this is about.   

I wish Mr Palmer and his family well. - LHL

Had a good lunch with religious leaders today. I meet them regularly just to keep in touch. My lunch guests represented Christians, Buddhists, Muslims, Jains, Zoroastrians, and Jews, all living together harmoniously here. The leaders guide their congregations, build good ties with other faiths, and maintain a spirit of tolerance and accommodation. They work with the govt to preserve our multi-religious harmony, a rare and precious jewel. - LHL

(MCI Photo by Kenji Soon)

Thoroughly enjoyed the 2012 National Chinese Music Competition Prize Winners’ Concert this evening. I thought the performances were outstanding, and the judges were very impressed too. The youngest winner, Chen Xinyu, is only 8 years old!   

We have many talented young musicians, who have lots of opportunities to pursue their musical interests, studies or careers. More students are learning to play Chinese instruments, making Chinese Orchestras a popular CCA in schools.   

Met some of the winners during the intermission. All are passionate young people, actively developing their talents. I hope they will keep up their interest in Chinese music, and perhaps even join the Singapore Chinese Orchestra one day. I wish them all the best! – LHL     

我刚在新加坡大会堂观赏了一场音乐会，台上表演的是今年“全国华乐比赛”的获奖者。这些年轻的新秀演奏水平之高，令我赞叹，比赛的评判也有同感。他们在新加坡华乐团的伴奏下，为我们带来首首悠扬悦耳的乐曲。年纪最小的参赛者是年仅8岁的陈欣宇。   

我国不乏富有音乐才华的年轻人。我们尽力栽培他们，为他们制造许多追求自己梦想的机会。近年来，华乐成了我国学校的一项相当热门的课外活动，培养了许多优秀的乐手。我今晚会见了多位年轻的获奖者，我祝贺他们，希望他们再接再厉，也希望其中一些年轻的乐手会加入新加坡华乐团，使这支优秀的乐团能够继续茁壮成长。- 李显龙

Watched some of the 1st leg of the AFF Suzuki Cup semi-final match between the Lions and Philippines, which ended 0-0. It was a close match. We had lots of chances but were unable to convert them. There is everything to play for in the return leg. Let’s give the Lions our full support next Wednesday at Jalan Besar! – LHL.

Opened Resorts World at Sentosa (RWS) today. RWS is a spectacular destination for families, which has greatly enhanced Singapore’s tourism appeal. Millions have visited Universal Studios or dined at its Malaysian Food Street (including me <http://on.fb.me/RgBoB4>). RWS has also created many jobs: two-thirds of its 13,000 employees are Singaporeans. Also saw the new Marine Life Park (MLP), the world’s largest oceanarium. Amazed by the diversity and beauty of the 100,000 marine animals there. – LHL

Visited the Duke-NUS Graduate Medical School (GMS) at Outram this afternoon, and was happy to see their progress. The GMS is a collaboration between Duke University and NUS. The students are performing well, more than equal to their counterparts in US medical schools. They are a mature and motivated bunch, with very diverse backgrounds. Most are Singaporean, but some come from as far away as Canada and Haiti! They learn much from one another.  

The GMS is a partnership with a world-class institution to train more doctors to meet our growing healthcare needs. NTU is doing the same with the Lee Kong Chian School of Medicine, collaborating with Imperial College London and Tan Tock Seng Hospital. Examples outside medicine are LaSalle College of the Arts’ partnership with Goldsmiths College, and Temasek Polytechnic’s with the Culinary Institute of America.   

These programmes create more educational choices for Singaporeans, and help our young people to achieve their diverse aspirations. – LHL

Inspiring story in Berita Harian today of a young engineer, 22-year-old Nur’rahmahdiah Salim, in the Jurong Shipyard accident. Nur’rahmahdiah was on the oil rig when it tilted over. She stayed behind to make sure her colleagues had evacuated safely before leaving the rig herself. She was taken to hospital for chest pains and breathing difficulties, but I am glad that she is back home and OK now, and so is her mother, as you can see from the pic. Well done Nur’rahmahdiah! – LHL

Cerita inspirasi dalam Berita Harian hari ini adalah tentang seorang jurutera muda, Nur'rahmahdiah Salim. Semasa kemalangan di Jurong Shipyard kelmarin,  Nur'rahmahdiah berada di pelantar perkapalan. Meskipun keadaan kelam kabut, beliau dengan tenang memastikan rakan-rakan sekerjanya diselamatkan sebelum menyelamatkan dirinya. Beliau kemudian dibawa ke hospital kerana sakit dada dan mengalami sesak nafas, tetapi saya gembira bahawa beliau telah pulang ke rumah sekarang dan pulih. Begitu juga ibunya seperti yang anda lihat dari gambar di bawah ini. Syabas Nur'rahmahdiah! - LHL

(SPH Photo)

At the Party Conference on Sunday, I mentioned our need to be more aware of big changes in the world around us. I gave the example of Tianjin: a vibrant Chinese city that is building itself up to rival Beijing and Shanghai. 

Yesterday Straits Times reported that another Chinese city, Chongqing, is trying to become a top outsourcing destination. It is pursuing a Shi Bai Qian Wan “十百千万” strategy to grow 10 (十) outsourcing zones, nurture one million (百万) IT graduates and attract 1,000 (千) global customers, i.e. 1,000 businesses outsourcing their operations to Chongqing. 

Although the article doesn’t say so, some of Chongqing’s global customers may well be from Singapore. We must be alive to this external environment, so that we can be mentally prepared for what the future holds, and gear ourselves up for a competitive but exciting world. – LHL

My sympathies to all those injured in the Jurong Shipyard accident. It was a serious accident, but could have been worse. The investigations will find out what went wrong, and needs to be put right.

Workplace safety is very important. We owe it to workers to make sure the working environment is safe, and that everyone follows safe work practices. This was why we set up the Workplace Safety and Health Council in 2008. We have made progress: the number of workplace incidents and injuries has come down. But today’s accident reminds us that we must remain vigilant, and do better still.  Everyone has a part to play, including employers, workers and safety inspectors. I wish those injured a complete and speedy recovery. – LHL

Spoke at the PAP Party Conference at the Kallang Theatre this morning.  I urged Singaporeans to maintain a balance between the ‘yin’ and ‘yang’ of our different aspirations. We must keep our economy vibrant even as we seek balanced, meaningful lives. We must strengthen our Singaporean identity while keeping our society open to ideas and talent. We must uphold meritocracy while giving extra help to those who started off with less in life. It is good that we are rethinking the balance in our National Conversation, but we must not go overboard and abandon values and principles that have served us well, and remain vital to us. – LHL

This week, the UN recognised Palestine as a “non-member observer state”. The vote in the UN General Assembly was 138 in favour and 9 against, with 41 abstaining. Singapore was one of the countries abstaining. Several readers have asked me why. As SMS (Foreign Affairs and Home Affairs) Masagos Zulkifli has explained our stand to someone who had asked him the same question, I thought I would share his reply with all of you. - LHL

Kai Kai and Jia Jia made their public debut today. They are the stars of the Giant Panda Forest at Wildlife Reserves Singapore’s River Safari, and symbolise the close friendship between Singapore and China. 

Glad that Kai Kai and Jia Jia are off to a good start, with crowds queuing up to see them. I am sure visitors will enjoy the pandas, and having seen them will spread the message of wildlife conservation. 

Apart from the Giant Pandas, the River Safari will also be home to the Red Panda, Mekong Giant Catfish, Giant Freshwater Stingray, Raccoon Dogs, the Golden Pheasant and many other animals. I look forward to attending the River Safari’s opening next February and meeting the pandas and their neighbours in their new home. – LHL

(ZB Photo)

Global warming is causing the Arctic ice to melt, so that ships can sail from Europe to Japan via the Arctic ocean, saving 20 days on the journey. How will this affect Singapore, one of the busiest ports in the world? In the short run probably not much, but over the long term we don’t know. Hence Singapore is seeking observer status on the Arctic Council, even though we are located almost on the equator. - LHL
A group photo with Temasek Polytechnic students, celebrating the launch of the Glocal Connect Village. (MCI Photo by Kenji Soon)

Ulu Pandan Fundraising Dinner and Launch of Choo Siu Heng Scholarship / 设立朱秀兴奖学金

Joined Christopher de Souza (www.facebook.com/chrisdesouza.ulupandan) and Ulu Pandan residents at a fundraising dinner this evening, where we launched the Choo Siu Heng Scholarship. This will fund the university education of one young Singaporean living in Ulu Pandan each year. 

Mr Choo Siu Heng was a dedicated grassroots activist in Ulu Pandan. He started volunteering in the 1960s and 1970s, when life in Singapore was much tougher than today. He and many others of his generation stepped forward, worked together and helped to build today’s Singapore. I hope today’s Singaporeans will emulate Mr Choo, serve their community, and create a better home for future generations. 

Also wish to thank the donors and volunteers who raised $800,000 for community activities in Ulu Pandan. The funds will go towards book prizes for students with special needs, Qigong and Dance Fit clubs to keep senior citizens active, and of course the Choo Siu Heng Scholarship. - LHL

刚出席了乌鲁班丹区的筹款晚宴。在热心人士支持下，我们筹得80万元，可用来开展各项社区活动，造福居民，这包括设立一项奖学金，以资助区内的优秀学子，并且借以纪念一位已故的基层领袖朱秀兴先生。朱先生在乌鲁班丹区服务了50年，非常热诚地为居民服务，是备受尊敬的“大好人”，同时也是多位议员的良师益友。我希望年轻一代能够向朱先生看齐，挺身而出，为社会大众服务，为国家的不断进步贡献自己的一份力量。- 李显龙

Here’s a video of the activities at Temasek Polytechnic's Global Community Day yesterday!

Had a good time at Temasek Polytechnic’s (TP) Global Community Day and Glocal Connect Village (GCV). 

The new GCV comprises residential facilities, a beautiful atrium and many common spaces. It is used to promote interaction and understanding between TP’s local and international students. 

The annual Global Community Day celebrates different cultures through performances and exhibitions. The students and staff put up a spectacular and colourful show – dancing, beatboxing, drumming, etc. 

Always energized after visiting our schools and tertiary institutions, and meeting enthusiastic and talented young people. – LHL

My best wishes to all students who received their PSLE results today! I am sure you studied hard for it, and rightly so, because the PSLE is an important exam. But PSLE is far from the only thing which counts. Our students must also develop good moral values, strong social skills, and a sense of duty to our families and nation. These are not in the PSLE syllabus, but they are important to a fulfilling and productive life.

I hope you do well in your studies, whichever school or stream you attend. Your schools and teachers will nurture you, and develop your talents. Our education system offers you many pathways and opportunities. Make the most of them. Study hard, but also make time to play and pursue your passions. May you find your own paths to success and happiness. – LHL

Spent three days at the ASEAN summit meetings in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. We made progress on the ASEAN Community (to be done by 2015), and on ASEAN Connectivity projects. These ASEAN programmes are important to us. Member countries are individually quite small in the global scheme of things. Hence we need to work together, despite our different situations and perspectives, to thrive in an uncertain world. 

One key event was the launch of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP). The RCEP will be a free trade area that links up all 10 ASEAN members and 6 ASEAN dialogue partners. This will cover nearly half the world's population and a third of the world's GDP.

We appreciate US President Obama’s strong support, visiting ASEAN on his first trip after re-election. For Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao and South Korean President Lee Myung-bak, this has been their last ASEAN meeting. We thank them for their support and wish them all the best. – LHL

Off to Phnom Penh for the ASEAN meetings this evening, so unfortunately will miss the PAssionART Community Singing @ Ang Mo Kio event tonite. But I managed to drop in on their rehearsal yesterday. We sang along to evergreen songs like ‘朋友’, ‘Dayung Sampan’ and ‘Beautiful Sunday’. Was good to see residents, young and old, singing and dancing together, and enjoying themselves. 

The PAssionArts Singing Festival (https://www.facebook.com/PAssionArtsSG) will continue until 15 Dec. Do join your family and neighbours for a sing-along in your neighbourhood! – LHL

(MCI Photo by Daniel Choo)
Admiring student art works displayed at Townsville Primary School. (MCI Photo by LH Goh)

Celebrated Townsville Primary School’s 30th anniversary last evening. The school has educated many young Singaporeans over the years and served the Ang Mo Kio community well. It provides a holistic, values-based education and has established a niche for itself in the creative arts. 

There are many good schools like Townsville Primary all over Singapore. We work very hard to give every child a good education, regardless which school he attends. We have created many pathways to success in our education system. Even if students do not get the school of their choice, they still have other good choices. So parents, encourage your children to study hard, but please don’t pressure them too much. PSLE is important, but it is not the be-all-and-end-all in your children’s lives. - LHL

Launched the Campus for Research Excellence and Technological Enterprise (CREATE) today, a handsome building at NUS’ University Town. It houses research labs from ten leading R&D institutions including MIT, Technical University of Munich, ETH (Switzerland), and Shanghai Jiao Tong University. 

CREATE is a “collaboratory”, which makes it easy for the different teams to work with one another and with our own universities and research institutions. Hopefully these interactions will spark creative insights and new discoveries, and help us build and root a well-integrated R&D eco-system in Singapore. 

Also launched the second National Innovation Challenge (NIC). An NIC is a way for us to focus research on a big and complex challenge facing Singapore. This NIC, on “Land and Liveability”, will study how we can create new space, e.g. by building underground, and how we can use our existing space more creatively. Then our economy can grow, and we can all enjoy a highly liveable city. – LHL

Congratulations to the Communist Party of China (CPC) on the success of their 18th National Congress, and to Mr Xi Jinping on his election as General Secretary of the CPC. I hosted Mr Xi in Singapore in 2010, when Singapore and China celebrated 20 years of diplomatic relations. He met many of our leaders and businessmen, and unveiled a bust of Deng Xiaoping by the Singapore River. 

Looking forward to working with Mr Xi, Mr Li Keqiang and the other newly elected members of the Politburo Standing Committee to strengthen China-Singapore ties further. - LHL 

(MCI Photo by Kenji Soon)

Hosted Sultan of Johor Ibrahim Iskandar and his wife, Raja Zarith Sofiah, to dinner. Earlier, Their Royal Highnesses had visited the Johore Battery war memorial site, and the Changi Chapel and Museum. 

The Johore Battery (http://bit.ly/RTQMSH), along Cosford Road in Changi, was a gun emplacement that formed part of Singapore’s defences in WWII. The British built it with a donation from the Sultan of Johor (the present Sultan’s great grandfather), hence the name. 

The dinner was a good opportunity for us to reaffirm Singapore’s warm ties with Malaysia, and close friendship with Johor. – LHL

(PMO Photo by Terence Tan)

Hosted Mr Vincent Siew and his wife to a popiah dinner last night, together with Wong Kan Seng and a few others. Mr Siew is an old friend of more than 20 years from Taiwan. He was Minister of Economic Affairs in the early 1990s, and we attended some of the early APEC meetings together. 
 
On one of my visits to Taiwan, Mr Siew arranged for my wife and me to make a trip up Alishan. We took the narrow-gauge train up the mountain from Chiayi city, which is Mr Siew’s hometown. The next morning, we got up very early to watch the sunrise over a sea of clouds. It was unforgettable.
 
Mr Siew later served as Vice-President to President Ma Ying-jeou, retiring this year. It was good to see him again, looking well and relaxed among friends. – LHL
 
(MCI Photo by Kenji Soon)

Deepavali is the Festival of Lights. I wish all Indians who celebrate it a Happy Deepavali! இனிய தீபாவளி வாழ்த்துகள்! – LHL

(SPH Photo)

Attended the National Day Awards Investiture Ceremony this evening. The recipients have all served Singapore well in different ways, and it is good that we honour them and thank them for their contributions. Singapore depends on our people giving their best and serving fellow citizens, as these recipients have done. - LHL

Also met Laurentia Tan, who won two equestrian medals at the London Paralympics, together with her parents. She continues riding three or four times a week, so hopefully will be winning more medals for Singapore in future! - LHL (MCI Photo by LH Goh)

One of the SAF recipients was BG Lee Shiang Long. He reminded me that I had attended his Polytechnic graduation in 1985, where he received a Gold Medal. When his name was called, I had stood up thinking they were calling me! Glad that he got an extra cheer from the audience this evening. :-) - LHL (MCI Photo by LH Goh)

Happy that among the recipients were two grassroots leaders from Teck Ghee – Bernard Tay (to my left) and Ng Choon Teck (to Bernard’s left). Choon Teck was Chairman of Teck Ghee Community Centre. Bernard Tay has been serving in Teck Ghee for many years. When his son was born he was doing a Meet-the-People Session with me, and his son is now 24 years old. Glad their families came for the Investiture too – our volunteers often have to sacrifice family time to do grassroots work. - LHL (MCI Photo by LH Goh)

Mdm Tauyanagi d/o Narayanasamy Gopalsamy received a Best Cleaner Award. She is in charge of the carpark at Blk 229, Ang Mo Kio Ave 3. A dedicated and responsible worker, she takes great pride in keeping the neighbourhood clean. Well done! (PMO photo by Terence Tan)
Posing for a budding young photographer. (PMO photo by Terence Tan)

Watching a skit performed by NEA staff about keeping Singapore clean. The trash bins have been designed and painted by youths from the AMK GRC & Sengkang West SMC Youth Executive Committees. (PMO photo by Terence Tan)
Enjoying a game of ring toss with a young resident. I think we did quite well! (PMO photo by Terence Tan)
Planting a cempaka tree (sometimes called the “joy perfume tree”), which produces very fragrant white or yellow flowers. (PMO photo by Terence Tan)

Launched Our Clean & Green Home@Ang Mo Kio GRC-Sengkang West SMC this morning. Planted a cempaka tree together with my grassroots leaders, an annual ritual in Singapore since 1971, when Dr Goh Keng Swee did the first Tree Planting Day at Mt Faber. 

We are creating a City in a Garden, with the Active Beautiful and Clean waters programme, more green spaces and the Gardens by the Bay. Let us all do our part to make this vision a reality. Please don’t litter, please care for the environment and remember to keep our surroundings clean and green. - LHL

Celebrated Active Ageing Night with Teck Ghee residents this evening. Several seniors received walking sticks and wheelchairs, helped by the Seniors’ Mobility Fund. 

We had a very good response – all our own residents, staying active, well and cheerful. They sang along with the golden oldies, songs like 望春风, 上海滩, and 月亮代表我的心. The seniors took part in the entertainment too, drumming, line dancing, and even putting on a Balloon Sculpting Fashion Show. 

Students from ITE College Central helped us to organise the event. They also visit old people in Teck Ghee regularly, helping them to cope. We are most grateful for their concern and support. – LHL

(MCI Photo by Kenji Soon)

Congratulations to the Singapore Children’s Society (SCS) on your 60th birthday! You have done much for children’s welfare in Singapore. 

The SCS is a good example of civic society: people actively doing something about an issue they are passionate about. The Government will always help the less fortunate, but it cannot do everything. We must all help one another – the successful giving a hand to the less fortunate, having a care for our fellow citizens, making progress together. I am happy that many of us are supporting good causes, whether through donations or volunteerism. Let us do more of this, so that Singapore will continue being a Home with a Heart. – LHL 

(MCI Photo by L H Goh)

Visited the Church of St Mary of the Angels at Bukit Batok, to pay respects to the late Mrs Hon Sui Sen. To me she was always Auntie Annie, a gentle and kind lady whom I had known ever since I was a child. 

The Hons were my parents’ friends long before Mr Hon became a minister. They would visit us at Oxley Road from time to time, especially at Chinese New Year. My parents would take the children to visit them and their four daughters in their government bungalow at Malcolm Road. Auntie Annie was very good to us when we were small, and after we grew up and had our own children she was equally good to them too. 

Auntie Annie was a devout Catholic, who attended mass every day. The last time I met her was at a Commissioning Parade in SAFTI about 10 years ago, when one of her grandsons graduated from OCS. She was frail, but happy to see me. She lived to a ripe old age, to see 15 grandchildren and 9 great-grandchildren. May she rest in peace. - LHL 

(ZB Photo)

Congrats to US President Barack Obama and Vice-President Joe Biden on their re-election! Looking forward to continue working with President Obama and his Administration to strengthen US-Singapore relations. - LHL

Useful trip to Vientiane, Laos, for the Asia-Europe Meeting (ASEM). Happy to meet Singaporeans there too. One was the chef at our hotel – Haji Zainudin. He has been here since last year, and returns home every four months to be with his family. The General Mgr and Asst General Mgr are also from Singapore! This just shows what a global village we live in, and how mobile Singaporeans are. 

Europe is important to Asia – as a market, investor, lender and source of technology. The Eurozone's problems have affected Asia too, and we wish the Europeans all the best in resolving them. 

Such meetings are great opportunities to touch base with leaders whom I would normally not see. I invited a few to stop by Singapore en route to/from Laos. Poland’s PM Donald Tusk was here last Sunday, and Luxembourg PM Jean-Claude Juncker will be here tomorrow. – LHL

Tahniah kepada MENDAKI atas ulang tahun yang ke-30!
 
Saya hadiri sambutannya di Hotel Shangri-La malam tadi.
 
MENDAKI telah banyak membantu masyarakat Melayu/Islam terutama meningkatkan tahap pencapaian pendidikan dan memupuk semangat gotong royong. MENDAKI juga menggembeling usaha badan-badan Melayu/Islam melalui CLF. Ia juga memainkan peranan yang besar dalam kemajuan masyarakat Melayu kita.
 
Saya gembira dapat bertemu dengan isteri dan keluarga mendiang Ridzwan Dzafir yang hadir bagi pelancaran Anugerah Masyarakat Ridzwan Dzafir. Saya telah lama mengenali Pak Ridzwan ketika saya bekerja dengan beliau di MTI. Anugerah ini memang sesuai untuk memberi penghormatan kepada Pak Ridzwan, dan menggalak generasi muda untuk mencontohi kepimpinan beliau.
 
Saya juga gembira dapat berjumpa ramai orang muda yang melakukan kerja sukarela dengan MENDAKI ataupun yang telah mendapat manfaat daripada program-program yang dikendalikan oleh MENDAKI. Ada juga yang membuat persembahan malam ini termasuk Riduan Zalani, seorang pemain genderang yang berbakat. Beliau juga penerima Anugerah Harapan Belia Goh Chok Tong. Pemerintah akan terus menyokong MENDAKI dan badan Melayu/Islam yang lain. Saya berharap mereka akan memanfaatkan program-program dan dana Pemerintah bagi membantu masyarakat Melayu/Islam supaya terus maju. - LHL

Congrats to MENDAKI on its 30th birthday!

Attended the celebration at Shangri-La Hotel this evening. 

MENDAKI has served the Malay/Muslim community well, especially by improving educational performance and promoting the gotong royong (self-help) spirit. It has played a big part in the community's progress. 

Was happy to meet Mrs Ridzwan Dzafir and her family, who were there for the launch of the Ridzwan Dzafir Community Award. I knew Pak Ridzwan for many years, beginning when he was Director General (Trade) and I worked with him in MTI. It is fitting to honour him through this award, and encourage a younger generation to emulate his example of leadership and service.

Also glad to meet many young people who are volunteering with MENDAKI, or have benefitted from MENDAKI programmes, or often both. Quite a few performed for us this evening, including Riduan Zalani, an amazingly talented percussionist with his band, who received the Goh Chok Tong Youth Promise Award. Check out his YouTube clip at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qO9rw394mPU !

The Govt will continue to support MENDAKI and the MMOs. Do step forward to take full advantage of the programmes and funding to serve the community, and help Malay/Muslims to continue upgrading and improving. – LHL

A group of Singaporeans in Seattle put together a book (http://bit.ly/SzP75A) of their memories of home, to celebrate National Day this year. The book was dedicated to their loved ones. They sent me a copy. 

I was pleasantly surprised to discover an old photo of myself in the book. An old SAF comrade, Charles Lim, had moved to Seattle. He had contributed a chapter, and included a picture taken in 1978, when we both served in HQ 3 SIB. 

I was touched by the many heart-warming stories in the book. Quite a few men (Wong Hao, Nicky, Charles) spoke about their formative years in NS and how NS had shaped their values in life. Charles, who was a regular, recalled our Scrabble games in Ulu Pandan Camp. Others (Anthea, Wee Ling, Peter, Ai Lin) shared their memories of National Day, and the things they miss about Singapore. 

Thanks for taking the time to share the diverse threads of your lives that help bind us together. All the best for your pursuits in Seattle, and do visit us soon in Singapore! - LHL

Read that Disney has bought over Lucasfilm, and plans to produce a new Star Wars movie in 2015, and one every few years after that. The news seems to have stirred a hornets’ nest among fans online. Many think Lucasfilm has sold out, but others believe Disney can fulfil George Lucas’ vision for the entire Star Wars story. 

I have only watched one of the Star Wars movies myself (Episode III: Revenge of the Sith), but I hope that Singapore can benefit from this. DigiPen and ITE Central (in Ang Mo Kio) are training students in interactive digital media. Lucasfilm is building a brand new complex at the Fusionopolis. Hopefully part of the new Star Wars movies will soon be produced in Singapore, and not a long time more in a galaxy far, far away. :) – LHL

Had an enjoyable and fruitful trip to Brunei. It was good to meet old friends and get to know new, younger ones too. 

Started early this morning with a (rather vigorous) walk with His Majesty the Sultan at Tasek Lama Park. Then we planted two selunsur trees as a symbol of the close friendship between Brunei and Singapore. Tasek Lama is one of the oldest nature reserves right in the heart of Bandar Seri Begawan. Followed with a busy day, being briefed on Brunei’s energy sector, and visiting Universiti Brunei Darussalam. 

Unfortunately there are no troops training in Temburong right now, so I didn’t visit our SAF camp there. Hopefully on my next visit. 

Look forward to visiting Brunei again when it chairs the ASEAN Summits next year. – LHL

Off to Brunei Darussalam this morning for two days. My last visit was five years ago. 

Brunei is an old friend of Singapore. It began with Mr Lee Kuan Yew and the late Seri Begawan (the father of the present Sultan) in the 1960s. Both Mr Lee and the Sri Begawan negotiated to join Malaysia, and became friends. In the end Singapore joined, but Brunei stayed out. Today we are both independent countries.

This special friendship has endured and deepened. One area of cooperation is defence. Generations of SAF servicemen have done jungle training at Temburong, climbing Mount Biang and crossing Sungai Batu Apoi. Singapore and Brunei work together in many other areas too.

I wrote an op-ed to capture these longstanding ties. Will share more tomorrow. :-) – LHL
Visited Upper Seletar Reservoir this evening. Met many families enjoying the tranquil evening and the glorious sunset. This bridal couple must have got some beautiful pictures! - LHL

Happy to launch the 2012 National Healthy Lifestyle Campaign at Gardens by the Bay this morning. 

We have been promoting healthy lifestyles for 20 years. We have made progress – more people are exercising, fewer are smoking and Singaporeans are generally more conscious of staying fit and healthy. But unfortunately more people are becoming obese, with fast foods and sedentary occupations. In the US and UK, obesity has become an epidemic. If we don’t want to end up like that, we need to watch what we eat and find ways to exercise more. 

For myself, I enjoy brisk walks and also swim to keep fit. I take the stairs rather than the lift whenever I can. Every little bit counts. Why not try the Health Promotion Board’s new online tool -- the Healthy Lifestyle Index (www.healthylifestyleindex.sg) – for some personalised advice on how you can improve your health! :) - LHL

Selamat Hari Raya Haji or Salam Aidiladha to our Muslim friends here and abroad!

Today marks the end of the Haj (pilgrimage), one of the five pillars of Islam. Millions of Muslims have gathered in the holy city of Mecca. Unfortunately, this year Saudi Arabia accepted fewer pilgrims, as it is redeveloping the area around two Holy Mosques. Singapore’s Haj quota was also reduced, even though I wrote to the Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia to request more places. I hope that those who were unable to go this year will get the chance to do so before too long.

Muslims also perform the Korban (sacrifice) today, to celebrate Prophet Ibrahim’s faith in God. Min Yaacob Ibrahim and I were initially quite worried that our Korban ritual might be affected by Australia’s stringent new regulations on live sheep exports. Fortunately 16 mosques passed the Australian audits, and were able to import 2,500 sheep for the ceremony. 

When I met Australian PM Julia Gillard in Canberra recently, I thanked her for her government’s help on this matter. She told me that her government wants to continue exporting live animals. But I know that Australian animal welfare groups are pressing strongly to ban live exports completely, as New Zealand has done. We should be prepared for this possibility, and work out alternative arrangements in future.

I wish all Muslims well during this holy day. – LHL

Salam Aidiladha kepada semua umat Islam Singapura!

Semasa musim haji ini, jutaan umat Islam dari seluruh dunia berkumpul di kota suci Mekah. Malangnya, tahun ini, kerajaan Arab Saudi menghadkan bilangan jemaah dari luar negara kerana projek pembangunan semula di kawasan Tanah Suci. Kuota haji Singapura juga turut terjejas, walaupun saya telah menulis kepada Putera Mahkota Arab Saudi untuk merayu kuota tambahan. Saya berharap bahawa mereka yang tidak dapat menunaikan haji mereka tahun ini akan mendapat peluang untuk berbuat demikian tidak lama lagi.

Hari ini juga umat Islam mengerjakan korban untuk memperingati ketaatan Nabi Ibrahim kepada Tuhan. Saya dan Menteri Yaacob Ibrahim pada mulanya khuatir ibadah korban akan terjejas tahun ini sempena peraturan pemerintah Australia yang lebih ketat ke atas eksport binatang. Mujurlah, 16 masjid lulus pemeriksaan audit Australia dan berjaya mengimport 2,500 ekor kambing untuk dikorbankan.

Ketika bertemu PM Australia Julia Gillard di Canberra baru-baru ini, saya mengucapkan terima kasih kepada beliau atas bantuan pemerintah beliau mengenai perkara ini. Dia memberitahu saya bahawa pemerintah Australia mahu terus mengeksport ternakan hidup. Namun, saya tahu bahawa kumpulan-kumpulan hak asasi haiwan telah menggesa pemerintah Australia supaya mengharam sepenuhnya eksport ternakan hidup seperti apa yang dilakukan oleh New Zealand. Kita perlu bersedia menghadapi kemungkinan ini dan mencari alternatif jika ia berlaku.

Saya ingin mengucapkan yang terbaik bagi semua umat Islam pada hari suci ini. – LHL

Just came home from my Meet-The-People session in Teck Ghee. We had 114 cases tonight, about our usual number, both from Teck Ghee and the rest of Ang Mo Kio GRC. 

A fair share were residents with housing problems. But the root cause is family breakups. One resident I saw was locked out of his marital home years back, recently divorced, and has transferred the flat to his ex-wife. Another recent divorcee is having to sell her flat, leaving her and her teenage daughter to fend for themselves, with no other relatives here to fall back on. Both asked me for HDB rental flats. I often receive such messages through Facebook too.

Family breakups lead to so many other problems: housing, financial difficulties, custody of children, etc. MPs do our best to help, and HDB is building more rental flats. But ultimately the family members have to work things out themselves, and ideally avoid breaking up in the first place. That's why strong families are so important. – LHL

I often receive emails from the public either commending or criticising the performance of ministries and departments. This one is from Aaron Chew, a satisfied “customer” of ICA, who got a new passport with minimum fuss. We have come to expect such high standards in Singapore. But it is good to remind ourselves once in a while how unusual this is compared to other countries. We must work hard to maintain and indeed raise standards of our public services. But I am sure the ICA staff will be encouraged that their good work has been noticed and appreciated. - LHL

Flew to Phnom Penh, Cambodia this morning to personally offer condolences on the passing of His Majesty King-Father Norodom Sihanouk. His Majesty worked tirelessly for Cambodia and was revered by his people. When Singapore became independent in 1965, Cambodia under then Prime Minister Sihanouk was one of the first countries to recognise our new Republic. 

I first met His Majesty in 1967, when Mr Lee Kuan Yew visited Cambodia and brought the family along. I remember him taking us around Phnom Penh in an open-topped car, and proudly showing us the facilities he was building such as the sports stadium. 

He will be missed by all Cambodians and by many in Singapore. – LHL

Attended the graduation ceremony of my PCF kindergartens, held at Teck Ghee Primary School. 

Pre-school is important, to give all our children a good start in their education. The Government has major plans to improve pre-school education while keeping fees affordable, especially for middle and low income families. I talked about this at the ND Rally.

PCF Teck Ghee has been upgrading our teachers and improving our curriculum. All four of our kindergarten centres have attained SPARK (Singapore Pre-school Accreditation Framework) certification, thanks to the hard work of the principal and teachers. 

Chatted with the kids and their parents after the ceremony. I know parents are anxious about preparing their children for P1, but I hope you will also let your children have their childhood and learn through play. I wish the students all the very best in their new journey. Congrats! – LHL

French PM Jean-Marc Ayrault decided that Singapore would be the first country outside Europe that he would visit as PM. France and Singapore have been close friends for a long time, and the Strategic Partnership will strengthen our relations further. – LHL

Visited our water facilities in Johor for the first time today. Wanted to see for myself the Linggiu Reservoir (http://bit.ly/PE8xqn) built in the 1990s, and the Johor River Water Works (http://bit.ly/OLdQCT) near Kota Tinggi. PUB built and managed these facilities. 

The Linggiu Reservoir regulates the flow of the Johor River. In dry periods PUB releases more water from the reservoir into the Johor River, so that it can still draw 250 million gallons of water per day, as provided for under our 1962 Water Agreement with Johor.

PUB has quietly done a great job supplying Singapore with enough water from our four taps: the Johor River, our Singapore reservoirs, desalination and NEWater. But water will always be a precious commodity and a strategic resource for Singapore. We must use it with care and conserve where we can. – LHL

Spent three productive days here in New Zealand. Enjoyed catching up with many Singaporeans living and studying in Auckland, learning about their lives here, and sharing news and memories of home. Then met old friends Philip Burdon (Chairman, Asia:NZ Foundation) and Don McKinnon (former NZ Deputy Prime Minister) who have done much for Singapore-NZ relations, at dinner hosted by the Asia:NZ Foundation. Also met two young New Zealanders who studied at NUS on Asia:NZ Foundation scholarships: Tessa McGregor (civil engineering) and Robina Ang (bio-engineering). Both enjoyed their time in Singapore and have built life-long friendships.

Yesterday, I called on PM John Key in Wellington, as well as Governor-General Terry Mateparae. Both not only lived several years in Singapore, but have a child each born in Singapore too! Also learnt much about Maori culture and history at the Te Papa Tongarewa, the national museum of New Zealand.

Today I wrapped up my visit with a tour of our Navy frigate the RSS Stalwart that is in harbour in Wellington. The weather was chilly, but we had a warm time on board, meeting the crew, plus other Singaporeans living here who were also visiting the ship. The Stalwart is mid-way through RSN’s longest naval deployment this year. I wish the ship and crew all the best for their voyage and exercises. They return to Singapore in November.

I am next heading to Australia, and will have more to post then. - LHL

Several of you wrote to me through Facebook about the person who posted offensive comments about Malay weddings on her Facebook page. I was shocked to hear about this. The comments were just wrong and totally unacceptable. 

Just last week I shared a WSJ Asia article on why people say nasty things online that they would never say face-to-face. I reminded netizens that we needed to be extra careful and watch ourselves. I did not expect to see such a dramatic example so soon. Fortunately the person has promptly apologised for her grievous mistake. But the damage has been done, and NTUC did the right thing in terminating her services. 

Let us treat this incident for what it is: an isolated case that does not reflect the strength of race relations in Singapore. But it sharply reminds us how easily a few thoughtless words can cause grave offence to many, and undermine our racial and religious harmony. Let us all be more mindful of what we say, online and in person, and always uphold the mutual respect and sensitivity that holds our society together. - LHL

Leaving tonight on a week-long trip to New Zealand and Australia. These two Commonwealth countries are old and close friends of Singapore. It has been 6 years since my last visits to Wellington and Canberra. Look forward to meeting many new and old friends there.
 
Both PM John Key and Governor-General Jerry Mateparae of NZ have lived in Singapore – PM Key while working for a bank, and Governor-General Mateparae while serving in the NZ armed forces. I will be calling on them in Wellington, and also visiting RSS Stalwart, an RSN frigate taking part in an exercise there.
 
In Australia I will be meeting PM Julia Gillard again following her visit here in April, as well as political and business leaders. I am also visiting our servicemen on Exercise Wallaby at Shoalwater Bay.

I also look forward to meeting some of the many Singaporeans living in Australia (in Melbourne) and in NZ (in Auckland). I was happy to get an email yesterday from one Singaporean living in Auckland. Jackson Li wrote:

“Dear Mr Lee,

Welcome to New Zealand.

Just to let you know that the Security of Auckland Airport  Forecourts, Taxi Ranks and VIP parking spaces is headed by a team headed by a Singaporean - i.e. me :-)”

Jackson will be on duty when I fly from Auckland to Wellington. Hope to see him at the airport on Monday! 

Will share more updates during the trip. - LHL

In my National Day Rally, I expressed concern about some of the nasty views expressed online, especially anonymously. This problem is not unique to Singapore. This article explains why people can be so rude online, and say things that they would never say face-to-face. 

I hope this understanding helps us to be more aware of what we do online. We should feel free to express our thoughts and opinions.  But let us always be courteous and respectful in our comments and postings, and behave towards others as we would like others to behave towards us. – LHL

Technology is transforming our world and every facet of our lives. I have been reading about Baxter, an industrial robot recently launched in the US. Baxter belongs to a new generation of robots which are safer to operate, more flexible in the tasks they can do, and more easily “taught” new skills. Baxter can also sense its environment, e.g. whether it has bumped against somebody or something, and adapt intelligently to it (http://econ.st/UwDSaM). 

In Japan, a team is developing an artificial intelligence system, running on a single laptop computer, that can pass the University of Tokyo’s stringent entrance exam. Such a system can do work in many industries. (http://bit.ly/P2JcAk)

Driverless cars already exist (Google has tested prototypes extensively). Last week, California passed a bill to license such cars to drive on public roads. (http://yhoo.it/SjUSiz)

IT and robotics will revolutionise industries and jobs (take a look at the video “The Robot Factory Future” in http://nyti.ms/SDtGwu). Singapore should thrive in this new world. We are one of the most wired countries and Singaporeans are tech-savvy. But Singaporeans must master the skills and the technology, and keep upgrading ourselves. Let us make sure that we exploit the robots and IT, and not get displaced by them. – LHL

Mid-Autumn Festival / 庆祝中秋节

A happy Mid-Autumn Festival to all! While Singapore does not really experience autumn, the Mid-Autumn Festival is very much a part of our heritage. I’m always happy to see Singaporeans old and young, of all races and backgrounds come together to celebrate it with lanterns and mooncakes. – LHL

今天是中秋节，祝各位节日愉快！我们的社会不断地在变，但是人们庆祝这个传统节日的热忱不减。中秋节是亲朋好友相聚赏月的好日子。许多非华族人士也参加中秋节的活动，享受提灯笼、吃月饼的情趣，拉近了各族群之间的距离，这是令人鼓舞的现象。-李显龙

Came across this book review in the Weekend Wall Street Journal, by Sadanand Dhume, a scholar at the American Enterprise Institute. Entitled “Sins of Their Founders”, the piece reviews a book on the civil war in Sri Lanka. The civil war started in 1983, but as Dhume pointed out its roots go back to the country’s independence in 1948. Instead of embracing an inclusive view of citizenship, Sri Lanka (then called Ceylon) marginalised the Tamil minority. The Tamil revolt was led by Velupillai Prabhakaran, a brutal guerrilla leader. The bloody conflict killed tens of thousands, and set the country back many years. Now that it is over, I hope Sri Lanka can enjoy lasting peace and stability.

Dhume noted that Singapore took a different path, with a different result. We are fortunate that right from the birth of our nation, our founders upheld multi-racialism and equal opportunity as the fundamental basis for our society. Thus we have maintained harmony between the different races and religions all these years. But we must never take this harmony as given, and must continue to work hard together to uphold and strengthen it. – LHL

Enjoyed answering the questions submitted by Singaporeans to Singapolitics.sg, which Zuraidah Ibrahim and her team put to me on Monday. Singapolitics received 400 emails containing questions, so I could not answer all the questions asked. But I answered the ten which received the most votes from Singapolitics readers, plus a few more picked by the journalists.

The questions give a picture of your concerns and interests. Some were challenging and did not have easy answers, but for each question I tried my best to explain how I saw things. I hope you will find my answers useful. Please let me know what you think. - LHL

录制电视座谈会《和总理对话》 / A Conversation with PM Lee

今早在电视台录制了一个座谈会，与30位各行各业人士作了很有意义的交流，讨论的都是新加坡人关心的切身问题，包括学前教育，生育率，新移民和华社的发展。参加座谈的还有我的三位内阁同事：振声，莉明，沈颖。在一个小时多的座谈会上，大家踊跃发言，只可惜时间有限，因此不能完全尽兴。不过，“全国对话”即将开展，我们可以继续热烈交换意见。

座谈会节目将在星期天晚上9时于8 频道播出。希望大家能够抽空观赏节目。-李显龙

This morning, I had another TV conversation, this time in Mandarin at the Channel 8 studio. We had a lively exchange on issues like pre-school education, our falling birthrates and integration. With me were Chun Sing, Josephine and Sim Ann. For over an hour, we heard frank and heartfelt views, and it was a pity we did not have more time. There will be more opportunities for Singaporeans to share their views later in the National Conversation.

This morning's Conversation will be broadcast this Sunday, 9pm on Channel 8. Do watch it. - LHL

Congratulations to the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau on its 60th anniversary! 

Singapore’s high standards of integrity are hard-earned and crucial. Anyone who gives or takes bribes will be caught and punished, no matter how senior he is. Far better for the government to suffer embarrassment and keep the system clean, than to pretend that nothing has gone wrong, and let the rot spread. 

To keep our system corruption free, political leaders must lead by example, the public service must strengthen its culture of probity, and Singaporeans must continue to reject corruption. 

We are all indebted to the CPIB and its officers, past and present, for helping to keep Singapore clean and incorrupt all these years. Well done and thank you! – LHL

Aidilfitri celebration at Ang Mo Kio / Sambutan Aidilfitri di Ang Mo Kio

Held an Aidilfitri dinner at Teck Ghee CC last night. Residents came in their Hari Raya best. Many families were colour coordinated, and took lots of pics together.

Non-Muslim residents came to dinner too, to celebrate with their Muslim neighbours and friends. I reminded the guests how precious and unique this religious harmony was, and why we should not let our society be affected by quarrels and fights elsewhere. The recent Youtube hate video denigrating Prophet Muhammad has triggered riots and violence in several countries. Both are wrong.

Telah mengadakan majlis perayaan Aidilfitri di Kelab Masyarakat Teck Ghee semalam. Ramai penduduk datang memakai pakaian tradisional Melayu yang sedondon dengan ahli keluarga yang lain dan mengambil banyak gambar bersama-sama.

Ramai penduduk yang bukan Muslim juga hadir di majlis makan malam itu untuk meraikan Hari Raya dengan jiran-jiran dan rakan-rakan Islam mereka. Saya mengingatkan para tetamu pentingnya semangat perpaduan dan harmoni yang kukuh ini, dan mengapa kita tidak harus membiarkan masyarakat kita terjejas oleh pertengkaran dan pergaduhan di tempat lain. Terdapat sebuah video di Youtube yang memburuk-burukkan Nabi Muhammad yang telah mencetuskan rusuhan dan keganasan di beberapa negara. Kededuanya salah. - LHL

This is a good start to the national conversation. Do catch the programme on CNA this evening at 8pm and join the live web chat to be led by Lawrence Wong. – LHL

我上午在俄罗斯符拉迪沃斯托克（又称海参崴）跟我的老朋友连战博士及其夫人茶叙。连战博士是国民党荣誉主席，他代表台湾出席亚太经合组织峰会。– 李显龙

In Vladivostok for the APEC Economic Leaders’ Meeting. Vladivostok is a port city located near Russia’s borders with China and North Korea. In the days of the former Soviet Union, Intraco (which was the Singapore company doing business with the Communist countries) used to buy seafood from here! The APEC meeting itself is taking place on Russky Island (just south of the Vladivostok mainland), a former naval base to protect Russia’s Far East. 

The Russians have made tremendous efforts to prepare Vladivostok for the APEC meeting. They built highways from the airport, two new bridges to Russky Island, and a whole new campus for a university, where we are staying and holding the APEC meeting. This is the view from my balcony at dawn – all the buildings you can see will belong to the Far Eastern Federal University. Hope you like the view! - LHL

Meeting with Premier Wen Jiabao and Visit to the Central Party School / 会见温家宝总理，走访中共中央党校

Had a good meeting and dinner with Premier Wen Jiabao. We had candid and warm discussions on bilateral relations and international developments. Our ties with China have grown steadily in the last ten years when Mr Wen has been Premier.

Also visited the Central Party School this morning. I gave a talk on China’s relations with the world, with ASEAN and with Singapore. My audience - senior people in the Chinese system - came prepared, and asked sharp questions. I found it a fruitful exchange. You can view my speech here (http://sg.sg/QdfwpV).

Two more meetings tomorrow before flying to Vladivostok for the APEC meeting. – LHL

我下午会见了温家宝总理，针对双边关系和国际局势的发展进行了坦诚和友好的讨论。过去十年，在温先生担任总理期间，新中关系取得稳健的进展。

我上午走访了中央党校，并且发表了演讲。我着重分析中国与世界、亚细安和新加坡的关系。参加交流的都是中国的高干 – 他们有备而来，问了一些颇为尖锐的问题。对我而言，这是一场很有收获的对话。- 李显龙

Meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao & Visit to Tianjin Eco-City/会见胡锦涛主席与走访天津生态城

Had a good meeting with President Hu Jintao today. We reviewed how our cooperation had progressed, and why the economic troubles in the West make it more important for Asian countries to work together. 

Also visited the Tianjin Eco-city (TEC), a highlight of our bilateral cooperation. A green city is rising from what used to be a barren wasteland of marshes and salt evaporation pans. The Eco-city is earning a reputation as a model for sustainable urban development. It’s off to a good start, though it’s still early days yet. – LHL

我在星期二上午会见了胡锦涛主席，针对多个课题作了有意义的交流。我们讨论了两国合作计划的进展，也谈亚洲国家之间应该如何加紧合作，以缓解西方国家的经济困境所带来的冲击。
我也到天津生态城参观。这是新中两国现有的一个重要的合作项目。天津原本的一片盐碱荒滩、废弃盐田已经蜕变成一座绿化的新城，并且开始在国际上引起注意，被视为可持续性发展计划的一个模范。这个计划有了好的开始，但是我们还需要继续努力，才能达致目标。
Calling on President Hu Jintao.
Meeting Tianjin Party Secretary Zhang Gaoli.
A boat ride after dinner on Hai He (海河) in Tianjin. Many historic buildings along the river from a century ago.
Planted a tree at Yong Ding Zhou Park.

Visiting Yingxiu town, epicentre of Wenchuan earthquake / 走访重建后的映秀镇

Just visited Yingxiu town with the Party Secretary of Sichuan Province, Mr Liu Qibao. Yingxiu was the epicentre of the devastating Wenchuan earthquake in 2008. Only 5,000 out of 12,000 residents survived. The school building, which collapsed, is now the memorial to the earthquake victims.

I also met 4 students from nearby Deyang town. They are studying in two of the schools rebuilt with help from Singaporeans. They presented me gifts to thank Singaporeans for our help and support. One told me about her experience in the earthquake, and wept again as she told it. But they have recovered, rebuilt, and will be the stronger for it. I wished her and all her friends every success, on behalf of all of us. - LHL 

在四川省省委书记刘奇葆先生的陪同下，我今天下午走访了映秀镇。这个小镇在2008年的汶川大地震中受到重创。全镇本有1万2000名居民，地震之后只有5000人生还。其中一个坍塌的学校现在成了一个纪念遗址。

我会见四位来自附近德阳市的学生。他们目前在两所经过重建的学校就读。两所学校部分的重建费来自许许多多新加坡人的捐款。这四名学生送了一份礼物给我，表达他们对新加坡人慷慨捐助的感激之情。其中一位学生含泪向我叙述了她过去几年的生活。然而，他们表现得很坚强，决心重建自己的家园和生活。我代表新加坡人向这些学生送上我们深深的祝福。- 李显龙
Touring Yingxiu town, completely rebuilt after the earthquake.
Students from nearby Deyang town presented me with gifts to thank Singaporeans for our help and support during the Wenchuan earthquake, and I gave them presents in return.

Visit to China and Russia / 启程走访中国和俄罗斯一周

Leaving today for a week-long trip to China and Russia. 

I last visited China two years ago, but China changes so quickly that I look forward to visiting again.

My 1st stop is Chengdu, in Sichuan province, where I will be visiting two Singapore projects – the Singapore-Sichuan Hi-Tech Innovation Park and the Raffles City mall. I’m also going to Yingxiu Town, the epicentre of the May 2008 Wenchuan earthquake. The Sichuan government has done a tremendous job reconstructing the town and rebuilding the people’s lives, and are very proud of the results.
I’m also going to Tianjin, to visit the Tianjin Eco-city. This is an important project for Singapore, which I look forward to seeing for the first time. 

In Beijing I will be calling on Chinese leaders, including President Hu Jintao and Premier Wen Jiabao. I am also speaking at the Central Party School (CPS), followed by Q&A. Many up and coming Chinese officials attend the CPS and I expect a lively exchange with them. 

From China, I will head to Vladivostok for the annual APEC meeting. This year Russia is hosting. Vladivostok is a port city on the Pacific Ocean at about the same latitude as Hokkaido in Japan. The weather is extremely cold in winter, which is why APEC is being held early this year, in September.

l’ll post updates on my trip when I have something to share. – LHL

今天下午，我将飞往成都，开始对中国的六天访问。我的访问行程排得满满，希望争取时间观察中国在各方面所取得的巨大成就。

我将会见中国领导人，包括胡锦涛主席和温家宝总理，期待跟他们针对彼此关心的课题交换意见。我也受邀到中央党校演讲，跟中国政界的后起之秀做一席谈。这是我第二次到党校演讲，上回是在2005年。
访问期间，我也将参观新加坡人参与的几个投资项目，包括天津生态城，四川高新技术创新园以及成都的莱佛士城购物中心。

我也会到四川省的映秀镇，看一看四川省政府如何安顿受汶川大地震影响的众多居民。

在结束对中国的访问后，我将从北京飞到俄罗斯的海参崴，出席一年一度的亚太经合峰会。海参崴是俄罗斯太平洋沿岸的滨海城市。冬天天气极为寒冷。俄罗斯选择在温暖的9月举行会议，算是尽地主之谊。- 李显龙

Re-opening of Malay Heritage Centre (MHC) / Pembukaan semula Taman Warisan Melayu (TWM)

Happy to re-open the Malay Heritage Centre this morning. It has been given a beautiful facelift, with many new exhibits to showcase our rich Malay culture. 
 
One exhibit which caught my eye was a realistic 3D computer rendering of Bugis houses built on stilts over the water. Temasek Poly students did this, working from old plans. The Bugis (who were seafaring traders) used to live in the Kampong Glam area, hence the name Bugis Street.
 
I hope you will visit the Centre, join in its activities or even volunteer your time to be a guide. 
 
Congratulations to the Malay Heritage Foundation, National Heritage Board and all those in the community who have worked hard to make this Centre a reality!

     Kuning emas warnanya indah
     Memberi cahaya kepada yang lama
     Taman Warisan tersergam megah
     Lambang kebanggaan kita bersama

Hari ini saya sangat gembira and bangga kerana dapat merasmikan pembukaan semula Taman Warisan Melayu yang telah dinaik taraf dan diberikan nafas baru. Pusat ini sekarang lebih cantik dan gah. Lebih banyak artifak yang dipamerkan untuk memaparkan kekayaan budaya, tradisi dan warisan orang Melayu.

Satu pameran yang menarik perhatian saya ialah sebuah projek grafik multimedia 3D yang menunjukkan rumah-rumah orang Bugis yang dibina di atas air, hasilan sekumpulan pelajar Politeknik Temasek. Orang Bugis pernah menetap di daerah Kampong Glam and begitulah Bugis Street mendapat namanya. 

Saya berharap bahawa rakyat Singapura akan menyokong pusat ini dengan melawat dan menyertai aktivitinya, ataupun menjadi sukarelawan di pusat ini. 

Tahniah kepada Yayasan Warisan Melayu, Lembaga Warisan Kebangsaan dan masyarakat Melayu yang telah bekerja keras untuk menjadikan pusat ini sebuah kenyataan! – LHL
A Happy Teachers’ Day to all who have dedicated their lives to nurturing and providing a quality education to the next generation of Singaporeans! :) - LHL

Just heard that our Paralympians Laurentia and Gemma did well in the equestrian team event. Well done!

To the rest of our Paralympians in London - do your best and push on. Your determination and spunk inspire us all to give our best regardless of our circumstances. We are all proud of you and your achievements. – LHL

I started my Facebook page & Twitter account four months ago. It has been useful and fun, though lots of work. Now after every event, writing an FB post and choosing pics to share with fans have become habits. I appreciate your wall comments and private messages, which help me understand your hopes and concerns. Your Likes and Shares too tell me what posts struck a chord with you, and what I should post more about.

Today I met 19 of my fans and followers over tea. You came from many backgrounds and age groups (Jiajia was the youngest :) ), and some of you are more active online than others (mrbrown, Dr JiaJia Big Brother, Ming Shen). 

We talked about many issues, from Twitter and Reddit (President Obama just did an Ask Me Anything session today, and crashed the servers), to online behaviour (some favoured requiring real names, some didn’t), and Singapore’s declining birth-rate (no magic solutions, alas). Thank you also for your feedback on my Facebook page.

I look forward to meeting more of you in future. Thank you all for your continued support! – LHL

Thank you all for your feedback and comments on my National Day Rally. I’m heartened that many of you liked my speech. I value your ideas on how to give our young hope of a brighter future, how we can be a gracious, big-hearted people, and how to make Singapore the best home for us all. 

This is a major effort. That is why we need to have a national conversation on Our Singapore, and to work together to realise our ambitions. I’ll be holding more discussions in the weeks ahead, and look forward to a constructive dialogue. Let us come together to create a Home with Hope and Heart in our future Singapore! – LHL

At the National Day Rally on Sunday, I said that it is good for young children to play and learn through play. We should not force feed our kids, and turn pre-school into a prep course for Primary One. I am glad that many parents and educators have agreed with me. I hear that “No homework is not a bad thing” became the most re-tweeted tweet from my Twitter account (maybe by pupils :))!

This article gives an idea why this is so, and describes how children will gain much more (educationally) through playing games and fun activities, than through drills and rote learning. - LHL

Chatting with Le Ha Thanh Mai, who came from Vietnam on a scholarship at 15 years old. Now in SMU, Mai encourages international students to integrate with locals. Also in the pic are Goh Peng Hong (grassroots leader in Sembawang), Josephine Ng (Founder of Alteration Initiative), and Sufian Anuar (Striker, Lions XII, at the extreme rear right. I did not know that it was his birthday!). (MICA Photo by LH Goh)
With grassroots leaders from Serangoon, accompanied by Mrs Lim Hwee Hua. (MICA Photo by LH Goh)
With two students attending the ND Rally for the first time. (MICA Photo by LH Goh)
Catching up with my old army comrade Omar Haron, whom I met recently again after nearly 40 years. (MICA Photo by LH Goh)
Having a laugh with Praveen, a Primary 6 student from Townsville Primary School, his teachers Mdm Suhaizan and Mr Quek, and Praveen’s father Mr Balu. (MICA Photo by LH Goh)
PM to parents of preschoolers: “No homework is not a bad thing. It is good for children to play, and learn thru play.” (National Day Rally 2012; MICA Photo by Kenji)
Photo with Swee Keat, Lawrence and Halimah, taken backstage immediately after their speeches. We are all in shades of red! :) - LHL

Concluding the Rally with stories of Singaporeans and his own personal anecdotes, PM said that it is our shared memories as Singaporeans that define the Singapore story for all of us. He rallied Singaporeans to work together to create a better Singapore, where we look to our shared future with confidence and Hope, where we treat one another with a big Heart and where we build for our children and grandchildren our best Home.

PM said Singapore must be a Home where we feel a sense of belonging, and take pride in what we’ve achieved together and what we stand for. Singapore also has to be a home where people want to get married, have children and bring up the next generation. 

Unfortunately, total fertility rate has been falling steadily. But PM said we cannot give up.

The National Population and Talent Division is consulting the public widely on the marriage and parenthood issue before deciding what needs to be done. The ideas the Government is looking at include better work-life balance, flexible work arrangements, priority housing for couples with young kids, paternity or shared maternity leave, defraying childhood medical expenses, better pre-school, childcare and infant care, and improving the baby bonus.

PM: Singapore of the future must have a bigger Heart. He gave several examples of how we have built a harmonious society through mutual respect and a spirit of give-and-take. Most Singaporeans are big-hearted and generous, and more are donating to charitable causes. But he added that a minority seemed to be less tolerant towards others, and urged Singaporeans not to allow this trend of not-so-good behaviour to spread. 

On relations between Singaporeans and non-Singaporeans, PM said it was fair for people to express concern or to disagree with immigration trends and policies, but he was worried by some of the nasty views expressed, especially online and anonymously. This, he said, speaks poorly of who we are and damages our international reputation. 

He urged Singaporeans to show a generosity of spirit to one another, including toward new arrivals. He urged new arrivals to also make the effort to embrace our values, commit themselves to Singapore and integrate into our community.

PM said this year’s Inclusive Budget was a major shift to set a new strategic direction in our social policy. There were significant initiatives for the elderly, low and middle-income and the disabled. 

Looking ahead, PM said that as Government spends more on social services, taxes must go up – not immediately, but certainly within the next twenty years. PM stressed that safety nets have to be coupled with self-reliance and resilience. He also urged those who have succeeded to help others succeed too.

PM said quality of pre-school education has to be substantially raised, while keeping pre-school affordable, especially for middle- and lower-income households. 

Hence, the Government will invest substantial resources in pre-school and play a more active role. It will establish a new statutory board to oversee the sector but will not nationalise the sector. MOE and MCYS will study this.

PM also cautioned parents against “over-teaching” pre-school children and said having no homework is not a bad thing. It is good for young children to play and learn through play, he said.

PM said the Government is opening up more paths in higher education. It will increase full-time places for applied degrees. Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) and SIM University (UniSIM) will be made Singapore's fifth and sixth universities. This will increase current full-time university intake, and enable 40% of each cohort to go to university by 2020, up from 27% today. 

Government will also give more support to part-time students. Besides making more part-time places available, Government bursaries and loans will be extended to UniSIM part-time students, so that they get the same support as part-time students in NUS and NTU. MOE will announce details later.

PM said the Government is making major investments in the MRT system, spending $60b over 10 years. But train projects take time to complete. So, the Government is also working on Bus Services Enhancement Programme. Commuters should start to see new services and better frequencies by next month.

On healthcare, PM noted that new hospitals are being built - Ng Teng Fong Hospital in Jurong and another in Sengkang. The Government plans to build more nursing homes and day care centres but PM was quick to add that the best and cheapest healthcare is to keep fit and live healthily.

PM also said the Government knows the concerns of singles who can only buy from the resale market but not directly from HDB. He said that MND is looking into this issue.

PM began his English speech by asking Singaporeans where they want Singapore to be 20 years from now. Much will depend on what we make of our resources and what we want Singapore to become, he said.

PM has asked Minister Heng Swee Keat to lead a national conversation on this. He urged Singaporeans to think about our future, contribute ideas and work together to make it happen.

PM then went on to say Singapore must always offer Hope of a better future.

总理华语群众大会演讲
努力发展经济，也积极建立更温馨、更优雅的社会

新加坡近50年来取得巨大的发展，我们已经告别了快速发展的阶段，现在必须寻找一条新的发展策略。我们要继续发展和进步，我们的社会必须保持朝气，也必须有一种前瞻性的思维，并且为年轻一代制造施展才华的空间。当然，我们也应该照顾年长一代，帮助他们应付环境的改变，我希望年长一代也能保持身心活跃，尽量做到自力更生。

我鼓励新加坡人自我更新，但也希望大家保留文化的根，宗乡总会今年初提出设立“新加坡华族文化中心”的构想。福建会馆最近也提出开办“福建会馆文化学院”的建议。政府支持这两项计划，希望它们能够开创新的文化天地。

新加坡华人社会富有特色，也有独特的词汇，这有利认同感的建立。但是，这也使到新移民不容易融入我们的社会。我希望新移民多了解我们的特殊国情，并且吁请新加坡人以包容的态度对待他们，使我们的社会更和谐。

Rapat Hari Kebangsaan 2012 – Ucapan Bahasa Melayu 

PM telah berucap tentang hala tuju Singapura dan bagaimana masyarakat Melayu/Islam boleh maju bersama negara. Beliau berkata bahawa kita harus terus amalkan dasar berbilang kaum dalam menghadapi isu-isu negara demi mengekalkan Singapura sebagai kediaman yang terbaik untuk keluarga kita di masa hadapan. 

Beliau menyeru agar kita terus berusaha untuk meningkatkan pembangunan masyarakat Melayu/Islam, supaya kita dapat maju bersama sebagai satu bangsa. 

Sambil memberi beberapa contoh belia yang cemerlang, beliau juga mengatakan bahawa para belia Melayu/Islam telah menunjukkan prestasi yang baik dan mengikut jejak langkah pemimpin masyarakat yang berjaya.

PM menambah bahawa pemerintah akan menyokong usaha masyarakat Melayu/Islam untuk meningkat maju, termasuk usaha mengekalkan budaya Melayu, tetapi masyarakat harus manfaatkan sepenuhnya sokongan itu. 

Demi memastikan masyarakat Melayu/Islam akan terus menjalani transformasi, dan meningkat ke tahap yang lebih tinggi, PM juga mengingatkan bahawa selain membimbing golongan yang berkebolehan, kita juga harus bantu mereka yang susah, dan galakkanlah yang sederhana supaya meningkatkan prestasi.

Menggulung ucapannya, beliau berkata masyarakat Melayu/Islam adalah bahagian penting dalam masa depan Singapura dan berharap agar masyarakat Melayu/Islam dapat berjaya sebagai sebuah Masyarakat Cemerlang dalam negara yang bersatu padu.

Minister Heng Swee Keat, Senior Minister of State Lawrence Wong and Minister of State Halimah Yacob have just concluded their speeches at the National Day Rally. 

Mr Wong spoke about the importance of creating opportunities, improving Singaporeans’ quality of life and building stronger communities. Referring to the ideals expressed in the pledge, he urged Singaporeans to work actively with the Government to achieve happiness, progress and prosperity for our nation. 

Madam Halimah spoke on the need to ensure that a widening income gap does not make it harder for Singaporeans to excel. She emphasised the importance of maintaining social mobility, and said the Government is committed to doing more for those who need help. 

Minister Heng highlighted the need for a national conversation about “Our Singapore”, for Singaporeans to come together, and ask: What matters most? Where do we want to go as a country, as a people? He said the national conversation will be as inclusive as possible, and urged Singaporeans to take part in it.

PM Lee began the Rally by explaining the change in the NDR format this year. Tonight he is giving Minister Heng Swee Keat, SMS Lawrence Wong and MOS Halimah Yacob a chance to speak. Perhaps in future Rallies he will invite others to speak.

PM has taken a seat in the audience, and will speak again at 8pm – in Malay, Chinese, and then English.

Leaving soon for the National Day Rally at the University Cultural Centre at NUS. Looking forward to the speeches by Lawrence, Halimah and Swee Keat, and to speaking to you. My staff will post “live” updates on the speech on this page while I’m on stage. – LHL

This is Berita Harian’s feature on Muhd Asyraf Chumino. It is a moving life story. Asyraf quit school when he was 10 to take care of his mother after his dad died. He did the housework, cooked for his mother and siblings and taught himself at home. Asyraf eventually made it to Northlight School and became its best student. He’s currently studying Facility Technology at ITE College East and hopes to go to polytechnic just like his siblings. Congrats Asyraf, and press on! You fully merit the Lee Hsien Loong Award for Special Achievement, and are an inspiration to many.

Beliau terpaksa menguruskan kerja rumah dan memasak untuk ibu dan adik-beradik. Beliau juga belajar sendiri di rumah. Asyraf akhirnya memasuki Sekolah Northlight dan muncul sebagai pelajar terbaik. Beliau kini mengikuti kursus Teknologi Kemudahan di Kolej Timur ITE dan berharap untuk melanjutkan pengajian di politeknik seperti abang dan kakaknya. Syabas Asyraf, dan semoga terus berjaya! Reshuffled the Cabinet today. Promoted Grace Fu to full minister, and five Ministers of State to Senior Ministers of State (Chuan-Jin, Chun Sing, Lawrence, Masagos, and Yi Shyan). Also appointed two MPs to office (Indranee Rajah as Senior Minister of State, Muhammad Faishal bin Ibrahim as Parliamentary Secretary). 

Come November, we will restructure MCYS and MICA into three new ministries – the Ministry of Social and Family Development; the Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth; and the Ministry of Communications and Information. We want to focus sharply on three priority areas: (1) Strengthening families and social safety nets; (2) Promoting arts and sports, building social capital and engaging the young; and (3) Improving public communications and engagement. 

These changes will help us to serve Singaporeans better. I hope that all Singaporeans will give my team your full support, and work with us to build a better Singapore for all. – LHL

Many thanks for your enthusiastic responses to my post about my National Day preparations yesterday. Your suggestions for my Rally speeches were most useful. 

Quite a few of you felt that I should talk about population issues, including integration with new arrivals (e.g., Yap Fred, Qi Yong, Jessica.Chan) and parenthood (e.g., Suresh Kumar, Sherin Tan, February Amethyst). Other readers suggested cost-of-living (e.g., Peter Cheng, Jasmine P'ng Siok Lee), education (e.g., Steven Ooi, James Phoon), and housing (e.g., Yusoff Yb, Sean Lim). These are all issues preoccupying many Singaporeans.

Did my Meet-the-People session last night. We had 116 cases, about the usual number. Half were from my own ward Teck Ghee, the rest from other parts of AMK GRC. Finished past midnight, also as usual.
 
I always find it useful to listen to my residents’ problems. We can’t always simply grant their appeals, as making an exception for one may not be fair to others. But we always do our best to help wherever we can.
 
Very grateful to my branch volunteers, who faithfully serve our residents week after week, sometimes for 20 or 30 years. Thanks also to my fellow MPs who share my case load – tonight Seng Han Thong took cases with me. - LHL
Reviewing a case with Ms Helen Goh and Ms Noelene De Foe. They make sure everything runs smoothly, and all the letters are filed properly.

Singapore’s achievements in maths and science education are internationally recognised. I was delighted to read that Lim Jeck, a student at NUS High School, has achieved a perfect score and the top position in the International Mathematical Olympiad in Argentina this year. The Singapore team of six students won one gold medal, two silver and two bronzes, and ranked sixth overall. Congratulations to Lim Jeck and the whole Singapore team!

Congratulations also to our team at the International Biology Olympiad, which won first place (and four gold medals) last week! This was the first time we have won the Biology Olympiad, and also the first time that Singapore hosted the event. 
- LHL

Was very happy to launch the book about our former Mufti, Shaikh Syed Isa Semait at the National Library this afternoon. For nearly 40 years Shaikh Syed Isa guided the Singapore Muslim community to be both good Muslims and good citizens. 

It was good to see many other religious leaders at the book launch too, to honour Shaikh Syed Isa. He touched the lives of people of all races and faiths, and made a quiet but important contribution to our racial and religious harmony. - LHL

Sangat memberangsangkan dapat melihat ramai pemimpin agama lain di majlis pelancaran buku itu juga, sebagai penghormatan kepada Shaikh Syed Isa. - LHL

Enjoyed an early morning walk-a-jog with friends and residents at Bishan-Ang Mo Kio Park, gathered for a Community Sports Festival. We bumped into MP Josephine Teo and a group from Bishan, who also had a walk-a-jog this morning in the Park that we share. The weather was perfect. The Park looks beautiful and well-used, with the naturalised river and lots of mature trees. Glad that both Bishan and Ang Mo Kio residents are enjoying it. 
 
Visited the sports booths at our Sports Festival, which challenged residents to try out tricycle rides, basketball, table tennis & even dodge ball. Penned my good wishes for the AMK athletes participating in the Singapore National Games. Confident that they will do us proud! – LHL

Got back this morning from India. Always feels good to arrive home, even from a short trip. I found it a useful visit. We were warmly welcomed, both by the government and the business community. They were interested in what we had to say, and keen to do more with us. Singapore’s standing in India is high. Hopefully my trip will give our ties another nudge forward. Now back to work. – LHL
India's Ministry of External Affairs has posted a photo album of PM's visit to India.

Visiting India at PM Manmohan Singh’s invitation. My last visit was seven years ago, when PM Singh and I signed the Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA).  It was a major step forward in our economic cooperation, but since then the world has moved on.  We need to upgrade our cooperation, both bilaterally and within ASEAN.

We are doing so in many areas – trade and investments, arts and culture, security and defence, and education.  ITE will be cooperating with the Delhi state government in vocational education, to build a World Class Skills Centre.  And tomorrow our Speaker and theirs will be launching a new India-Singapore Parliamentary Friendship Group. – LHL

Launched “One Connect” at  Greenwich V mall this evening – a programme to serve private estate residents in AMK and Sengkang West. Presented 200 citizenship certificates and pink ICs this morning to new citizens living in Ang Mo Kio GRC and Sengkang West SMC. I encouraged them to make the effort to integrate into our society, to make friends with other Singaporeans and adapt to our norms and way of life. A few are already volunteering in our grassroots, immersing themselves into our community. 

Quite many have Singaporean spouses, and have lived in Singapore for many years. I think for them the adjustment will be easier. For their children, it will be easier still. I asked one teenager where he came from, and he promptly (and correctly) answered “Ang Mo Kio”! :) - LHL”

欢迎新公民，希望他们入乡随俗

两百位宏茂桥集选区和盛港区居民今早宣誓成为新公民。我出席了这个简单但庄严的宣誓仪式，表达对新公民的热烈欢迎。他们是经过慎重的考虑，才作出这个艰难和重大的抉择。

我希望他们顺利地融入新加坡这个大家庭。他们的口音可能改不了，但是应该尽力适应这里的生活习惯，文化习俗和价值观念，做到入乡随俗，进而在这片土地上扎下深根。我也吁请新公民好好爱护新加坡；我对他们说：发展它、建设它、捍卫它！

The new Yale-NUS College broke ground this afternoon. We are building up our universities, ITEs and Polytechnics, and schools, to give every Singaporean a good education. 

Yale-NUS is an exciting addition to our education system. It will combine Yale's strengths in the liberal arts with NUS' understanding of Asia to create a new model of education in Singapore. Yale is supporting it strongly, and so is the Singapore government. 

Yale-NUS will offer another attractive option to our students going to university, different from NUS, NTU, SMU or SUTD. - LHL

Chun Sing, Maliki, Sim Ann and I met with youth leaders today over tea. They come from diverse backgrounds but share one common goal – to contribute to society and help other Singaporeans.

I was impressed with their passion and energy. Ivan developed an app to match volunteers with VWOs’ projects. David gives motivational talks to at-risk youths. Grace is a social entrepreneur trying to help fellow social entrepreneurs get started. In big ways and small, they are helping to build a better Singapore for all of us.

I wish them the very best in pursuing their hopes & passions. – LHL
Sharing a laugh with Hannah, Farhan, Kheng Leng, Edgar, Rahayu & Jing Jing. (MICA Photo by Stephen Chew)
