Reviewed the SAF Day Parade this evening and met many of our young people serving and defending Singapore. Always happy to have the chance to thank those who keep our country safe and secure.
 
This year marks 45 years of NS. More than 900,000 men have completed this rite of passage, and NS has become a vital national institution.

I remember when I was called up in 1971, and was a recruit in ‘A’ Company, 2 SIR, at Holland Road Camp. The facilities were basic, the equipment often incomplete. We did not even have steel helmets for everybody. We were issued only the inner liners covered with camouflage nets, except when we went to the firing range.

When it came to my sons’ turn to be called up, my wife and I went with them to BMTC at Pulau Tekong. I met many other parents, who had similarly done NS themselves. We (the fathers) all ooh’d and aah’d over the barrack rooms, the cupboards and mattresses, and of course the cookhouse food. We told our sons about the old days, but I am not sure how impressed they were.
 
Long after we have finished NS, the bonds and friendships remain. Last Sunday, at the Singapore Youth Awards (SYA) Presentation Ceremony, someone came to say hello. He had served under me in 23 SA in 1980, as a gunner. Now he was on the SYA panel choosing the awardees. We were so happy to meet again.
 
Thank you to all our servicemen, regular and NS, for safeguarding our peace, security and progress! Thanks also to all the families and employers, for your support and understanding! 

Here’s an old photo I dug out from my recruit days in 2 SIR, plus photos from today’s parade. 
 
- LHL
With my parents after our BMT Passing-Out Parade at 2 SIR, March 1971.

Speech & dialogue at AMP convention / Ucapan dan dialog di Konvensyen AMP

Had a good dialogue on Malay/Muslim community issues at the AMP Convention today.

The Malay/Muslim community has progressed well, together with Singapore and other ethnic groups. Household incomes have risen, and education performance has improved. But there’s room to do better.

AMP Singapore has contributed to this progress, by focusing on programmes to help the community do better educationally, socially and economically. AMP produced a good report outlining the progress made, and its proposed strategies for the next 10 years. I encouraged AMP to maintain its focus on educational, social, and economic issues. They should help all segments of the Malay/Muslim community, and work together with other Malay/Muslim organisations and the Government.

Am confident that AMP will continue to do its best to help the community become a Community of Excellence. – LHL

Telah mengadakan dialog yang menarik tentang isu Melayu/Islam di Konvensyen AMP hari ini.

Masyarakat Melayu/Islam, bersama kumpulan etnik lain di sini,  telah mencapai kemajuan baik. Pendapatan keluarga telah bertambah, prestasi pendidikan pun lebih baik. Tetapi masih ada ruang untuk perbaiki pencapaian ini.

AMP telah monolong masyarakat Melayu Islam untuk maju dari segi pendidikan, sosial dan ekonomi melalui rancangan-rancangan nya. AMP juga telah menyiapkan satu laporan yang baik yang menunjukkan kemajuan yang telah dicapai dan strateginya bagi 10 tahun mendatang. Saya ingin menggalakkan AMP supaya terus memberi perhatian pada persoalan pendidikan, social dan ekonomi. Di samping itu, AMP juga harus menolong setiap lapisan masyarakat sambil bekerjasama dengan badan-badan Melayu/Islam yang lain dan juga dengan pemerintah.

Saya yakin AMP akan terus memainkan peranan penting untuk membantu masyarakat menjadi sebuah Masyarakat Cemerlang. - LHL

Jamiyah honoured its former President Haji Abu Bakar Maidin, who built up the organisation and served with distinction for many years. His dedication and commitment are an inspiration to many. – LHL

Presented the Singapore Youth Awards to three outstanding young Singaporeans today - Aaron Maniam, Jovin Tan and Yeo Sze Ling. 

Aaron writes poetry, and volunteers actively in MENDAKI, SINDA, and the National Youth Council. 

Jovin, born with cerebral palsy, overcame his fear of the sea to become a champion sailor. He will be representing Singapore (again) in the Paralympics in London. 

Sze Ling went blind at the age of 4, but persevered and excelled. She earned a PhD in Mathematics and become an A*STAR researcher. 

All three are also deeply involved in community work, helping others to succeed and encouraging them to overcome adversity, as they themselves have done. 

Congratulations, Aaron, Jovin and Sze Ling! You are inspirations to us all.

– LHL

Team Singapore received the National Flag yesterday. I wish all our Olympians and Paralympians every success in London. Do your best, and you will do us proud. We are all cheering for you! – LHL (ZB Photo by Vincent Woo Fook Leong)

Went for a walk at Woodlands Waterfront this evening. Met lots of residents, young and old. Many brought their kids, some were exercising, others were just enjoying the fresh air and greenery.

These two retirees, old friends of each other, have lived in Woodlands for 40 years. They used to work for the Royal Navy. I wonder how many of the park visitors know this history – Sembawang used to be the British Naval Base, and later the Royal Malaysian Navy had a base there called KD Malaya. But today Woodlands Waterfront is a green oasis, and on the old jetty where warships used to berth now couples court and fishermen try their luck. - LHL

Happy Father’s Day to all dads!
 
Fathers too play a big part in caring for their children, especially since many mothers are working nowadays. 
 
Both my parents worked when I was small. But they always made time for me and my siblings, and were always there for us at critical moments. 

Now with children of my own, I know how tough a father’s task is, but Ho Ching and I both treasure the joy and fulfilment of seeing our four children grow up and become self-reliant young adults. Here is an old pic of me carrying Hongyi, then aged almost two, and Ho Ching pregnant with Haoyi. Seems not so long ago that the children were little, and we were changing their diapers. A more recent pic shows the whole family enjoying our makan, kids almost grown.
 
My best wishes to all fathers in Singapore and overseas! – LHL

Two thoughtful commentaries on population and integration issues by Prof David Chan of SMU in ST. Prof Chan analyses the difficulties in integrating large numbers of foreigners into our society, and what it is that upsets people. He then goes on to propose sensible approaches to managing the problems and getting positive outcomes for Singapore. 
 
Getting our population and integration policies right is crucial to our social cohesion, economic wellbeing and sense of belonging. This is why we are encouraging discussion and dialogue on this difficult problem.
 
We have to recognise the human and emotional reactions that people understandably feel when they see our society changing. We must also acknowledge our economic and demographic realities – our need for enough workers and more talent, as well as our shortage of babies and aging population. Only then can we anticipate the challenges, and address the problems comprehensively. 
 
Let us work towards a shared understanding of what is at stake, so that we can manage these issues better, and improve our lives in the future. – LHL

MENDAKI Learning Festival/Pesta Pembelajaran MENDAKI

The MENDAKI Learning Festival is a good example of how self-help groups are working with communities to uplift the less fortunate, strengthen community bonds, and promote learning in a fun environment. Such efforts, sustained over the years, have helped the Malay community to make steady progress. I hope Singaporeans will give such initiatives their fullest support and take part in the festivities. – LHL

Pesta Pembelajaran MENDAKI merupakan satu contoh baik  bagaimana kumpulan-kumpulan bantu diri bekerjasama dengan masyarakat untuk membantu golongan kurang bernasib baik, mengukuhkan ikatan kemasyarakatan dan menggalakkan pembelajaran dalam suasana yang menyeronokkan. Usaha-usaha sedemikian, yang dijalankan selama bertahun-tahun, telah berjaya membantu masyarakat Melayu mencapai kemajuan berterusan. Saya harap warga Singapura akan memberikan sokongan padu kepada inisiatif-inisiatif sedemikian dan akan menyertainya. - LHL

A BBC article on urban crowd sourcing: US cities are encouraging the public to report problems using smartphone apps, to help municipal governments improve services, e.g. fixing potholes, removing graffiti, or repairing street lighting. 

We are doing some of this too. For example, Ang Mo Kio Town Council has an app, iConnect@AMK, for iPhones (http://bit.ly/N6AiX3) and Android phones (http://bit.ly/KNJ0bG). Residents can report defects, and also see what others have reported, and what the Town Council has done about it.

Attended the Economic Society of Singapore Annual Dinner last night. Had a good discussion on Singapore’s progress over the past decade, and where we are heading over the next 20 years. 

Our economy has grown faster than expected, but that has brought stresses and strains which we feel in our daily lives. Singaporeans are also anxious over competition and job security. We are working hard to address these concerns and improve Singaporeans’ lives. 

In 20 years’ time, we hope Singapore will be one of the leading cities in the world. Our economy needs to be vibrant and strong to create opportunities for our people, and generate resources to invest in ourselves. Every Singaporean should benefit from growth. We will do our utmost to help all citizens through education and upgrading. We will also strengthen our social safety nets. Government will spend more on social programmes, such as affordable healthcare, support for low income households, and help for the elderly. But more important than spending more, we must foster self-reliance, keep ourselves competitive, and grow the pie so there is more to share. Singaporeans must make sensible choices together, to build a brighter future for ourselves and our children. - LHL

Many of you have shared with me your worries about healthcare costs. You can do something about it by signing up for CHAS, the Community Health Assist Scheme. CHAS will help pay for treatment by GPs and dental clinics near your home, so that it becomes like visiting a polyclinic. 

We recently improved CHAS to benefit more Singaporeans. Saw this homely video clip on TV last night, which tells you more about CHAS. Please sign up for yourself and your loved ones, and spread the word to your neighbours and friends! — LHL

Meeting Guangdong Party Secretary Wang Yang 与广东省委书记汪洋一席谈

Had a fruitful exchange with Mr Wang Yang, on his second visit here (he was last here in 2008). 

Our trade with Guangdong province is large and growing. We are collaborating on the Guangzhou Knowledge City, a significant project involving both hardware (developing the township) and software (urban management, business environment, focus on education). Mr Wang Yang proposed building a long term relationship between Singapore and Guangdong, and I was happy to agree.

Having made great economic progress, Guangdong must now tackle social issues. As Mr Wang Yang put it: when people were poor and hungry, the government concentrated on growth; but now that basic needs are largely met, new aspirations have arisen. He came to see how Singapore has dealt with the social side of things. I shared what we have done on housing, healthcare, education and community development, and how in Singapore too as old problems are solved, new issues have arisen. There is much that we can learn from each other.

我下午跟广东省委书记汪洋会面交流，收获丰富。汪书记在2008年也曾在新加坡作客。

新加坡与广东的贸易量大，而且还在增长。两地还联手在广东打造“宜业宜居”的知识城。这是个标志性的发展项目，涉及硬件的建设和软件的管理：一座全新的城区将拔地而起；与此同时，它将遵循现代的城市管理理念，并且营造优质的商业和教育环境。汪书记建议新广两地建立长期的合作机制，我欣然同意。

广东省已经在经济上取得巨大的发展，近年来集中精神处理各种社会问题。汪书记说，当人民还很穷，还吃不饱的时候，政府的首要责任是促进经济的增长。现在，人民生活好起来了，基本需要解决了，也开始有了新的期望。他这回到访，是要考察新加坡在建设一个和谐社会的经验。我解释了我们在公共建屋，医药，教育和社区建设方面的方针，并且说我们的情况也一样：旧的问题解决了，新的问题也出现了。我们两国大有互相借鉴的地方。

-	LHL 李显龙

Busy weekend meeting visitors here for the Shangri-La Dialogue. A good way to keep in touch with ministers from countries big (US) and small (Tonga), far away (France) and near (Indonesia).

These informal exchanges help build mutual understanding and trust, and contribute to peace and stability for Singapore and Asia. – LHL

Dinner with Prof Ezra Vogel 与傅高义教授共进晚餐

Spent a lively and interesting evening last night catching up with an old friend, Prof Ezra Vogel from Harvard. Ezra is an expert on Asia, particularly China and Japan. He recently published a book "Deng Xiaoping and the Transformation of China". On this visit, he has given a public lecture on Deng Xiaoping, which was very well received. 

Back in 1999, Ezra arranged for me to spend a few weeks in Harvard, meeting professors and students interested in Asian affairs. 

Over dinner we talked about his recent book, and about developments in China. He sees the enormous progress that China has made, and the major challenges that lie ahead. He is convinced, as we are, that a stable, prosperous China will be a great plus to the world.

著名东亚问题专家、哈佛大学教授傅高义正在新加坡访问。我昨晚邀请他一起用晚餐，由几位朋友和同事作陪；大家谈兴很高。傅教授用了十年撰写的新书《邓小平与中国的变革》最近出版了。他就邓小平时代这个课题在新加坡举行了公开讲座，引起热烈的反应。

1999年，我在傅教授的安排下到哈佛大学逗留数周，会晤多位亚洲问题的学者和学生。

我们昨晚谈了他的新著和中国的动态。傅教授分享他对中国的观察，分析中国近几十年翻天覆地的进展和它所面对的艰巨的挑战。傅教授认为一个繁荣和稳定的中国将是世界之大幸。我们完全同意这个观点。

– LHL ( 李显龙)

Chinese Development Assistance Council (CDAC) turns 20 this year. Happy to celebrate the anniversary with the Council over dinner, and see the happy faces of the volunteers and beneficiaries.
 
Many thanks to the CDAC Board, staff and volunteers. You are the helping hands for the Chinese community, and the heart and soul of the CDAC. 
 
Self-help groups like the CDAC (and Yayasan Mendaki, Singapore Indian Development Association, Eurasian Association) do much to help those in their communities who are not doing well. They understand the problems of these community members best, and do much good work to uplift the less fortunate ones. 
 
Every one of us should do our part to support these self-help groups, as donors and volunteers. I was happy to meet many CDAC volunteers tonight, including people like Jia En, Bryan Ong and Mdm Teo Lung Hiang who had themselves benefitted from CDAC’s programmes. Let us all embrace this spirit of paying it forward!

My previous post on the call centres in the Philippines attracted many thoughtful comments, which I have read with great interest.

As several readers pointed out (e.g. Aaron Quek, Eric Lee, Melvin Chen), I was not suggesting that Singapore should aim to attract call centre jobs, or compete with the Philippines on the basis of low wages. We have gone well past that phase of development. Furthermore, our fundamental aim is to improve the wages of our workers, not join in a race to the bottom. My point was that many jobs which used to be done in the developed countries are gradually migrating to lower-cost providers around the world, such as call centres in the Philippines. This global trend will affect us too.

The Filipinos will not stop at call centres. They are already moving on higher value-added services such as animation for movies and video games. India has upgraded from running call centres to hosting higher-end business process outsourcing (BPOs), e.g. providing professional services such as legal advice and filing tax returns for Americans, at a fraction of the cost of American lawyers and accountants. 

As more and more services are “crowdsourced” at the click of a mouse, Singaporean workers will face growing competition. Not just in unskilled and low-paid jobs, but white-collar jobs too; and not just from foreign workers here, but from workers and professionals thousands of miles away in other countries. 

This is why, although we want our workers to earn more, we cannot simply push up Singaporean wages as we would like. Globalisation and technology make this impossible. We will watch the inflow of foreign workers, so that Singaporeans don’t get overwhelmed. But in the long term, the only way for our workers to do better is to compete on knowledge and innovation, upgrade our skills, and stay ahead of the pack. We also have to continue welcoming talent, to boost our competitive edge. This is not easy to do, but the Government will walk this journey with Singaporeans every step of the way. 

- LHL

A sobering BBC story about the Philippines developing their call centres business, and overtaking India. This is the international backdrop to our own efforts to raise wages of low- and middle-income workers. Singapore does not exist in a vacuum; we face direct and increasingly fierce competition from other countries. By making full use of technology and skills, we can improve our lives. – LHL

祝各位劳动节愉快！我上午出席五一劳动节群众大会，我在演讲中谈到政府帮助工友提高收入、改善生活的方针。我们没有捷径可走，唯有逐步提高生产力和技能，工友的薪酬才能逐年改善。多年来，我们实行了一套有效的发展策略：全力保持经济的朝气，维持对外开放的风气，以及确保全民分享经济成果。我希望大家支持这些策略，使新加坡一年比一年好。 – 李显龙

Happy May Day!

Our economy is doing quite well, and unemployment is very low. But I know workers are concerned about issues like the cost of living, our low-wage workers and our ageing workforce. We are tackling these tough issues directly. 

At the same time, we must get our overall strategies right. Singapore needs to stay open and connected to the world, as a society and a people. It is the only way for a small country to progress and prosper. 

Second, our economy must grow. Not simply by expanding, but by upgrading ourselves, raising productivity and creating better jobs for all. This will give us the resources to build a better Singapore. 

Third, all Singaporeans must share the fruits of growth. In particular, we must do our best to help low-wage workers. This is how we build an inclusive society which leaves no Singaporean behind.

I talked about these issues at the May Day Rally. The journey is challenging, but I am confident we will succeed. Let the tripartite partners – employers, unions and government – work as one for a brighter future and a better Singapore!

LHL

The thriving German economy is short of skilled workers. It is attracting talent from countries like Spain and Portugal, where unemployment is very high. Germany is benefitting: if the inflow continues, in the long term German industry will grow more powerful. But Southern Europe is worried that it may be only left with agriculture and tourism.
 
But the Germans have difficulty integrating foreigners into their society too. They talk about needing to develop a welcoming culture. Their issues are quite similar to ours in Singapore. – LHL
